abstract: Editorial on US credit standing in London market; Editorial comments on US credit standing in London market
snippet: Editorial on US credit standing in London market; Editorial comments on US credit standing in London market
lead_paragraph: The mail received on Sunday evening from England to the 19th of March, reports continued firmness in the London market for American Stocks. This fact speaks well for the due appreciation of our recent successes in the field and our financial measures in Congress, by the people of England. Their real opinion ofthe situation on this side appears to be better reflected from their principal Stock Exchange than by their leading journal. The latter continues persistent and most unfair in its representations of both the military and financial news from this side. While the record of what is actually occurring in the field and in the money market of the United States is not suppressed, the practical end to which it points is utterly ignored and the facts themselves perverted. Thus, in the London Times, of March 19, now before us, we have a labored effort to show that the fall in the price of Gold in New-York in exchange for United States Notes is a bad sign for the future of our credit, and the stability of our National Currency. Gold, it is argued, fell on the passage of the Treasury bill, because the United States Notes of the existing issue rose in value on their recognition as a medium for the payment of Customs! Of course, this is a gross perversion of the facts communicated from this side. Gold did not fall in exchange for United States Notes alone, but in exchange for the current bank credits, in the shape of deposits and bank notes of the City of New-York, the very best standard in the whole country, because representing the commercial and financial centre of the country. There was no account taken of what might thereafter be wanted at the Custom-house for the payment of duties. The question was one of the supply and demand of gold at the time; influenced, to be sure, to some extent, by the brilliant successes of the Government in dwarfing the proportions of the Southern rebellion. The fall in gold was not temporary, as we have since been. On the contrary, the price has continued to go down, until a minimum next to a nominal premium over the ordinary currency of New-York, has been reached.

abstract: Editorial on Jackson campaign in northern Virginia
snippet: Editorial on Jackson campaign in northern Virginia
lead_paragraph: -- The column of the rebel Gen. JACKSON, which has just been routed at Winchester, chased from Strasburgh, and is now probably plodding its weary, way through the mountains, and up the Shenandoah Valley for Stanton, was, as Gen. SHIELDS says, considered the bravest and best-disciplined corps in the rebel army. It was composed of men who had been in the very hardest service ever since the war opened; and, for its supposed invincible qualities was known as the "Stone Wall Brigade." The rebel papers have given it credit, too, for a continuous series of quite wonderful victories. At the beginning of lostWinter, JACKSON was put in command of Northern Virginia, and he was ordered to drive the National troops from that part of Virginia between Harper's Ferry and the western line of Maryland, and to destroy whatever had been rebuilt of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, which was then guarded by the troops of Gen. BANKS. With a force estimated at 6,000 strong, JACKSON set out from Strasburgh last December, advanced rapidly to Winchester, and thence toward Martinsburgh, destroying the Baltimore and Ohio Road, tearing up the rails and using them to finish the line between Winchester and Strasburgh. In the beginning of January he advanced toward Bath, in Morgan County, where were two National regiments and a force of cavalry and artillery, supported by two other regiments at Hancock, ten miles north. Our troops at Bath were driven across the Potomac, and a number of them taken prisoners. Ho then advanced to Hancock, sent notice to the Mayor that he intended to cross at that point, and began shelling the town. He next moved upon Romney, and our troops stationed there retreated north to Cumberland. Having thus cleared that entire section of the National forces, he returned to Strasburgh, but in February again occupied Romney, from which he was driven by Gen. LANDER. From Strasburgh he advanced once more to Winchester, and of late has been flitting between these two points, and occasionally approaching well up to the Potomac. When he saw his best line of retreat cut off by our occupancy of Manassas, and found Gen. BANKS' corps d'armce advancing in force against him, he began to move up the Shenandoah Valley; but, imagining that BANKS' army had nearly all gone to Manassas, he again came up a fortnight ago to his old ground at Winchester, where his forces were suddenly attacked and routed by Gen. SHIELDS, on the 23d ult., and subsequently chased up to and beyond Strasburgh. The official reports indicate that his original force had been more than doubled by reinforcements from the main rebel body. As his column seems to have been terribly cut up, and the remnant has retreated from Northern Virginia, we will not be likely to hear any more of this audacious rebel in this quarter. Gen. JACKSON is a Virginian and a West Point soldier, and his troops are mostly Virginia mountaineers, with regiments from the far Southern States. He has been a terrible scourge to the section over which JEFF. DAVIS gave him command; but his defeat and retreat clears the mountain region of armed rebels.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE. The cold glitter of fashionable life, as reflected in Mr. BOUROICAULT'S comedy of "Old Heads and Young Hearts," may well leave the mind in doubt as to whether civilization has benefitted the upper circles of English society in the same ratio that it has dropped gentleness into the hearts of the ruder classes. Whether, in fact, there is ...
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's THEATRE. The cold glitter of fashionable life, as reflected in Mr. BOUROICAULT'S comedy of "Old Heads and Young Hearts," may well leave the mind in doubt as to whether civilization has benefitted the upper circles of English society in the same ratio that it has dropped gentleness into the hearts of the ruder classes. Whether, in fact, there is not a limit to the refining process. The characters portrayed by the author are prodigiously polished, but it is by the process of rubbing against something as hard as themselves. Their conversation has the fitful sparkle of the firefly, and it scattered with as little purpose. Politeness becomes not only a duty, but a ceremony; and yet in its stony-heartedness, it is worse than barbaric. Fortunately, for the sake of the emotional interest of an otherwise almost intellectual play, Mr. BOURCICAULT has preserved some freshness of feeling in his female characters, and has been peculiarly happy in the delineation of an aged minister -- Jesse Rural -- whose snowy pow is the warmest and most lovable object in the play. Amid the clash of conversational weapons, words of tenderness and simplicity are dropped by these characters, and hence that happy mixture of dialogue which delights the listener. The plot is one of Mr. BOURCICAULT's best, and the construction almost faultless. The distribution last evening was admirable, and we hardly know on whom to bestow the most praise. Mr. BLAKE merited the call before the curtain, which he received at the end of the second act: his performance of Jesse Rural is, without doubt, his best effort. Mrs. HOEY was delightfully vivacious as the widow. Miss GANNON all that could be desired as Miss Rocket, and Messrs. FISHER, SMITH, YOUNG and FLOYD merited the heartiest approval. The comedy has been finely mounted and was a complete success. It will have many repetitions.

abstract: At 3 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in the second story of No. 107 Wall-street, corner of Front, occupied by JOHN T. BRADY, a wine and liquor broker. The flames soon extended to No. 105 Wall-street ...
lead_paragraph: At 3 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in the second story of No. 107 Wall-street, corner of Front, occupied by JOHN T. BRADY, a wine and liquor broker. The flames soon extended to No. 105 Wall-street occupied by BRANDON & FULLER, produce merchants and from thence to Nos. 111 and 113 Front-street, adjoining. The interior of No. 111 Front-street was entirely burned out. Messrs. CARTWRIGHT & HARRISON, produce merchants, occupied the latter building. Their loss is over $25,000. They are insured in the Home, Knickerbocker and United States Insurance Companies. The aggregate loss sustained by the other occupants of the buildings burned, is estimated at about $14,000, consisting mostly of office furniture, fixtures and samples. The fire is believed to have originated from a stove in the office of Mr. BRADY, at No. 107 Wall-street. An alarm of fire was given the evening previous from this place. Several fire companies made their appearance, and put out the fire, as it was then believed, and two Policemen and two Insurance Patrol were placed there to watch the premises. From that time until 3 o'clock, when the fire again broke out, it was smouldering in the building.

abstract: If one will go back mentally to the early experiences of the war, he will see how great is the silence change that has come over not only military operations themselves, but the public estimate of military operations. We may well smile over the recollection of the "desperate struggles" and "tremendous encounters," in which nobody was hurt on either side, and which first excited the wonder and then the ridicule of the whole world. We have changed all that. We have now a standard of measurement that approaches accuracy, and a vocabulary that hears some proportion to truth. A scrimage is apt to be called a serimage, not a "bloody engagement," and when we say a "battle" Europeans may understand thereby precisely what passes by that name in their own military annals. It is not difficult to see how the inflated nomenclature common in the early part of the campaign arose. Jostled out of peace into the novel experiences of war, it was inevitable that we should view everything in a false and exaggerated light -- a tendency favored all the more by the ardent temperament of our people. But the progress of the war has brought with it real battles and genuine fighting, and by bringing trifles into their due relations, has taught us by contrast what is really large. Fort Donelson, the Ozark Mountains, Newbern, Hampton Roads, have seen genuine fighting, not playing at war, and have at once taught the soldier what real war calls for on his part, and the public to estimate achievements at their proper value. Of course thin is positive gain, in every sense. It is not only absurd to indulge in the foolish exaggeration current some months back, but such confusion of all relations is intellectually vicious, and is sure, in the long run, to bring its retributive punishment.

abstract: On Sunday afternoon, we learn from the Washington Republican, a detachment of STEWART's Virginia Cavalry made a dash at the residence of a Union lady named TENNANT, who lives about a mile and a half from Difficult Creek, and about six miles from the Chain Bridge. While engaged in ransacking and pillaging the residence of Mrs. TENNANT they were discovered by a portion of Col. BAYARD's Pennsylvania Cavalry, who at once charged down upon them, when quite a smart engagement ensued, which resulted in the hasty flight of the rebel cavalry, but not before they had secured Mrs. T. and her daughter, whom they conveyed away in Mr. TENNANT's buggy, into which they had previously harnessed the horse for that purpose. The only casualty to Col. BAYARD's Cavalry in the skirmish was the wounding of one soldier, who was conveyed to the city the same night.

abstract: MESSAGE IN ENGLAND. -- We were not mistaken when we said the President's Message, looking toward aiding States that may seek to initiate amancipation, would produce a profound effect in Europe. Already the first echoes of its reception in England interpret it as the most important measure of policy since the outbreak of the war. The Times, however, while recognizing its importance, puts a characteristic interpretation upon the Message. In its curious phraseology, it is "the first bid made to the South toward putting an end to the war;" and that journal thinks that, if the North gradually rise in its offers, until something ecceptable has been put forth, the South may be brought to listen!

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition was presented from the workman in the late armory at Harper's Ferry, asking for the reestablishment of the armory, and for work. A joint resolution, appointing THEOD RE WOOLSEY Regent of the Smithsonian Institute, in place of President FELTON, deceased, was passed.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition was presented from the workman in the late armory at Harper's Ferry, asking for the reestablishment of the armory, and for work. A joint resolution, appointing THEOD RE WOOLSEY Regent of the Smithsonian Institute, in place of President FELTON, deceased, was passed. The Secretary of Warwas asked to furnish the Senate with a copy of Gen. MANSFIELD's report of the fight between the Merrimac and the Monitor. A bill to create a Bureau of Transportation was introduced and referred. A bill to provide a Territorial Government for Arizona was introduced. Resolutions from the Legislature of Maine were presented, in favor of the President's emancipation policy. The bill for the abolition of Slavery in the District ofColumbia was taken up, and Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, addressed the Senate in favor of its passage. His speech will be found in full in this morning's TIMES. At its conclusion, the bill was postponed until to-day, and the Senate, after an Executive Session, adjourned.

abstract: Capt. KINSLEY, of the bark Princeton, arrived yesterday from Demerara, bringing datets to March 10.  Business was dull. Money matters were very tight, owing to the American war.
lead_paragraph: Capt. KINSLEY, of the bark Princeton, arrived yesterday from Demerara, bringing datets to March 10. Business was dull. Money matters were very tight, owing to the American war. All parties were anxious that the troubles should be speedily arranged. A large number of apprenticed coolies had arrived during the previous two months, and had been distributed among the different plantations.

abstract: The regular meeting of the Board of Councilmen was held yesterday the President, Mr. PINCKNEX, in the Chair. A resolution granting permission to tap the Croton Aqueduct at One Hundred and Fifty-eighth-street, the expense thereof to be borne by the residents cf that vicinity and parties interested, and, as the present wording obviated the objections of the Mayor in his veto on the subject, it was adopted ...
lead_paragraph: The regular meeting of the Board of Councilmen was held yesterday the President, Mr. PINCKNEX, in the Chair. A resolution granting permission to tap the Croton Aqueduct at One Hundred and Fifty-eighth-street, the expense thereof to be borne by the residents cf that vicinity and parties interested, and, as the present wording obviated the objections of the Mayor in his veto on the subject, it was adopted after some discussion. A resolution to place a gas lamp in Clinton-street, brought out the fact that one of the members was about to open a public garden, and wished the lamp there and, after piling amendment upon amendment it was adopted as offered.

abstract: American, says that the show in Northern Vermont and New-Hampshire is of great depth. In Peacham, Vermont, the people are using their chamber windows for doors, and the orchards are so buried that the tops of trees appear like bushes, the uppermost twigs only coming above the snow. One drift in Troy has been tunnelled over a distance of 50 rods, and loads of hay, wood, &c., pass through. In Newport a large drift was excavated, so as to make a room 60 feet by 40, and 18 feet high in the centre, in this room a festival was held, 180 ladies and gentlemen being present. Two large tables were spread, and the snow palace was illuminated by 12 hanging lamps.

abstract: Mr. SUMNER is one of those far-seeing and comprehensive statesmen, who omit from their scheme of policy nothing but practical common sense, and a wholesome expediency. Than to propound legislative theories, applicable to men in a milennial stage of existence, nothing is easier; nothing more difficult than to take into just consideration all the elements which distinguish the race as it is, and bad as it is, from the race as it might be under conditions at present impossible to conceive.Mr. SUMNER, and those who think with him, eschew all concrete right for that which is entirely abstract. They drop from their equation all unknown quantities. That a principle is right irrespective of facts and circumstances which essentially qualify its application, is sufficient for these earnest, well-intentioned, but misguided philosophers. They devote themselves to it with implacable energy, and succeed at the cost of untold mischief and misery.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Jura at Portland last evening, we receive advices from Europe two days later. The intelligence is in some  respects important. President LINCOLN'S Message, proposing gradual emancipation, with pecuniary aid to the s ave-owners, had been received, and though there had not been much time for comment, that which had been bestowed upon it was of the most favorable character.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Jura at Portland last evening, we receive advices from Europe two days later. The intelligence is in some respects important. President LINCOLN'S Message, proposing gradual emancipation, with pecuniary aid to the s ave-owners, had been received, and though there had not been much time for comment, that which had been bestowed upon it was of the most favorable character. The Liverpool Post believes it will have the most favorable effect upon the cause of the North. Even the London Times praises it, characterizing its reception as the "most important news since the split." Parliamentary proceedings had been of no importance.

Mr. WILLIAM M. EVARTS presided, and Messrs. WM. BOND, of Connecticut, and MOSES PERKINS, of Vermont, acted as Secretaries. Addresses were made by ...
lead_paragraph: A very large and influential meeting of citizens of New-England, resident in this City, was held at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, last evening, with a view to adopt some plan for relieving the wants of the sick, wounded and disabled soldiers returning home through this City. Mr. WILLIAM M. EVARTS presided, and Messrs. WM. BOND, of Connecticut, and MOSES PERKINS, of Vermont, acted as Secretaries. Addresses were made by Rev. Drs. OSGOOD, BELLOWS and VINTON, Cols. HOWE and BLISS, Messrs. BLUNT, HIDDEN, CHAS. GOULD and others, and a Committee appointed to carry out the purposes of the meeting, consisting of three gentlemen from each New-England State. Mr. EVARTS is Chairman, Mr. CHARLES GOULD is Vice-Chairman, and the Association of Physicians and Surgeons, of this City, is requested to send delegates.

lead_paragraph: A very large and influential meeting of citizens of New-England, resident in New-York, was held at the Fifth-avenue Hotel last evening, with a view to make some arrangements to provide for proper attention to the wounded soldiers passing through this City on their return from the battle-field. The meeting was called to order by Mr. CHAS. GOULD, upon whose motion Mr. WM. M. EVARTS was chosen Chairman.

abstract: The gailand dash of Col. BUFORD upon the rebels at Union City, Tenn., and the rout of the latter therefrom, renders the position of the No. Ten rebels very precarious. Union city is in [???] County; at the point where the [???] railroad from Hickman intersects the Mobile and Ohio road, and is pretty nearly in the rear of the rebel troops and bolieries on the eastern shore of the Mississippi, which are acting as supports for the islanders. The No. Ten rebels expected, which they should find it necessary to evacuate their river strong old, to make their way to this Mobile and Ohio Road, and their [???] the cars for Jackson on Corinth, to join the main rebel body. But this line of escape is now cut of -- that is, if we continue to hold Union City. They cannot get up the river, nor dawn the river, nor [???] it and not much more work now is required to circumvallate with a line of fire the whole force. We are in a fair way of achieving a neater victory than would be the driving away of the rebels from the position they have so tenaciously held.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the Committee on the Conduct of the War, was directed to make inquiries relative to the alleged barbarities practiced by the rebel soldiers with the remains of Union soldiers killed at Manassas, and also relative to the enlistment of Indians in the rebel service. A [???] for the better organization of the militia of the District of Columbia, was introduced. The Secretary of War was directed to transmit to the Senate the correspondence between Gen. WOOL and the War Department since the General took command at Fortress Monroe. The bill for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, was then taken up and debated until the adjournment. Mr. WRIGHT, of Ohio, made a speech against its passage, and Mr. FESSENDEN, of Maine, in favor of it. One of two amendments were adopted, but the bill was not finally disposed of.

abstract: Editorial on public confidence in McClellan command
snippet: Editorial on public confidence in McClellan command
lead_paragraph: The rapid growth of what the London Times is pleased to call the "mob" in the Christian graces of faith and patience, is not the least remarkable phenomena of the hour. Three weeks ago the gratified oi polloi sat down to its daily battle and victory with the same calm confidence as to its matutinal roll and tea, and grew restive when the morning paper had no narrative of fresh successes, and no fatal catalogue of killed and wounded, So blunted, indeed, had the popular sensibilities become under the influence of a martial satiety, that popular enthusiasm failed utterly of any response to the stirring bulletin, and the stock market sank, as if battles won were National calamities. Such was the law of that particular period. It does not apply at present. For nearly a fortnight there has been recorded no fresh and splendid success. Bulletin-boards have been blanks; the Herald has confined its sensation headings within three-fourths of a column. "We have grown used to the tranquil aspects of a campaign. Without a victory, the stock market moves steadily upward. The language of the street and the table is cheerful, assured, buoyant. A settled confidence in the result of the war, and a conviction that the end will be reached before the fading of Summer, are in the minds of everybody, and give tone to public feeling.
headline: {'main': 'Public Confidence and the War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Public Confidence and the War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: editorial on British interpretation of maritime laws in regard to privateering as debated in Parliament
snippet: editorial on British interpretation of maritime laws in regard to privateering as debated in Parliament
lead_paragraph: If calmly to bear calumny be one of the most difficult trials which either an individual or a nation can be called upon to undergo, there is a proportionate reward when Time, bringing round his revenges, brushes away the falsehood and blazons the truth. The UnitedStates have long been taunted with having refused to accede to that part of the Treaty of Paris, of 1858. whereby the maritime Power of Europe declared that privateering should be abolished, and that the neutral flag should cover the enemy's goods, with the exception of contraband of war. But it has not been convenient for those who have delighted to cast opprobrium upon us for not giving in our adhesion to these doctrines, to remember the ground on which our Government based its refusal. While lustily charging us with holding on to a remnant of barbarism in maritime war fare, they have been very careful to keep in the extreme background the fact that the United States Government declined giving its adhesion to the doctrines of the Paris Conference, not because they went too far, but because they did not go far enough. We were quite willing in 1856 to agree both that privateering should be abolished, and that neutral goods (with the exception of contraband of war) should be exempt from capture under an enemy's flag, but only on condition that the exemption should be extended to the ship as well as to its cargo. We desired, in fact, to carry the law to its legitimate conclusion by making all private properly free from capture at [???]; and declared that any other doctrine would be but a temporary makeshift, not a permanent and efficacious principle.

abstract: Not all the watchers of the rebel coast sleep always. The steamer Oriental has a tale to tell of the vigilance exhibited by a blockading vessel at Charleston, which goes far to redeem the character of that branch of the service.
lead_paragraph: Not all the watchers of the rebel coast sleep always. The steamer Oriental has a tale to tell of the vigilance exhibited by a blockading vessel at Charleston, which goes far to redeem the character of that branch of the service. The Oriental was steaming by the port named, late upon a dark evening, when she was discovered by the Florida, one of the vessels stationed there. The Florida at once bore down upon the transport, firing as she approached, and disregarding the signals exhibited by the little steamer, ordered her to stop, under penalty of being run down. She stopped accordingly until explanations had cleared up her character.

abstract: -The participants with Mr. HACKLEY in the interesting came of all pay and no work, are quarreling over the stakes. HACKLEY, it seems, pockets them all. His partners object clamorously, and Courts which have no power to enjoin the contractor to clean the streets, are invoked to compel a distribution of his wages for cleaning them. We trust they will do nothing of the kind. The backers of HACKLEY embarked with him in the job at a comparatively low price, with a deliberate resolve of enriching themselves by systematically defrauding the public out of the equivalent of their pay. The bargain among themselves is, therefore, of a kind which the law declines to recognize or enforce; and the tribunal which lends itself to the enforcement will be as careless of law and equity, as it is of the public welfare. Let them divide their plunder as best they may.

abstract: Comment on merits of Turkish bath about to be established in NYC
snippet: Comment on merits of Turkish bath about to be established in NYC
lead_paragraph: It is somewhat mortifying in this age of the world for a Christian to be forced to take lessons of a Turk in the matter of "cleanliness, which is next to Godliness," but as John Bull, who seldom patterns after anybody but himself, has condescended to introduce the Turkish bath into his dominions, and suffers himself to be scrubbed by a Tellak, while he extols the manipulation, it certainly cannot be amiss in Brother Jonathan, the father of a nation of "unwashed Democrats," to follow so illustrious an example. The praises bestowed upon the Turkish bath by the British soldiers, on their return from the Crimean campaign, have led to the formation of a Turkish Bath Company in London, with a capital of half a million dollars, and the result is said to have been entirely successful, both in a pecuniary, popular and sanitary point of view. We have received the prospectus of a similar Company about being organized here, though with a much smaller capital, and from the names of the parties engaged in the enterprise, we have no doubt that it will meet with equal success. Among the Board of Directors are: Dr. Valentine Mott, Wm. C. Bryant, Ex-Mayor Tiemann, Charles King, C. Godfrey Gunther, A.W. Bradford, and others of not less note. The institution is to be managed by Prof. C. OSCANNYAN, a native of Constantinople. The peculiar merits of the Turkish bath, and its modus operandi, are thus set forth in the circular:

abstract: Our Judges and Justices must be a little cautious in the manifestation of their partiality for criminals. Times have changed. Honest business is not so urgent now as to preclude a little thought and attention to public interests. Our citizens are becoming somewhat...
lead_paragraph: Our Judges and Justices must be a little cautious in the manifestation of their partiality for criminals. Times have changed. Honest business is not so urgent now as to preclude a little thought and attention to public interests. Our citizens are becoming somewhat sensitive to the perversion of power on the part of public servants. They don't see why, if good government is worth fighting for, it is not worth voting for; and the nomination and election of Justices. Judges, and municipal officers generally, so disinterestedly controlled heretofore, in a good degree. by Liquor-Dealers Associations and dram-sellers, is in a fair way to be taken into the hands of men who pay the taxes and bear the burdens of the City.

abstract: ELVING HALL -- A billiard tournament on a scale of sufficient magnitude to illustrated the skill of America in this scientific game, will take place to-night. It is gotten up for the benefit of the widow and family of a celebrated billiard-player who unhappily lost his life in BROADWAY. PHELAN, SEERVILES, TIEMAN and many other renowned names appear among the contestants. Irving Hall has been arranged expressly for sight, and seats in any part of it will enable the occupant to see the table.

abstract: SERIOUS EXPLOSION IN BROADWAY -- FIRE IN A CHEMICAL FACTORY. -- About 12 o'clock on Monday night, a fire broke out in a chemical manufactory, between Fiftieth and Fifty-first streets. Soon after the alarm of fire was given, an explosion took place, which created great consternation among the residents of the neighborhood, and shook the adjoining building with great violence. The premises were immediately enveloped in a dense smoke, and the flames burst out to a great height, carrying with them, by the force of the explosion, large quantities of stones, brick and timber. A large three-story frame house adjoining soon took fire, and was consumed. The building in which the explosion took place was two stories in height, occupied by LOUIS M. DORMBACK, as a manufactory of cartridge-paper and gun-cotton for the Government. By some means, at present unknown, fire was communicated to these materials instantly. The building was entirely destroyed. It belonged to DAVID BALL, whose loss will probably amount to $4,000. The buildings in the vicinity, except the one above alluded to, all escaped injury. Fire-Marshal BAKER will investigate the case to-day. So far as in now known no lives were lost, although it is known that a man and his wife resided on the premises which were blown up. Nothing has been heard of them since.

abstract: Legal decision made in dispute over property he gave late granddaughter M A Ward at time of her marriage
snippet: Legal decision made in dispute over property he gave late granddaughter M A Ward at time of her marriage
lead_paragraph: Francis Morris vs. Margaret Astor Ward.-- The question in this case (which was stated in the TIMES of Feb. 10, when decision was reserved) was whether Samuel Ward took by descent from his son, William Samuel Ward, an estate in fee simple in certain lots at the foot of Fourteenth-street in this City, or only an estate for life. The property was settled by John Jacob Astor upon his grand-daughter, Emily Astor, (daughter of William B. Astor,) a few days after her marriage with Samuel Ward. The deed of settlement declared the consideration to be one dollar and natural love and affection. The lots in question were settled upon Mrs. Ward for her life, with remainder to her issue, in fee. Mrs. Ward died in 1841, leaving two children, Margaret Astor Ward and William Samuel Ward. The latter died shortly after his mother, and the question was, what estate did his father take in the son's moiety of the lands. It appeared that Samuel Ward, upon the death of his son, assumed only to take an estate for life in the lots. During his absence in California, his daughter brought an action against him, and caused the estate to be sold to pay the father's share of taxes, and other expenses incident to the lots. She was a minor at the time, and her grand-father. Wm. R. Astor, who was her guardian, conducted the suit on her behalf. The title of Mr. Ward appeared to have been vested normally in Mrs. Mary Griffin, who was also made a defendant in the suit. Morris became the purchaser under the judgment, and afterward, for the benefit of Ward, procured a conveyance from Mrs. Griffin of whatever estate she might hold for the life of Samuel Ward, which was sold under the judicial proceedings. Being thus invested with the claim, he asked for a decree that he was certified of the simple, and not merely for the life of Ward.

abstract: The work on the frigate Roanoke progresses very satisfactorily. The energies of the Navy-yard seem concentrated on this vessel, and she will be completed as early as the resources of the yard will allow. It is said that the contract for the manufacture of the Roanoke's armor-plates has been divided among  several firms, so that the armor may be ready without any avoidable delay.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, favorable reports were made on the bill to rebuild the locks on the Oneida Lake Canal, and the bill to incorporate the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church. The bill to legalize certain acts of the New-York Common Council was ordered to a third reading. A number of bills were passed, none of them of special importance, after which the Excise Amendment bill was again debated in Committee of the Whole. The license fee was fixed at $20 for the minimum, and $100 for the maximum rate, with penalties ranging from $10 to $250.

abstract: Editorial on Yancey speech in New Orleans
snippet: Editorial on Yancey speech in New Orleans
lead_paragraph: If Ms. YANCEY has really been delivering at New Orleans the speech which comes to us through the Southwestern papers, it may well be a subject of congratulation that he was not captured by the way. The sentiments which he is reported to have uttered in a public address in the Crescent City, are at once so true, so little like what an adroit Southern politician would be apt to say, and so much like what might be falsely put into his mouth, that we we were at first disposed, on internal evidence, to doubt that any such speech had been made. The fact of his non-capture, however, and the detailed report of the speech which comes to us through an Alabama paper, would seem fully to credit it; and if YANCEY continues the character in which he has made his first appearance since his return from his diplomatic mission, we may account him a most efficient auxiliary of the Union cause. Mr. YANCEY returns from Europe "a wiser and a sadder man" and tells his fellow rebels more wholesome truths that they have probably ever heard before. The ex-Ambassador of Half-Moon-street frankly tells them that it is his deliberate opinion that the South has no friends in Europe; that there is, in fact, a strong prejudice against the South because of its peculiar institution; that there are many persons in Europe who consider the Southern people semi-civilized, and believe that negroes are raised upon the same plan that stock is; and finally, that for any good the rebel commissioners now in England and France can accomplish in the way of obtaining European intervention, they might just as well be immediately recalled.

abstract: battle of Newbern, N.C., it was reported that Sergeant JAMES HAMILTON, of the Fifty-first New-York Regiment, was killed while fighting gallantly with his comrades. News has just been received that his wound, though severe, is not considered mortal, and that with a little care he will shortly recover. Col. FERRERO, in writing of Sergeant HAMILTON, says: "I take great pleasure in giving my testimony to the bravery and patriotism of your son, whose conduct was in every sense noble. It is by such men as he that our country is to be restored to its once happycondition."

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. LATHAM, of California, announced that he had received the correspondence from the State Department relative to the Knights of the Golden Circle, with the exception of one letter, and proceeded to read it. Its character has already been made known. A resolution was adopted, making inquiries of the Secretary of War relative to some of FLOYD's transactions with WARDELL. The bill for the relief of the Danish bark Joergen Lorentzen was passed. The House resolution, to cooperate with States desiring to emancipate the slaves, was debated at considerable length, and finally passed, 32 to 10. The bill for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia was then taken up, and debated until the adjournment.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. LATHAM, of California, announced that he had received the correspondence from the State Department relative to the Knights of the Golden Circle, with the exception of one letter, and proceeded to read it. abstract: LIVERPOOL, March 20 -- The ship Nabob, previously reported stranded in Cork Harbor, has been floated off, and arrived here on the 17th. A large number of vessels from American ports, have arrived here with damaged cargoes, viz.: Ships Shakespeare, Marathon, C. Courrier, Harvest Queen, Shooting Star, Ocean Scud, Addison, Constitution, Theresa, Martha, and others, all causing a serious amount of damage to breadstuffs; the damage, generally, from insufficient bins, allowing the grain to find its way through to the skin, thence to the pumps, were it swells and becomes a solid cement, requiring, in some instances, an augur to bore through. The water then reaches the grain, which heats and spreads through the whole cargo in time, and in many instances leading to the abandonment of the vessel.
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, March 20 -- The ship Nabob, previously reported stranded in Cork Harbor, has been floated off, and arrived here on the 17th. The water then reaches the grain, which heats and spreads through the whole cargo in time, and in many instances leading to the abandonment of the vessel.

abstract: WALKER and JOHN DORRS were arrested, yesterday, upon the charge of passing counterfeit $3 bills on the Bank of Otsego, N.Y. A large number of the spurious bills were found in the possession of the accused. The Police say that these bills have been extensively circulated in the City. Justice OSBORNE held the prisoners to answer. Several spurious notes on the Townly Bank, of Massachusetts, were put into circulation, yesterday. They are so well executed that the best of judges are deceived by them.

abstract: Editorial says areas of cultivation of sea island cotton in South are now occupied by Union forces; Editorial says areas of cultivation of sea island cotton in South are now occupied by Union forces
snippet: Editorial says areas of cultivation of sea island cotton in South are now occupied by Union forces; Editorial says areas of cultivation of sea island cotton in South are now occupied by Union forces
lead_paragraph: that most singular and important region of the South, in which Sea Island cotton is grown, is now in possession of the National forces; and this year there will be none of the exquisite fibre raised, unless it be cultivated by free-black labor. It is grown only on the sea-coast of the States of South Carolina, Georgia and Florida, and the line of its growth extends from John's Island, just south of Charleston, to Amelia Island, Florida. John's, Island we do not yet possess, though it is deserted by its civilian inhabitants, both white and black. The island at the other end of the chain, Amelia Island, is that upon which is situated Fernandina and Fort Clinch, which were taken possession of by Commodore DUPONT two or three weeks ago. Thesea islands between these extremes which are not yet occupied by our troops, are all deserted and desolate. From the adjacent shores of the mainland, and on the tide-laved banks of the streams, also, where this valuable species of the cotton plant is grown, the whites have fled, and the slaves have been driven inland. So that the whole of the sea island supply this year from the American market will be what may be raised by the South Carolina negroes, who have now begun the experiment of planting under Government superintendence. The average annual crop of late years is about 50,000 bales (300 pounds to the bale;) but there will probably not be a tithe of that quantity raised upon the whole Southern coast this year.

abstract: editorial on Fort Pulaski siege
snippet: editorial on Fort Pulaski siege
lead_paragraph: Although the course of the war has given the public a glimpse of almost every form of military and naval operation, our experiences have been hitherto deficient in one particular -- we have had until lately no systematic investment of a regular fort. The tidings from the Georgia coast supply this want. Fort Pulaski, one of the great National strongholds, commanding the passage by river to Savannah, is now beleaguered by the National force, and the public may soon have all the excitement of a siege.

abstract: family of the late Jos. W. WHITE, the billiard players of the country proposed a grand tournament at Irving Hall in this City. Last night, in the presence of a crowded house, Messrs. Phelan, Tieman, Serieter, Fox, Dewy, Stone, Coon, Goldthwaite, Benjamin, Kavanagh, Foley and Bird played a game of a thousand points -- six on a side, the strangers against the City men. The strangers were victorious. The play was very poor, the players evidently not caring to expose their points to each other. To-night a grand match will come off at the same place, at which playing of a different nature may be anticipated. FOLEY and KAVANAGH will be the players.

abstract: Brig.-Gen. HARVEY BROWN, who is now in command of the forts in the harbor of New-York, invited a number of gentlemen to inspect, with him, Fort Wood, on Bedloe's Island, yesterday. Owing to indisposition, the General was not enabled to be present. On the invitation of Col. GRAHAM, of the Fifth Regiment Heavy Artillery, who is in the charge of the post, the party, which consisted of Mayor OPDYKE, Brig.-Gen. EWEN, Brig.-Gen. COOK, Messrs. DENNING DUER and GEO. T. HOPE, of the Chamber of Commerce Harbor Defence Committee, and others, visited the fort.

lead_paragraph: act of Congress virtually constitutes the SubTreasury in this City where most, if not all, the United States Notes will be made payable a great National Bank of Circulation and Deposit. The Circulation is now limited to $150,000,000. The lowest denomination will be five dollars; the highest, one thousand dollars. The Deposits are limited to $50,000,000, and the interest to be allowed thereon to five per cent, per annum. Deposits are authorized at all the Sub-Treasuries, but is in the case of the ordinary negotiations of the Government, the greater portion of the fifty millions will be placed on deposit here. The Associated Banks of New-York alone have resolved to use the office here to the extent of twenty millions, for the convenience of creating an interest-bearing medium wherewith to make their daily settlements with each other at the Clearing-house. When the Government and the Banks, at the end of the war, resume payments in specie, the redemption of United States Notes will no doubt be almost altogether at New-York. The revenues from Customs are already collected to the extent of 70 or 75 per cent. at this point. The collections from the excise and import tax bill now being perfected by Congress, will probably, for the convenience of the Treasury Department, be directed to New-York for disbursement. A liberal additional allowance has been voted by Congress for the support of the New-York Office, in view of its greatly increased business, and the present Custom-house, at the corner of Wall and Nassau streets, has been assigned to the Sub-Treasury after May next, when the Custom-house officers will remove to the Merchants' Exchange building. The alterations of the present Custom-house to suit the new and important purpose, to which it is to be devoted, are now being ordered, and the probability is the interior of the building will be made one of the most commodious, as it will be the largest, banking-room in the country. We shall thus have a great National Bank, without the objectionable attribute (always liable to political abuse or favoritism,) of a bank of discount.

abstract: The course of Gen. BANKS is onward. He advanced from Strasburgh to Woodstock on Tuesday, and thence pursued the retreating rebels to Edenburgh, five miles beyond. The rebel force, supposed to be that under ASHBY, made a show of resistance at Stony Creek, near Edenburgh, but yesterday morning they were driven from their position, with only one man killed on our side. The rebels, in their retreat, of course destroyed all the bridges in their path. That over Stony Creek was to be built yesterday, when the advance would probably continue.

abstract: The British brig J. Titus, of St. John, N.B., arrived at this port yesterday morning, having left Savanilla, New-Granada, on March 19. She reports that trade at Savanilla was very dull. There had not been any water in the canal for seven weeks, and there were no goods received from  Baranquilla for shipment. Hopes were entertained of having water every day.

abstract: of the State of Maine recently adopted a resolution of thanks and congratulation to the gallant army of the West, and to the troops of Illinois especially, for their heroic conduct at Fort Donelson. An additional resolution directs the foregoing to be sent to the Governor of Illinois, and the Governors of other Western States; meaning, in the estimation of the authorities nearest sunrise, all States West of New-England, and first in importance, the State of New-York! The document was duly received by Gov. MORGAN, and if a joke were intended, his Excellency failed to see it, and so transmitted the resolution, with the customary message, to his own Legislature.

abstract: Editorial on Confederate fear of attack on 1st anniversary of their April 15 attack on Fort Sumter
snippet: Editorial on Confederate fear of attack on 1st anniversary of their April 15 attack on Fort Sumter
lead_paragraph: The Charlestonians, it seems, are looking forward with fearful forebodings to that scarlet date, the 15th of April -- the anniversary of the rebel assault on Fort Sumter. They have come to the conclusion that the National Power is reserving till that day the taking of its "capable and wide revenge" on the original home of the secession-treason. Accordingly, the valiant sons of chivalry, born insensible to fear, are making preparations for a vigorous -- flight. In what direction it shall be, however, it is really difficult to see. Their favorite haunts among the Sea-islands of Port Royal are now in the hands of the hated Yankees; Savannah is imminently menaced by a great military and naval force; Northward, their avenue is stopped by BURNSIDE, while the hills of East Tennessee, where of old they used to "Summer high in bliss," are in the possession of the arms of the Union.

abstract: meeting of the Chamber of Commerce to-day will be exhibited a valuable portrait of Gen. WINFIELD SCOTT. Two years ago the authorities of the Virginia Military Institute requested Gen. SCOTT to sit for an equestrian portrait, to be placed in their Institute, and employed Mr. E. TROYE, the artist of the Dead Sea, the Bazaar of Damascus, and other well known paintings, to execute the work. At the same time, distinguished Virginians requested Mr. TROYE to paint another picture, to be purchased by the State of Virginia. Gen. SCOTT, at great personal inconvenience, recalled an intention he had expressed not to sit for a portrait, and not only sat, but mounted a horse, resembling one that he rode at Chepultepec, and devoted much of his valuable time, when his health was greatly impaired, to the artist's studio and labors. Both pictures were completed, when the rebellion broke out, and Virginia refused to take them. One of the pictures is in the Rotunda at Washington; the other, a magnificent historical portrait of the General at Chepultepec, some nine by twelve in size, is at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce, where it will be seen by the members to-day. It is proposed by the merchants of New-York to purchase this portrait for a purpose that will undoubtedly meet with the enthusiastic cooperation of all our citizens.

abstract: Editorial on Confederate practice of mounting wooden "Quaker guns" in place of real ones to camouflage their retreats from entrenchments
snippet: Editorial on Confederate practice of mounting wooden "Quaker guns" in place of real ones to camouflage their retreats from entrenchments
lead_paragraph: certain Quaker guns which were found in position at Centreville, after its evacuation by the rebels, and which are held up as proof-positive of the cowardice or inefficiency of Gen. MCCLELLAN. This view can be honestly taken only on the assumption that the works at Centreville were never mounted with any other than Quaker guns -- a conclusion which could be arrived at only by those who are entirely ignorant of the arts and practices of war. For this device of Quaker guns is one constantly and successfully used by commanders who intend to retreat from forts or entrenchments. Next to his men, an officer's first care is his artillery. But to remove his guns in sight of the enemy would be to notify him in the quickest and most unmistakable manner of the intended evacuation. So his pickets are strengthened, and even pushed forward, as if for an advance, then in the night the guns are removed, and wooden ones of similar size and appearance, so like as to make detection even with a glass impossible, are substituted for the real Simon Pures. Daylight manifests no change in the apparent strength of the works; the bulk of the troops move off by daylight; and when the next night comes, the pickets withdraw suddenly, and run for it. There is obviously no protection against this trick, except a nightly driving in of pickets, and reconnaissance in force in the dark, which is generally more harrassing to those who undertake it than to the enemy, and in rarely productive of much good. The supposition that, because the rebels left only Quaker guns behind them, they took none of "the world's" guns with them, makes it plain that they did not use up all the wood in the world in making sham artillery.

lead_paragraph: chiefs of the rebellion, knowing that the eyes of the world are upon them, have been careful to put themselves on their good behavior, and "assume the virtues if they have them not." That men, however, who have begun the work in which they are now engaged by violating every oath and breaking every moral obligation, would not do the same to carry on that desperate work, was hardly to be supposed. The rebel "President" has justified his character by advising the Confederate Congress that the prisoners released by the United States Government should be absolved from their oath, "and allowed to take part in the approaching struggle for independence." The wretch claims that the measure is "in retaliation for the infamous and reckless breach of faith exhibited by LINCOLN in the exchange of prisoners." What the lie may be which he has devised for the purpose of justifying this gigantic perfidy to those whose consciences may not have reached the callosity of his own, does not appear.

abstract: RUSSELL to the London Times dated from this side early in March returned by the last mail. In it he commends the moderate elation of the people of the North on the fall of Fort Donelson, and commends to the attention of the English public the "resolution and vigor" of the Southern Confederates at Richmond under this and other defeats.
lead_paragraph: RUSSELL to the London Times dated from this side early in March returned by the last mail. In it he commends the moderate elation of the people of the North on the fall of Fort Donelson, and commends to the attention of the English public the "resolution and vigor" of the Southern Confederates at Richmond under this and other defeats. Their counsels breathe resistance, he says, to the last. The North speaks with bated breath "in face of the unyielding attitude of the South!" This stuff, we repeat, was written early in March. The letter probably went out in the same mail, or followed immediately after the message of Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, which, it will be recollected, was anything but unyielding. It set out indeed by yielding that the Confederates had undertaken more than they had been able to accomplish -- that their line of territory for defence was too extended -- in short, that the work of establishing such a Confederacy is thus far a failure. So much did the opening paragraphs of this message yield, that many of our people here were even disposed, on its first publication, to doubt the genuineness of the document. Perhaps Mr. RUSSELL participated in the doubt and ignored the admissions of Mr. DAVIS accordingly. The conclusion would be a charitable one, if it were borne out by the remainder of his letter.

abstract: The steamship Niagara arrived at Halifax last evening, with advices from Europe two days later than were brought by the Jura. She left Liverpool on the 22d, and Queenstown on the 23d ult. Nothing of special importance had occurred in the British Parliament. More extended comments on the Emancipation Message of President LINCOLN had appealed in the London papers, which were generally disposed to regard it with favor, but with small hope that it would effect much good. The news from the Continent is not important. Cotton in the Liverpool market was quoted dull, with prices unchanged. Breadstuffs were declining, and Provisions were quiet. The latest quotation of Consols is 94 1/8@94 1/4 for money.

abstract: -- We gave place, not very long ago, to a lively correspondence about the unreasonable tasks imposed upon pupils in the Public Schools. The impression given by the parents complainant seemed to be, that it was less the teachers than the system which should be held responsible for such excesses; the comparative progress made by the scholars of different schools being the criterion accepted by the Board of education, in judging the merit and efficiency of the various instructors. The subject, it is gratifying to find, is not to escape the attention of the Board. In the annual report of the very able and conscientious Superintendent, Mr. S.S. RANDALL, whose reelection is a proof that in one department of the City Government, at least, the fitness of the incumbent is consulted, we note an earnest reference to this mischlevous abuse, with recommendations tending to correct it. We can hardly believe the appeal will be presented vainly.

abstract: -- We publish this morning an important prize decision made by Judge BETTS in the case of the schooner Louisa Agnes and her cargo. The case on the merits was very similar to many other cases of attempted violation of the blockade, the facts showing clearly an attempt on the part of the owners of the vessel and cargo, residing in Halifax, from whence she sailed, to run the vessel into some one of the Southern ports, under cover of a voyage to Baltimore. This intention was made more than usually clear in this case by letters of the shipper, found on board, addressed to a correspondent at Wilmington, N.C., stating that he had previously sent a vessel to him, but by misconduct of the Captain she went to Baltimore, while he had confidence in this Captain, and giving directions about a return cargo.

abstract: As the Spring advances, business is rapidly looking up, and promises to be quite satisfactory in spite of the war. The active season is somewhat backward owing to the extensive snows of the North, and a natural timidity among country merchants. The prospect of a speedy conclusion of the war, and the wonderful exhibition of the ability of this security to pass through the crisis comparatively unseathed, has, however, established, within the last few weeks, a greater confidence. Our wholesale houses begin to show signs of life, and not a few exhibit the [???] spectacle of busy cartmen, porters and packers laboring far into the night. The railroads and other means of transportation already begin to feel the impetus of the revival. Among the heavy deslers especially to the revivification felt. The bountiful last year's crop has left the West well off, and in a small degree makes up for the loss of Southern patronage. Then the necessity of clothing, feeding and keeping well-equipped our army of seven-tenths of a million soldiers, affords a desirable and reliable costumer to many branches of trade concentrating in this City. There is indeed a good demand and fair prices for all kinds of staple goods, on account of the falling off in manufacturing. To a great extent the war has changed the course of trade, and made up in one quarter what has been lost in another.

abstract: The bill for abolishing Slavery in the District of Columbia was passed yesterday in the Senate. The vote was sufficiently decisive. Only fourteen names are recorded as opposed to it, while for it there were twenty-nine. But of the twenty-nine, several Senators had taken occasion to express objections to leading provisions of the bill. Some deprecated its effect upon the Border States. Others would have had the subject referred to a vote of the whites in the District. Others still would have made the emancipation gradualyand provided for the removal of the blacks from the country. But the adherence of the majority to the bill as reported from the Committee, was too steadfast to be shaken. The only modification accepted was one appropriating $100,000 for the colonization of the liberated negroes. There was no other alternative, therefore, for those who were friendly to the measure on general principles, but who objected to various of its provisions, than to vote for or against it directly. It therefore received their voices.

abstract: Editorial on Union efforts to take possession of cotton area of Appalachicola, Ga
snippet: Editorial on Union efforts to take possession of cotton area of Appalachicola, Ga
lead_paragraph: The late advices from Key West announce that among the expeditions fitting up at that point, was one which was about setting sail to take possession of the town of Appalachicola. As this port has no defences but a few carthworks thrown up by its inhabitants, it can offer no very prolonged resistance, and has probably already succumbed to the long ranges of National guns, and fallen into the hands of our soldiers. The capture of this town, in its relation to the supply of cotton, is one of the most important movements which has yet been made upon the Southern Coast. Nothing but the paramount interests of the war could have hitherto closed the eyes of our military leaders to the commercial importance of this port. It was said by travelers returning from Appalachicola early last Fall, that there were more than ten thousand bales of cotton lying upon the wharves of this town, and that in spite of every exertion the stock was constantly increasing. But the significant circumstance connected with this supply, and which is now of especial importance, is that it is not brought, as is the case with both Charleston and Savannah, by the precarious agency of railroads from planting sections situated at great distances in the interior. Here the town is connected with the plantations by water. The Appalachicola River, with its two branches, the Chattahooche and Flint, running far back into the country, unites this port to some of the best cotton lands of Georgia.
headline: {'main': 'A Cotton Port Upon the Gulf.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Cotton Port Upon the Gulf.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The siege of Island No. Ten looks as though it might last as long as the siege of Troy or of Sebastopol. The correspondents who went there expecting excitement and glory, complain that they suffer horribly from ennui, and that their time is spent in yawning and wishing it was the next day. They can find nothing to write about, and half of them, including our own, are leaving in disgust, in order to find more exciting operations than a bombardment. Even the imperturbable Commodore FOOTE, it seems, suffers from the general dullness. It was not thus that he blazed out at Fort Henry, nor thus that he faced the frowning guns of Fort Donelson. To relieve the tedium, and as a reminder to the enemy of what they formerly experienced, and may soon again look for, he has just planned and carried out, and this morning reports, one of the neatest little dashes of the war. He fitted out and armed five small boats, manned them each with twenty river marines, and dispatched them down the river on an expedition to the rebel isle. The work assigned them was to spike the guns of the main rebel battery on the island. At midnight the boats reached the upper fort on No. Ten, and, pulling directly in its face and in the face of the astounded and terrified rebel troops, they gallantly landed and spiked the six guns mounted in the fort, and returned with the boats uninjured. The Commodore characterizes the conduct of his men as cool and determined, but says they are ready to perform still more hazardous service. If the gallant hundred sailors had taken prisoner the whole rebel force on the island, the action would have been complete. We have no doubt they would have done so had they had rope enough to bind them. This little dash is probably only the interlude to a larger operation in the same style against the same place.
lead_paragraph: The siege of Island No. Ten looks as though it might last as long as the siege of Troy or of Sebastopol. abstract: Not to mention the hopeless fortunes of the rebels on their main lines in Virginia and the Southwest, several of their outlying strongholds and minor military detachments are just now in a most precarious situation. At New-Orleans, not only has Fort Pike, which guards the entrance to the rearward of the city, been captured by Gen. BUTLER, but Fort Jackson also, below the city on the river, was at latest advices being assailed by our gunboats; so that all the defensive outposts of the Southern metropolis are likely soon to be in our hands, and the city itself at our mercy. At Savannah, Fort Pulaski, which guards the river passage to that city, is besieged by our troops, and the fort has offered to surrender on conditions; but Gen. SHERMAN demands an unconditional surrender, and in default thereof, he threatens to open fire at once upon the five hundred cooped-up rebels. At Beaufort, North Carolina, Fort Macon and its rebel defenders are isolated and out off from relief, and if it also do not soon surrender unconditionally, it will be stormed by the veterans of Gen. BURNSIDE. Several of the rebel positions in Eastern Virginia are immediately menaced; and we hope to be able soon to publish news of their fall. In Northern Virginia, in the Shenandoah Valley, the "Stone Wall Brigade" of the rebel JACKSON is in a somewhat dangerous plight. It is scudding up the valley with a victorious National column not far in its rear; and, if it do not make good time to Stanton, it will either be captured or cut to pieces. The Number Ten rebels, too, are most precariously placed, and their only means of escape now would seem to be by balloons. Altogether and all around the rebels are in tight places.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill for the completion and extension of the Buffalo and Alleghany Railroad was ordered to a third reading; also the bills to incorporate the Brooklyn Pharmaceutical Association, and to incorporate the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church. Bills were introduced to provide for the payment of the interest on protested State drafts, and to enable the City of New-York to purchase lands under water. The bill to amend the law for the collection of taxes from non-residents was passed. The Congressional Apportionment bill was debated in Committee of the Whole.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill for the completion and extension of the Buffalo and Alleghany Railroad was ordered to a third reading; also the bills to incorporate the Brooklyn Pharmaceutical Association, and to incorporate the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church. Bills were introduced to provide for the payment of the interest on protested State drafts, and to enable the City of New-York to purchase lands under water. The bill to amend the law for the collection of taxes from non-residents was passed. The Congressional Apportionment bill was debated in Committee of the Whole.

abstract: Between 8 and 9 o'clock last evening, a deliberate attempt was made to murder one of the waiter girls in the Concert Saloon, No. 444 Broadway. The following are the facts in the case: JAMES FRANCIS NORMAND, a man about 35 years of age, entered the place named, at about 8 1/2 o'clock, sat down beside one of the girls and entered into conversation with her. She told him that she understood he intended to shoot her. He denied any such intention, and told her to get drinks. She went to get the drinks, and on returning he shot her in the left side. He was arrested immediately and taken to the Fourteenth Precinct Station-house. The wounded girl, whose name our reporter was unable to learn, was taken to the Hospital. At the Station-house the prisoner said that some time ago he had been engaged to be married to KATE WHITE, one of the girls in the saloon; that in view of that event, he had given her $100 to purchase house furniture, with which she absconded, and he was determined to kill her friend, and he was very sorry he had not blown her brains out. At 11 o'clock last night the wounded girl was out of danger, the ball having been extracted from her body. The prisoner says he has plenty of money, is a cousin of Secretary SEWARD, and resides with Mr. JAMES FARLEY, No. 56 Morton-street. He was very sure that "this affair would maybe finish up the concert saloon business."

abstract: LARGE SEIZURE OF ARMY BEDDING STOLEN FROM THE GOVERNMENT ON STATEN ISLAND. -- Detective Officers SAMPSON and DEVOS, connected with the United States Marshal's office, yesterday made a large seizure of army bedding, consisting of mattresses, pillows, blankets, &c., which had been stolen from the different barracks and encampments on Staten Island. They were discovered concealed in barns and out-houses near the Quarantine Landing. A portion of the goods were found in a building connected with the residence of a Mrs. CATHARINE DAVIS, a widow woman in low circumstances. Another, and still larger portion, was found in a barn not far from the same place. Mrs. DAVIS pretended to be entirely ignorant of the manner in which the goods found their way to her premises, nor could a claimant be found for the goods stored in the barn, or even the owner of the barn be ascertained. No arrests were made, it being deemed prudent by the officers to await further developments, which it is hoped will bring to light the guilty parties.
lead_paragraph: LARGE SEIZURE OF ARMY BEDDING STOLEN FROM THE GOVERNMENT ON STATEN ISLAND. -- Detective Officers SAMPSON and DEVOS, connected with the United States Marshal's office, yesterday made a large seizure of army bedding, consisting of mattresses, pillows, blankets, &c., which had been stolen from the different barracks and encampments on Staten Island. abstract: The United States vs The Schooner Louisa Agnes and Her Cargo. -- This  vessel was captured Sept. 9, 1861, by the Cambridge, off coast of Virginia or North Carolina, and sent into this port, where she was libeled as prize, for "being engaged on an unlawful voyage," The owner of the vessel and the owner of the cargo appeared to defend, averring that they were British subjects, resident in Nova Scotia, and that the vessel was bound to Baltimore, and denying that the vessel was lawful prize. Each, of them added a deposition of Nickelson, the master, which they prayed might be received as part of their claims. The papers found on board the vessel show her to have been owned by the claimant, Josiah Slaughenright, and freighted by the other claimant, James A. Moren, at Halifax, where her crew were shipped, and whence she cleared Aug. 21. The voyage named in the shipping articles was "to a port or ports in the United States and back to Halifax." On Sept. 6 she was boarded from the United States ship Susquchanna, off Cape Lookout, and warned not to enter any port between Cape Henry and the Gulf of Mexico. On the 9th she was boarded from the Cambridge, thirty miles south of Cape Henry, on a course back of that she was on when first boarded, and was then seized as a prize.

abstract: An adjourned meeting of this body was held last evening in the Kings County Jail, President CROOKE in the chair. A communication was received from the Judges of the Supreme Court, asking that the ventilators to the room occupied by them in the City Hall be repaired. The subject was referred to the Committee on Courts, with power. The Committee on accounts, to whom was referred the final report of the old Volunteer Relief Commission, reported that the same was correct. The account shows that between the 18th of June and the 9th of October, 1861, there was paid out for the relief of families of volunteers, the sum of $107,486, and that the expenses of the Commission for the same period was $768 71. The report was adopted. A Communication was received from the Managers of the Brooklyn Industrial School Association and Home for Destitute Children, asking for the use of ground in the vicinity of the Home, on Flatbush-avenue, as a playground for the inmates -- to Committee on Grades. The report of the Committee on Salaries, in favor of raising the salary of the clerk of the City Court, was taken from the table, and various amendments were proposed and voted down, and no definite result was reached. A resolution to apply to the Legislature for power to raise $50,000 more for the families of volunteers, was laid on the table. It was stated, while this matter was before the Board, that after the prevent fund was exhausted -- which will be about the 1st of May -- that no more money would be paid to the families of volunteers. On motion of Supervisor KIRBY, the Relief Commissioners were directed to extend to the families of members of the Fifth Regiment of Artillery, as is now extended to the families of other volunteers in the service.

abstract: GEORGE W. BLUNT, Esq., whose right to speak on maritime matters will not be called in question, sends us a communication, which we publish elsewhere, defending the Navy Department against the plentious censure it has received for allowing the escape of the Nashville. He is quite correct in claiming that no blockade can be perfect in the absolute meaning of the term, and as the chief maritime Powers have acknowledged that the blockade of the Southern ports is effective in the international sense, there is no need of discussion on that head. We well understand that any blame which can rightly be cast on Secretary WELLES' administrationof the Department committed to his care must be relative; and in regard to the escape of the Nashville, Mr. BLUNT's explanation of the failure to stop her is one that is satisfactory, or not, in proportion as we confine our investigation to the means at the disposal of the Department for the moment, or extend it to the inquiry whether ampler measures should not have been secured in advance. Undoubtedly all that Mr. BLUNT tells us of the activity of the Department on the receipt of the intelligence of the presence of the Nashville at Beaufort is quite correct. Telegrams were sent flying in every direction -- here for a gunboat which is on its trial trip, there for a second which was not quite ready, and elsewhere for vessels that were on the stocks. No doubt there was zeal and energy enough in the specific directions in which they were exercised, but this does not quite cover the case. The truth of the matter is, that the Department had no vessel at its disposal for this extra service. With all our immense resources, and all the time for preparation, there was not a single vessel available for such an emergency! This is the unpleasant truth which sticks in the throat of the nation, and which no gloss, official or unofficial, has yet been able to explain away.

abstract: -- We have copied in another place an abstract of the legal points made on this question in the Court of Appeals of New-York, and of the more recent act of Congress, and opinion of the Secretary of the Treasury. The decision pronounced by Judge DENIO loses whatever force it may have had at the time by the subsequent direct and unequivocal exemption of all stocks, bonds and other securities of the United States from all taxation under or by State, authority, by the recent act of Congress. The disposition of our Tax Commissioners to controvert or in any way traverse this very plain provision of the supreme authority of the country will only serve to multiply the costs of litigation without the possibility of ultimately producing a cent to the local revenue. These securities cannot now be taxed. They are made exempt in the hands of all individuals, corporations and associations, from all liability to assessment under or by State authority. No holder, in view of the positive enactment of Congress, will suffer himself to be taxed, and no banking company, in view not only of this law, but of a recent act of the Legislature of New-York, permitting such corporations to purchase and hold United States securities, will submit to the attempt now making to contravene these authorities.

abstract: After a discouraging delay, our Albany legislators have finally taken up the subject of the Concert Saloon brothels. We publish, in another part of to-day's paper, both the original bill for their suppression, and the substitute which Mr. [???], of Brooklyn, has seen fit to offer. The latter proposes to confer upon the Police Commissioners the power of granting licenses to all places of public amusement, and of making regulations for their government; to require proprietors to give bonds for their obedience to the regulations, and to give the Police Commissioners power to close any place of the kind, and to inflict other penalties, when convinced that the regulations have been transgressed. It is enough to say of Mr. MCMULLEN's measure that, setting aside the questionable policy of putting so much legislative and judicial power into the hands of the Police Commissioners, it leaves unaffected the abominations of Pretty-waiter-gallism and dram-selling, against which the decency and morality of the City have revolted, and claimed legislative interference.

abstract: John Williams et al. vs. Charles Beth -- This was the return to a motion to show cause why an order granted on the 20th day of March, 1862, requiring one Andrew Harmon to pay over $400 to one Martin Cramer should not be revoked. It appeared that on the 29th day of October, 1860, the plaintiff herein obtained attachments against the property of the defendant, and placed the same in the hands of the sheriffs of the Counties of New-York and Kings for execution. Martin Cramer, however, had on the 16th of December, 1860, obtained a judgment against the defendant for over $1,400, and issued an execution thereon, which was returned unsatisfied. Soon thereafter he commenced supplementary proceedings against the debtors of the defendant, by which it appeared that Andrew Harmon was indebted to the defendant in the sum of $400.
lead_paragraph: John Williams et al. vs. Charles Beth -- This was the return to a motion to show cause why an order granted on the 20th day of March, 1862, requiring one Andrew Harmon to pay over $400 to one Martin Cramer should not be revoked. It appeared that on the 29th day of October, 1860, the plaintiff herein obtained attachments against the property of the defendant, and placed the same in the hands of the sheriffs of the Counties of New-York and Kings for execution. Martin Cramer, however, had on the 16th of December, 1860, obtained a judgment against the defendant for over $1,400, and issued an execution thereon, which was returned unsatisfied. Soon thereafter he commenced supplementary proceedings against the debtors of the defendant, by which it appeared that Andrew Harmon was indebted to the defendant in the sum of $400.

abstract: Commodore FOOTE reports a gallant exploit performed by a small-boat expedition sent against Island No. Ten. On Tuesday he fitted out five boats, manned with a crew of 100 sailors, and dispatched them to spike the guns of the enemy's main battery on the island. They reached No. Ten at midnight, pulled directly in the face of the battery, carried it, spiked the six guns, scared off the enemy, and returned unharmed.
lead_paragraph: Commodore FOOTE reports a gallant exploit performed by a small-boat expedition sent against Island No. Ten. On Tuesday he fitted out five boats, manned with a crew of 100 sailors, and dispatched them to spike the guns of the enemy's main battery on the island. They reached No. Ten at midnight, pulled directly in the face of the battery, carried it, spiked the six guns, scared off the enemy, and returned unharmed.
