abstract: History has failed to record the largest "run" made by CALIGULA, who is said to have played billiards; or to mention whether CATULLUS "scratched" in his nervous anxiety to get the better of his opponent. In an emergency, like the present, it would be gratifying to the reporter to draw a comparison between the ancients and the moderns to the disadvantage of the former, and the glorification of the four-ball game. Under any circumstances we can afford to pooh pooh the Romans, for the four-ball game is certainly an invention of the Western World. The Crusaders -- those tremendous heroes who turn up on every possible occasion, and swagger through the middle ages as if they (the ages) belonged to them -- cut their lances into cues, and became billiard sharpers when all else failed. A billiard-room must have been a pleasing sight in those days, with its suits of armor hanging on pegs, and its overwhelming odor of stable. The conversation of the players dashed with the chivalric oaths, which were then in vogue, must also have added a charm to the entertainment. Well might the proprietor tremble when an rate knight sulkily twisted a link from his chain to pay the shot, and after kicking the marker, stalked into the street seeking whom in the shape of a Jew he might devour. The Jews, as far as we have been able to learn, were never greatly attached to the game, although it is said to have come from the East. The circumstance is remarkable, when it is remembered that there are no fewer than six pockets in a billiard table, and that something is put in all of them during a good game, and frequently with two others that are not attached to the mahogany. The monks and priests, it it said, picked up the game, as they did many other things, and preserved it for the present generation. It is now one of the leading amusements of City life, and may fairly claim to afford more exercise to the young men of New-York than any other recreation. Our forefathers played bowls and smoked long pipes; our sward is as green as theirs but it is made of cloth, and instead of pipes we eat one end of a cigar and burn the other. Perhaps theirs was the healthier of the two games, but pressed on all sides by brick and mortar, Young America has done the best it could, and has certainly succeeded in producing some of the finest players of the world.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, resolutions of the Pennsylvania Legislature, relative to the defences of the Delaware River and Bay, were presented and referred. They recommend the construction of gunboats, and tender the credit of the State to the amount of a million of dollars. The bill authorizing the Secretary of the Navy to test plans for making floating batteries invulnerable, was passed, with an amendment reducing the appropriation to $25,000. A bill for the relief of the widows and orphans of the officers and seamen who lost their lives on the Cumberland and Congress was passed. Resolutions from the Legislature of Wisconsin, against any stump duty on newspapers, were presented; also, a memorial from the tobacco planters of Maryland, against the proposed tax on leaf tobacco. Resolutions relating to the rendition of fugitive slaves, to the prosecution of the war, and to the Armory at Harper's Ferry, were laid over. The bill providing for the administration of the oath of allegiance to citizens in foreign countries was passed. The bill to abolish Slavery in the District of Columbia was then taken up, debated at great length, and finally passed, 29 to 14, as follows:

abstract: There is nothing easier than to exaggerate the force of armies in the field at a given point, or on a particular line of invasion or defence. The highest reasonably authenticated estimate of the whole force of the rebels is about 230,000, or 350 regiments of about 700 effective rank and file each.
lead_paragraph: There is nothing easier than to exaggerate the force of armies in the field at a given point, or on a particular line of invasion or defence. The highest reasonably authenticated estimate of the whole force of the rebels is about 230,000, or 350 regiments of about 700 effective rank and file each. One of our morning cotemporaries, of yesterday, accepts this estimate, and renders a schedule by States of the different regiments; yet another morning journal speaks with all confidence of 150,000 or 180,000 under Gens. JOSEPH JOHNSON and LEE, behind the Rappahannock, in Virginia alone, while another estimate of 120,000 at Corinth, in Mississippi, is currently spoken of as the force concentrated for a general engagement with GRANT and BUFEL in that quarter.

lead_paragraph: A bulletin from Secretary STANTON establishes two new Military Departments -- one consisting of that portion of Virginia and Maryland between the Mountain Department and the Blue Ridge, to be called the Department of the Shenandoah, under command of Major-Gen. BANKS; and the other, consisting of that portion of Virginia east of the Blue Ridge and west of the Potomac and the Fredericksburgh and Richmond Railroad, including the District of Columbia and the country between the Potomac and the Patuxent, to be called the Department of the Rappahannock, under command of Major-Gen. MCDOWELL.

abstract: The great billiard return match that was played on Thursday evening, at Irving Hall, between DUD- LEY KAVANAUGH, of New-York, and MICHAEL FOLEY, of Cleveland, resulted in the victory being gained, at an early hour on Friday morning, by FOLEY. He won it in a well-contested match by 34 points.

abstract: Every glimpse that we get of the movements of rebel troops confirms the likelihood of the theory broached in these columns a fortnight ago -- that the rebels do not propose to seriously defend the many threatened points in the vast territory nominally in their hands, but that their design is to concentrate from all quarters all available troops on a new defensive line, stretching from some point on this side of the mountains across to Chattanooga, and along the line of the railroad, by Decatur and Corinth, to Memphis, and there, in mass, give battle to the National army. This is a line not likely soon to be reached by us from the South; and, if they mean to make a serious effort for success at all, it is the best strategic base upon which they can plant themselves to stop our columns advancing from the North. Not only are the troops whose duty it has been to guard the menaced cities and strongholds of the Gulf Coast, as Pensacola and New-Orleans, hastening forward to the western positions on this line -- not only have the divisions of the rebel Generals, SMITH and EVANS, been moved hither from Eastern Virginia, but the armies of PRICE and VAN DORN have been ordered to the same field from the far-away regions of Northwestern Arkansas; and from the peninsula of Florida, and from Georgia also, every available regiment has been forwarded north to swell the new line. On this line is Gen. BEAUREGARD, the ablest engineer and the most famous fortifier among rebels; here is BRAGG, the brilliant and bragging artillerist; here is SIDNEY JOHNSTON, the long-headed strategist; here is Rev. Gen. POLK, at once Thug and saint; here is SMITH, the dashing, and EVANS, the invincible; here, though under a cloud, are PILLOW, the peacock, and FLOYD, the "hero of thirty battles;" to this point are advancing PRICE, the war-horse of the West, and VAN DORN, the rival of FLOYD, though not in heroism, Indeed, nearly all the principal Generals of the South are now to be found between Corinth and Memphis. And, to head the roll of rebels, JEFF. DAVIS has caused it to be announced that he himself intends removing to the Southwest -- as soon, probably, as he gets pushed from his stool at Richmond. With the collective troops of rebeldom, led by Generals such as those named, and stimulated by desperation, the great stand is to be made in the Southwest, with the centre apparently at Corinth, the right wing from Decatur to Chattanooga, and the left wing from Grand Junction to Memphis. The rebel papers describe, in glowing terms, the vast natural and artificial strength, the railroad facilities, and the innumerable advantages of this position; they tell of the whole region being black with rebel troops, "many of them veterans, who have fought upon the bloodiest fields of the war;" they declare that here at last have they fallen upon the true strategic line of the South, upon which there can be no defeat and from which there will be no retreat.
lead_paragraph: Every glimpse that we get of the movements of rebel troops confirms the likelihood of the theory broached in these columns a fortnight ago -- that the rebels do not propose to seriously defend the many threatened points in the vast territory nominally in their hands, but that their design is to concentrate from all quarters all available troops on a new defensive line, stretching from some point on this side of the mountains across to Chattanooga, and along the line of the railroad, by Decatur and Corinth, to Memphis, and there, in mass, give battle to the National army. On this line is Gen. Gen. abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to abolish the office of State Assessor was reported favorably. A general bill to amend the Excise laws was also reported. The bill to incorporate the State Convention of Universalists was ordered to a third reading. Among the bills passed were the one to extend the time for the completion of the Buffalo and Alleghany Railroad, the one to incorporate the Brooklyn Pharmaceutical Society, the one to incorporate the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church, and the one to declare the Canal Enlargement completed on the 1st of September, and to reduce the number of Engineers. The Congressional Apportionment bill was then taken up and debated at considerable length. The substitute offered by Mr. BELL was adopted.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to abolish the office of State Assessor was reported favorably. A general bill to amend the Excise laws was also reported. The bill to incorporate the State Convention of Universalists was ordered to a third reading. Among the bills passed were the one to extend the time for the completion of the Buffalo and Alleghany Railroad, the one to incorporate the Brooklyn Pharmaceutical Society, the one to incorporate the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church, and the one to declare the Canal Enlargement completed on the 1st of September, and to reduce the number of Engineers. The Congressional Apportionment bill was then taken up and debated at considerable length. The substitute offered by Mr. BELL was adopted.

abstract: Editorial on Doctrine's principles; editorial on British intervention and on principles of Monroe Doctrine
snippet: Editorial on Doctrine's principles; editorial on British intervention and on principles of Monroe Doctrine
lead_paragraph: It appears from the British Blue-Book on Mexican affairs, that Sir J. CRAMPTON, of contraband-enlistment notoriety, has again become ambitions of the attentions of the Press. The gentleman, who now represents England at the Court of Madrid, has a second time overstepped the limits of his authority, having assured Marshal O'DONNELL, during one of thier conversations touching intervention in Mexico, that "Her Majesty's Government could never recognize what was commonly called the 'Monroe Doctrine.'" This piece of information was, of course, communicated to the Spanish Premier to encourage him in his designs against, the land of MONTEZUMA, though the special business of Sir J. CRAMPTON, at the time, was to impress on the mind of said Minister that the British Government could give no countenance to schemes of aggression or conquest. The distinguished diplomat, however, had an old score to reckon with us, and the opportunity was so favorable that he could not refrain from exhibiting his spleen by having a fling at the doctrine in question. But why had he the audacity to do so in the name of "Her Majesty's Government"? Most certainly he had no instructions, no authority from Lord RUSSELL, to make any such avowal. The object of the British, Foreign Secretary, then, in fact, was rather to sustain the Monroe Doctrine than to profess enmity to it. Nor, even were that not their object, can we perceive they should proscribe a doctrine really so equitable. The "Monroe Doctrine" has been much misunderstood. It is a shield, not a sword. Its aim is protection, not aggression. "With the existing colonies, or dependencies of any European Power," says its author, "we have not interfered, and shall not interfere. But, with the Governments who have declared their independence and maintained it, and whose independence we have, on great consideration, and on just principles, acknowledged, we could not view any interposition for the purpose of oppressing them, or controlling in any other manner their destiny, by any European Power, in any other light than as the manifestation of an unfriendly disposition toward the United States." There is the "Monroe Doctrine" literally, and what is there in it which could prevent its acceptance and recognition by the British Government ? It does not call in question the right of that or any other European Government, to exercise supremacy over its possessions in the Western World, but merely declares that the United States will regard with repugnance the intervention of a transatlantic Power in the internal affairs of any independent American community, with a view to overthrow their liberties, or Republican institutions. This declaration, which has given such needless offence to the Governments of Europe, was in fact elicited by their own acts. One of the avowed objects of the "Holy Alliance" was the conversion of the Spanish-Amoricnn Republics into monarchies, and if was against the aggression contemplated by the despois who were parties to that alliance, that the "Monroe Doctrine" was originally directed. In a word, if was a protest, on the part of the United States Government, against any such outrage then, or in the future -- a protest which, so far from beingdistasteful to the British Minister of the day, actually embodied his sentiment, and received his support. Now, a doctrine which so illustrious a man and so eminent a statesman as CANNING sustained, neither PALMERSTON nor RUSSELL need blush to sanction. Its open recognition and faithful observance by the British Government are, in truth, the best guarantee for England's secure possession of her American dependencies. As long as the monarchies of Europe manifest a decent respect for the rights and institutions of our American democracies, there is no danger of any attempt being made by the Republics of the Western Hemisphere to capel foreign Powers [???] its shores: but it once a systematic design of aggression on the liberties of the States of this Continent is betrayed by Europeans, and it becomes evident that the toleration of their supremacy over any portion of America is incompatible with the safety of the popular Governments, then it may be predicated that the downfall of that supremacy is at hand. The Monroe doctrine is, therefore, the Magna Charta by which the Powers of Europe hold their cisatlantic possessions, and whether their tenure of said possessions be long or short, must depend altogether on their mode of observing this much vilified doctrine.

abstract: A meeting of very respectable gentlemen was held at the Fifth-avenue Hotel in this City, a day or two since, to extend aid and encouragement to an organ of the cause of this country in London. The customary resolutions were passed, and the matter commended to the consideration of the Chamber of Commerce, an influential body in this City. The idea was that we must be adequately represented by a newspaper Press abroad, to disarm ignorance and prejudice against us, and secure the consideration which, as a nation, we deserve.

abstract: Major HERBERT, the private Secretary of Gov. OLDEN, of New-Jersey, under the direction of the Governor, visited Lieut.-Gen. SCOTT, at the Clarendon Hotel, on Monday last, and presented him with the joint resolutions passed by the Legislature of that State at its late session. In tendering these resolutions to the General, Major HERBERT spoke at the affection with which he is regarded by the people of New Jersey, and stated that the resolutions were intended faintly to convey the appreciation in which his distinguished services are held by them. In reply, the General expressed his warm attachment to New-Jersey, and spoke with evident pleasure of the near approach of the time when he should again take up his residence at Elizabeth. The conversation turning upon the war, the General -- among other matters not proper to relate -- stated his conviction to be, that are Midsummer the Southern Government would be at an end.

abstract: so great an interest as a zoological collection, consequently it was a matter of no surprise to find VAN AMBURGH & Co.'s mammoth menagerie crowded on its opening, Thursday evening. There has not been so fine nor so large a variety of living animals exhibited in this City for many years. The gentle gazelle, the frisky monkey, the spotted leopard, the striped tiger, the noble lion, and the sagacious elephant, are all represented, and what is more, a pupil of VAN AMBURGH toys and plays with the beasts as though they were as harmless as kittens.

abstract: NY Custom House activities described
snippet: NY Custom House activities described
lead_paragraph: The month of March has been an unusually busy one at the New-York Custom-house. In times of peace the monthly receipts rarely exceeded those of the past month. Every department has been overrun with business, and the undivided attention of the clerks employed has been necessary to give satisfaction to importers and others doing business at the Custom-house. The large sum of money received for duties, during the month, has been derived, in great measure, from articles on which Congress has levied very high rates of duties. Notwithstanding the large sums required of importers of certain classes of goods, they have not ceased to import, and, in fact, have scarcely diminished the quantity which they usually bring to this country. The war and the high rates of duty seem to have had but little effect on the consumption of such articles as tea, coffee and sugar, which are imported to an extent that many persons would not suspect. The importation of dry goods, too, which has been for some months past considerably inferior to that of other years, has revived, and every steamer from England, France and Germany brings large cargoes of this kind of merchandise. The number of steamers arriving during the month of March, with cargoes of dry goods and general merchandise, has been large. A change is noticeable in the kind and quality of the dry goods imported, as compared with those imported in other years. They are, to the credit of our people, of a more useful and substantial character than usual. Such articles as laces and embroideries are not imported to near as great an extent as has been customary, and those which have been imported, in almost every case, have been taken from the vessel in which imported immediately on its arrival; but few entries of such goods are made for warehouse. Those which had been placed in bond before the troubles of the nation caused a diminished importation, have been withdrawn and thrown in the market. The same diminution may also be seen in the importation of foreign silks. A greater change is manifest in the importation of this article than in that of any other class of dry goods. The large silk houses which heretofore were enabled, by the demand for their goods, to bring hither very large and valuable invoices, seem to have contracted their business very much in consequence of the state of the country. But few silks now find entry on the warehouse books, the importation being only sufficient to meet the current demand, owners and consignees being unwilling to take the risk of having large invoices left on hand without a demand therefor. When the high and complicated rates of duty now required were first levied on cotton goods, it was thought that the importation of the latter would almost cease; that the rates of duty were, to use a favorite expression of our law-makers, "prohibitory." When the act first went into effect, but few cottons, comparatively, were imported, but of late more have been brought to this port. Woolen goods, and those composed partly of wool and cotton, are now imported in considerable quantities. The ladies will have their delaines and worsted goods from abroad whether peace reigns or war rages.

abstract: papers intimate an intention on the part of the Government to relax at an early day, the rigors of the telegraphic censorship. The announcement will be received with satisfaction. The restriction has proved to be simply a source of vexation. It has in no way operated to curtail the circulation of war news in quarters where it might be useful to the enemy. The journalist, advised privately of army movements, but compelled to preserve silence, has had the pleasure of hearing his secret intelligence the universal topic of discussion, influencing the money market, and passing freely from mouth to mouth, while its non-publication has only served to diminish the interest of newspaper columns. This is now to cease, and the loyal population to have the same early knowledge of the doings of the National Army as the rebels have always enjoyed. One incident of the new order will, no doubt, be the cessation of the fitful and reasonless opposition to the attendance of newspaper correspondents upon the movements of the army.

abstract: BROOKLYN MERCANTILE LIBRARY ASSOCIATION -- ANNUAL ELECTION OF OFFICERS -- SUCCESS OF THE INDEPENDENT TICKET. -- The annual election of officers for the Mercantile Library Association, was held on Thursday -- the polls closing 9 o'clock in the evening. The contest between the friends of the members' or "Regular" and the "Independent" ticket was spirited, but confined strictly, we believe, within the bounds of gentlemanly competition. Although the polls closed at 9 o'clock in the evening, there was so much "scratching" that the canvassers did not get through with their arduous labors until 3 o'clock yesterday morning, when they announced the following as the result of the election: President -- JAMES THORNE, Vice-President -- Franklin Woodruff. Corresponding Secretary -- A.V.B. Van Dyck. Recording Secretary -- Charles W. Beebe. Treasurer -- Henry M. Crans. Directors -- Henry W. Merian, William Sherer, G. Hubert Van Wagenen, Gilbert L. Haight, James How, Jr., P.M. Myers, John R. Kennaday, James B. Frothingham, Adrian Van Linderen.

abstract: News from Western press; latest news from island
snippet: News from Western press; latest news from island
lead_paragraph: Late arrivals from Pittsburgh and Savanna, Tenn., report no movements, except scouting parties, by our troops, on account of the continued high water. Gen. BUELL's army is supposed to be in the vicinity, and it is supposed that Gen. GRANT has sent an escort to meet him. A number of siege guns and appurtenances, and a large quantity of heavy chains have arrived. The river is falling rapidly, and if it continues to recede, may perhaps interfere somewhat with operations. Secession cavalry are scouring the country along the Tennessee River, pressing into the rebel service all the men they meet.

abstract: The crew of the steamer Huntsville, at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, were mustered yesterday and inspected by Capt. GANSEVOORT, Capt. ALMY and Lieut. BARRETT. They then were put through the small arms and marine artillery drill, and acquitted themselves to the satisfaction of the above-named officers, who will report accordingly. The Huntsville will be put out of commission to-day. Lieut. HENRY ERBEN, Jr., of this vessel, has been detached, and ordered to report to Flag-Officer FOOTE.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, after the presentation of petitions, Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, gave notice of his intention to propose a new rule for the Senate, providing that during the rebellion the majority may fix a time when debate on any subject may be terminated, and the Senate shall then take a vote on the question. A bill to aid in the construction of a railroad and telegraph line to the Pacific was introduced from the Special Committee on the subject. Business relating to the District of Columbia then occupied attention until the Senate went into Executive Session, after which it adjourned until Monday. Among the bills passed was one allowing the circulation of small notes in the District.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, after the presentation of petitions, Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, gave notice of his intention to propose a new rule for the Senate, providing that during the rebellion the majority may fix a time when debate on any subject may be terminated, and the Senate shall then take a vote on the question. A bill to aid in the construction of a railroad and telegraph line to the Pacific was introduced from the Special Committee on the subject. Business relating to the District of Columbia then occupied attention until the Senate went into Executive Session, after which it adjourned until Monday. Among the bills passed was one allowing the circulation of small notes in the District.

lead_paragraph: The Secretary of War, unlike King Lear, does not want soldiers. The army of the Union is now complete, and an order has gone forth, throughout all the land, that enlistments shall stop. The recruiting Sergeant henceforth ceases his bland persuasions, and the ear-piercing fife shall no longer summon "able-bodied young men" to the pride, pomp, and circumstance of glorious war. The grand triumphal procession that for near a year has moved through our City, en route for the seat of war, our eyes shall look on no more. Or, when we do, 'twill be when the return tide sets in, when the holy mission on which those patriot soldiers went shall have been accomplished in the crushing of this foul rebelllion, and our returning heroes, with the consecration of the sacred cause and the glorious scars' of battle and of victory upon them, shall come back to the homes they have secured for ever to freedom.

abstract: VISION FOR THE WOUNDED. -- The experience of the Newborn wounded has had a salutary effect upon the public. There is to be no lack hereafter of ample accommodation for as many as shall be sent homeward during the Summer campaign; and as the probability is that all the wounded who can bear the journey will be removed as early as possible from the hot and malarious atmosphere of the Southern coast, the utmost provision made here by the charitable will be wanted. The State authorities, we understand, have appropriated the Broadway wing of the Park Barracks to hospital uses. The agent of Massachusetts has secured for the reception of the New-England wounded, a large building upon the corner of Broadway and John-street. These receptacles will no doubt meet every requirement so far as room is concerned. And what with the beneficent association of the City surgeons, and the appointment by Commissioners by the Eastern States, with funds necessary for the relief of want as well as of suffering, there is assurance that the wounded soldiers of the Union will lack little in their passage through New-York save one thing -- quietude.

abstract: just a month to-day since the Merrimac made her renowned raid on the fleet in Hampton Roads. Each day has brought its bulletin advising us of the quiescence of the marine monster, and the announcement has grown almost as stereotyped as "All is quiet on the Potomac." This delay of a whole month in renewing the attack is only susceptible of two interpretations, either the Merrimac was really so seriously damaged in the encounter as to require all this time to put her in repairs, or else the Norfolk rebels are aware of the ample preparations that have been made to meet and destroy her, and are afraid to venture a renewal of the experiment. We are disposed to think the latter the more likely. These preparations can hardly have been concealed from them, and they are probably far from fancying the outlook of things in the vicinity of Fortress Monroe. Though the nature and extent of the force the Merrimac would have to encounter if she should venture out have been withheld from publication, enough is already known to remove from the public mind all fears of trouble from her, and inspire perfect confidence that her destruction will be accomplished as surely as she appears. And this confidence would be further strengthened should we disclose the additional preparations that have been made since we last made note of this matter. The foreign vessels-of-war which are reported to have "taken a front seat in the Roads," for the purpose of viewing the anticipated spectacle, will, we think, therefore, be disappointed. Unless the rebels are willing to make a desperate throw, and let the Merrimac come out, with the certainty of being sunk, satisfied to let her do what damage she can in the meantime, she will not again venture on the rampage.

abstract: On Saturday evening, the 29th of March, a young man called upon the pastor [???] of our principal uptown churches, and represented himself as a thorough Union man, who had recently escaped, with his wife and the small children, from the town of Corinth, Miss. He stated what he and his family had endured hardships and sufferings of the most unheard of nature, and that he was entirely destitute. He alleged that his young wife, who had come on with him to this City, was then laboring under blindness and partial insanity, in consequence of the barbarities practice upon her and her children. The reverend general (Dr. [???]) to whom this army was told, felt that if the case was a genuine one the parties were deserving of aid. Several benevolent people were at once enlisted in the cause. Steps were taken to pay the hotel bill, and the young stranger and his wife were urgently pressed to take up their abode at the residence of one of the wealthy members of the church, which invitation was accepted the same evening. Throughout the next day (Sunday) the guest were treated in the most kindly manner. In the afternoon he delivered an address to the congregation of one of the churches in the City, in which he described his hardships and sufferings during his residence to "Dixie's land," in substantially the following language: His name, he said, was R.C. HALL. He was a native of Mississippi, and has resided in Corinth, in that State, since the war broke out until a few days ago. One day a squad of armed rebels entered his house and demanded his money. He told them he was a minister of the gospel, and that gospel was one of peace. His wife told them they had no money. One of the party, not believing what was told them, then suggested that the money might be hidden in the clothes of the baby, which the nurse held in her arms. "Let's look," said one of them and not finding any such deposit, another said, "Let's kill the dammed Union brat," and with one stroke of the butt and of his musket, dashed its brains out. After that, on his return home, he was warned by a good Union [???] -- one of thousand in that portion of the country -- to remove forth with. In accordance with this coursed, he began by sending his fast two children to their grandmother, at Benson, Vc. To aid him in escaping, his friends provided a horse and buggy, and he and his wife get out on their journey for the Union lines. Such was the result of his boldness in standing up for the Star Spangled Banner under which he had fought in Mexico. He was a Southerner by birth, and bad lived in the South all his life, and he would never forsaken the flag which had protested his life and his property.

abstract: Reporters have given to the Press full derails of the investment and attack of New-Madrid, some 18 miles up the river from this place, and the enemy's sudden panic and inglorious light from that place. It was truly a post of considerable strength to the rebels. Their fort, on which they had expended much labor, commanded the river, or rather each of the forts did so, as there were two of them.

abstract: The London Shipping and Mercantile Gazetic, the special organ of the glasses denoted by its title, pronounces the United States hopelessly bankrupt, while it sees no reason to doubt that the Confederate States have full credit everywhere, and resource. inexhaustible. This West India [???] paradox is easily tested, In New-York, where there is no doubt about the ability of the Government to quell the rebellion very shortly, National five per cent, stocks sell at 86. In London the same stocks are quoted at 77 1/2. Has the Slipping Gazette an idea that Confederate bonds, will sell in London within ten per cent. of the value they possess in voluntary transactions at New-Orleans? And has it not found out that gold in the Southern States is at a premium of forty-five per cent?

abstract: One reason why the English are at a loss to comprehend the importance of Mr. LINCOLN's emancipation project, is that they have not attended to the history of the American Government during the last forty years. Here, we know the value of any declaration from, the National Executive which discloses a belief that the sole purpose and aim of our political system are not the protection of Slavery, in England, where opinions on cis-Atlantic matters are generally formed without examination into the basis of fact, Mr. LINCOLN's proposition falls so far short of that wholesale emancipation they demand of us, that they agree to regard it with disdain. Time, and not much of it either, will soon teach John Bull better.

abstract: The Boston Commercial Bulletin, of the 5th of April, says: "Mr. JOHN H. [???] will sell, on Thursday next, one of the largest and most desirable lots of comestic fleece wool ever [???] in this market .These wools were all selected with great care last Fall by an agent sent through the woll-growing regions to select and buy choice fleece wools. They have never been offered upon the market, and this sale is for the purpose of closing the account. The fleeces have all been taken from the bags and 'cast,' and piled up in separate tiers, thus exposing at least three faces, and sometimes four, so that the purchaser sees at a glance what he is buying. We are informed that there never has been offered in this city so large a quantity of equal grades. Considering that the wool has been selected, and not a promiscuous lot, and that the region of country from which it was selected is the best for wool-growing, manufactures will have a rare opportunity to make selection."

abstract: For several days the panic-[???] have been active in the endeavor to create the impression that the Government comtemplated the [???] of the Confederate States' [???] from Richmond, to [???] point deemed more secure from the Yankee advance, and as a show of foundation for this absurd rumor, it is stated that the efficient Superintendent of the armory has been absent for some weeks, with view to select a more suitable location. We have it from good authority, that in such removal is thought of, and that the absence of the Superintendent has reference alone to business connected with the operations of the armory at this point. abstract: ARREST OF COUNTERFEITERS OF UNITED STATES Coin. -- Sergeant CROFT and Officer Fox of the Second Precinct Police, have succeeded recently in breaking up one of the most formidable gangs of counterfeiters of United States coin that has been known to exist in this city. For months past, New-York and Brooklyn has been flooded with counterfeit fifty cent pieces, quarters and dimes, so well executed that when first issued, even experts, unless their attention was specially called to the coin, were likely to be deceived.The police have for weeks past been on the lookout for the manufacturers of this coin, but it was not until Thursday last that any definite information was obtained as to their whereabouts. On Thursday the officers above named arrested two men, who subsequently gave their names, ANDREAS HENRIQUES and MICHAEL CHEREMANTI, and upon examining the apartments occupied by them at No. 217 Gold-street, they found dies and all other necessary implements and (materials for the successful manufacture of counterfeit United States silver coin, and also a quantity of coin in every stage of its manufacture. When HENRIQUES was arrested,he attempted to throw a way a handful of coin, but was detected in the act and the "contraband" was taken from a gutter, where he had throw it. The officers, surmising that these men had associates in their crime, continued their search, and succeeded on Friday night in arresting, in the upper part of New-York, two men supposed to be accomplices. The accused were brought before Justice PERRY yesterday, when, after a partial examination, VALERIO LAZARETTO was dischared upon his own recognizance, there not appearing evidence enough to hold him. FRANCISCO BEDINI, the other accomplice, was committed with the first two named, to await an examination. CHEREMANTI, when arraigned, pleaded guilty to the charge of counterfeiting United States coin. He is a barber by profession, 32 years of age. HENRIQUES is a physician, 51 years of age, and BEDINI is a barber, 30 years of age. All of the prisoners were born in Italy.
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF COUNTERFEITERS OF UNITED STATES Coin. -- Sergeant CROFT and Officer Fox of the Second Precinct Police, have succeeded recently in breaking up one of the most formidable gangs of counterfeiters of United States coin that has been known to exist in this city. abstract: Sixteen hundred muskets in boxes marked "British pattern for 1861," passed through Mobile a few days ago, en route for Gen. VAN HORN, Arkansas, Those boxes are an instalment of ten thousand [???] guns which arrived at a certain [???] in Florida not long since, on board of a steamer. There is reason to believe that the steamer which bore Mr. YANCEY also brought arms, and others are on the way. A Columbus, Georgia, paper mentions the arrival, up the St. Mary's River, of the steamer Hard Times, laden with arms and ammunition. She was pursued up the river by a Federal gunboat, but escaped by running into a creek.

abstract: The Northern Day Book states that a most horrible deed was committed lately by a widow lady of Appomatox County, Va., named Mrs. SINOLAIK, while  laboring under a fit of derangement. Conceiving, as she said, that herself and little boy, aged about five years, would die in a short time from starvation, she carried the boy in an upper room of her house, and ...
lead_paragraph: The Northern Day Book states that a most horrible deed was committed lately by a widow lady of Appomatox County, Va., named Mrs. SINOLAIK, while laboring under a fit of derangement. Conceiving, as she said, that herself and little boy, aged about five years, would die in a short time from starvation, she carried the boy in an upper room of her house, and hung him by the neck from a joist, and then attempted to cut her own throut with a razor. She, however,was prevented by the timely presence of some member of the household from taking her own life, but not until the disclosed it herself, was the hanging of Her little, boy made known -- she making the request that some one should go up stairs and see if her boy [???] not been hanging long enough. Upon going up stairs it was then found that the little boy had been hanging at least an hour, his feet a short distance from the [???], and that life was entirely extinct. The poor [???] mother, it is said, appeared delighted when informed of the fate of her child, and only regretted that she had not succeeded in taking her own life.

abstract: In the Confederate Senate, on March 14, Mr. PHELAN,of Mississippi, presented a bill prohibiting the planting of cotton during the year 1862, allowing for each planter only three acres for each laborer, and from which not more than five bales of five hundred pounds each, for each said laborer, shall be gathered. The penalty is fixed at $1,000 fine, not less than twelve months imprisonment, and the forfeiture of the crop. A short discussion ensued thereon, pending which the subject was, on motion of Mr. ORR, postponed, and the Senate went into Executive Session.

The penalty is fixed at $1,000 fine, not less than twelve months imprisonment, and the forfeiture of the crop. A short discussion ensued thereon, pending which the subject was, on motion of Mr. ORR, postponed, and the Senate went into Executive Session.

abstract: It is pleasant to read of captures of vessels which the cupidity of their owners has sent to run the blockade, and a profitable thing for our tars to make such captures; but justice requires that we should hold the even balance between the rights that belong to belligerents and those which may be claimed by neutrals. It is scarcely possible for seizures not to be made sometimes that turn out to have been unwarranted; but our Government has always hastened to make due reparation in such cases. There is every appearance that the capture of the British screw steamship Labuan, by the United States sloop-of-war Portsmouth is of this character. From the official documents relative to the case, which we publish elsewhere, it would really appear that the commander of the American cruiser allowed his zeal to outrun his discretion. At the time of the capture of the Labuan she was lying off the mouth of the Rio Grande, loading cotton from Matamoras, having been chartered by a Manchester house to trade regularly between Havana and that port. As the ship was in neutral waters, loading from, a neutral port with a cargo (itself not contraband of war) the property of neutral owners, the case would seem to be sufficiently clear. If these points are fully established, as they seem to be, the seizure is of course unjustifiable, and the Secretary of State, before whom Lord LYONS bas laid the matter, will set it right with the same promptitude that has characterized his treatment of analogous cases.

lead_paragraph: -- The Arizona Territorial bill has been laid over, in the House, until the Tax bill shall be disposed of. In the Senate, the bill is before the Committee on Territories, and will probably be reported back with the Wilmot Proviso -- which, by the way, is regarded of little consequence, as all parties now pretty well understand that legislation, one way or the other, can have no effect on the peculiar institution in that section of country.

abstract: Abraham S. Lee vs. James Myers & Co. -- This action was brought by the plaintiff to recover commissions alleged to be due him as broker for the defendants for the sale of a quantity of dry goods. The goods in question were originally intended for the Southern market; but the condition of the country rendered it necessary that they should seek other channels of trade, -- and the plaintiff, as he alleged, diposed of about $10,000 worth of the surplus stock to Messrs. Ubsdell, Pierson & Co. and Messrs. Lord & Taylor, of this City, in the interest, and upon the request of the defendants.

abstract: Editorial on Congress appropriations for more iron-clad ships
snippet: Editorial on Congress appropriations for more iron-clad ships
lead_paragraph: Congress never made a more sensible or a more judicious appropriation than that it has just passed, devoting twenty-five thousand dollars to be expended in procuring plans and information regarding iron-clad ships and floating batteries. The county is full of inventive genius -- of constructive brains fit to "build the lofty rhyme" in iron bars and plated steel. This appropriation -- which only fails in [???] four times too little --- will ser this inventive genius to work, and [???] constructors and mechanics to bring forward their experiments and suggestions. We have no doubt the result will be to call out a multitude of plans, designs, models, experiments, suggestions and information, in which, along with a good deal of crudity, (as is inevitable,) there will be much that will prove to be of positive practical value, adding largely to our stock of information on the still obscure problems of iron ship-building.

abstract: Editorial on deposition of "King Cotton" in South; Editorial on deposition of "King Cotton" in South
snippet: Editorial on deposition of "King Cotton" in South; Editorial on deposition of "King Cotton" in South
lead_paragraph: A people must be hard pressed when they are forced to destroy the gods to whom they looked for protection, and support. Cotton was King and Saviour -- both. Under its shield any crime might be committed with impunity. The world could not go on without it. It could be had nowhere but in the Southern States. Hence lawless passions became the rule there, as lawless passions always will, when no restraints or penalties are imposed upon that indulgence. A Government was to be overthrown; the North reduced to vassalage, and the "institution" envelope in its slimy folds the whole of our wide-spread Continent.

abstract: -- Our obituary column announces this morning, we regret to state, the death of Miss CURTIS, a lovely young lady, twenty years of age, and eldest daughter of Major-Gen. S.R. CURTIS, now so gloriously serving his country at the head of the army of the Southwest. The deceased resided in Rolla, while her father was in command at that place, was taken ill of typhoid fever, and expired yester~day, a few days after her return to this city. -- St. Louis Republican.

abstract: Frank S. Eager a young and promissing engraver, was [???] on the evening of the 25th inst., near West Point while crossing from the barge-Seaquehannah to the steamer [???]. Mr. Eager resided at Newburgh, and had taken passage to this City on the barge, and not being able to obtain a state-room or berth on the barge, attempted to cross to the steamer along side for that purpose. The plank upon which he attempted to cross broke in the centre, and he was precipitated into the river an I drowned. The small boats of both vessels were immediately manned and launched, but too late to effect a rescue. The deceased was the son of the late Hon. Samuel W. Eager, of Newburgh, and was 26 years of age. He leaves a young wite and child. Mr. Eager was an engraver of great promise. He engraved the whole of the Lord's Prayer some years since, upon two-thirds of the side of a three-cent piece, a piece of work which was regarded by his profession as being the most minute specimen of engraving ever executed. His body has not yet been found, though boats have been continually in search since his loss. The Corporation of Newburgh has offered a handsome reward for his recovery.

abstract: From Gen. BANKS' Department we learn that detached parties of the rebels were still in the vicinity of Edenburgh. On Friday they unmasked a battery upon our right wing near the town; but they were shelled out in short order. Our advance batteries command all the elevations beyond Stony Creek, and are unassailable by the enemy. The position was selected by Gen. BANKS under a hot fire of the enemy. There is a rumor that part of the rebel JACKSON's force have refused to serve him longer, and have intrenched themselves in Page and Rockingham Counties, and defied him.

abstract: The colonization of American negroes, now amounting to one-fourth more than our entire population in 1776, is proposed by some statesmen. Several insuperable objections occur: First -- The labor of the one million or so of these negroes -- its working force -- is essential to the Southern and Southwestern planters, and without them, for several years, there would be a ruinous reduction in the American product of cotton, sugar, rice and tobacco, [???], injuriously, our whole country, and the South most of all. Second -- it is inhuman to drive forth the poor negro from his native home and abode, and break up his local and social attachments. Third -- The expense of removing and setting four millions of people in a new home, would be from five to eight hundred millions of dollars. Fourth -- If these poor negroes are to be driven forth by legal inflictions, or forcibly expelled, the curse of God and the excuations of all Christian nations would fall deservedly upon us. This colonization scheme is wholly impracticable. Gradual emancipation -- changing within twenty-one years our slaves into free laborers by a slow and sure process, leaving them, in the meantime, in compulsory apprenticeship, in the place of Slavery and its wrongs and disqualifications. WILBERFORCE.

This colonization scheme is wholly impracticable. Gradual emancipation -- changing within twenty-one years our slaves into free laborers by a slow and sure process, leaving them, in the meantime, in compulsory apprenticeship, in the place of Slavery and its wrongs and disqualifications. abstract: THE ARREST OF TWO BOYS FOR GRAND [???] -- JOHN THEISS and [???] HARDEN, two boys, each about 35 years of age, were arrested yesterday by Officer VAN RANCE, of the Seventeenth Precinct, upon the complaint or Mr. A. N. FANNING, of No. 225 Bowery, who alleges that the boy THEISS has for several months past been in his employ as errand boy. That, on Friday afternoon, he sent him to a broker's in the vicinity with $283, in uncurrent money, for which the boy was to get bankable bills, THEISS obtained $282 from the broker, but did not return to the store of Mr. FANNING. Yesterday morning the latter instituted a search for the boy and money, which resulted in finding $240 75 of it in the possession of the boy HARDEN, at No. 215 Bowery. When THEISS was questioned upon the subject, he stated, at first, that when he was returning from the broker's office with the money, he was attacked by some other boys in the street, and the money was taken from him. The presence of a police officer, however, induced him to confess that his associate, HARDEN, had the money. The boys were then taken to the Station-house, and there searched, when it was ascertained that they had each bought a silver watch, a six-barreled revolver and a ticket for Albany, with Mr. FANNING's money. They told the officer who arrested them, that they would have been on their way to the West at 9 o'clock A. M., if they had not been taken into custody. They were taken before Justice OSBORNE, at the Essex Market Police Court, and committed in default of $500 bail each.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, very little business of importance was done. A memorial from the NewYork Chamber of Commerce, relative to the Usury laws, was presented. The bill to incorporate the State Convention of Universalists was passed. The bill to appropriate money to pay the National Government the State's quota of the General Tax, was ordered to a third reading. The Congressional Ap- portionment bill was made the special order for Tuesday.

abstract: Observations of Confederate press
snippet: Observations of Confederate press
lead_paragraph: There is no reason why the people of the Confederate States should allow their confidence in our ultimate success to abate or waver. At no time during the old Revolutionary war were the prospects of the Colonies as encouraging as ours are to-day. True, we have suffered reverses, but what man ever yielded the battle of life because he encountered occasional disappointments? Who succeeds at all times, and in all his undertakings? But for the darkness we should never behold the beautiful stars of heaven, and but for reverses, we should go down to our graves in ignorance of the noblest and most heroic qualities of our nature. Suffering and misfortune but the tests of virtue, patience and merit, The brave yield only to God.

abstract: Editorial on reported resignation as managing editor of NY Tribune
snippet: Editorial on reported resignation as managing editor of NY Tribune
lead_paragraph: -- It seems to be generally understood, and we believe it is true, that CHARLES A. DANA, Esq., who has been for the last fifteen years Managing Editor of the Tribune, has withdrawn from that position, and dissolved his connection with that journal. The reasons of this step are not known to us, nor are they proper subjects of public comment. We presume, however, that Mr. DANA intends to withdraw from journalism altogether, and devote himself to the more congenial pursuits of literature. He is one of the ablest and most accomplished gentlemen connected with the newspaper Press. The ranks of the profession are not sufficiently crowded with such members to reader his departure from it matter of indifference. The Albionmakes the following just and merited notice of this incident:

abstract: Great Britain and US consider reviving Newfoundland-Ireland project
snippet: Great Britain and US consider reviving Newfoundland-Ireland project
lead_paragraph: At the general meeting of the Atlantic Telegraph Company the result of which was briefly stated in our impression of yesterday the Directors reported that the American Government had addressed a dispatch to their Minister in this country, offering, in a very handsome manner, to cooperate with the British Government in order that the telegraph might be laid between Newfoundland and Ireland, and for rendering it inviolate even in time of war. The propositions which had been submitted to the Cabinet by the Company had been to the effect that the Government should give a moderate guarantee on the undertaking, or that it might join with the United States, and also with France, if so decided, in which case the guarantee required from each Government would be smaller. It was understood that the discussion in the Cabinet had not been so satisfactory as could have been desired; but it was believed that if the Government saw that a strong feeling was manifested in favor of proceeding with the enterprise, the proposition of the Company would be complied with. An influential deputation will have an interview on Friday (to-day) with the Prime Minister on the question. The Chairman (Mr. S. WORTLEY) expressed [???] opinion that the telegraph would, at no [???]time, be completed, and that it would be [???]. In answer to a question, the Chairman stated that he could not give the particulars of the [???] which had been made to the Company by Messrs.[???] & Co., [???] he considered it very favorable.

abstract: Editorial on Northern missionaries who went to Port Royal to work with freed Negroes
snippet: Editorial on Northern missionaries who went to Port Royal to work with freed Negroes
lead_paragraph: It would be the height of folly to expect anything like Christianity from the New-York Herald. Whatever enterprize is moral or [???]or religious, of course, knows that its first baptism before the world must be a showed of mad from this low print. Any movement originating from the conscience of the public, which should meet with the approval of that journal, would have reason at once to doubt its own honesty or morality. This, of course, is perfectly understood in the community. Yet there are situations in public affairs in which we expect and claim decency of behavior, even from ruffians and blackguards. There are times in which even men who have no spark of generous feeling themselves, do that "homage to virtue," as to act as if they possessed it.

abstract: Killed in Civil War battle; editorial; Contributor F-J O'Brien killed in Civil War battle
snippet: Killed in Civil War battle; editorial; Contributor F-J O'Brien killed in Civil War battle
lead_paragraph: The death of this gallant young gentleman is announced by telegraph this morning, from the effects of a wound recently received in a cavalry skirmish on the Upper Potomac. It will not be forgotten that, in the combat referred to, he met the rebel leader hand to hand. They fired simultaneously, the rebel officer being killed on the spot. The wound of Lieut. O'BRIEN in the shoulder was not at first believed to be fatal. His gallantry in the affair was at once acknowledged, by special dispatch, by Gen. MCCLELLAN. The wound continued to grow worse, and after the amputation of the arm at the shoulder, lock-jaw intervened from the intense irritation of the wound, and no skill of surgery could save him. Lieut. O'BRIEN had but recently received a lieutenancy in the regular service, after volunteering in one of the New-York regiments last Summer. He was an Irishman by birth, and came to New-York about ten years ago, where his good scholarship and fine literary and critical taste gave him varied employment on the Press, in contributions to the leading monthly magazines of the country, as well as to the daily journals. His first essays in this City appeared in our own columns, soon after the establishment of the TIMES.

abstract: The order relative to the breaking up of the recruiting service has not yet reached any of the officers on duty in this City, and it is supposed to affect the volunteer force only.
lead_paragraph: The order relative to the breaking up of the recruiting service has not yet reached any of the officers on duty in this City, and it is supposed to affect the volunteer force only. If it includes the regular army, its effect will be to leave all the new regiments of infantry, and several of the old ones, very far from complete, and to deprive those Captains and Lieutenants who have commissions, but no men to command, of any chance of active service during the war. At the same time, recruiting is so exceedingly slow, that it is very doubtful whether the regiments referred to will be anything like full before the war is over.

abstract: -- The enemies of Gen. MCCLELLAN are at a loss for the material of warfare. For the lack of anything better offering just now, they seize upon the creation of a new military district for MCDOWELL, and a new department for BANKS, as evidence that the Commander of the Army of the Potomac is in disfavor with the President, who thus seeks to curtail his authority. The truth is, the new arrangement is simply an affirmation of the obvious fact that it is impossible for Gen. MCCLELLAN to be in three places at once. Should his advance carry him to Richmond, there are palpable reasons why he should be unable to control the operations in front of Washington, much less the movements of Gen. BANKS beyond the Blue Ridge. The President merely consults public necessity in making the change. The fact has no personal significance whatever.

abstract: The country will hear with pleasure that this gallant officer is recovering from the serious injuries received in the action with the Merrimac, and that he will soon be ready to resume command of the Monitor. We trust that in the distribution of honors and rewards he will not be overlooked by the Government or the country. The service has no more gallant, devoted or disinterested member than he. At the very outset of the rebellion he incurred, knowingly and without a moment's hesitation, the pains and deprivations of a long imprisonment, by conveying through the rebel lines orders to the commander of the squadron at Fort Pickens, which led to the reinforcement of that work, and immediately after his release rendered an equally signal service in command of the Monitor. We commend his case to the attention of the merchants and others of our public-spirited citizens who are raising money to procure a testimonial for Capt. ERICSSON. This is well-deserved -- but Lieut. WORDEN's case is equally meritorious and still more pressing. He has nothing but the pay of his minor office to support and educate a large family; his health is delicate and probably his eyesight will be affected for life by the wounds he received at Hampton Roads. He is as modest as he is brave, -- and would be the last man living to present any claims on the gratitude of Congress or the country. But he should not be allowed to suffer on that account.

abstract: The fewpeaceful indications we have been receiving from Mexico are deceptive. The French Government declines to recognize the validity of the preliminaries arranged by Gens. PRIM and DOBLADO, and is hurrying forward reinforcements, obviously with the design of carrying the war into the interior before midsummer shall render the coast untenable. We do not learn that Spain has strengthened its contingent, or that it has consented to disregard the negotiations of Gen. PRIM. It is quite possible, indeed, that the Spanish army may be withdrawn from Mexico. The understanding between the Tuileries and the Escurial is not at this moment entirely cordial. The Emperor is pressing the old claim for indemnity arising out of the French expedition into Spain, in 1823; a claim, the injustice of which is vehemently urged by the most conservative and judicious of Spanish statesmen. It is hard to pay a Bonaparte debt due to a Bourbon; and still harder to pay for an act of violent and unsolicited intervention, which held the Spanish people back twenty years from the career of prosperity and progress upon which they have since entered. The sudden pressure for this money, prompted by the poverty of the French treasury, must seriously disturb the relations of the two countries, and may lead to a dissolution of their anti-Mexican alliance. It is needless to say, this result is of all things most desirable.

It is quite possible, indeed, that the Spanish army may be withdrawn from Mexico. The understanding between the Tuileries and the Escurial is not at this moment entirely cordial. The Emperor is pressing the old claim for indemnity arising out of the French expedition into Spain, in 1823; a claim, the injustice of which is vehemently urged by the most conservative and judicious of Spanish statesmen. It is hard to pay a Bonaparte debt due to a Bourbon; and still harder to pay for an act of violent and unsolicited intervention, which held the Spanish people back twenty years from the career of prosperity and progress upon which they have since entered. The sudden pressure for this money, prompted by the poverty of the French treasury, must seriously disturb the relations of the two countries, and may lead to a dissolution of their anti-Mexican alliance. It is needless to say, this result is of all things most desirable.

abstract: By an arrangement recently made, North Missouri is subdivided into three Military Districts. The first embraces all that part of the State lying between the Mississippi River and the line which forms the eastern boundary of Linn County, and between the...
lead_paragraph: By an arrangement recently made, North Missouri is subdivided into three Military Districts. The first embraces all that part of the State lying between the Mississippi River and the line which forms the eastern boundary of Linn County, and between the Iowa State line and the line which forms the northern boundary of Randolph County, and is placed under command of Col. JOHN M. GLOVER, of the Third Missouri Cavalry, with headquarters at Palmyra. Thus Col. GLOVER becomes Acting Brigadier-General.

abstract: Our dispatch from Fortress Monroe, dated Saturday, states that cannonading had been heard all the morning in the direction of Yorktown. A rumor was current that the place had been burnt, but it was not generally credited. A later dispatch, received by way of Washington, states that at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon the headquarters of our army was within five miles of Yorktown. The cannonading spoken of had been apparently without effect on either side.

abstract: Mr. KNOEDLER, (GOUPIL'S,) corner of Broadway and Ninth-street, has CHURCH's picture, "The Heart of the Andes," on exhibition. It is placed in the neat little gallery of the establishment, and has been isolated so that there is nothing to seduce the eye from the contemplation of its beauties.
lead_paragraph: Mr. KNOEDLER, (GOUPIL'S,) corner of Broadway and Ninth-street, has CHURCH's picture, "The Heart of the Andes," on exhibition. It is placed in the neat little gallery of the establishment, and has been isolated so that there is nothing to seduce the eye from the contemplation of its beauties. A work of such proportion and intrinsic merit is a matter of public concern, inasmuch as it indicates a very high standardof landscape art in America. Mr. CHURCH has plucked from the land of the Andes the secrets of its charms, and poetically places them before the senses. The scope of a fine fancy is fully sustained by a treatment which, whilst it is far-seeing and comprehensive, is also singularly minute in detail. The picture is so well known that no more is needed than a reference to its return to New-York. In a few days it will be withdrawn from exhibition, and forwarded to Boston. No one should miss the opportunity of seeing this really fine work.

abstract: MAYORALTY EXCITEMENT IN HOBOKEN. -- The good citizens of Hoboken are somewhat excited over a pending Mayoralty contest. Mr. SEBA M. BOGNAY, has been nominated by the regular Democratic Convention, Mr. HOUSEMAN by the Republicans, and the present incumbent. Mr. F.R. JOHNSTON, by the seceding wing of the Democracy, who are dissatisfied with the regular nomination. A large and enthusiastic meeting of the Hoboken Democracy took place on Saturday evening and unanimously ratified the nomination of Mr. BOGERT. The chances seem to favor the idea that either Mr. BOGERT or the Republican will be elected. The latter are in the minority in the city, but Mr. HOUSEMAN may slip in a la OPDYER, between the contending factions of the unterrified. Secession is, therefore, likely to prove as disastrous to the Democracy in this case as it did at Charleston.

abstract: The public mind is impatient of the slow action of Congress in regard to a supply of ironclad steamers-of-war.
lead_paragraph: The public mind is impatient of the slow action of Congress in regard to a supply of ironclad steamers-of-war. Under ordinary circumstances, this action would be deemed quite as rapid as would be consistent with economy and efficiency; but there is a special emergency to be provided for, and every day lost may involve the most serious consequences. It is very well understood that the Merrimac has been repaired, and is ready for another dash upon our fleet at Hampton Roads; and it is further reported that two other vessels of the same general character have been prepared at Norfolk. At New-Orleans, moreover, it is said, four vessels have been clad with iron and are ready for a crusade up the Mississippi. It is impossible to predict the injury which these vessels may inflict upon the Union cause; and not a day nor an hour should be lost in preparing for their reception. The Executive Department of the Government should act instantly in initiating such measures. The danger would justify such action, and Congress and the country would sanction it.

abstract: FLAG-RAISING. On Wednesday last the boys and girls of Grammar School No. 45, in Twenty-fourth street, indulged in a most pleasing and successfull display of patriotism.
lead_paragraph: FLAG-RAISING. On Wednesday last the boys and girls of Grammar School No. 45, in Twenty-fourth street, indulged in a most pleasing and successfull display of patriotism. The pupils of this school, numbering some 1,500, had resolved that their are building should no longer be destitute of the glorious symbol of their country, and, accordingly, by their own efforts, had caused a large and handsome flag with the proper adjuncts, to be prepared, and on the day named, on their invitation, a large company assembled to witness the ceremonies. The residents of the vicinity seemed to have caught the enthusiasm of the pupils, and from every window and house-top the Stars and Stripes were fluttering in the warm air of a fine April day. The ceremonies in the street were inaugurated by the singing of various patriotic songs by the children, and at the appointed time the "Hero of Fort Sumter," Maj.-Col. ANDERSON, took the halyards, and with his own heads raised the Star Spangled Banner to the top of the pole prepared for it. Interesting addresses were made by RICHARD WARREN, Esq., Alderman DAYTON, Rev. Dr. GILLETTE, and other friends of education; and the whole [???] so neatly and creditably conducted by the Principal, Mr. MCNAIRY, and the teachers and pupils of the school, must long be remembered by all who witnessed it.

abstract: When the best families were clustered around the Bowling-green, and gentlemen dandies who promenaded on the Battery were expected to wear white kid gloves, the name of DELMONICO first became known to the lovers of good living in the City. His establishment was the resort of the fashionable, as it now is of the commercial classes of the metropolis. Since then, we have witnessed the success of an up-town branch, on the corner of Chambers-street and Broadway, and are now called upon to record the establishment of another off-shoot of the parent stem on the corner of Fifth-avenue and Fourteenth-street. The Brothers DELMONICO are determined, it would seem, to keep pace with the rapid up-town strider of society, and to secure once more the patronage of all classes of the community. Their new location is in the very centre of fashionable life. It is touched on the homeward stretch of a large majority of the merchants of the City, and is peculiarly handy for those who are hungry and athirst, after the theatres. A select party assembled in the new house on Saturday evening, and were favored with an opportunity of testing the excellence of the cuisine and the resources of the cellar. The establishment (which was formerly the mansion of Mr. MOSES H.GRINNELL) has been fitted up with faultless taste, and is, without any exception, the handsomest place of the kind in the City. We doubt, indeed, if Europe can boast its equal in quiet elegance and real comfort of decoration. The large restaurant on the ground floor is an extremely cheerful apartment, commanding from its windows a view of the always animated promenades of Fifth-avenue and Fourteenth-street. On the same level, but quite detached from it, is a cafe in the true Parisian style, being fitted up with small marble-top tables, and destitute of a bar. This is a new experiment, which we trust will succeed. Up stairs there are innumerable private apartments, large and small, intended for dinner and supper parties, and all fitted up with lavish luxuriousness, but without the slightest excess that can be called garish or vulgar. The establishment is, in fact, as unique as it is beautiful; and when we mention that it is placed under the charge of Mr. CHARLES DELMONICO, we have, we think, commended it thoroughly to the consideration of our readers. It will be opened to the public on Wednesday next.

abstract: The bald places which one witnesses now a days in theatrical audiences indicate the age of the season, and admonish the managers that their career for the present is nearly at an end.
lead_paragraph: The bald places which one witnesses now a days in theatrical audiences indicate the age of the season, and admonish the managers that their career for the present is nearly at an end. Nothing can bemore capricious man the favor of the public during the early months of Spring. It reflects the inconstancy of the weather, being all sunshine one moment and all storm the next; but with this grave difference, that whilst the weather gets gradually better, the theatrical season gets steadily worse. The business last week at the theatres was frequently excellent, but it baffled calculation by being frequently bad. There seemed to be no steady desire for amusement; only fitful spasms of curiosity on the subject. In a month or six weeks the principal Broadway theatres will close for the Summer. It is probable, however, that various experiments in management will be made by new hands. We hear already that Mr. BATEMAN has secured the Winter Garden, and will give a series of first-class entertainments, in which Miss BATEMAN is to take part. A couple of other establishments may also try the precarious experiment of a Summer season.

abstract: morning repeated a report published in the Philadelphia Bulletin, on the authority of a "gentleman from Washington," that Dr. C.A. FINLAY, Surgeon-General of the United States Army, had been arrested and sent to Fort Warren. We have no reason for saying that the report is not true, -- but it is only fair to remind the public that there is not, as yet, any sufficient ground for saying that it is. Dr. FINLAY is a native of Ohio, and has lived for many years in Philadelphia. His service on the medical staff of the army has been long and honorable; and we shall be very slow to believe that he has done anything to tarnish his character, or cast just suspicion upon his loyalty. We shall not credit the rumor until it receives further confirmation.

lead_paragraph: The two great National armies the Army of the East and the Army of the West are now in the situation promised by Gen. Mc- CLELLAN in his address to the soldiers of the Potomac "face to face with the rebels;" and it is evident that it cannot be long before they meet the rebellious foe "on the decisive battlefield." In the East, the late Army of the Potomac -- a host greater than that of either of the belligerents at Waterloo -- and under commanders of approved loyalty, skill and courage, -- is moving upon the strong places and key positions of the audacious enemy who, for over a year, has stood before the Capital defying the National power and insulting the flag of the Union. At any hour the telegraphic wire may tremble with news grander and more momentous than it has ever yet borne since - lightning was used as an agency for transmitting thought. When it photographs before us the scenes of the great day and the be great field -- a day and a field upon which will be decided the fate of this Satanic revolt -- we shall see not merely legions of men, and miles of steel, and an hundred parks of artillery in collision, but principles and ideas greater and more enduring than these, contending for the supremacy. Our army is strong, not merely in numbers and equipment, but in courage, and in having a just quarrel. The enemy is inspired only by the lust of Slavery, and stimulated by desperation. We have met him this year already on twenty fields; we have fought him, with the odds in his favor, at Newbern, and at Winchester, and at Pea Ridge; we have conquered him behind intrenchments at Donelson and at Roanoke. In no instance has he stood the onset of our columns, or the contact of the bayonet. In every case he has given way before the invincible men of the North and the great flag of the Republic. With this prestige on our side, our troops now advance to meet him in general battle; and, if he dare to face us at all on either of the lines, East or West, on which he is now showing fight, like results must inevitably, under Providence, crown our arms. There are rumors, however, and they are likely enough to be correct, that, as our various Eastern corps d'armee advance southward, the rebels are preparing to flee from Virginia altogether. They see, not only that their late boasts of conquering the North, are false and futile, but that they are unable, even with all their forces concentrated and planted behind intrenchments, to make a successful resistance to our army. They think that by retiring Westward and Southward, our army will be unable to follow them among the mountains of the West, and into the alligator swamps and under the hot Summer sun of the Gulf States. In making this confession, and in acting upon it, they virtually give up the whole contest; for, with our army advanced to the line of the warm States, and with our seaboard navy and army acting on the coasts of North and South Carolina, Georgia, Florida, Mississippi, and Louisiana, and our river navy and our Western army acting on their lines, a residence for the rebels in the everglades and alligator swamps would be as fatal as for us. If, moreover, they really mean to leave Virginia without giving battle, it would be well for them to be in haste.

abstract: Editorial says history will show Confederates committed more uncivilized deeds than Union; Editorial foresees great battle in East, another in West
snippet: Editorial says history will show Confederates committed more uncivilized deeds than Union; Editorial foresees great battle in East, another in West
lead_paragraph: The King of Dahomey ornaments his palace with the skulls of his enemies. The ruler of the new Dahomey, which is striving to erect itself into a nationality at the South, has not yet progressed so far into barbarism as this, but the custom appears not to have been unknown or unpracticed among those of his subjects who whiled away their time for some months back about Manassas and Centreville. The tale was too horrid for belief at first, and though we never exactly agreed with some of the English papers in their opinion that the rebels had carried on the war like a high-minded and civilized people, yet we could hardly believe that any human being, who was not an acknowledged savage, would be guilty of taking the skulls of fallen foes for ornaments, making castinets out of their ribs and spurs out of their jaw-bones -- and there are those in our community to whom the whole story is still only an enormous canard. "It is not possible," they say, "that such things can be. The rebels were our brothers, living in peace and amity with us little more than a year ago, and is it to be supposed that they should so soon have lost all feelings of kindliness, so soon have degenerated from our boasted American civilization so far as to be guilty of such deeds as these?" And we see that even Dr. BELLOWS disposed of the matter by saying that there were doubtless barbarians in both armies, and that the Virginians with whom he had conversed expressed the greatest horror at such atrocities. We doubt no that this is so. We know that there are among our lower classes at the "North men whom vice and crime have brutalized, and who, in the license of war, would show themselves barbarians. And yet, from all the evidence that has come to our knowledge, we protest against any such equalization of the two armies. We believe that when the story of the time comes to be written, the impartial historian will be compelled to admit that in all the elements of civilization, in patient endurance and firm courage on the battle-fields and in kindness and gentleness and true nobility toward those whom the fortune of war placed in their power, the Union troops were immeasurably the superiors of the rebels. For cruelty, for malignity, for use of both hand and tongue for evil, for deeds of atrocity and barbarity, the rebels, on the whole, will easily bear off the palm.

abstract: Officers from Woodstock to-day report the bridge over Stony Creek as completed yesterday. To-day our brigades, when crossing, were greeted by a lively canonading from ASHBY's battery, but they were dispersed by our guns, and we are now in full possession of his late position. ASHBY retiring as usual, taking advantage of every position to retard our progress.
