abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- Last evening a new and original play was presented at this theatre, entitled "Sibyl," written by Mr. JOHN SAVAGE, a gentleman of high reputation, both in the literary and political world. It has many claims on popular interest, picturing, as it does, events which at the period of their occurrence, some thirty years ago, created an unexampled sensation in this country. "Sibyl" is founded on the story known to all the readers of the romance of American history, as the "Beauchamp Tragedy of Kentucky" At the same time, the play is by no means an exact dramatization of the incidents of that thrilling story. In the story, revenge is the all-absorbing thought of the heroine; in the play, the author's idea is evidently to picture her in a more womanly color, and to show that the passion of love is stronger even than that of revenge. In doing so, he has fitted the part far more perfectly to the peculiar genius of Miss HERON, which finds its fullest sweep in the portrayal of the depth and self-sacrifice of woman's love.

abstract: The Austrian Prince WINDISCHGRATZ, whose death we learn simultaneously with that of NESSELRODE was some time Generalissimo of the Austrian troops, and had bombarded more capital cities than any commander of his time. He was descended from WALLENSTEIN, and on account of hit high aristocratical manners, no earned the title of "the first Austrian gentleman." He was an Absolutist in politics, and shortly after the breaking out of the Liberal movements in 1848, he took the chief command of the army against the Hungarians. He bombarded Prague in July, and soon after he bombarded Vienna. He rejected all overtures on the part of the Hungarians, imprisoned their envoys, and amused himself by shooting the suspected. He took the field in December, swept in three weeks from Vienna to Posth, driving the Hungarians before him, and was extolled by the Absolutits as the greatest general in Europe. When the Hungarians recovered themselves, and in turn drove him and his army beyond their frontier, he was superseded, and those who had before extolled him to the clouds, now abused him, while the people exulted in the fall of the harsh and blood-stained aristocrat. He will be remembered only as the man who destroyed some of the most flourishing cities of Germany, who murdered ROBERT BLUM, one of the ablest and most patriotic men in the Frankfort Parliament, who suppressed newspapers, and administered musket-balls to a large number of unhappy editors.

When the Hungarians recovered themselves, and in turn drove him and his army beyond their frontier, he was superseded, and those who had before extolled him to the clouds, now abused him, while the people exulted in the fall of the harsh and blood-stained aristocrat. abstract: The Union-Republican State ticket achieved a decided and complete success at the election is Connecticut yesterday; and Gov. BUCKINGHAM was triumphantly reelected. This is a gratifying indication of the confidence of the people of Connecticut in the Administration, and will help to strengthen the hands of our rulers in the great work of National conservation. It is a pleasing corollary to the triumph of the Union-Democratic candidates in Rhode Island last week.

abstract: It will have been noticed that the Commission authorized by Secretary SEWARD to make a proposal on the part of the American Government to cooperate with England in a renewed effort to lay the Atlantic telegraph cable, has been favorably received and is reported to feel confident that the British Cabinet will accept the offer. We are not sure, however, that some recent developments will not dispose Mr. SEWARD to reconsider his proposition. In the course of the late extended debate on Maritime Rights in the House of Commons, a doctrine of international good faith was avowed by Lord PALMERSTON, the Lord Advocate and other speakers, official and non-official, which is certainly far from inspiring the conviction that such a cooperation would be a judicious measure on our part, and which indeed, if taken literally, would in the event of hostilities between the two nations, turn the Atlantic cable into a terrible weapon of war against ourselves. According to this doctrine, which has received the sanction of the leading English Press, war breaks up all treaties, and Lord PALMERSTON, in a series of aphorisms that would not have done discredit to MACHIAVELI, went even so far as to erect bad faith into the dignity of a principle. The special subject under discussion was the Treaty of Paris, the provisions of which are already found to be so inconvenient that one party in the Commons is desirous of abolishing them altogether, while another party urges the noble step of advancing to, and accepting the American doctrine of neutral rights propounded by Mr. MARCY in 1856. It was seriously argued, however, by several Government speakers, that there was no necessity for abrogating it, as in the event of a war, Great Britain could disavow her treaty obligations, or as the Lord Advocate put it, she might "retract under the pressure of an actual struggle the engagements she had made in peace!"

The special subject under discussion was the Treaty of Paris, the provisions of which are already found to be so inconvenient that one party in the Commons is desirous of abolishing them altogether, while another party urges the noble step of advancing to, and accepting the American doctrine of neutral rights propounded by Mr. MARCY in 1856. It was seriously argued, however, by several Government speakers, that there was no necessity for abrogating it, as in the event of a war, Great Britain could disavow her treaty obligations, or as the Lord Advocate put it, she might "retract under the pressure of an actual struggle the engagements she had made in peace!"

abstract: Editorial on Confederate appeal for church bells to be melted down for manufacture of weapons; Editorial on Confederate appeal for church bells to be melted down for manufacture of weapons
snippet: Editorial on Confederate appeal for church bells to be melted down for manufacture of weapons; Editorial on Confederate appeal for church bells to be melted down for manufacture of weapons
lead_paragraph: If theSouthern people remain much longer under the rule of the Confederacy, they will assuredly be as thoroughly despoiled as was the land of Egypt by the swarm of locusts. A little while ago the Richmond usurpers issued an imperative demand for all firearms; they now go further, and make an appeal for the church-bells, with intent to turn them into cannon. The "appeal," issued from the Ordnance Bureau of the rebel Government at Richmond, urges congregations to send in their bells "for the purpose of providing light artillery for the public defence." The special metallurgic reason set forth for this measure is that "while copper is abundant, the supply of tin is deficient to convert the copper into bronze; and bells contain so much tin that 2,400 pounds of bell-metal, mixed with the proper quantity of copper, will suffice for a field battery of six pieces." Accordingly, congregations are recommended to send along their bells for this "patriotic purpose" to places of deposit provided at Richmond, Fayetteville, Charleston, Savannah, Montgomery, Columbus, Baton Rouge, and other points designated. At the close of the war the clergy are assured, the bells will be paid for or replaced -- that is, things will be restored to the condition ante bellum. It remains to be seen with what degree of alacrity the people will respond to this appeal, which significantly reveals the desperate straits of the rebels. As there is every probability that most of the points indicated as depots will be in our possession before the bells can be sent along and cast into cannon, we need not look with any great trepidation to the anticipated increase of rebel light artillery. The only subject of regret in this connection is that the bells should not remain long enough in their belfries to ring the funeral knell of the secession-rebellion and its nefarious leaders.

abstract: Is to be regretted that the appropriation for the completion of this vessel was left dependent by the Senate, upon the decision of the Secretary of the Navy. This will certainly occasion delay, since, as the Secretary has not only never been called upon to investigate the subject, but has expressed his entire ignorance about it, he would of course take advice, perhaps of a Committee who would sit several months. The success of the Stevens Battery has been decidedly pronounced upon by a large number of experts in every branch of marine engineering, and it is to be hoped that the House will avail themselves of this information, without delaying the completion of a vessel so sorely needed, in order that another set of examiners may make their report. It is undoubtedly important that every member of the Department and of the Senate should have the opportunity of going over the usual round of inquiries concerning the Stevens Battery; but the question of completing the vessel and putting her into commission on the ample evidence already before Congress, would seem to be more timely, just at this juncture of our affairs.

abstract: The War Department has given forth a summary of the intelligence received from the neighborhood of Yorktown up to 10 o'clock last night. On Sunday the enemy's works were examined and found to be strong and the approaches difficult. There was sharp firing upon our right, but it is said no harm was done. Another dispatch, at 10 1/2 o'clock, says that some of the outworks had been taken; but that the city could not be taken without a siege of several days. Gen. WOOL states that the rebel MAGRUDER has 30,000 troops. The latest intelligence announces that on the afternoon of Sunday Shipping Point was taken, and the gunboats had shelled out the water batteries. Resistance had been made by the rebels at our crossing of a creek, and several casualties occurred. All the fortified places before Yorktown had been taken by our troops, and the army was full of enthusiasm.

abstract: Editorial on cotton harvests accumulating in South; Editorial on cotton harvests accumulating in South
snippet: Editorial on cotton harvests accumulating in South; Editorial on cotton harvests accumulating in South
lead_paragraph: The Southern planters have not destroyed their last Cotton crop, nor will they give over planting their next crop. The former is safe on hand; not all ready for market to be sure, but in the gin houses ready to be prepared for market. A few thousand bales have successfully run the blockade; a few thousand more have been captured in the attempt to run the blockade. With these trifling exceptions a full average crop of Cotton is now in the country. The war ended, it will soon be seen with what alacrity and certainty this crop will come forward. There has been no application of the torch to it yet, and we venture to say there will be none unless through force of the military rule in particular localites, and then only in the desperation of retreat. Even in the rebel counsels at Richmond a proposition to burn the crop was voted down. The proposition was simply the mad thought of men who have little or nothing of Cotton or any other material wealth to lose. It scarcely rose to the dignity of a self-sacrificing idea, since all the sacrifice would be with the planter and not the politician. The talk of Moscow is worse than moonshine. The conflagration of the whole three million of bales, believed to be on hand in the States in insurrection, would not prevent the National authority from repossessing the places, and territory, and channels of trade which secession is attepmting to deprive it of. The conflagration of Memphis, and Vicksburgb, and New-Orleans would not deter the same authority from restoring the freedom of the navigation of the Mississippi, from its head waters to the Balize. The Government is not after the capture of Southern cotton or Southern cities. With the first it has nothing whatever to do. The latter they will either occupy or restore to their allegiance, not for their own sakes alone, but for the restoration of the commerce of the whole Union to its accustomed channels. The President of the United States could not, if he would, give up the freedom of the Mississippi. Backed by the whole North and East, if such backing were possible, he would not be permitted to do so. The great Northwest would never submit to its surrender. That point is certain. End this war when and where you may, the free navigation of the great Father of Waters is part and parcel of the inalienable heritage of Ohio, Kentucky, Indiana, Illinois, Missouri, Iowa, Minnesota and Wisconsin. As much so, and more, if possible, than the heritage of Tennessee, Arkansas, Mississippi and Louisiana.

abstract: By the arrival at Portland of the steamship Hibernian, we receive advices from Europe five days later than were brought by the Niagara at Halifax. She left Liverpool on the 27th, and Londonderry on the 28th ult. The proceedings of the British Parliament had not been of special importance. Mr. GREGORY had called attention to the case of the British steamer Labuan, captured by our blockading fleet off Galveston, and Mr. LAYARD, in behalf of the Government, had stated that measures had been taken to ascertain the facts in regard to it. The British Press continued to comment upon President LINCOLN's emancipation Message. The Sumter and Tuscarora were still at Gibraltar. The deaths of Prince WINDISCHGRATZ and Count NESSELRODE are announced. It is stated that the Spanish Government has ordered Gen. PRIM not to negotiate with the Mexicans until the troops shall have entered the City of Mexico. This will necessitate a breaking of the treaty arranged between PRIM and DOBLADO at Soledad, a short time ago. GARIBALDI was making a tour through Lombardy to stir up the young men to join the volunteer corps. Demonstrations were reported to be becoming quite frequent in Venetia, and numerous arrests were being made. Cotton is reported dull but firm, with an advance of 1/8 d. on middling grades. Breadstuffs were very dull, and Provisions quiet. Consols were quoted at 95 3/4 on money.

abstract: The Lancaster is here, commanded by Capt. HOFF, a most estimable and accomplished officer. Flag-Officer CHAS. H. BELL has his flag flying on board the Lancaster. He is a strict disciplinarian, unflinching in the exercise of his duty, and commands the respect and esteem of all who know him. To the professional acquirements of Flag-Officer BELL are added all the attributes of a Christian gentleman. -- Panama Union.

abstract: The National Intelligencer, which one would hardly think of calling a sensation journal, has nevertheless on several occasions anticipated the War Department with impunity; and yesterday it again outruns the official utterance by the announcement that the National army advanced on Saturday to Yorktown, with three divisions, and attacked the enemy's position, and that "the bombardment of MAGRUDER's fortifications was progressing well, with very few casualties on our side." As this intelligence supplements Gen. WOOL's telegram, that firing was heard in the direction of Yorktown that same morning, if will, doubtless, be accepted as authentic, and will naturally concentrate public attention on the peninsula where operations have been begun that can have but one aim, and a line of march taken up that can have but one goal -- the possession of the rebel capital! But without attempting to outrun in anticipation what we must ere long hear of as a stirring actuality, we may well pause awhile at the historic field whence the booming of the National artillery comes to our ear. Yorktown marked the close of the Revolutionary struggle, and may be said to mark a new era in the existing contest. It was here that, eighty years ago, CORNWALLIS took up his position, in trenched behind powerful works; here he was nought out and assailed by WASHINGTON, and, after a desperate siege of many days, was finally compelled to surrender his whole army to the American commander. The siege of Yorktown was among the most wisely planned and the most vigorously executed of all WASHINGTON's military operations; and there are many features in which the present siege promises to resemble its illustrious prototype. WASHINGTON was careful to take to this decisive work an overwhelming force -- four or five times that of the enemy -- with abundance of artillery and a powerful cooperating French fleet; we have probably ten times the number of the rebel force, and artillery and fleet to match. WASHINGTON carried the royal stronghold by a flank movement -- a favorite mode of attack with our Union Generals against the rebels. CORNWALLIS had made all his arrangements to escape with his army; MAGRUDER has, doubtless, like his fellow rebel commanders, done the same. But WASHINGTON captured the whole force, and we sincerely hope the example will be emulated by our present General. Finally, the capture of Yorktown was described by a journal of the times as having "dispelled those nocturnal vapors that hung around us, and put the most pleasing aspect upon our present political affairs that any era of the present war has ever beheld." And though the capture of this place at the present time will not be, as it was last century, a termination of the campaign, yet the operations that are immediately beyond can be nothing less than "the swelling prologue to the imperial theme" of a vanquished rebellion and a rehabilitated Union.
lead_paragraph: The National Intelligencer, which one would hardly think of calling a sensation journal, has nevertheless on several occasions anticipated the War Department with impunity; and yesterday it again outruns the official utterance by the announcement that the National army advanced on Saturday to Yorktown, with three divisions, and attacked the enemy's position, and that "the bombardment of MAGRUDER's fortifications was progressing well, with very few casualties on our side." As this intelligence supplements Gen. WOOL's telegram, that firing was heard in the direction of Yorktown that same morning, if will, doubtless, be accepted as authentic, and will naturally concentrate public attention on the peninsula where operations have been begun that can have but one aim, and a line of march taken up that can have but one goal -- the possession of the rebel capital! But without attempting to outrun in anticipation what we must ere long hear of as a stirring actuality, we may well pause awhile at the historic field whence the booming of the National artillery comes to our ear. Yorktown marked the close of the Revolutionary struggle, and may be said to mark a new era in the existing contest. It was here that, eighty years ago, CORNWALLIS took up his position, in trenched behind powerful works; here he was nought out and assailed by WASHINGTON, and, after a desperate siege of many days, was finally compelled to surrender his whole army to the American commander. The siege of Yorktown was among the most wisely planned and the most vigorously executed of all WASHINGTON's military operations; and there are many features in which the present siege promises to resemble its illustrious prototype. WASHINGTON was careful to take to this decisive work an overwhelming force -- four or five times that of the enemy -- with abundance of artillery and a powerful cooperating French fleet; we have probably ten times the number of the rebel force, and artillery and fleet to match. WASHINGTON carried the royal stronghold by a flank movement -- a favorite mode of attack with our Union Generals against the rebels. CORNWALLIS had made all his arrangements to escape with his army; MAGRUDER has, doubtless, like his fellow rebel commanders, done the same. But WASHINGTON captured the whole force, and we sincerely hope the example will be emulated by our present General. Finally, the capture of Yorktown was described by a journal of the times as having "dispelled those nocturnal vapors that hung around us, and put the most pleasing aspect upon our present political affairs that any era of the present war has ever beheld." And though the capture of this place at the present time will not be, as it was last century, a termination of the campaign, yet the operations that are immediately beyond can be nothing less than "the swelling prologue to the imperial theme" of a vanquished rebellion and a rehabilitated Union.

abstract: THE SHOOTING AFFAIR IN BROADWAY. -- LOUISA BRADY, EDWARD ALLEN and Officer AMMAN, of the Concert Saloon No. 444 Broadway, appeared before Justice STEERS yesterday, and gave their testimony in the case of JAMES A. NORMAN, who is charged with shooting ELLEN FOOS at the above named place of amusement, on the night of the 3d inst. In answer to the usual inquiries NORMAN stated that he was a sail-maker by occupation, aged 37 years, and that he fired the pistol at ELLEN. He was committed to await the injuries of the wounded girl, now in the New-York Hospital.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a report was made from the Military Committee, authorizing the President to transfer the appropriation made for fortifications to the building of iron-clad gunboats. The Confiscation bill, introduced by Mr. TRUMBULL, of Illinois, was taken up, and Mr. TRUMBULL made a long argument in favor of its passage. Mr. HARRIS, of New-York, announced his intention to introduce a substitute, and the subject was postponed until to-day. The Senate then went into Executive session, and subsequently adjourned.

abstract: Editorial sees Confederates retreating everywhere
snippet: Editorial sees Confederates retreating everywhere
lead_paragraph: tivity pervades the army of Virginia in every Military Department. This morning we have news that Gen. MILROY, who for some time has been holding the pass of Cheat Mountain, Randolph County, in the northern part of the State, has advanced to the rebel position at Camp Alleghany, some twenty miles in a northeasterly direction, and that the rebels there have retreated before him; while the bodies of rebels stationed at Monterey, the capital of Randolph County, and at Huntersville, the capital of Pocahontas County, have also fallen back in the direction of Staunton, from which they will have a railroad escape toward Richmond. It appears, also, by our special dispatch from Wheeling, that a general southeasterly movement of all the main columns in Northwestern Virginia has commenced simultaneously with the retreat of the rebels over the mountains. The rebels have kept these and other bodies of troops in the Western mountains during the Winter to prevent the advance of our army into the Shenandoah Valley, towards the rear of JACKSON's lately defeated force. Their retirement now would seem to be another indication that they have given up all hope of holding any part of Virginia west of the Blue Ridge, if indeed they have not given up hope of retaining any part of the State. If Gen. MILROY is able to advance much further in the direction he is pursuing, he will get in the rear of JACKSON's brigade, which is still annoying our forces at Edenburg. With BANKS in his front and MILROY in his rear, brief work will be made with that insolent rebel. Cheat Mountain and Gen. MILROY are in FREMONT's new Department of the Mountains.

abstract: Editorial sees complete Union takeover and reconstruction of Virginia
snippet: Editorial sees complete Union takeover and reconstruction of Virginia
lead_paragraph: The reduction of Virginia to the National rule, which now bids fair speedily to happen, will be a most important step, not only in the progress of our arms, but in disclosing the degree of resistance we are to encounter in restoring the status ante bellum. Eastern Virginia is as antagonistical to the spirit of our institutions, and to a true nationality, as South Carolina; while her commanding geographical position, her vast resources in spite of their negligent culture, the important part she played in the drama of the Revolution, and in the formation of the Government, had secured to her such an hereditary prestige that she exerted more influence in National affairs than a half a dozen States of equal population. All this had pampered a pride that brooked no restraint, while she fancied that she possessed a power commensurate with her natural gifts. In these Virginia, more than any other member of the Confederacy, is an imperium in imperio. The fertile imaginations of her people were never weary in looking forward to, and in expatiating upon the wealth, numbers, commercial and manufacturing greatness, that wore to be realized in a future, in which Norfolk was to supplant New-York, and the James River and Kanahwa, the Erio Canal. In South Carolina we had to contend with caste, which Slavery creates in its most perfect form. A few families had come to monopolize both the soil and labor of the State. Their ambition stepped at the ostentatious display of a long roll of serfs and of wide domain. They had the quiet demeanor that belongs to persons conscious of their wealth, and of the secure tenure by which it is held. The State had no harbors -- no coal nor iron -- no elements to which the inductive spirit of modern progress could attach itself, and plant, as in Massachusetts, populous and thriving communities upon sterile plains. Its people were not avaricious of political power, because they had few objects to which it could be directed, and were modest in their demands, for the very good reason of a conscious inability to enforce them.

abstract: The title to this little volume scarcely prepares the reader for the merit of its content, nor does the timid, self-distrustful language of its dedication to Prof. LONGFELLOW give any earnest of the power that is latent beneath it. Sybelle is a beautiful creation. A young girl, in a seclu  sion that is almost solitude, pants for the great outer world and its raging conflicts of passion and ambition.
lead_paragraph: The title to this little volume scarcely prepares the reader for the merit of its content, nor does the timid, self-distrustful language of its dedication to Prof. LONGFELLOW give any earnest of the power that is latent beneath it. Sybelle is a beautiful creation. A young girl, in a seclu sion that is almost solitude, pants for the great outer world and its raging conflicts of passion and ambition. She thirsts for activity and fame elsewhere, and filled, as her being is, with every keenest sympathy with all the loveliness and mystery of the universe, this mad dream of a grander life consumes it with unreasonable longings. Raimond, who has tasted all the follies of the outside struggle, and sought repose in the delicious quiet which causes Sybelle to repine, calmly rebukes this discontent.

Mr. O'BRIEN laid aside the pen to espouse the cause of his adopted country, and in the brilliant skirmish at Bloomery Gap met the death of a hero. The funeral will take place at 12 o'clock.

abstract: MARY PROVOST's THEATRE. -- A little piece called "Grist to the Mill" was played here last evening, and although slight in structure and not very brilliant in dialogue, served the useful purpose of further introducing Miss MARY PROVOST to the public. The lady played with much vivacity, and is entitled to the merit of very thorough study, -- for not only did she know her own part, but prompted the other actors in theirs. She is quick-witted, coquettish and merry, but her style is provincial and explosive. It needs to be toned down for two reasons -- first, because spasmodic demonstrations are out of date here; and, second, because her voice becomes nasal the moment it is forced. A short experience of metropolitan audiences will place Miss PROVOST on the right road, and then we shall be mistaken if she does not speedily become a favorite with the public. The play does not call for further mention.
lead_paragraph: MARY PROVOST's THEATRE. -- A little piece called "Grist to the Mill" was played here last evening, and although slight in structure and not very brilliant in dialogue, served the useful purpose of further introducing Miss MARY PROVOST to the public. abstract: The great victory achieved by the combined military and naval forces of Gen. POPE and Commodore FOOTE, at Island No. Ten, on the Mississippi River, and the capture of six thousand rebels, and their arms and a hundred siege guns, without the loss of a single man on our side, crowns in a worthy manner the long siege of the famous river stronghold.
lead_paragraph: The great victory achieved by the combined military and naval forces of Gen. POPE and Commodore FOOTE, at Island No. Ten, on the Mississippi River, and the capture of six thousand rebels, and their arms and a hundred siege guns, without the loss of a single man on our side, crowns in a worthy manner the long siege of the famous river stronghold. In its importance, it is second only to the capture of Fort Donelson -- if, indeed, it be second to that achievement. The fall of Fort Donelson opened our way into the States of Alabama and Mississippi, and gave us virtual possession of all of Tennessee, excepting its southwestern corner. The fall of Island No. Ten must soon give us possession of that rebel corner, and will thus open our way through the entire rebel territory to New-Orleans and the Gulf of Mexico. Fort Donelson was won by terrific fighting, and after the loss of between one and two thousand brave men; Island No. Ten is gained by pure strategy, and without the loss of a single National soldier. At Fort Donelson, we took twice the number of rebels prisoners; but we did not get half the number of siege and other heavy guns that now fall into our hands, which latter are a far greater loss to the rebels than men would be. The artillery and warlike munitions the rebels cannot supplement; and they will soon have to stop the war, if but from the lack of the death-dealing implements. At Forts Henry and Donelson, at New-Madrid, and now at Island No. Ten, we have captured nearly three hundred pieces of ordnance, besides immense quantities of small arms and miscellaneous material. Gen. POPE and Commodore FOOTE have raised themselves even higher than the position they have heretofore achieved; and their persistence and spirit have won for them unmingled admiration. With such heroes and such strategists on the side of the nation, there is not a shadow of danger of the success of this atrocious rebel war.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Assembly amendments to the bill authoriising the Supervisors of New-York to raise money and create a Court-house stock were concurred in. The Congressional Apportionment hills were referred to a Select Committee, with instructions to report a single bill complete. The bill to amend the act to suppress intemperance and regulate the sale of intoxicating liquors was reported complete; also, the bill to reduce taxation in this City, by appropriating the surplus revenue of the Sinking Fund to the payment of the interest of the City debt. A resolution was adopted requiring the Clerks of Boards of Supervisors to transmit a statement of expenses to the Comptroller by the 15th of December. The bill authorizing the formation of Companies for inland navigation was ordered to a third reading. Messrs. FOLGER, WOODRUFF and ANGEL were appointed a Select Committee to re-district the State.

abstract: The marine corps at the Flushing-avenue Barracks will be increased by three sergeants, six corporals, and forty privates, who have been detached from the force at the Washington Barracks, and will arrive to-day. This will amply provide marine guards for vessels going into commission, and leave a sufficient number of men for guard duty at the barracks and Navy-yard. The guard of marines which left the North Carolina a few days since, with a detachment of blue-jackets, for Cairo, Ill., returned to their old quarters yesterday. The journey was expeditiously made, and the men reached their destination safely.

abstract: -- The course or events in this country promises ill for the reputation for sagacity of the most prominent London journals. With the cause of Slavery and rebellion, its British apologists and abettors are rapidly coming to grief. The case of the London Times is, indeed, so pitiable that we hasten, for its name's sake, to its relief. Let its conductors, then, when they stand wondering and puzzled how to get out of the hobble in which their time-serving and the power and determination of the faithful citizens of this Republic have placed them, turn to its files at the time when they began to be occupied with the discussion of rebellion, and they will find that, just as usual, they are able to say, "We told you so." In a leading article in the Times of Nov. 26, 1860, we read:

abstract: It is an established law of Political Economy that all giving is, scientifically, a blunder; but it is a blunder which, happily, it is impossible to keep the human heart from conniving at when a deed of private charity, filly bestowed, or of public beneficence, wisely directed, contravenes our cold economics. We do not care to inquire what a Mill or a McCulloch would say of Mr. PEADODY'S gift of...
lead_paragraph: It is an established law of Political Economy that all giving is, scientifically, a blunder; but it is a blunder which, happily, it is impossible to keep the human heart from conniving at when a deed of private charity, filly bestowed, or of public beneficence, wisely directed, contravenes our cold economics. We do not care to inquire what a Mill or a McCulloch would say of Mr. PEADODY's gift of three-quarters of a million of dollars to the poor of London, satisfied that this munificent largess justifies itself by a higher economy than that of the schools. The distinguished American merchant has made a benevolence which is indeed princely, in the best meaning of that term, and which widens our experience of the generous qualities of human nature. And Mr. PEABODY's gift acquires a peculiar moral interest from the fact that it is to a considerable degree the fruit of a vow made with himself many years ago. We learn from the letter which conveys the offer, and which is addressed to Mr. ADAMS, our Minister at London, that he, at a comparatively early period of his commercial life, resolved in his own mind that, should his labors be blessed with success, he would devote a portion of the property thus acquired to "promote the intellectual, moral and physical welfare and comfort of his fellow-men, wherever, from circumstances or location, their claims upon him should be the strongest." He has already carried this resolve into effect in two conspicuous instances in his own country, having founded in 1852 an institute and library for the benefit of the people of his birthplace in Danvers, Mass., and in Baltimore an institute devoted to science and arts, with a free library, which is now completed, though not yet opened. The present gift, accordingly, he devotes to the benefit of the poor of London, where he has resided for the past five and twenty years, and been blessed with great worldly prosperity. Our Minister at London, with Lord STANLEY, Sir JAMES EMERSON TENNENT and Messrs. CURTIS LAMPSON and JUNIOS S. MORGAN, are made trustees of the fund, and to them he transfers the sum of 150,000, (or $750,000,) to be used in such ways as shall "ameliorate the condition and augment the comforts" of the poor of the great English capital; and, among other ways, by the construction of such improved dwellings for the poor as may combine in the utmost possible degree the essentials of healthfulness, comfort, social enjoyment and economy. The trustees have certainly a wide field of action before them in descending to benefit that class with which MAYHEW makes us acquainted in his terrible piece of social anatomy, the London Labor and London Poor. Our countryman thus not only does an act of very pure and noble charity, but at the same time teaches a lesson of practical democracy. Such acts put the whole world under contribution, and it can scarcely be that this munificent benefaction of one who, by his sympathies and ties, is, as it were, at once American and Briton, shall not prove a new bond of international amity.

abstract: Robert M. Ward and Walter S. Grove vs. Charles Kelsey. -- This was the return to an order to show cause why an injunction restraining the defendant from collecting the wharfage at an addition to a certain pier in Brooklyn should not be dissolved. Affidavits were read on the motion to show that the defendant rented to the plaintiffs eleven stores in Brooklyn, with the bulkhead and pier in front; and that subsequently he agreed, in writing, to erect an addition to the pier on the north side. The rental of the addition to the pier was to be $1,700 per annum. On plaintiffs failing to pay the rent on the addition, defendant, by summary proceedings, obtained possession thereof. The plaintiffs thereupon obtained an injunction against defendant, restraining him from collecting the wharfage from vessels lying alongside of the addition. The defendant obtained an order to show cause why the injunction should not be dissolved, to which this was the return.
lead_paragraph: Robert M. Ward and Walter S. Grove vs. Charles Kelsey. -- This was the return to an order to show cause why an injunction restraining the defendant from collecting the wharfage at an addition to a certain pier in Brooklyn should not be dissolved. The plaintiffs thereupon obtained an injunction against defendant, restraining him from collecting the wharfage from vessels lying alongside of the addition. The defendant obtained an order to show cause why the injunction should not be dissolved, to which this was the return.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, petitions in favor of and against a General Bankrupt Law were presented. The Confiscation bill was again considered, and Mr. HENDERSON, of Missouri, made a long argument against its passage. A bill to confirm the act of the President in accepting the services of volunteer engineer troops was introduced by Mr. WILSON, of Massachuseets, and referred. Au Executive Session was then held after which the Senate adjourned.

abstract: editorial speculates on Mexico's future under allied occupation
snippet: editorial speculates on Mexico's future under allied occupation
lead_paragraph: The Emperor NAPOLEON need not be under much apprehension that peace will be made in Mexico before the arrival of his reinforcements. The friendly disposition which some time back seemed to animate the negotiators, is rapidly giving place to feelings of distrust and antipathy. The financial necessities of JUAREZ have driven him to impose a forced loan of $500,000 on certain foreign houses and this impolitic act has 80 incensed the Allies that they have determined to send an ultimatum to the Mexican Government, threatening it with a declaration of war, if said loan be not immediately annulled.
headline: {'main': 'A Dark Future for Mexico.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Dark Future for Mexico.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Henry T. McCann et al., vs. Jacob Manning. -- This was an action brought by the plaintiffs, who are merchants in this City, to recover the sum of $1,075 81, the value of goods sold by them to Ezra Manning, a son of the defendant. Plaintiffs allege that in April, 1859, the defendant came to their store, and represented to them that his son Ezra, who was a merchant at Cohoes, in this State, was doing a good business and making money, and that he did not owe more than $100, and that by reason of these representations they trusted Ezra Manning to the amount claimed. It was alleged, also, that Ezra Manning did not own at the time more than $100. The defence set up was a denial of the allegation of the complaint, and an allegation that at the time he believed his son to be doing a good business, and to be making money.

abstract: Article on improved accommodations, Ward's Island, NY, for immigrants
snippet: Article on improved accommodations, Ward's Island, NY, for immigrants
lead_paragraph: During the past year, Ward's Island has undergone a much-needed sanitary improvement, and, detected by the present administration of Mr. FAGAN, its internal economy has exhibited marked financial resuits. The drainage of sixteen acres of miasmatic swamp land, and clearing away of useless thickets, has enhanced the value of the property, while it has removed a long standing nuisance. A productive addition is thus made to a farm, of some sixty-five acres in extent, which affords the main supply of edibles for the sojourning emigrants. It is estimated that $5,880 are by this means saved to the treasury yearly. In connection with the farm is another acceptable and highly sanitary feature, the Dairy, the establishment of which has heretofore been unsuccessfully attempted, but now is a permanent arrangement, to which the physicians attribute the decrease in mortality among children of tender years. Including the expense of purchasing cows, the sum of four hundred and fifty dollars has, during this, its first year, attested its economy over the contract provision of former years. Sheds and appropriate space are allotted the cows, and they are kept in a healthy condition. Fifteen acres of the Island are appropriated to grass land, and nobly grown Southdown sheep reposed their wealth of wool and flesh upon the rolling mounds.

abstract: -- We are enabled to say that, even before the surrender of Island No. 10, Gen. SCOOT expressed the opinion that the rebels were so disorganized and demoralized that they would offer little further armed resistance to the authority of the Government, and only make such stands and take to such shifts as their desperate leaders could intimidate or cajole them into. This opinion from one who has judged and dealt so wisely upon all public affairs, in peace or war, heretofore, and who appreciated in the very beginning the magnitude of the task of the Government in putting down the rebellion, and saw that it was not to be accomplished by a direct march into the hostile country, is, we need hardly say, of great importance, and will add much to the feeling of confidence which is now universal.
lead_paragraph: -- We are enabled to say that, even before the surrender of Island No. 10, Gen. abstract: Editorial on Union intention of using Negro soldiers for garrison duty
snippet: Editorial on Union intention of using Negro soldiers for garrison duty
lead_paragraph: The Secretary of War, with provident eye to the heats of Summer, and the necessity of holding forts and arsenals in places where the yellow fever demon will enlist, for three or four months, on the side of the rebels, has, we are told, conceived the possibility of using negro soldiery for garrison duty. The blacks, thoroughly acclimated, will be saved from the risks of climate; while in the well-defined limit of fortifications they will be restrained from the commission of those revengeful excesses which are the bug-a-boos of the Southern people. And, indeed, we hardly know why so much care should be taken of those same Southern nerves, seeing the merciless readiness of the rebels to turn upon us the Indian savages of the Southwest. But there is an argument for the use of the negro troops sufficient to acquit Mr. STANTON of sympathy with Garrison Abolitionism. Experience proves the blacks to have rare merit in the handling of artillery. Both in the British and American service has this excellence been noted. They are proof to the heat and smoke of the casemate, unendurable by whites in a warm elimate, while the ardor of their labor and courage throws the utmost energy into their gunnery. It is also asserted that their practice is quite as accurate as that of the white artillerists. Other considerations equal, and the expediency of arming the blacks in any circumstances once determined -- a subject we are sure the Secretary will weigh carefully before deciding -- this faculty of the negro as a gunner would would go far to commend his employment.

abstract: Among the many young gentlemen of position and character who assisted Col. VAN BUREN in raising the 102d Regiment New-York Volunteers, was Mr. ROBERT AVERY, of Brooklyn, an attendant at Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER'S Church, and a young man in every material point of life correct. He was assigned the command of Company A in the regiment on account of his quickness, energy and power of control, and was mustered into the service of the United States in the early part of March.

abstract: -- The most exciting and important action of the war, thus far, the siege of Yorktown, is veiled in great part from the people's eyes by the mandates of the military authorities, and we only get the dryest and most meagre outline of what is going on. This is all unlike the glowing pictures we have heretofore had of battles, sieges and bombardments, even while they were in progress; and it is to be feared that posterity will lose as much as we do from the lack of special telegrams and special correspondence. But the work is, nevertheless, going on. The progress of the siege dally show favorable signs; and, added to the glorious news from the West, we shall probably soon have news of the fall of Yorktown.
lead_paragraph: -- The most exciting and important action of the war, thus far, the siege of Yorktown, is veiled in great part from the people's eyes by the mandates of the military authorities, and we only get the dryest and most meagre outline of what is going on. abstract: "Island No. 10 is ours!" This time the announcement is founded, not on conjecture or belief, but on positive knowledge. The imminence of the danger threatening them after the crossing of Gen. POPE to the Tennessee shore, and the running of two of our gunboats by their batteries, proved too much for the rebels, and on Monday night, at midnight, they hastily evacuated their shore batteries, leaving everything behind them, and surrendered the island into the hands of Commodore FOOTE. The gallant Commodore, in adispatch dated at 3:25 A.M. yesterday, announced to the Navy Department that he had just been boarded by two officers of the rebel navy, by order of their commanding officer, with instructions to surrender to the Commander of the Union naval forces. The Commodore, of course, made no delay in availing himself of the rebel offer. By this surrender, a large number of heavy cannon, quantities of munitions of war, the famous floating battery, and a number of gunboats and steam-transports come into our possession. The number of prisoners is not stated in our dispatches.

abstract: A sanitary commission of the right sort, not intent upon uprooting and discarding established usages for the introduction of experiment and salaried officials, but one which comprehends not only the physical but the mental health of our soldiery. All persuasions have a voice and a hearing in its councils, and its benefits are extended alike to sons of our own and those of foreign lands, who are rallying in defence of the Government that has nurtured and protected them; and yet further does its Christian philosophy carry the forbearing spirit of benevolence -- even into the hospitals and prisons where are gathered our rebellious brothers, who receive, in common with our own loyal soldiers, the encouragement to a higher life.

abstract: The People vs. Simon Katz. -- The prisoner was convicted of arson in the first degree, having been indicted for setting fire to the premises corner of Division and Attorney streets, in this City, in 1860. The lower part of the premises were occupied by the defendant as a grocery, and the upper portion occupied by families. Upon the trial it appeared that the prisoner's nephew, a lad of about 17 years of age, set fire to the building, but he testified that he did so upon the solicitation and request of the prisoner, by whom he was instigated to do it.

abstract: editorials on bill
snippet: editorials on bill
lead_paragraph: The House or Representatives has rid itself of the labor of revising and perfecting the Tax bill by sending it to the Senate. How far the latter body will conceive it proper to alter radically a "bill for raising revenue," originating legally in the popular branch, we cannot foretell; but it is certain the measure is very far from perfect, and we should not be surprised if, leaving only the framework standing, the Senate were to replace the manifold subjects of taxation in the bill by a dozen leading and equally profitable sources of income. Time is certainly short. There is still time, however, to borrow wisdom from the veteran experience of Great Britain, by simplifying the provisions of the act.

lead_paragraph: The iron-clad frigate in course of construction near Philadelphia is progressing quite rapidly, some of the 4 1/2-inch plates having already been placed on the bow. The work of putting the plates on the sides of the vessel was to have been commenced yesterday. The plates are bent to suit the formation of the vessel, and but a short time is required to fasten them on the vessel, large iron screws, about two feet long, being used for the purpose of keeping them in place. A large number of the plates for the spar-deck have already been laid.

abstract: The second siege of Yorktown threatens to rival the first in time, as it far outrivals it in magnitude. Its reduction occupied WASHINGTON's army almost a month, and Gen. MCCLELLAN's army has been already close on a week in front of the place. As the War Department thinks it prudent to shroud operations in that quarter as much as possible, thus depriving the public of the excitement of special telegrams and special correspondence, excitable readers are taking a sort of historic revenge by diligently perusing the history of the siege of 1781. They could not do better; and, for this purpose, let us tell them, there is nothing so good as the journal of the operations kept by WASHINGTON himself, and transmitted by him, day by day, to the President of the Continental Congress.

abstract: The Navy Department has doubtless good reasons to give for permitting the disabled Merrimac to be refitted at leisure, and to select her own time and place for another essay of her destructive powers. The Department had good reasons to give for the original loss.
lead_paragraph: The Navy Department has doubtless good reasons to give for permitting the disabled Merrimac to be refitted at leisure, and to select her own time and place for another essay of her destructive powers. The Department had good reasons to give for the original loss of the vessel, along with the Norfolk Navy-yard, and for the success of its former desperate attempt. It had reasons quite as good for the successive escapes of the Sumter and the Nashville. They all, however, resolve themselves into the very simple formula, that adequate measures are not taken by the Department until the rebels have had ample opportunity to do their worst. Among those in New-York who understand such matters, quite as well as the Secretary himself, it is believed that the means instituted (partly by Government) to destroy the Merrimac, would have done the work far more effectually had they attacked her boldly at the Navy-yard, crippled and without steam, than they can do it, now, when she is repaired, newly armed, and with steam up and abundant sea-room. That these advantages are on her side is unquestionably a source of extreme alarm, not only to the people but to the Government. The latter, for fear of the monster, is unable to harbor the fleet of transports tributary to the army of the Potomac under the guns of Fortress Monroe; and the public, equally fearful, shows none of the enthusiastic satisfaction which the splendid victories on the Mississippi and Tennessee so fully warrant. Why, if our mailed champions are what they are represented to be, do they not seek their enemy, and at once terminate the general suspense?

abstract: -- The reception to be given to-night, at the Academy of Music, for the benefit of the crews of the United States ships Cumberland and Congress, who so nobly signalized themselves in the engagement with the rebel steamer Merrimac, should be responded to by every citizen who values the existence of our Government, and who appreciates the valor of those noble-hearted seamen who defended the flag of our country when assailed by its enemies. This exhibition promises to be a grand affair. The sailors of these ships are to come over from Brooklyn this afternoon at 5 o'clock, and will march through Fulton-street and thence up Broadway to the Academy of Music, accompanied by the bank of the United States ship North Carolina. In the midst of the achievements of our soldiers, which have electrified the heart of the nation, let not these brave sailors be forgotten by our citizens. Let the reception be worthy of the men and the loyal City of New-York.

abstract: Editorial on London Times correspondent J Russell departure for England
snippet: Editorial on London Times correspondent J Russell departure for England
lead_paragraph: Mr. W.H. RUSSELL, Special Correspondent of the London Times, was among the passengers by the China, which sailed for Liverpool yesterday. Mr. RUSSELL's stay in the United States had extended over more that a year of our eventful times, during which time he has contributed letters of a varying merit to the leading London journal. Some of his earlier descriptive letters were characterized by all his brilliant and unrivaled power in that style of writing; but he was less happy, and sometimes extremely unhappy, in his speculative and philosophical essays, and thus incurred the odium of many who were, perhaps, not always willing to make due allowance for the extreme difficulty and delicacy of his task.

abstract: Of the splendid achievements of the Union army, day unto day utters speech. Barley have we noted the tranquil success of the plans, so admirably matured by FOOTE and POPE for the reduction of Island Ten, when we are called upon to chronicle the brave fighting of GRANT and BUELL on the Upper Tennessee. The battle at Pittsburgh is justly described by the reporter, whose account is, thus far, our only source of information ...
lead_paragraph: Of the splendid achievements of the Union army, day unto day utters speech. Barley have we noted the tranquil success of the plans, so admirably matured by FOOTE and POPE for the reduction of Island Ten, when we are called upon to chronicle the brave fighting of GRANT and BUELL on the Upper Tennessee. The battle at Pittsburgh is justly described by the reporter, whose account is, thus far, our only source of information and which we assume to be only defective in its exaggeration of the number killed and wounded, as the most formidable and destructive of modern times. What with the numbers engaged on either side, the desperate character of the fighting, the tremendous part played by artillery, and the fatal consequences of the defeat, it certainly lays just claim to this preeminence; for on no other recent battle-field have all these conditions been so thoroughly represented. The conflict sets at rest forever the doubt whether courage is a national trait. On the side of the Union as on that of rebellion, there was exhibited the most obstinate displays of valor; the loyal army resolute to win, the rebel army with the impulse of desperation, determined not to lose. Of generalship there would seem to have been less than there was of personal daring and persistent intrepidity; what, in fact, may be properly termed soldiership. Of such a struggle the fruit could not be other than a frightful sacrifice of life. There was, indeed, reason in Congress receiving the bulletin of victory in silence. On whichever side the dead had fallen, they were our own dead; our brethren and friends, who had gone out loyally to redeem the country, or those other brethren, and sometime friends, who, misguided and untaught, are struggling for the overthrow or prevention of imaginary wrongs. There is no aspect of such a victory, save one, which has not its tinge of melancholy. That one is the hope it authorizes of the war drawing to an early close.

abstract: -The hero of the fierce fight at Pittsburgh is evidently Gen. ULYSSES GRANT. Throughout the action he is reported as constantly on the perilous edge of battle, rallying the men, and leading them upon the enemy, in contempt of danger. Let the malicious aspersion upon his courage, founded on an incident at Fort Donelson, be expunged forever. The only doubt about his bravery, is whether or not it amounts to rashness.
lead_paragraph: -The hero of the fierce fight at Pittsburgh is evidently Gen. ULYSSES GRANT. Throughout the action he is reported as constantly on the perilous edge of battle, rallying the men, and leading them upon the enemy, in contempt of danger. Let the malicious aspersion upon his courage, founded on an incident at Fort Donelson, be expunged forever. The only doubt about his bravery, is whether or not it amounts to rashness.

abstract: Thos. Moyo vs. Lewis Brosi. -- This case was stated in the TIMES of yesterday. The plaintiff sought to recover the value of freightage upon several casks of wine, brought to this port from Rotterdam in his ship, the Golden Rule. The defence was that 150 gallons of the wine were lost by the breaking of the casks containing it, through the defective system of stowage. The defence set up the value of this wine as a counter claim. The plaintiff replied that by the bill of lading he was not to be accountable for leakage, and that the weight and contents of the casks were unknown.

abstract: The Chatham Bank vs. Frederick B. Betts et al. -- This was an action on a promissory note, to recover the sum of $2,350. The defence set up by defendant Betts, who alone appeared to defend, was that in 1861 he made the note in suit and delivered it to the defendant, Archibald A. Thomas, as an accommodation note, and without any consideration. That Thomas subsequently entered into an agreement with the defendant Samuel B. Potter, by which Potter gave an usurious rate of interest and agreed to pay Thomas for the note the sum of $150, more than its face. It was also alleged in defendant's answer, that plaintiffs were not the real parties in interest, but that the suit was commenced and prosecuted at the instance of and for the benefit of the defendant, Potter, who, as alleged, was the real party in interest; and the defendant alleged that he had an equitable set-off to the note as against Potter.

abstract: Gen. BUELL having arrived on Sunday evening, in the morning the ball was opened at daylight, simultaneously by Gen. NELSON's Division on the left, and Major-Gen. WALLACE's Division on the right. Gen. NELSON's force opened up a most galling fire on the rebels, and advanced rapidly as they fell back. The fire soon became general along the whole line, and began to tell with terrible effect on the enemy. Generals MCCLERNAND, SHERMAN and HURLBURT's men, though terribly jaded from the previous day's fighting still maintained their honors won at Donelson; but the resistance of the rebels at all points of the attack was worthy a better cause.

abstract: The battle at Pittsburgh, Tenn., a few miles from the rebel position at Corinth, brief dispatches regarding which were published in our first edition yesterday, and fuller details of which appeared in extra editions, proves to have been one of the first magnitude in its progress and results. It was brought on by the rebels themselves, early on Sunday morning, and continued, with an Intermission lasting only through the darkness of Sunday, night, until late in the afternoon of Monday. The collision of the two armies was hurried by the desire of the rebel leadersto engage our Southwestern army in detail instead of in mass -- the necessity, in fact, of defeating Gen. GRANT before he could be joined by Gen. BUELL. Dispatches received from Louisville informs us that BRAUREGARD left Corinth with his command for Purdy, a few miles west of Pittsburgh, on Thursday last, and that JOHNSTON, with his command, left on the same day for the same destination, by a different route -- intending to concentrate their forces at Purdy and make an attack upon Gen. GRANT on Friday or Saturday, should the state of the roads permit. Fortunately they were delayed so that the attack could not be made until Sunday, as before stated, when Gen. BUELL was so near the scene of action that he was able to participate on the second day, and turn the tide of battle in our favor. The brigades of Gens. SHERMAN and PRENTISS were first engaged, and the rebel attack was successful. Our entire force was driven back to the river, when the advance of the enemy was first checked by the fire of two of our gunboats. Gen. GRANT then arrived at the scene of action, with the troops from Savanna, and our men, who had been contending against fearful odds, were inspirited by the news that two Divisions of Gen. BUELL's army had also arrived. The next morning our forces, now out-numbering those of the rebels, assumed the offensive, and, after a hard-fought day, succeeded in routing the enemy at every point. Our losses on the first day were heavy, and beside the killed and wounded, embraced the camp equipage at Pittsburgh and thirty-six field guns. On the second day, however, by two o'clock P.M., we had retaken the camps and batteries, and some forty of the enemy's cannon, beside a number of prisoners. A number of our men were taken prisoners on the first day, including, one report says, Gen. PRENTISS. The reports of our killed, wounded and missing are doubtless much exaggerated, but it is likely the number will approach five thousand, while the enemy's losses must be much heavier, as our artillery was served upon them with terrible effect. Among their killed the name of their best General, ALBERT SIDNEY JOHNSTON, is given.

abstract: REGARD, deficient in brass, has been begging the disloyalists of the Southwest to send in their dinner bells as material for cannon. The success of Capt. FOOTE and Gen. POPE at Island Ten must demand a further appeal. The number of heavy guns captured in the land batteries was seventy; while there were many others taken upon the rebel gunboats and floating battery. Losses like these must convert the very buttons of the army into artillery.

abstract: New-York, yesterday, wore quite a gala-day appearance. The occasion was the receipt of the news of victory from Island No. 10, and Pittsburgh. At an early hour the TIMES, and other newspaper offices, were beseiged by an expectant crowd, who after devouring all the news that had arrived, anxiously waited, and like Oliver Twist, asked for more. In the absence of reliable news many rumors of the most startling character got afloat. Great battles were being fought at almost every hour during the day. But the rumor that obtained the greatest credence was that the Merrimac had come out, and had been sunk by the Monitor.

abstract: In view of the pressure caused by legal business, growing out of the war, the Secretary of the Interior has authorized the appointment of an additional assistant, Mr. Smith has accordingly promoted to the position of Assistant United States District-Attorney, Mr. George P. Andrews, late Chief Clerk, who has won the confidence of the District-Attorney and the public by close attention to the business of the office. He is a man of integrity and talent. Mr. Smith and his assistants have promptly transacted all the business arising in the District-Attorney's office during the last year, and have materially reduced the number of pending suits.

abstract: George Stein vs. Henry Neil. -- This was an action to recover damages for the alleged destruction of a lease, whereby the plaintiff claimed he lost possession of a house in Hamilton-street which, as claimed, he had rented from May 1, 1860, for five years, from the defendant, at $400 per annum. The plaintiff averred that the defendant sent for the lease, under the pretence of wishing to make a copy of it. But that, when in his possession, he destroyed it, and subsequently rented the premises to other parties, thereby depriving the plaintiff of the benefit of his lease. The plaintiff laid his damages at $3,000. The defendant denied the making of the lease, and set up that even were there a lease, that the plaintiff could not recover more than the sum total of the rent. The jury, after canvassing the evidence, returned a verdict for the defendant.
lead_paragraph: George Stein vs. Henry Neil. -- This was an action to recover damages for the alleged destruction of a lease, whereby the plaintiff claimed he lost possession of a house in Hamilton-street which, as claimed, he had rented from May 1, 1860, for five years, from the defendant, at $400 per annum. The jury, after canvassing the evidence, returned a verdict for the defendant.

abstract: Editorial scores Government concentration of funds and contracts at Washington and Norfolk Navy Yards; Editorial scores Government concentration of funds and contracts at Washington and Norfolk Navy Yards
snippet: Editorial scores Government concentration of funds and contracts at Washington and Norfolk Navy Yards; Editorial scores Government concentration of funds and contracts at Washington and Norfolk Navy Yards
lead_paragraph: When the conspirators began to put into shape and form, several years since, their plan for erecting a Cotton Kingdom on the ruins of the American Union, one of their first steps was to provide the means of warfare. To that end their eye fell upon the Navy-yards at Washington and Norfolk. These yards, located within slave territory, were nurtured and enlarged in every possible way. They intended that when the theft was accomplished the booty should be worth the stealing. As a means to this end, they secured for these yards enlargement and the monopoly of certain species of naval material, so that other parts of the country should be dependent upon them. Immense sums were lavished on these two yards, especially on that at Washington. A man of some talent in supervising mechanical operations, was selected to superintend this yard; hundreds of thousands of dollars were spent on his education to make him an adept. In some of his gun improvements and adaptations he was successful; in fact, he has produced the most effective cannon used in any service. It was contrived that a large class of munitions should be manufactured at this yard only. Even the great New-York Yard has to send to the Washington Yard for half of the ordnance fabrications required. The Norfolk Yard was made the great storehouse of ordnance. Large contracts were given to the Tredegar Works, at Richmond, fostering the manufacture there till the result was attained -- that those Works produced the best cannon in the country. Three thousand cannon fell into the hands of the enemy with the Norfolk Yard. These have been distributed all over the "Confederacy," and on every battle-field have they dealt death among the loyal men of the country. But the plan was only half successful. The Washington Yard, when the open rebellion was reached, slipped through their traitor fingers, and remained the property of the Union.

abstract: Gen. JOHNSTON, the bogus report of whose capture at Fort Donelson gave him a biographical fame two months ago, is now certainly disposed of at last, as his dead body is in our hands. He was one of the five rebel "Generals," the other four being BEAUREGARD, LEE, COOPER and JOE JOHNSTON. He was for half a year commander of the rebel Department of Kentucky, with his headquarters at Bowling Green, which famous stronghold he evacuated six weeks ago. He is 50 years of age, a native of Kentucky, and graduated at West Point in 1826. He was engaged in the Black Hawk war, in the Texan war of independence, in the Mexican war, and in the war against the Mormons. He was Brigade-General in command of the Military District of Utah, and at the opening of this rebellion, was in command of the Department of the Pacific. Shortly after the rebellion got under way, his loyalty was suspected, and Gen. SUMNER was sent out to supersede him. Before Gen. SUMNER reached California, JOHNSTON had left to join the rebels. For fear of being caught, he took the overland route, with three or four companions, on males, and passed through Arizona and Texas, and thence to Richmond. At first he was appointed to a rebel command on the Potomac; but upon the great importance of the Western Department being seen by JEFF. DAVIS, he was appointed to take chief command at Bowling Green. He did everything to strengthen that position, and bring as large a force as could be got for its defence. But, on being outflanked by our advance up the Cumberland, he incontinently deserted his stronghold, fled to Nashville, from thence to Decatur, and from thence to Corinth, and now has fallen -- a traitor to his native State and to his country. JOHNSTON was a little over six feet high, of a large, bony, sinewy frame, with a grave, gaunt and thoughtful face; of quiet, unassuming manners -- forming, in all, a soldier of very imposing appearance. He was considered by military men the ablest General, for command, in the rebel service, and his loss will be a severe blow to the tottering rebellion.
lead_paragraph: Gen. JOHNSTON, the bogus report of whose capture at Fort Donelson gave him a biographical fame two months ago, is now certainly disposed of at last, as his dead body is in our hands. He was one of the five rebel "Generals," the other four being BEAUREGARD, LEE, COOPER and JOE JOHNSTON. He was for half a year commander of the rebel Department of Kentucky, with his headquarters at Bowling Green, which famous stronghold he evacuated six weeks ago. He is 50 years of age, a native of Kentucky, and graduated at West Point in 1826. He was engaged in the Black Hawk war, in the Texan war of independence, in the Mexican war, and in the war against the Mormons. He was Brigade-General in command of the Military District of Utah, and at the opening of this rebellion, was in command of the Department of the Pacific. Shortly after the rebellion got under way, his loyalty was suspected, and Gen. SUMNER was sent out to supersede him. Before Gen. SUMNER reached California, JOHNSTON had left to join the rebels. For fear of being caught, he took the overland route, with three or four companions, on males, and passed through Arizona and Texas, and thence to Richmond. At first he was appointed to a rebel command on the Potomac; but upon the great importance of the Western Department being seen by JEFF. DAVIS, he was appointed to take chief command at Bowling Green. He did everything to strengthen that position, and bring as large a force as could be got for its defence. But, on being outflanked by our advance up the Cumberland, he incontinently deserted his stronghold, fled to Nashville, from thence to Decatur, and from thence to Corinth, and now has fallen -- a traitor to his native State and to his country. JOHNSTON was a little over six feet high, of a large, bony, sinewy frame, with a grave, gaunt and thoughtful face; of quiet, unassuming manners -- forming, in all, a soldier of very imposing appearance. He was considered by military men the ablest General, for command, in the rebel service, and his loss will be a severe blow to the tottering rebellion.

abstract: -day, at noon, the steamer Magnolia, that was captured off Mobile trying to run the blockade, was sold at auction by Mr. D.H. BURDETT, by order of the United States Marshal, JAMES C. CLAPP. The first bid was $20,000, which was run up, by Mr. STARK W. LEWIS, to $50,000, and to him knocked down. Immediately after the sale the vessel was at the risk of the purchaser. The Magnolia was built in Brooklyn, in 1857, and is 843,80-95 tons burden. Her length is 240 feet, 35 feet beam, and 55 feet over all. She has accommodations for 125 cabin passengers, and about 100 second-class passengers. Her two boilers are low pressure. Shortly after the purchase, Mr. LEWIS transferred her to the Government, and she is now under control of Col. TOMPKINS, the United States Quartermaster at this port. The brass cannon belonging to the steamer was also purchased by Mr. Lewis, for $310.

abstract: ETTE. -- Gen. DIX and Judge PIERREPONT, the two Commissioners, with their Secretary, E.D. WEBSTER, Esq., of the State Department, appointed by the President to investigate the cases of prisoners of State confined in Fort Lafayette, commenced their sessions in this City on Monday last, and have thus far examined ten cases, of whom four have been released and six recommitted. The names of the released prisoners are as follows; Wm. W. Hendricks and Jonah Potterfield, released on taking the oath of allegiance; David C. Wattles and Capt. Isaac L. Vigue, released on their parole of honor not to extend aid or comfort to the rebels. The following were recommitted: Wm. W. Hill, Sidney, Bennett, W.H. Childs, E.W. Cecil, Col. Tacuana, (known as the French lady,) and Mr. Chaplin, who is placed on the footing of a prisoner of war.

abstract: The hasty dispatches that were received yesterday of killed and wounded officers are probably both incomplete and incorrect in many particulars. In deed, some of those reported dead have already turned up, and others will doubtless do so. Under these circumstances it might be both injudicious and painful to give sketches of the officers reported fallen until the facts are definitely ascertained. We will briefly notice some of those honorably engaged in the battle, and some of the fallen, regarding whom the statements seem to be authentic. The officers in chief command were Major-Gen. GRANT, who acted so gallantly on Sunday, and Major-Gen. BUELL, who was in joint command on Monday.

abstract: -- The Southern chivalry, who are so desirous of shedding the last drop of their blood that they are unwilling to shed the first drop, are advertising in the rebel journalist for "substitutes," and offer as high as $1,500 to any of the "white trash" that will take their place. This does not show that the said "white trash" are insensible to the seductions of the lucre; it only shown that they have a pretty just estimate of the value of the Confederate scrip, in which the $1,500 is to be paid.

abstract: The late terrible struggle at Pittsburgh adds another to the long list of Sunday battles. The facts are so clear in this and numerous other conflicts, and the results have been so uniform and decisive, that comment is not only warranted but demanded, alike by philosophy, patriotism and piety. The general ...
lead_paragraph: The late terrible struggle at Pittsburgh adds another to the long list of Sunday battles. The facts are so clear in this and numerous other conflicts, and the results have been so uniform and decisive, that comment is not only warranted but demanded, alike by philosophy, patriotism and piety. The general statement cannot be gainsaid, that the more important movements of the National forces, in the early stages of the present war, were made on Sunday; and that they were undeniable failures. PATTERSON's column was constantly notorious for its manoeuvreing on Sundays, -- and for little else. Big Bethel, Bull Run, and Ball's Bluff were the great blunders and defeats of attacking armies on Sunday. All these engagements, excepting Bull's Bluff, under the now imprisoned Gen. STONE, preceded Gen. MCCLELLAN's noble Sabbath order. Thence forward the rebels have made the Sunday assaults, with invariable loss of the battles thus waged. Mill Spring opened their career of Sunday lighting, which closes with Pittsburgh. The battle of Winchester was begun on Sunday morning. The first of these, battles cost the rebels Kentucky; the second, the valley of Virginia; and the third, the Mississippi Valley. The Merrimac, too, after its destructive Saturday's raid, ran a much against the Monitor on Sunday, and has spent a month in repairing damages.

abstract: -- Yesterday afternoon the above Board held its semi-monthly meeting. The regular weekly statement shows that on March 29, 1862, there were remaining in the various institutions 7,711, and since admitted 1,943, making a total of 9,564. A communication was received from Dr. ALEXANDER B. MOTT, inquiring of the President if wounded soldiers, who had no homes, could be furnished with accommodations at Bellevue Hospital. The answer was in the affirmative, provided they paid $3 per week. The use of the Tombs court-yard was granted by the Board for the execution of WM. HAWKINS, who is now under sentence of death. CHARLES M. JEFFERDS, who is now under sentence of death, also sent a communication to the Board, requesting permission to take exercise at the City Prison, or else be transferred to the Hospital. The request was referred to the Warden of City Prisons, with instructions that while he (JEFFERDS) should be treated with all liberality, he must not be permitted to go beyond the rule, in all cases to be adhered to of safe keeping. The Board then adjourned.

abstract: Among  the killed on the National side, at the late bloody victory in Tennessee, was Acting Brig.Gen. WILLIAM PEGRAM. He was a brother of ...
lead_paragraph: Among the killed on the National side, at the late bloody victory in Tennessee, was Acting Brig.Gen. WILLIAM PEGRAM. He was a brother of ROBERT PEGRAM, commander of the Nashville, who has rendered his name forever infamous. Though born in Virginia, he had resided for a number of years in Kentucky, and was never seduced from his loyalty by the poor sophisms that led his brother into treason. From the first he was a staunch loyalist, raising a regiment of cavalry, which was in the engagement at Pittsburgh Landing, and has now offered up his life in defence of the country against which his brother has lifted up a traitor's hand. There is certainly no feature of the present war so tragic as when brother is thus found arrayed against brother; but it should teach foreign critics, who magnify the unanimity of sentiment at the South, how baseless is the claim that the rebellion against the Union is founded on any deep or universal conviction.
