abstract: It seems very certain that the only thing  that has kept the Merrimac from coming out any time during the present week, is the storm that has lashed the waters of the Chesapeake into fury for the last three days. Whatever ...
lead_paragraph: It seems very certain that the only thing that has kept the Merrimac from coming out any time during the present week, is the storm that has lashed the waters of the Chesapeake into fury for the last three days. Whatever the power of the rebel monster may be against wooden walls, the one condition of her doing anything is that the have a smooth sea. She could not live an hour amid such a gale as swept over the Chesapeake on Tuesday and Wednesday, for a wave catching her overlapping, eaves-like sides, would peel off her iron coat like pasteboard. Indeed, Sir HOWARD DOUGLAS, the first authority on iron-clad war ships, in discussing the qualities of a vessel of the form of the Merrimac, (for nothing is more absurd than to suppose that her model is a rebel invention,) proves mathematically that such a ship is wholly unseaworthy. And here is precisely where our plucky little Monitor has the advantage; she can buffet any sea, and is capable of being completely submerged without hurt. And this only disposes one to reiterate the question we have already put, namely: Why are not our mall-clad champions allowed to seek out the enemy, (which is said to be lying off Craney Island,) and strike when she cannot follow? Now that fair weather has returned, we may at any moment expect to hear that the rebel monster is out a Merrimac-ing.

abstract: The contest between the two sections, and the triumph of the North, is to be followed by a pretty radical change in the construction of the organic law of the country. Such law should always be in exact harmony with the interests of a people, and its growth or construction reflect the progress of the nation, and every permanent change in its habits and ideas. Such harmony must obtain in the end, ...
lead_paragraph: The contest between the two sections, and the triumph of the North, is to be followed by a pretty radical change in the construction of the organic law of the country. Such law should always be in exact harmony with the interests of a people, and its growth or construction reflect the progress of the nation, and every permanent change in its habits and ideas. Such harmony must obtain in the end, as the prevailing sentiment or interest will be sure, sooner or later, to express itself upon the statute-book. This is as it should be. We do not think of using the modes of locomotion practiced, from necessity, by the framers of our National chart. We have new powers, new objects, new relations, and new interests, and we must have a tether as wide as our newly-acquired faculties and gifts.
headline: {'main': 'The Real Triumph of the North.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Real Triumph of the North.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Metropolitan  Health bill has passed the Assembly by a strong vote, and it was brought up yesterday for action in the Senate. A warm contest ...
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Health bill has passed the Assembly by a strong vote, and it was brought up yesterday for action in the Senate. A warm contest ensued on the question of its reference, which indicated that some of the members were not willing to let the bill stand on its merits at all, but were disposed to drag in side issues of no moment. This kind of work was anticipated in the Senate. It is there, of course, that the enemies of the bill propose to make their last stand, and it is upon this body that they mean to bring to bear all possible influences to defeat it. Members will have to be exceedingly careful of their good names; for there are and have been rumors that corrupt tactics are to be resorted to, and that money and men to use it have gone up to the Capital from this City to defeat a bill which otherwise could have but few opponents. It is to be hoped, nevertheless, that there is virtue and intelligence enough in the Senate to overrule all such attempts. The importance of the bill to the health of the City is undeniable; its necessity may be learned from the mortality statistics. So, let the Senate, with as little manoeuvering as possible, give us the Metropolitan Health bill, and the improved health of the Metropolis will be their speedy recompense.

abstract: Congress,  we learn, is about to take a step at least, the subject is favorably before it which will do more for transportation, military or otherwise, between the Metropolis and the Capital, than all the railroads that could be hung upon the mountain-tops of Pennsylvania. It is to make a post-route of ...
lead_paragraph: Congress, we learn, is about to take a step at least, the subject is favorably before it which will do more for transportation, military or otherwise, between the Metropolis and the Capital, than all the railroads that could be hung upon the mountain-tops of Pennsylvania. It is to make a post-route of the whole shore line from Jersey City to Washington, and compel or allow it, as the case may be, to use steam through any city, and to transport passengers and freight without breaking bulk, and to avoid delays from local, thieving ordinances, and all other causes. This system of coercion costs nothing, while the system of promiscuous aid to poor railroads, which the Reading and Columbia scheme was invented to establish, simply knocks the bottom out of the Treasury. If legislation will go a step further and compel the several connecting railroads to lay a double track, there will be no occasion for circuitous lines.

abstract: The brave tars who survived the terrible onslaught of the iron-clad steamer Merrimac on the frigates Congress and Cumberland, received a most flattering welcome at the Academy of Music last evening. Besides the handsome sum realized from the sale of tickets, large amounts were subscribed to a fund, which is to be devoted to the relief of the wounded and the widows and orphans of the killed, so that, aside from the personal testimonial to the survivors, there will be a more substantial return for the sufferers and their families.

abstract: A Washington tel  egram reports that an officer, who has just come from the scene of operations near Yorktown, states, that "the intrenchments might be taken without bloodshed in two or three weeks, but, as the country expects urgency, a different course will be taken."
lead_paragraph: A Washington tel egram reports that an officer, who has just come from the scene of operations near Yorktown, states, that "the intrenchments might be taken without bloodshed in two or three weeks, but, as the country expects urgency, a different course will be taken." This may be the engineer's view of the matter, but the inference he wishes to convey -- namely, that it is a view shared by Gen. MCCLELLAN -- is certainly an erroneous one, as assuredly it places the country in a false position toward the Army of the Potomac. After the unmurmuring patience with which the Nation has, for almost a year, awaited operations in Virginia, Gen. MCCLELLAN is the last man to feel that any popular "urgency" will compel him to lay aside a well-considered plan. The country expects that no "different course will be adopted" from that best calculated to put his business through with vigor and success.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the Secretary of Wa. was requested to report to the Senate what disposition had been made of the vessels captured by Gen. BURNSIDE at Roanoke. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, gave preliminary notice of a bill to amend the Fugitive Slave law. The bill to establish ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the Secretary of Wa. was requested to report to the Senate what disposition had been made of the vessels captured by Gen. BURNSIDE at Roanoke. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, gave preliminary notice of a bill to amend the Fugitive Slave law. The bill to establish a line of steamers from San Francisco to Shanghai, was then taken up, and Mr. LATHAM, of California, made a speech in favor of its passage. The Confiscation bill was then debated at considerable length by Messrs, HALK of New-Hampshire, WILLEY of Virginia, TRUMBULL of Illinois, and others, but no vote was taken upon it. After an Executive session, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Editorial speculates on effects of Union victory in war
snippet: Editorial speculates on effects of Union victory in war
lead_paragraph: We print this morning another and most clear and intelligent account of the great battle and Union victory of Sunday and Monday last on the Tennessee River. It is written by an eye-witness, to one of the Cincinnati daily journals, and will command attention for its succinct narrative of the two days' fighting. It leaves no question of the terrific and bloody nature of the engagement, or the completeness of the Union victory. It diminishes the extreme peril in which the first report placed the army of Gen. GRANT on Sunday afternoon, while it adds to the promptness and efficiency with which our gunboats were brought to his assistance. Two other important facts are made manifest. First, that the division of Gen. LEWIS WALLACE, who mistook his way, in the early hours of Sunday, was enabled to cooperate with the remainder of Gen. GRANT's forces before the close of the eventful day; and, secondly, that the army of Gen. BUELL, which reached the opposite bank of the river, was thrown across during the night with extraordinary promptness and expedition, and without a single accident -- the means of transportation being at once ample and available. The last point is equally gratifying, from the triumphant results which followed, and important as removing all color of delay or mismanagement.

abstract: The rebel Government has  made its last desperate bid for foreign recognition in the shape of an act that has just passed the rebel Congress establishing Freetrade with all the world. The precious band ...
lead_paragraph: The rebel Government has made its last desperate bid for foreign recognition in the shape of an act that has just passed the rebel Congress establishing Freetrade with all the world. The precious band of traitor-legislators, at a time when the capital they have usurped is momentarily menaced by the avenging army of the Union, have "Resolved, That the ports of the Southern Confederacy are open to the free entry of goods from every nation of the world except the United States!" The desperate bid has come too late. The measure might possibly have had some weight if made a year, or even six months ago. It would have taken John Bull in a soft place, and might very likely have brought them a certain kind of "sympathy" at least. But they have allowed the opportunity to slip by, and now not even poor purblind Bull is likely to be deceived by a measure which, if it had any basis in real intention, would have been announced long ago. As for legislating that the Southern ports are open, in face of the present perfection of the blockade -- that is a delicious fiction, such as only the Southern legislative mind is capable of.

abstract: The President's  Proclamation though less a proclamation than a prayer, so is it pervaded by a beautiful natural piety setting apart next Sabbath as a day of thanksgiving for the victories Heaven has vouchsafed the Union arms, will meet with a heartfelt response. Secretary STANTON ...
lead_paragraph: The President's Proclamation though less a proclamation than a prayer, so is it pervaded by a beautiful natural piety setting apart next Sabbath as a day of thanksgiving for the victories Heaven has vouchsafed the Union arms, will meet with a heartfelt response. Secretary STANTON has already issued an order directing every Chaplain to offer public thanks at the head of his regiment at noon of the same day. The order will reach to all the armies of the United States, and half a million of men in the field will unite in grateful acknowledgment to that beneficent Providence who has so signally crowned with triumph the National arms; while with their voices will blend those of the millions in the peaceful walks of life. This is meet and Christian behavior for a Nation that professes to be a Christian nation. The day, moreover, is signally appropriate, as Sunday, the 13th of April, is the anniversary of the day when the nation received its stab at Fort Sumter. What an interval of gloom and glory is there between the dates! But now the sky is so radiant with the Divine smile, that every loyal heart will be a shrine whence grateful incense will ascend to Heaven.

abstract: JUSTUS SCHMIDT, who arrived here in the Schooner Edwards from Tampico on the 7th ult., and was arrested on supposition of being a rebel agent, was yesterday released on parole by the Commissioners appointed to examine into the cases of prisoners confined at Fort Lafayette. WM. T. SMITHSON, a Washington baker, declined to take the oath of allegiance and was recommitted to the Fort. The following persons were also examined by the Commissioners and recommitted as prisoners of war: Thos. E. Sanders, H.R. Duble, Geo. Baker, Thos. C. Fitzpatrick, Joseph D. Smith, J.S. Hughes, John Greenough, Jeremiah Kelley, Roben Redman, Geo. Hale -- all of them captured on board the rebel [???] schooner Royal [???].

abstract: The reception of the crews of the frigates Cumberland and Congress at the Academy of Music last evening was a brilliant success. A vast audience was present, and addresses were made by PELATIAH PERIT, Dr. HITCHCOCK, WM. M. EVARTS, GEORGE BANCROFT, WM. E. DODGE, and Jack-tars MARLOW and WILLIAMS, of the crews of the Cumberland and Congress. The sailors sang a number of their songs, which were enthusiastically received. The proceeds will be devoted to the relief of the wounded and the widows and orphans of the killed.

abstract: In the Senate, last evening, but little was done; most of the session was consumed in the consideration of a bill to amend the Code of Procedure, and to extend the term of office of the Commissioners of the Code appointed under the act of April 6, 1857. An amendment was finally adopted that no Justice or Judge shall sit as Referee in any action pending in any Court in which he is a Judge.

abstract: EXPLOSION IN A KEROSENE OIL FACTORY  THREE LIVES LOST. At about 6 o'clock last evening, a still in the kerosine oil factory owned by D.O. KETOHAM, located at the corner of Smith-street and Hamilton-avenue, exploded, killing three men instantly, and mortally injuring another.
lead_paragraph: EXPLOSION IN A KEROSENE OIL FACTORY THREE LIVES LOST. At about 6 o'clock last evening, a still in the kerosine oil factory owned by D.O. KETOHAM, located at the corner of Smith-street and Hamilton-avenue, exploded, killing three men instantly, and mortally injuring another. The names of the killed are JOHN SMITH, JOHN PLANAHAN and MICHAEL FARREL. PATRICK O'HARE was injured so seriously that he cannot recover. The men killed were engaged in experimenting with the still in the manufacture of some now kind of oil, when the still exploded, killing all the persons in the room, and entirely destroying the building in which it was located. O'HARE, as the explosion occurred, was entering the premises to obtain his coat. When restored to consciousness, he inquired for the other persons employed in the building, and when told they were all dead, he exclaimed that they were better off than himself. SMITH leaves a wife, who resides on Hamilton-avenue, near Smith-street. FLANAHAN leaves a widow and children, who reside on Centre-street; and FARRELL leaves a widow and children, who reside on President-street. O'HARE resides on Hamilton-avenue, near the bridge. No explanation as to the cause of the explosion can be given. JOHN COOK, foreman of the establishment, was absent at the time of the explosion. The still was of the capacity of 2,000 gallons, and the explosion, as may well be supposed, was heard at a great distance. The damage to the premises is estimated at $1,500.

abstract: The  letter in another column, from the officers of the Flambeau, must set at rest sundry charges impeaching the loyalty and energy of Lieut. TEMPLE, ...
lead_paragraph: The letter in another column, from the officers of the Flambeau, must set at rest sundry charges impeaching the loyalty and energy of Lieut. TEMPLE, who, during the Winter, commanded that vessel on the Nassau station. We are assured that the delicate duties imposed upon the Lieutenant were fulfilled with rare intelligence and the utmost activity; and were effective in withholding from the rebels a vast quantity of war material. The Navy Department has acknowledged the value of Lieut. TEMPLE's services, not only in express terms of eulogy, but by placing him in charge of ordnance at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, a position heretofore intrusted to no one below the dignity of Commodore.

abstract: Two dispatches from Gen. WOOL to Secretary STANTON, received late last night, announce that the rebel steamer Merrimac, accompanied by several gunboats and tugs, made her appearance between Newport's News and Sewall's Point yesterday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: Two dispatches from Gen. WOOL to Secretary STANTON, received late last night, announce that the rebel steamer Merrimac, accompanied by several gunboats and tugs, made her appearance between Newport's News and Sewall's Point yesterday afternoon. The only damage done by them, however, was the capture of three small vessels, one of which was loaded with coal and one empty. The Merrimac proceeded a short distance oward the Monitor and the Stevens, (Naugatuck,) and four shots were fired from the latter and one from the Merrimac, when the rebel vessels all returned to Craney Island. Gen. WOOL's latest dispatch is dated 5 o'clock P.M. yesterday.

abstract: It is impossible to overrate the importance of the lesson contained in the incidents of the late sea-fight between the Federal and Confederate squadrons. In this unexpected and unparalleled engagement we get the first real glimpse of a new system of naval warfare, and it will be our own fault if we do not profit by the instruction afforded. It is clear, however, that neither the Merrimac nor the Monitor can be exactly measured against our own productions. It does not appear, for instance, that either of these vessels could put to sea, or venture far from land, whereas our own Warrior, as will have been seen from Capt. COCHRANK's report in our impression of yesterday, is fit for active service in any part of the world. Still there are points of great interest involved in the comparison. Both the American vessels have sloping sides, or if the Monitor's sides are not set at an angle they are so low as to offer little mark for shot. The Americans, therefore, seem to rely upon the protection obtained by this expedient, whereas we have not yet adopted it, and, indeed, the "Iron Plate Committee" of the Institution of Naval Architects have just declared their conclusion, that "angulated sides possess no real advantage as compared with the usual upright sides." Yet one objection which was urged against sloping sides has not been supported by the experience of the late action. It was plausibly said that a ship acting like a ram might run over one of these low vessels with the greatest ease; but the Merrimac did strike the Monitor without any such result. Another notable point is suggested by the armaments of the two vessels. The Monitor had two guns only, but each of these guns was nearly twice as large as one of the Merrimac's, and they were worked from a "turret." If, therefore, two guns proved a match for twelve, it must have been owing either to their calibre, or to the new method of working them. One conclusion, however, admits of no doubt whatever, and it happens to be the most important of all. There is an end of wooden ships for ever, and the Americans are now recognizing the fact to some purpose. In addition to what they have lavished on iron-clad vessels during the last twelve months they are now preparing to to vote $26,000,000, or upwards of 5,000,000l., more, for structures of the same class, 'and' will probably spend on this object, without stint or scruple, in the course of a year or two, a sum which no British Minister would venture to demand. Let us hope that we may turn their teaching to good account, and match them in the efficiency, if not in the expensiveness, of our proceedings.

abstract: George W. Platt vs Andrew V. Stout. This was an action by the plaintiff as assignee of Nathan C. Platt, late Chamberlain of the City, to recover $2,000 alleged to have been received by the defendant as foes while contesting his right to the office of Chamberlain, and in which contest the plaintiff's assignor was succesful. It was alleged in the complaint that...
lead_paragraph: George W. Platt vs Andrew V. Stout. This was an action by the plaintiff as assignee of Nathan C. Platt, late Chamberlain of the City, to recover $2,000 alleged to have been received by the defendant as foes while contesting his right to the office of Chamberlain, and in which contest the plaintiff's assignor was succesful. It was alleged in the complaint that subsequent to Mr. Platt's appointment as Chamberlain, and before he took possession of the office, Mr. Stout received $200,000 of the State tax, paying over to the State Treasurer all but $2,000, which he retained as fees, and which it is claimed, of right, belonged to Mr. Platt, by reason of his appointment. The matter was before the Court on a demurrer to the complaint, the defendant contending that it did not state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action. The Court now gave judgment for the plaintiff on the demurrer with costs, and ordered that that judgment be given for the plaintiff on the merits, unless the defendant pay the costs of demurrer and put in an answer within twenty days.

lead_paragraph: Mr. CYRUS W. FIELD has returned home in the Asia His mission to Europe, as is well known, had reference to the resuscitation of the Atlantic Telegraph. We understand that Mr. FIELD -- after having been in intimate communication with many of the leading men of England, including not only the members of the present Government, but prominent men of all parties, and having also had interviews with some influential parties in Paris -- draws the most favorable conclusions for the ultimate success of the enterprise, and is satisfied that it is in a fair way for early solution. abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill to increase the duty on salt having been reported, a motion was made to recommit it, with instructions to the Committee to sit during the recess, to consider wheather it is possible to enact a law to increase the revenue from salt.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill to increase the duty on salt having been reported, a motion was made to recommit it, with instructions to the Committee to sit during the recess, to consider wheather it is possible to enact a law to increase the revenue from salt. This motion was carried, after some debate. A number of bills from the Assembly were reported favorably -- among them the one to reorganize the Militia of the State, and the one to incorporate an Association in this City for the education and maintenance of the children of volunteers. The bill for the completion of the Chenango Canal was made the special order for last evening. The Congressional District bill was reported complete, and ordered to a third reading. Among the bills passed was one to impose a tax on dogs, the one to provide for permanent water in Brooklyn, the one to provide for the payment of bonds issued in this City, and the Annual Appropriation bill. The Metropolitan Health bill then came up again, the question being as to the mode of reference. It was finally referred to the Committee on Internal Affairs, 15 to 11.

This was an action to recover the sum of $6,000 damages for injuries al leged to have been sustained by the plaintiff through the negligence of the defendants. The defendants run a line of ferryboats between Staten Island and the dock at the foot of Whitehall-street, in this City.
lead_paragraph: Henry W. Hicks, Jr., vs. The Staten Island and New-York Ferry Company. This was an action to recover the sum of $6,000 damages for injuries al leged to have been sustained by the plaintiff through the negligence of the defendants. The defendants run a line of ferryboats between Staten Island and the dock at the foot of Whitehall-street, in this City. The plaintiff alleged that about 6 o'clock in the afternoon of a day in November, 1859, he paid his fare of six cents to the agent of the company at the ferry-house on this side, and proceeded to go on board the ferryboat Josephine, which was then lying at the dock; that the prow of the Josephine was very sharp, and did not fill up the space at the dock, and, by reason that the defendants had neglected to place lights at the right side of the dock, and that the Josephine was then on the left, the plaintiff stepped from the dock into the water, and was thereby greatly injured.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, introduced his bill amendatory of the Fugltive Slave Law, published in the TIMES a day or two ago. A resolution was adopted instructing the Military Committee to inquire what troops have been or are being mustered into the service of the United States as Home Guards, and who refuse to go beyond the limits of their States.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, introduced his bill amendatory of the Fugltive Slave Law, published in the TIMES a day or two ago. A resolution was adopted instructing the Military Committee to inquire what troops have been or are being mustered into the service of the United States as Home Guards, and who refuse to go beyond the limits of their States. The bill to remove all disabilities of color in carrying the mails was passed, 24 to 11. The Confiscation bill was then taken up and debated until the Senate went into Executive session. The adjournment was until Monday.

abstract: The bill providing for the emancipation of the District slaves passed the House of Representatives yesterday. Itlacks, therefore, nothing but the approval of the President to become law. The disposition of Mr. LINCOLN toward the measure is, howover, still a matter of doubt the friends of the bill representing him...
lead_paragraph: The bill providing for the emancipation of the District slaves passed the House of Representatives yesterday. Itlacks, therefore, nothing but the approval of the President to become law. The disposition of Mr. LINCOLN toward the measure is, howover, still a matter of doubt the friends of the bill representing him as eager to see it realized, while its enemies pretend to know that the recent articles in the National Intelligencer, opposing the act, were prompted by the President himself. The usually well-informed correspondent of the Journal of Commerce speaks with confidence of Mr. LINCOLN's determination to apply his veto. The doubt will be of short duration, as any delay will have all the injurious effects of the signature of the act, without any of its beneficent tendencies. The slaves, in other words, will have been carried bodily beyond the boundaries of the District.

abstract: Editorial reviews 1st year of war on anniversary of firing on Fort Sumter
snippet: Editorial reviews 1st year of war on anniversary of firing on Fort Sumter
lead_paragraph: The President, in issuing his noble Proclamation setting apart to-morrow as a day of National Thanksgiving, has doubtless been mindful of the significance of the date, and has fitly chosen that the anniversary of the blackest day of our National annals shall be signalized by a devout recognition and grateful remembrance of all the Providential experiences that fill the intervening twelvemonths. It is a year ago, to-day, an hour before sunrise, that the first gun was fired on Fort Sumter; a year ago, to-morrow, that its little band of heroic defenders surrendered to armed traitors. This, then, is the first anniversary of the war for the Union. We shall have enough of them in days to come -- anniversaries of triumph -- some few of defeat; of Hilton Head and Henry, and Donelson, and Roanoke Island, and Newbern, and Pea Ridge, and Pittsburgh Landing, of LYON's death and the surrender of Lexington and of Bull Run, and of glorious victories yet to be won. But none of all of them will come to us, as this first one comes, the anniversary of the attack upon Fort Sumter, of the first felon blow struck in the bad cause of secession and rebellion.
headline: {'main': 'A Year of the War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Year of the War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ing of lovers of the sports of the turf was held at the New-York Hotel last evening, with view to complete the arrangements for the coming Spring running races, Mr. FRANK MORRIS presided. It is designed to collect an extensive stud of the best running horses in the country, to attend at meetings of a week in length, to begin about the middle of June, at Philadelphia and continue at New-York and Boston. Subscriptions have already been raised for purses to the amount of about $5,000 for each city. There an already in training about thirty horses in this vicinity, Messrs. D. WELDON, KEAN RICHARDS, Col. ZEE, WARD and Col. MOORE, of Kentucky, CHEATHAM, of Tennessee, BOWIE and HALL, of Maryland, and BATHGATE, of New-York, have signified their intention to enter horses. These races an intended to take the place of the annual New-Orleans, Mobile, Nashville and Memphis running races and will afford rare sport for the lovers of the turf. It is expected that the meeting in this City will come off about the last week in June at the Fashion Course. Entries to close on the 1st of May. Mr. JOHN L. CASSADY, of Wilkes' Spirit, far the manager for this City, to whom communications to be addressed.

abstract: This Club held its second meeting last night. A platform for the party, which was offered to the Club for adoption, was, on motion of WM. L.REED, Esq., returned to the Committee to embody the plank that the Democratic Party will support the decisions of the Supreme Court of the United States.
lead_paragraph: This Club held its second meeting last night. A platform for the party, which was offered to the Club for adoption, was, on motion of WM. L.REED, Esq., returned to the Committee to embody the plank that the Democratic Party will support the decisions of the Supreme Court of the United States. JOHN S. BENSON, Esq., offered resolutions, in which it was recommended that the Democratic Party refrain from agitating the abolition question, but leave, that question to the Republicans and Abolitionists. The resolutions were opposed by Mr. REED. He was in favor of speaking and acting against the abolition measures of the Republicans, and of letting the people know where the young men of the Democratic Party stood. Mr. BENSON replied at some length, defending his resolutions. Messrs. HENDERSON and TALLENT spoke against the resolutions, and they were finally rejected, only one voting in favor of their adoption. A large number joined the Club.

abstract: -- The above Committee met last evening at the Steuben House, Nos. 291 and 293 Bowery, Mr. ANDREAS WILLMANN, the President of the organization, was in the Chair, and Mr. HENRY RICHARD, of the Twentieth Ward, was called upon to act as Secretary pro tem in the absence of Mr. WM. M. WERMERSKIRCH. After the ordinary detail business, Professor PREISSNER, of Union College, Schenectady, was presented to the Committee, and in complance with their request gave a very impressive and interesting statement of his recent experiences at Washington and in the Potomac camps. Dr. NAUMANN, the Treasurer of the head organization, and Chairman of the Executive Committee, then read the financial report for the past year, which represented a flourishing condition of affairs; and Mr. HANDSCHUG, of the Committee on By-Laws, reported a plan of business routine. Both reports were cordially accepted. Mr. HENRY RICHARD, in very eloquent and feeling terms, alluded to the death of Mr. MARTIN STRAUBINGER, of the Twentieth Ward, for many years an active and influential member of the Central Committee, and, at a late hour, the session was adjourned.

abstract: Clara A. Davenport vs. Elisha Ruckham, impleaded with tke Mayor,  c. This was an action to recover damages claimed to have been sustained by the plaintiff from falling down the steps of an area in front of the premises No. 320 Eighth-avenue, in this City.
lead_paragraph: Clara A. Davenport vs. Elisha Ruckham, impleaded with tke Mayor, &c. -- This was an action to recover damages claimed to have been sustained by the plaintiff from falling down the steps of an area in front of the premises No. 320 Eighth-avenue, in this City. The plaintiff is well known in town as the "Blind Lady," for whose benefit a book was written by William Cullen Bryant, and for whom many other literary persons have interested themselves. As alleged in the complaint, the Mayor and Commonalty, as agents of the City, neglected to maintain an iron railing and a grate around the steps leading to the basement, and that the plaintiff being nearly blind, while walking along the street fell into the area and, as alleged, was very much injured; so much so that she was unable to superintend the publication of her book, and from the delay in the publication she claims to have sustained great damage.

abstract: An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner COLLIN, at the Twenty-eighth Precinct Station-house, upon the body of JOHN B. EDWARDS, who was almost instantly killed on Thursday evening, by being run over in Canal-street, by a car of the Hudson River Railroad Company. At the time of the accident, Mr. EDWARDS was in the act of getting on an up-car with the intention of going to his residence in Yonkers. Another car was at that moment coming down on the other track, and unfortunately he was between the two. In trying to get out of the way of the down-car, he was knocked down by the one he was endeavoring to get upon and caught under the wheels of the other. His body was thus crushed and mangled in a shocking manner. He was immediately taken up by a Policeman and some citizens, placed upon a shutter, and carried to the nearest Station house. He died while on the way there. The deceased was 58 years of age, a native of Connecticut. He has left a wife and five or six children. For the last twenty years he has been the confidential book-keeper in the Methodist Book Concern in Mulberry-street. He was for many years Recording Secretary of the Methodist Missionary Society, and also Treasurer of the Methodist Tract Society. Until he removed to Yonkers, was a prominent member of the Central Methodist Episcopal Church in Seventh-avenue, and Superintendent of its Sabbath School. Throughout the Methodist persussion he was extensively known, and highly respected by all. The Coroner's Jury rendered a verdict exonerating the drivers and employes on the Hudson River Railroad from all blame. The funeral of deceased will take place this morning at 9 1/2 o'clock, from the Methodist Church in Seventh-avenue.
lead_paragraph: An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner COLLIN, at the Twenty-eighth Precinct Station-house, upon the body of JOHN B. EDWARDS, who was almost instantly killed on Thursday evening, by being run over in Canal-street, by a car of the Hudson River Railroad Company. At the time of the accident, Mr. EDWARDS was in the act of getting on an up-car with the intention of going to his residence in Yonkers. Another car was at that moment coming down on the other track, and unfortunately he was between the two. In trying to get out of the way of the down-car, he was knocked down by the one he was endeavoring to get upon and caught under the wheels of the other. His body was thus crushed and mangled in a shocking manner. He was immediately taken up by a Policeman and some citizens, placed upon a shutter, and carried to the nearest Station house. He died while on the way there. The deceased was 58 years of age, a native of Connecticut. He has left a wife and five or six children. For the last twenty years he has been the confidential book-keeper in the Methodist Book Concern in Mulberry-street. He was for many years Recording Secretary of the Methodist Missionary Society, and also Treasurer of the Methodist Tract Society. Until he removed to Yonkers, was a prominent member of the Central Methodist Episcopal Church in Seventh-avenue, and Superintendent of its Sabbath School. Throughout the Methodist persussion he was extensively known, and highly respected by all. The Coroner's Jury rendered a verdict exonerating the drivers and employes on the Hudson River Railroad from all blame. The funeral of deceased will take place this morning at 9 1/2 o'clock, from the Methodist Church in Seventh-avenue.

abstract: editorials on bill
snippet: editorials on bill
lead_paragraph: We beg the Tribune to reconsider its demand upon the Senate to substitute the Mayors of New-York and Brooklyn for the two Police Commissioners who are made members of the Board of Health by the bill now pending in the Legislature. The reason why the Police Commissioners are put on this Board is, that the execution of the details of the bill, -- the inspection of the Wards, the discovery of sources of disease, and the other duties which should now be, but are not, performed by the Health Wardens, is imposed upon the Police Department, and must be performed under the immediate supervision of the authorities of that Department if it is to be performed at all. The Mayors have nothing whatever to do with the Police, and could contribute nothing to the practical efficiency of the Health bill. We beg the Tribune not to overlook this important consideration in canvassing the merits of this bill.

abstract: editorial on Union position outside Yorktown
snippet: editorial on Union position outside Yorktown
lead_paragraph: We can well affordto take our time for the capture of this position, if it is defended, as we trust it is, by a large force. We hope all the military strength of Virginia is concentrated there. The western portion of the State has for a long time been under our full control. Gen. BANKS, with a strong column, is moving down the Shenandoah Valley, the finest part of the State, and from which the greater portions of the rebel supplies for the war have been drawn. The loss of this fertile productive region, the rebels already admit to be a great calamity. Other movements will doubtless soon threaten Richmond from the Northwest. Two columns are rapidly overrunning the State, while the great bulk of its forces is holding Yorktown in its extreme eastern section. If Gen. MCCLELLAN remains simply on the defensive, the rebels must soon abandon their position, or they will be cut off from retreat to Richmond. But we presume that our forces have already made guild headway in dislodging the enemy. After our glorious successes in the West, the capture of the rebels at Yorktown would end the rebellion, as did the capture of the British forces there end the War of the Revolution. We have steadily forced the enemy back by skilfully planned flank movements. We are now executing one on a grand scale in Virginia.

abstract: The telegraph announces the death at Newark, yesterday, of Hon. THEODORE FRELINGHUYSEN, of New-Jersey, one of the purest statesmen and most accomplished scholars of the generation of great men now rapidly disappearing from, the scene of life. Mr. F, was the cotemporary, in the American Senate, of WEBSTER, CLAY, BENTON and CALHOUN. He entered Congress in 1829, with the advent of the Jackson Administration, and participated in the able and stormy debates of the Senate on FOOTE's resolution -- the text of the great encounter between WEBSTER and HAYNE -- on the Tariff; the removal of the Indians; the recharter of the Bank of the United States; the Force bill, and the removal of the deposits. No such scene have since been witnessed in the discussions of that body in point of giant ability; and among the distinguished representative men of the old Whig Party, Mr. FRELINGHUYSEN was not the least conspicuous, for profound information and commanding personal influence, joined to an earnest philanthropy which made itself conspicuous on the Indian policy of the Government, at that time one of the leading topics of the day. He enjoyed, in a very eminent degree, the confidence of the great Kentucky Statesman, then, as afterward, the acknowledged leader of the party; and nine years after his retirement from the Senate, was nominated for Vice-President of the United States, with Mr. CLAY for President, by the Whig Convention at Baltimore, in 1844.

abstract: There is one characteristic of our people pervading them at tho South, possibly more than at the North, which accounts in some degree for what would be in many countries utterly inexplicable, viz.: That a people should so suddenly change their Government, and that to change so suddenly undertaken should, nevertheless, in so short a period be accepted so generally among them. Our people, more
lead_paragraph: There is one characteristic of our people pervading them at tho South, possibly more than at the North, which accounts in some degree for what would be in many countries utterly inexplicable, viz.: That a people should so suddenly change their Government, and that to change so suddenly undertaken should, nevertheless, in so short a period be accepted so generally among them. Our people, more than, perhaps, any other in the world, are accustomed to change. Change, in fact, is rather the rule, the custom of our lives. We are not like the people of the Old World, who have lived for centuries under the same institutions, ruled by the same classes, in whose selection the people have no choice, and dwelling, generation after generation, contentedly under the shadow of the same hills or by the side of the same stream, until the whole course of their life runs in the same direction, and their associations from childhood to the grave all wrap around the same objects, and tend to make change of any kind an object of distaste and abhorrence. Our people are a wandering people. It has become the habit of their minds to seek for new resting-places on very slight provocation. The rich fields of the West have acted as a constant stimulus upon their imagination and their hope, before which homo associations, never too closely knit, were powerless. Especially has this been so at the South, where the exhausting cultivation of the soil under slave-labor, has driven the people continually to seek fresh lands, always to make their homes but a temporary resting-place, to be at once forsaken under the incitement of some fancied richer soil, or more convenient location. So, too, In our political system. We have been accustomed to frequent change of rulers. One dynasty has gone down and another has risen in its place continually. And the people have learned to accept each, when it came, with the same feelings and submission as if it were to abide forever, and with equal readiness to yield to the requirements of the new powers which speedily took its place.

abstract: editorial on war in New Mexico
snippet: editorial on war in New Mexico
lead_paragraph: REGARD's dispatch to the Confederate War Department from the battle-field on the Tennessee, is dated on Sunday evening. he makes haste to claim a complete victory. The death of SYDNEY JOHNSTON is admitted. The dispatches to the Mobile papers are equally modest. They confidently claim an overwhelming victory -- not actually won, as our army had not yet been exterminated, but in near prospect. The night which followed, and the cooperation of BUELL, materially changed the fortunes of the next day, and the final result proved that, if victory had not been claimed in advance, it could not have been boasted of at all. Some of the secession sympathizers in Wall-street, yesterday, were yet incredulous as to the ultimate repulse of the Confederates, for no other reason than that our Generals were not so prompt to announce their positive success as BEAUREGARD, in communicating the first day's work. On this point they had only to recur to the delay of Gen. GRANT, in his official report of what was done at Fort Donelson. The glory of that achievement, it will not be forgotten, was claimed by PILLOW up to a late hour on Saturday, 15th February; yet on the night of that eventful day he and FLOYD escaped from their intrenchments with their favorite regiments, leaving poor BUCKNER to surrender his 18,000 remaining troops unconditionally the next morning.

abstract: Gen. KING, commanding a division in the Department of the Rappahannock, has issued an order to his command, directing that any soldier caught in the act of committing depredations, or with evidences of theft about his person or quarters, will be stripped of his arms and accoutrements, and sent back to Alexandria, there to be confined in the common jail, and await his trial by the civil authorities. No thief shall be permitted to accompany the division on its march, if it be in the power of the General Commanding to prevent it.

abstract: The course of lectures bu Prof. AGASSIZ, finished on Monday evening, have drawn forth such an audience as rarely gathers in NewYork. This City, as is sadly known to lecturers, is not a lecture-hearing community. There are too many world-wide interests here there is too much life and intense activity to leave people any especial interest in the usual coruscations of rhetoric which serve to dazzle the Lyceum audience.
lead_paragraph: The course of lectures bu Prof. AGASSIZ, finished on Monday evening, have drawn forth such an audience as rarely gathers in NewYork. This City, as is sadly known to lecturers, is not a lecture-hearing community. There are too many world-wide interests here there is too much life and intense activity to leave people any especial interest in the usual coruscations of rhetoric which serve to dazzle the Lyceum audience. The men of science and thought, of course, cannot usually afford to waste their time in hearing that which they can learn from books in half the time. Thus it happens that, except for some great oration, or on some remarkable occasion, the most intelligent part of New-York society rarely meets in an audience-room. Prof. AGASSIZ's course has been a notable exception to the usual experience of lecturers among us. The benches have been crowded from an early hour every evening with an excellent audience, among whom could be seen a large number of the "representative people" of New-York. It seems as if our citizens gladly took refuge from the intense excitements and the tremendous questions of the day, in a brief and abstracted contemplation of the events and conditions of the world, ages before man had entered on the scene. It was an incredible relief for an evening to escape from the sound of "secession," and Slavery, and battle, and bombardment, and hear only of coral and polyps, of radiates and molluscs, of articulates and vertebrates. For the types conveying to us incessantly the thrilling news of a vast revolution, we had exchanged "the types of animal structure;" for the various and confused "plans of campaign," we had now "the plans of creation;" for the noise, and bustle, and hurry of the day, we had in exchange the thousand ages of silence, when the slow foundations were being laid on which we now securely rest.

He captured two hundred prisoners,
lead_paragraph: Gen. MITCHELL, with his division of the National army of the Southwest, has made a somewhat unexpected movement, the immense importance of which will be at once recoginzed. The Secretary of War has received information that he, on Friday, occupied Huntsville, Ala., about ten miles southeast of the Tennessee river, almost without resistance. He captured two hundred prisoners, and what is of more importance, fifteen locomotives and a large amount of tolling stock of the Memphis and Charleston Railroad, which runs through the place. This gives us what we have been aiming at in our recent operations on the Upper Tennessee -- control of the road on which the rebels have mainly depended for the transportation of troops and supplies since their now line of defence was assumed.

abstract: It is reported that the rebels have withdrawn their forces from Northwestern Arkansas, and concentrating them at Pocahontas, in the northeastern part of that State. Their force at that point is represented to be 10,000. The National forces, under Gen. STEELE, are between Greenville, Mo., and the Arkansas line, prepared to meet any movement the rebels may make.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, several bills of a local character were passed. The bill for the selection of a site for another State Prison was made the special order for Tuesday. The bill to provide for the enrollment of the Militia, and the organization of the American Guard, was ordered to a third  reading . The Assembly amendments to the Con  cert Saloon bill were concurred in, and the bill goes to the Governor.

abstract: City Judge McCUNN yesterday delivered the following opinion, arising out of the case of Ireland, and Mathews arrested for selling liquor on Sunday. As the parties arrested had already been discharged upon consent of the District-Attorney, there was really nothing before the Court to adjudicate upon, but the Liquor dealers, by their counsel, have been clamoring for an optnion, and the Judge has been fit to accommodate them.

abstract: LAST. -- The public will be surprised to hear of Gen. O.M. MITCHELL at Huntsville, Alabama. He was with Gen. BUELL at Nashville, but did not accompany that officer in his march to form a junction with Gen. GRANT, on the Tennessee. He took a northeasterly course from Nashville to Murfreesboro, and thence to Shelbyville, in Bedford County, by railroad; and from there he marched in a southerly line over the turnpike to Huntsville. Huntsville is a point of very great value. It is the centreof one of the richest districts of the whole South roads converge there from all directions; and, more important still, it is situated on the Memphis and Charleston Railroad --the only railway line connecting the rebel army in the Southwest with the rebel army in Virginia. Gen. MITCHELL will now prevent any further reinforcements being sent from the East to BEAUREGARD. He obtains control of the Upper Tennessee River. The way is open for him to Chattanooga, the strongest natural position in the Southwest, where the rebels have expected to make a "desperate stand." There the railroad diverges, one line taking southward, and the other following on eastward; and Gen. MITCHELL can either push on to East Tennessee, or enter Northern Georgia and menace the South Carolina rebels in a new direction. It is impossible now for JEFF. DAVIS to move to the Southwest, as he announced ho was going to do a fortnight ago. It is impossible for his army in Virginia to escape southward either, except by long marches through the Gulf States. The movement will defeat many of the plans of the rebels, and will render their now desperate situation more desperate still. Gen. MITCHELL is a fighting man, and he commands a fighting column -- one of the best drilled and most efficient divisions in the army; and we shall soon see still more important results follow the present brilliant movement.
lead_paragraph: LAST. -- The public will be surprised to hear of Gen. O.M. MITCHELL at Huntsville, Alabama. He was with Gen. abstract: Of all the elements thrown into the war, perhaps the one which deserves the credit of meeting this rebellion in a spirit fiercer than its own, is that contributed by the personal fibre of the West. No sectional distinctions can be made in point of heroism; but, speaking here from the Atlantic, it can hardly be acknowledged too deeply with what special admiration and gratitude we of the East have watched the part borne in the great contest, by the soldiers of the free West.

abstract: GENERAL ORDER, No. 20. The Governor congratulates the members of the Eighty-fourth and One Hundred and Tenth Pennsylvania Volunteers upon their gallantry in the recent severe and brilliant action at Winchester. Their bearing upon that occasion, under the formidable attack of a bold and desperate foe, was worthy the high reputation already won by the soldiers of Pennsylvania in the memorable fields of Drainsville, Roanoke Island and Newbern.

abstract: FIRE IN SOUTH-STREET About 5  o'clock last evening the premises No. 107 South-street, near Beskman, took fire, causing considerable damage in a few minutes. The demage by water sustained by P. O'BRYAN, who occupied the basement as a hat and cap-store, amounted to $2,500, upon which there was no insurance.
lead_paragraph: FIRE IN SOUTH-STREET -- About 5 o'clock last evening the premises No. 107 South-street, near Beskman, took fire, causing considerable damage in a few minutes. The demage by water sustained by P. O'BRYAN, who occupied the basement as a hat and cap-store, amounted to $2,500, upon which there was no insurance. A portion of the first floor was occupied by PATRICK ROGERS as a clothing-store. His stock was damaged by water to the amount of $50; insured in the Market Insurance Company for $1,000. The remaining portion of the first floor and the second floor was occupied by K. COULLARD, ship-chandler, and was damaged by water to the amount of $200; insured in the Security Insurance Company. The third flour was occupied in part by WILLIAM D. MURPHY as an office; damaged to the amount of $200; no insurance. The other portion of the floor was occupied by GALLWAY and SMITH, dealers in vegetables, who sustained damage to this amount of $100; no insurance. The fourth and fifth floors were occupied by GREEN and BAKER, sail-makers who sustained damage to the amount of $100; insured. The building is owned by Messrs. [???] and was damaged to the amount of $200.

abstract: little episode of Friday was such as we were perfectly prepared for the rebel steamer having been hovering round Craney Island for the past week, ready to run out whenever fair weather and a smooth sea should offer themselves. The capture of the three vessels is
lead_paragraph: little episode of Friday was such as we were perfectly prepared for the rebel steamer having been hovering round Craney Island for the past week, ready to run out whenever fair weather and a smooth sea should offer themselves. The capture of the three vessels is small game for the mailed monster, and will only occasion a momentary provocation at the stupidity that allowed such craft to be floating around loose when it was known they were liable at any moment to be seized or sunk. The only circumstance that gives this little dash significance is that it announces definitively that the Merrimac is again completely ready for action. It is simply an interlude between the wonderful act performed five weeks ago in Hampton Roads, [???] imminent, and which, when it [???] will probably prove the final catastrophe the rebel ship. To say that we await the renewal of the action with interest is but [???] express the feeling with which it is looked forward to, not only by ourselves but by the world -- by the world as affording a solution of the greatest maritime question of the age, and by ourselves as being of closer concernment, and holding the vastest and most momentous of interests.

abstract: Huntsville, the occupation of which by our troops is above reported, is the Capital of Madison County, in Northern Alabama; and is situated ten miles north of the Tennessee River. It is a station on the Memphis and Charleston Railroad. It is a small town of four thousand inhabitants, and is exceedingly pleasantly and beautifully situated, in a fertile and rich planting country. The town is well-built and elegant, and contains a handsome brick Courthouse in the Grecian style of architecture, erected at a cost of $45,000. The other principal buildings are the Bank (which cost $80,000, constructed of brown stone, with an Ionic portico;) a female seminary, a market-house, and six churches of various Protestant denominations, two Presbyterian, a Methodist, a Baptist, an Episcopalian, etc. There are three printing offices, each issuing a weekly newspaper. There is a macadamized road to the Tennessee River, and also a navigable canal. Madison County, by the census of 1860, had a population of 26,450. The principal feature of importance in the capture of Huntsville is the fact that thereby we cut the railroad connection between the eastern and western rebel States.
lead_paragraph: Huntsville, the occupation of which by our troops is above reported, is the Capital of Madison County, in Northern Alabama; and is situated ten miles north of the Tennessee River. It is a station on the Memphis and Charleston Railroad. It is a small town of four thousand inhabitants, and is exceedingly pleasantly and beautifully situated, in a fertile and rich planting country. The town is well-built and elegant, and contains a handsome brick Courthouse in the Grecian style of architecture, erected at a cost of $45,000. The other principal buildings are the Bank (which cost $80,000, constructed of brown stone, with an Ionic portico;) a female seminary, a market-house, and six churches of various Protestant denominations, two Presbyterian, a Methodist, a Baptist, an Episcopalian, etc. There are three printing offices, each issuing a weekly newspaper. There is a macadamized road to the Tennessee River, and also a navigable canal. Madison County, by the census of 1860, had a population of 26,450. The principal feature of importance in the capture of Huntsville is the fact that thereby we cut the railroad connection between the eastern and western rebel States.

He called upon Lieut.-Col. HERRON, at Van Buren, and stated during the interview that, on returning to the rebel army, he had resumed his place on PRICE'S Staff, but
lead_paragraph: Col. EDWARD W. SHANDS, the fact of whose arrest by Gen. PRENTISS, his release on parole in this city, his forfeiture of the parole, confinement in the McDowell College prison, and escape from thence, are of comparatively recent occurrence, was in the battle of Pea Ridge. He called upon Lieut.-Col. HERRON, at Van Buren, and stated during the interview that, on returning to the rebel army, he had resumed his place on PRICE'S Staff, but on the day before the battle he was assigned to the Staff of Gen. VAN DORN. SHANDS was in an exultant mood over his escape from St. Louis, but did not tell how he contrived to get free. Capt. MCKOWN, of Western Missouri, who also escaped from McDowell's College, was present at the interview. He was more communicative than SHANDS on the subject of his flight, and acknowledged that he had blacked his face and slipped past the prison guard in the guise of one of the negroes kept at the college for the purpose of handling coal and making fires for the prisoners.

abstract: The measure proposed in the Chamber of Commerce, on the 3d inst., by Mr. S.B. RUGGLES, late Canal Commissioner, for enlarging the locks of our State canals to a size sufficient to pass war vessels adequate to the defence of the lakes, seems to have met the approbation of the Legislature. The bill suggested by the Committee of the Chamber was promptly introduced by Senator SMITH, Chairman of the Military Committee, and favorably reported without delay by the Standing Committee on Canals. Their Report will be found in another column. It is of more than usual interest, as clearly and succinctly stating the merits of the measure, both in its military and commercial aspects.

abstract: -- Col. Jonas P. Holliday, of the First Vermont Volunteer Cavalry, who lately committed suicide on the banks of the Shenandoah, near Edenburg, was born in Central New-York, was graduated at West Point in 1851, when he took a high position, and those who knew him bear warm testimony to his excellent qualities as a man and as a soldier. He was 35 years of age, and gave promise of prominence and usefulness. He was only a short time connected with the First Vermont Cavalry, but had gained a firm hold upon the hearts of officers and soldiers, and was held in the universal regard and respect of the whole regiment, who mourn the loss of a man whose place they fear will not be easily filled.
lead_paragraph: -- Col. Jonas P. abstract: The public will hear with amazement that Mayor OPDYKE visited Albany on Saturday to resist the passage of the HEALTH BILL. The ground of his opposition, and the sole ground thus far disclosed, is that the Mayor of the City is not made a member of the Board of Health which it creates. This omission he considers disparaging to the office and to himself, and an infringement of the right of the City to provide for its own government. The Mayor confined himself to proposing that the Mayors of New-York and Brooklyn be substituted on the Board for the two Police Commissioners. But DAVID DUDLEY FIELD, Esq., who also appeared in aid of the Mayor, did not hesitate to say that, unless this amendment could be made, the bill ought to be defeated.
lead_paragraph: The public will hear with amazement that Mayor OPDYKE visited Albany on Saturday to resist the passage of the HEALTH BILL. The ground of his opposition, and the sole ground thus far disclosed, is that the Mayor of the City is not made a member of the Board of Health which it creates. This omission he considers disparaging to the office and to himself, and an infringement of the right of the City to provide for its own government. The Mayor confined himself to proposing that the Mayors of New-York and Brooklyn be substituted on the Board for the two Police Commissioners. But DAVID DUDLEY FIELD, Esq., who also appeared in aid of the Mayor, did not hesitate to say that, unless this amendment could be made, the bill ought to be defeated.

abstract: The iron-clad steamer Galena, which has been expected at the Brooklyn Navy-yard for several days past, has not yet arrived. The Galena is one of the three iron-clad vessels contracted for by the Secretary of the Navy under authority of the act of Congress approved Aug. 3, 1861. The other two are the Monitor and Kensington. Of the Monitor it is not necessary to say more than that the public are by this time pretty well acquainted with her. The Galens has also been described several times, but the following particulars will bear repetition. She was designed by Mr. JULIUS PATTERSON, and constructed at Mystic, Conn., by Messrs. MAXON, FISH & Co., the builders of the gunboat Owasco, now in active service. Naval Constructor ROOK was charged with the general superintendence of the work. As soon as possible after being launched, in February, she was sent to the Continental Iron Works, at Greenpoint, L.I., to receive her armor, which consists of iron plates, 29 feet long, 4 inches wide, and 3 1/2 inches thick, overlapping each other, and extending 4 feet below the water-line. Her dimensions are, length over all, 208 feel; breadth of beam, 36 feet; depth of hold, 12 1/2 feet; burden 1,000 tons. She is not at all like the Monitor, being simply an iron-plated screw steamer of great strength, and modeled with a view to speed. She is pierced for 18 guns, but will carry 6 only, viz.: 4 Dahlgren and 2 Parrott guns. Her rigging is made of copper wire.

abstract: The tardy action of Congress upon the important subject of a General Bankrupt Law occasions surprise. The fact is perhaps owing in some degree to the silence of the Press; and that has in turn been owing to the almost universal understanding that Congress had fully admitted the necessity and expediency of the measure, and that the only delay would be caused by the caution and care essential to the preparation of an act so important. These impressions would seem to be incorrect. The subject has been permitted to sleep until the session has passed its meridian; and the bill has not yet been called up for discussion in either House.
lead_paragraph: The tardy action of Congress upon the important subject of a General Bankrupt Law occasions surprise. abstract: It is an interesting fact that in the Revolutionary siege of Yorktown, WASHINGTON had no Southern troops. His force, numbering about twenty thousand men, consisted chiefly of New-York, New-Jersey, Pennsylvania and New-England regiments. Soldiers from the self-same region are now before Yorktown, prepared to battle for the maintenance of that independence and unity which their Northern forefathers won on that memorable historic ground.

abstract: BEAUREGARD is dead! So says a report which we publish this morning. Gen. BANKS telegraphed to Secretary STANTON, yesterday, that he had received this report direct from rebel sources, near Mount Jackson, the locality of JACKSON's camp. If the report is true, he must have been killed during the second day's fight at Pittsburgh Landing. It will be recollected that some of the earlier dispatches announced that he had his left arm shot off, and the story has thus a color of probability.

abstract: Editorial says Arkansas is open to occupation by Union
snippet: Editorial says Arkansas is open to occupation by Union
lead_paragraph: If the statement be correct that PRICE and VAN DORN, with their rebel troops, took part in the battle at Pittsburgh, then Arkansas must be nearly cleared of rebel soldiers, and the State is open for the march of our army to its capital. The whole of the troops of Arkansas, with the exception of those in Virginia and in Tennessee, were concentrated under the two leaders named, at the battle of Pea Ridge, and the rebel newspapers had already announced that they were all ordered for the defence of Memphis; so that the statement of their being present at the great battle is not at all unlikely. There have been rumors of the existence of small bodies of rebels at Pocahontas and Jacksonport, an the Big Black river, in the northeastern part of Arkansas; but the probability is that these are only detachments of the Home Guard or local militia. In no other part of the State are there any rebel troops, excepting a small body who are fortifying at Napoleon, at the mouth of the Arkansas river, and the garrison at Fort Smith, five hundred miles up the same stream, and perhaps the savages of the renegade PIKE and of MCINTOSH -- all these bodies being small, detached, widely scattered, and utterly ineffective against a brigade of National troops and a gunboat.

abstract: day observed, NYC churches
snippet: day observed, NYC churches
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, in accordance with the President's proclamation, prayers were offered in the various churches in this City, Brooklyn and Jersey City, and thanks given for our recent victories. The day was generally observed, many ministers selecting texts suitable to the occasion. Yet the gratitude for our successes was tempered with sadness on account of the many brave and gallant soldiers that have fallen. We give below notices of the sermons in some of the churches.

abstract: Editorial holds Southern States indefensible
snippet: Editorial holds Southern States indefensible
lead_paragraph: In spite of our best efforts we cannot teach Englishmen geography. The London Times admits that we have gained some successes; but these, it tells us, are upon the exterior lines of the rebel States; and it then goes on to describe the vast and inhospitable wastes and pestiferous swamps to be traversed by our troops -- swamps whose misasmatic vapors will be fatal to them, to say nothing of the impossibility of dragging over them heavy ordnance and trains of supplies. The end is as far off as ever, according to this journal. But the facts are exactly opposed to the arguments and conclusions it draws. There is no country in the world so indefensible as the Southern States, and so easily overrun, taking into consideration the fact that the inhabitants of the mountain districts are, a great majority of them, still loyal to the Union. The greater portion of the Southern States is an open, champaign country, and traversed in any direction by navigable rivers. The battle near Corinth, was fought, the first day at least, under the cover of our steamboats, which had transported our troops to the battle-field hundreds of miles within rebel territory, and rendered them efficient support when assailed. We are not compelled to traverse extensive districts by land to reach the rebel forces; but, having command of the watercourses, or being able to gain command of them by means of our formidable gunboats, to which the rebels can oppose resistance neither by land nor water, the whole country, in fact, lies at our mercy. It requires some time for preparation; but when this is complete, our forces move forward into the heart of the enemy's territory, on vast flotillas, which transports them, with whatever is necessary for active operations in the field. With the command of the Cumberland River, which was secured by the fall of Fort Donelson, the whole of Central Tennessee submitted to our arms without the loss of a man. The army fell back to another line of defence, approachable by the Tennessee River, which enabled us, with the greatest ease, to collect 80,000 men within a day's march of his stronghold. With the Mississippi River under our control, Arkansas, Mississippi and Louisiana will be incapable of any further resistance. By holding this great artery we can literally starve the people of these States into submission. They will be alike incapable of defensive or offensive operations. With the capture of a few more Southern ports we can disband the greater portion of our army, and quietly sit down to the game of endurance. The rebels will be carefully hemmed in, and it may be our wisest course to give them a little experience of entire isolation, in which they will have nothing to do but to prey upon each other. We shall take all their outlets, control all the channels of their commerce, when we can well afford to await their return to common sense, and obedience to laws. We do not desire extirpation; but as we can do very well without them, we propose to put them upon probation for good conduct, the length of which will be for them to determine. But whatever time they take, we shall all the time be growing stronger, and they the weaker.

abstract: Gen. O.M. MITCHEL, the soldier-astronomer, marshals the hosts of the Union quite as well as he has long marshaled the hosts of heaven. It is he that has just made the swoop down into Huntsville, Alabama, and performed the neat bit of surgery of "cutting the great artery" of railway communication between the Southern States. MITCHEL was undoubtedly born under Mars, and, thanks to his lucky future, is familiar with rapid movements and vast spaces. Wherever the astronomer-soldier shows himself, depend upon it he will be very sure to put the rebellion into total and permanent eclipse.

abstract: Mr. GRAU's opera season in Boston came to an end on Saturday. During the two weeks of this energetic manager's sojourn to the Tremontane city, he gave the Athenians no fewer than fourteen representations -- maintaining, at the same time, a large force of concert-giving skirmishers in the neighboring towns. The performances last week were as follows: On Monday, "La Somnambula;" on Tuesday, "Martha;" on Thursday, "La Favorita," (with D'ANGRI as Lenora;) on Friday, "The Child of the Regiment," (with KELLOGG Maria;) on Saturday. "La Favorita," (for the debut of a Boston lady, Mme. VERIAN by name;) and on Sunday a Sacred Concert. The company returns to New-York to-day, and will observe a religious fast until Monday next, when Mr. GRAU will commence a short season of a week. For this enterprise several new artists have been engaged. The return of Mr. MAX MARETSEK's company from Mexico, and of Mr. MURIO's artists from Havana, has overstocked the market, and hence there is no difficulty in the way of a prudent manager like Mr. GRAU obtaining what he wants for the limited Spring campaign contemplated. We are glad to hear that Mr. GRAU has effected an arrangement with Mr. MARETSEK for the coming season, (in September,) and that in consequence we shall have an opportunity of hearing the artists whom the latter will engage for the Tacon theatre. The importance of the combination will justify Mr. GRAU in placing the works of his repertoire before the public in a move creditable manner than was possible during the troublous times of his late essays.

abstract: William W. Shulter et al. vs. Amos F. Hatfield et al. -- This was an action by the plaintiffs, who are judgment creditors of Addison Brothers, to set aside a conveyance of real estate in this City, and certain transfers of personal property. The conveyance was made in September, 1857, from Sam'l. D. Addison, one of the firm, to Rachel Addison, his wife, of property valued at $13,000. A transfer was made, as alleged, in 1861, by Addison, as surviving partner of the firm, of a stock of goods valued at $45,000, to the defendants Hatfield and Marshall, and a certain lease claimed to have been worth $4,500, was also, as alleged, transferred from Addison to Hatfield.

abstract: The Fayetteville Observer learns from a reliable source that up to the 21st instant, Fort Macon had not been attacked, but that a Yankee regiment was at Shepardsville on the night of the 21st. Shepardsville is in Carteret county, about 14 miles from Beaufort, and 16 miles from Fort Macon. The enemy have taken possession of Swansboro', which is a small port at the end of Bogue Sound, about 50 miles from Wilmington, and had advanced to Pollockville, in Jones County. Gen. RANSOM's brigade, we learn, is looking after them. Of the strength of our force in that section we say nothing; it is, however, believed to be ample.
lead_paragraph: The Fayetteville Observer learns from a reliable source that up to the 21st instant, Fort Macon had not been attacked, but that a Yankee regiment was at Shepardsville on the night of the 21st. Shepardsville is in Carteret county, about 14 miles from Beaufort, and 16 miles from Fort Macon. The enemy have taken possession of Swansboro', which is a small port at the end of Bogue Sound, about 50 miles from Wilmington, and had advanced to Pollockville, in Jones County. Gen. RANSOM's brigade, we learn, is looking after them. Of the strength of our force in that section we say nothing; it is, however, believed to be ample.

abstract: The bill manumitting the slaves in the District of Columbia reached the President yesterday. If it is to become a law, it will, no doubt, be returned with approval to-day; while its retention will justify a belief that it is to go back to the other end of the avenue with a veto in company. Those who are best acquainted with the views of the President, give confident assurances of the executive sanction; asserting that Mr. LINCOLN's approbation would have been cordial had the measure been a little less hasty and radical, but that he does not care to take the responsibility of vetoing an act of Congress on other than constitutional grounds.

abstract: Gen. MITCHEL is rendering a good account of himself at Huntsville, Ala. On Saturday, the day after his occupation of the place, he sent out two expeditions -- one east on the railroad to Stevens, the junction of the Chattanooga with the Memphis and Charleston Railroad, and the other west to Decatur, at which place it arrived just in time to save the railroad bridge there, which had been set on fire. Two thousand of the enemy at Stevens retreated without firing a gun, and five locomotives and a large amount of rolling stock were captured there. Gen. MITCHEL now holds one hundred miles of the Memphis and Charleston Railroad.

abstract: was passed by a unanimous vote on Saturday, and the Senate concurred at once with the House amendments, so that it only needs Gov. MORGAN's name to make it a law. It has not been changed since its publication in the TIMES, with the exception of a single word. The public pests of our thoroughfares will disappear instantly; for the penalties are too formidable, and the counsel of the House of Refuge too vigilant to admit of trifling with its provisions. Its effect will be to purge our places of public amusement of most of their evils, and to make respectable and popular those that are properly conducted. Few laws have been enacted with more palpable beneficence in their aim, or reflecting more honor on all parties concerned in their passage. Senator ROBERTSON. Judge PRINGLE, and others that might be named, are justly entitled to the public approbation for their disinterested care of this bill. And the Grand Jury, Mr. WINTHROP, foreman, whose presentment furnished the basis of intelligent legislative notion, performed a noteworthy service.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Norwegian at Portland, last night, we receive advices from Europe, five days later than previously received. Two brigs, the Adelaide and the Mary Wright, had arrived at Liverpool, having run the blockade at Charleston, on the 3d of March. They carried over about 1,400 bales of cotton, and a quantity of tobacco and resin. They reported that the fleet of stone vessels sunk across the harbor was fast breaking up. The proceedings of the British Parliament had been of no special importance. The subject of iron-clad vessels was attracting much attention, and the London Times understands that orders had been transmitted to all the British dockyards to stop operations on all wooden ships. The improvements being made in projectiles in this country were also beginning to attract attention. The Liverpool Cotton Market is reported to be without material change.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition 700 feet long, signed by 15,000 women, praying for the abolition of Slavery, was presented by Mr. SUMNER. Petitions in reference to a bankrupt law, and to taxation were also presented. The resolution of inquiry as to whether further legislation is necessary to enforce the article of war for preventing the reclamation of fugitive slaves within the lines of the army, was taken up, and Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa, made a speech, in which he cited several cases in which the article in question had been violated. The confiscation bill was then considered, and Mr. HARRIS, of New-York, made a speech advocating the principle of confiscating, with certain restrictions. After an executive session, the Senate adjourned. During the proceedings Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, tendered his resignation as Chairman of the Naval Committee.

abstract: Freeman Campbell et al vs. Francis Price. -- This was an action to recover for work, labor and services, and for materials furnished in building two blocks in the North River, on the west bank, in New-Jersey, near Weehawken. The defence set up was that the plaintiffs agreed to construct the buildings according to certain plans and specifications, and agreed to make a foundation in a certain manner, which they had failed to do. The answer also set up a counter-claim for $1,500, for alleged damages sustained by the defendant by reason of the failure of the plaintiffs to perform their part of the contract. Plaintiffs' reply contained merely a general denial of the counter-claim. Case still on.
