abstract: -- Congress has laid the General Bankrupt act over until the Winter Session. Republics are, it seems, merciless as well as ungrateful. One-half the commercial community was ruined by the war; the other half has furnished all the moans the Government has had to defend and sustain itself. Both halves have demanded of Government this law. In refusing it, Congress has been pitiless to the one, and thankless to the other.

abstract: The death of the rebel General, SIDNEY JOHNSTON, at the battle of Pittsburgh, is now definitely settled; and the rebels grievously mourn the loss of their distinguished commander. He had previously been under a cloud on account of his want of success in Kentucky and Tennessee; but he vindicated both his courage and skill, as well as the sincerity of his treason, on the fatal Sunday upon which he fell; and though that affair, like all his previous efforts in this war, was a failure, yet rebel criticism is silent in presence of his death. It was undoubtedly he, and not BEAUREGARD, who conceived and managed the brilliant rebel maunoeuvering of Sunday, by which the rebel columns were shifted with such rapidity, and hurled now upon one of our wings, then upon the other, then upon the centre, then upon some apparently weak point, and everywhere with a spirit and dash that could not be excelled. The tactics were all characteristic of JOHNSTON. He exposed his person, too, with recklessness. It is probable indeed that he had been driven to desperation by the assaults that have recently been made upon him, and that in despondency and misery, he courted death upon the field. It is a sad ending to a career which had for so long time been eminent and honorable.
lead_paragraph: The death of the rebel General, SIDNEY JOHNSTON, at the battle of Pittsburgh, is now definitely settled; and the rebels grievously mourn the loss of their distinguished commander. It was undoubtedly he, and not BEAUREGARD, who conceived and managed the brilliant rebel maunoeuvering of Sunday, by which the rebel columns were shifted with such rapidity, and hurled now upon one of our wings, then upon the other, then upon the centre, then upon some apparently weak point, and everywhere with a spirit and dash that could not be excelled. The tactics were all characteristic of JOHNSTON. He exposed his person, too, with recklessness. It is probable indeed that he had been driven to desperation by the assaults that have recently been made upon him, and that in despondency and misery, he courted death upon the field. It is a sad ending to a career which had for so long time been eminent and honorable.

abstract: Our readers may be supposed to have "learned and marked" -- though none of them can "inwardly digest" -- the monstrous dictum of our City Judge on the Sunday Liquor traffic, and the authority of the Police to restrain it. It would be as easy to digest the lightning whisky dealt out by Sunday publicans, as to bolt the adulterated law enunciated for their protection in wrong-doing. We have no intention of reviewing an opinion too sophistical to mislead the plainest intellect, given under circumstances which convict its author of sympathy with offenders against the most wholesome laws, and as acting in the interest of conspirators against the administration of justice, and the morals and good order of society. Indeed, were it not evident that a plot has been laid, to which some of the Police Justices are parties, by which this opinion is made to cover their refusal to entertain complaints against liquor-sellers on Sunday, we should leave the case without comment. Justice CONNOLLY began this game yesterday, to be followed up, we suppose, by all the Justices who owe their office to the liquor-dealers.
lead_paragraph: Our readers may be supposed to have "learned and marked" -- though none of them can "inwardly digest" -- the monstrous dictum of our City Judge on the Sunday Liquor traffic, and the authority of the Police to restrain it. abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a number of bills were reported favorably. Among them the one providing for licensing ballast-lighters in the port of New-York; and the one extending the time for the completion of the Erie and New-York City Railroad. The bill to amend the law relative to taking testimony out of the State was passed. The bill to provide for the Collection of Agricultural Statistics in the State was ordered to a third reading; also the bill for the prevention of burglaries and other crimes. The bill for the enlargement of the Champlain Canal locks and the Erie Canal was debated, and progress reported.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a number of bills were reported favorably. Among them the one providing for licensing ballast-lighters in the port of New-York; and the one extending the time for the completion of the Erie and New-York City Railroad. The bill to amend the law relative to taking testimony out of the State was passed. The bill to provide for the Collection of Agricultural Statistics in the State was ordered to a third reading; also the bill for the prevention of burglaries and other crimes. The bill for the enlargement of the Champlain Canal locks and the Erie Canal was debated, and progress reported.

abstract: The thirty-seventh annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design opened, yesterday, at the new rooms of the Dusseldorf Gallery, No. 625 Broadway. The collection is placed in three apartment, two of which aro good; the third is without daylight, and is meanly illuminated by a series of upright jets (excellent for throwing a good light on the ceiling) from a gaspipe that surrounds the room....
lead_paragraph: The thirty-seventh annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design opened, yesterday, at the new rooms of the Dusseldorf Gallery, No. 625 Broadway. The collection is placed in three apartment, two of which aro good; the third is without daylight, and is meanly illuminated by a series of upright jets (excellent for throwing a good light on the ceiling) from a gaspipe that surrounds the room. Unthe Academicians posses their own building, difficulties more or less grave must always prevail concerning the place in which they hold their annual exhibition. They are fortunate this year in having a really elegant gallery. In stretching its capacity to the utmost, however, they have not been careful to make the few additional arrangements that were requisite in view of the crush. Room No. 3, to which we have referred, contains some excellent pictures, and merits at least sufficient battens to thrown the light properly, and also an arrangement by which the heat arising from the constant use of gas might in some way be obviated.

abstract: Editorial on flank movements in West in past week
snippet: Editorial on flank movements in West in past week
lead_paragraph: The past week has given the rebellion the most damaging blow it has yet received. The grand line of communication between the two extremes of the rebel States has, for the first time, been cut, and their two great armies isolated from and rendered incapable of supporting each other, defeat in either field of operations must be fatal to the army engaged, and so far to the cause. With our success or defeat in either, our Government would still be enabled to consolidate overwhelming forces upon any point menaced, or to be attacked. So that, in a strategic point of view, the capture of Huntsville must be decisive of the contest in the Southwest. The line of railroad we have severed was not only necessary for the maintenance of the rebel communications, but for feeding their army. In the Southwest we had completely driven them out of the food-producing districts. With the line of the Memphis and Charleston Railroad in their hands, they still had the best portion of Tennessee and Virginia for supplies of beef and grains. We have, by this success, dealt a more fatal blow at the commissariat of the enemy than at his forces in the field, because an army can be kept together only so long as it can be fed, and well fed. By simply maintaining our present positions, we can starve them into submission.

abstract: Editorial on Hunter orders for sanitary precautions in Port Royal to guard against yellow fever
snippet: Editorial on Hunter orders for sanitary precautions in Port Royal to guard against yellow fever
lead_paragraph: Gen. HUNTER's first care on assuming command of the Department of the South, is to provide in advance against the worst foe his troops will have to encounter -- namely: the hostile climatic influences of those Southern latitudes. In his admirable General Order No. 5, (published in another column,) he lays down such sanitary precautions as must be observed by the soldiers in his Department during the hot Summer months. They are sensible and practical in the highest degree, and, if rigidly enforced, will enable our men successfully to withstand the malign principalities and powers of the Southern air. Though each direction is simply a necessary precautionagainst some inimical element, several of them produce a rather odd impression, contrasted with the reckless ways on troops are able to indulge in in our healthier upper latitudes. Thus they are to be sure "not to rise till half an hour after sunrise, when breakfast will be ready for the men as soon as they leave their tents," they are to receive, during the hot hours of the day, "quinine in prophylactic doses, each dose combined with half a gill of whisky;" the importance of "good cooking" is insisted on with a gusto that would have warmed the heart of a Soyer or a Francatelli, and "fishing during the cool hours of the morning and evening -- not later than 9 A.M. in the morning, and not earlier than 6 P.M. in the evening "-- is commended as at once a pleasing mental pastime and a source of provender for the culinary department. The General justly observes that, "with proper care exercised, and certain simple rules of hygiene observed, the hardy soldiers of the Union, inured to toil and fortified by habits of industry, temperance and cleanliness, have nothing to fear from the climate of the Department in which it is their privilege to serve;" and when he instances in proof the fact that, during our war with Mexico, the soldiers of New-England, the Northwestern and Middle States, suffered far less from the diseases incident to a semi-tropical climate than the soldiers from the Southernand Gulf States, he is completely borne out by established sanitary statistics.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- A grand dramatic and musical entertainment will take place here to-night in aid of a fund for the widow and orphan of the late THOS. J. MORGAN, who was killed while in the discharge of his duty as a New-York fireman. The pieces "Still Waters Run Deep," and "Robert Macaire" will be performed, and Miss MAGGIE HAIGHT, Miss HALLOCK and Mr. CHARLES LOCKWOOD will furnish a musical intermezzo. The benevolent object of the entertainment commends it to the attention of the amusement-going public.

abstract: Our City Judge had an  opinion which he has seen fit to make public. In these circumstances, the weight to be given to this ex-parte warrant for illicit Sunday ...
lead_paragraph: Our City Judge had an opinion which he has seen fit to make public. It purports to be a legal opinion, the drawback being that there was no case before him for adjudication, and that there is neither law nor common sense in his utterances. In these circumstances, the weight to be given to this ex-parte warrant for illicit Sunday dram-selling is just that attaching to the personal and professional character of its author. Its official value is as little as would be the opinion on military discipline of a militia Colonel cashiered for profanity and unofficer-like conduct: no more.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa, introduced a bill prescribing the qualifications of electors in the City of Washington, which was laid over. The House bill for the establishment of a Branch Mint at Denver, Colorado Territory, was reported from the Finance Committee, without amendment. Mr. MCDOUGAL, of California, called up the resolution, calling upon the Secretary of War for information relative to the arrest of Gen. STONE, and made a long speech in vindication of that officer, in the course of which he censured the course of the Committee on the Conduct of the War, which called up Mr. WADE, of Ohio, who replied in defence of the Committee. The resolution finally went over until to-day, Mr. MCDOUGAL desiring to speak further on the subject. The Senate soon afterward went into Executive session.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa, introduced a bill prescribing the qualifications of electors in the City of Washington, which was laid over. The resolution finally went over until to-day, Mr. MCDOUGAL desiring to speak further on the subject. The Senate soon afterward went into Executive session.

abstract: Editorial discusses Confederate Army strength
snippet: Editorial discusses Confederate Army strength
lead_paragraph: Certain journals, having this in common, that so long as the thing was at all safe and profitable they adhered to the fortunes of the rebels, concur in the opinion that the insurgent Government will shortly have in the field an army three-fourths of a million strong. They found this figure upon data purely conjectural. Quite unadvised of the positions occupied by the forces of the enemy, or of his strength at any of his positions, they place him at random wherever there is the slightest chance of his being; and arrange the numbers to suit themselves. The result might as well be ten millions as a fraction of one:

abstract: The reduction of Fort Pulaski has been accomplished, and that old National stronghold is once more in possession of the Government. This gratifying news is obtained from the rebels themselves, by way of Fortress Monroe. The Fort was surrendered at 2 o'clock P.M. on Friday last, the 11th inst., after a bombardment continuing only a few hours, but during which, according to the Savannah Republican, seven large breaches were made in the south wall by a National batteryof eight Parrott guns, stationed at King's Landing, which fired conical balls of such a formidable character that the work, notwithstanding its great strength, offered very little resistance to them. All the barbette guns on that side were dismounted, and three of the casemate guns, leaving but one gun bearing on our battery; and three balls entered the rebel magazine, making a clean breach in it. Beside all this, over one thousand shells were exploded inside the fort, and Col. OLMSTEAD, who was in command there, telegraphed that no human being could stand upon the ramparts for even a single moment, so terrible was our fire. The losses on either side were very slight. It is understood that we had no men killed, while the rebels had but four wounded. The surrender was, of course, unconditional.

abstract: The United States transport Jersey Blue, Capt. JACKSON, arrived yesterday from Newbern, whence she sailed on the 11th, leaving Hatteras Inlet on the 13th. There had been nothing new at Newbern. Preparations were being made for the siege of Fort Macon -- getting heavy guns into position, &c. The bridge over the River Neuse had been finished. The transport Albany would sail for New-York on the 12th, with two hundred and fifty Confederate prisoners, taken at Newbern. The health of the troops continued good, and but few eases of fever and ague had been known. The transport Thomas Sparks had just arrived at Hatteras. There had been no new arrivals at Newbern. The Jersey Blue has the following passengers:

abstract: Mr. GRAU's new reason of opera will commence on Monday evening next. It promises to be one of the best yet given under that energetic and enterprising gentleman's management. Mr. GRAU has succeeded in affecting an engagement with Signora AEELAIDE BASSEGGIO, the successful and highly-praised dramatic prima donna, of the Tacon (Havana) Theatre. This lady is said to possess youth, good looks and ability. Her debut will be one of the most interesting events of the season. In addition to Signora BASSEGGIO, Mr. GRAU has also secured the sevices of Signor TOMBESI, a young tenor, whose voice is described as one of the freshest and best now on the lyric stage; also, of Signor FERRI, the fine baritone, and of Signor MUZIO, chef d'orchestre. With these valuable additions to his regular corps. consisting of Miss CLARA LOUISE KELLOGG. Miss ISABELLA HINKLEY, Mme. D'ANGRI, Signor BRIGNOLI, Signor MANOUSI and Signor SUSINI, Mr. GRAU will have no difficulty in giving a series of performances thoroughly admirable in distribution. The first performance will [???] place at the Academy on Monday next, when "II Trevatore" will be given with Signora BASSEGGIO as Leonora, Mme. D'ANGARI as Azucena, Signor FERRI as the Count, and Signor BRIGNOLI as the Trovatore. On the following Wednesday "Signor TOMBESI will make his debut.

Mr. GRAU has succeeded in affecting an engagement with Signora AEELAIDE BASSEGGIO, the successful and highly-praised dramatic prima donna, of the Tacon (Havana) Theatre. This lady is said to possess youth, good looks and ability. Her debut will be one of the most interesting events of the season. In addition to Signora BASSEGGIO, Mr. GRAU has also secured the sevices of Signor TOMBESI, a young tenor, whose voice is described as one of the freshest and best now on the lyric stage; also, of Signor FERRI, the fine baritone, and of Signor MUZIO, chef d'orchestre. With these valuable additions to his regular corps. consisting of Miss CLARA LOUISE KELLOGG. Miss ISABELLA HINKLEY, Mme. D'ANGRI, Signor BRIGNOLI, Signor MANOUSI and Signor SUSINI, Mr. GRAU will have no difficulty in giving a series of performances thoroughly admirable in distribution. The first performance will [???] place at the Academy on Monday next, when "II Trevatore" will be given with Signora BASSEGGIO as Leonora, Mme. D'ANGARI as Azucena, Signor FERRI as the Count, and Signor BRIGNOLI as the Trovatore. On the following Wednesday "Signor TOMBESI will make his debut.

abstract: Editorial on Union successes in Southwest
snippet: Editorial on Union successes in Southwest
lead_paragraph: Every day that passes only serves to show the magnitude and value of the recent triumph of the Union arms in the Southwest. That holding our ground at Pittsburgh Landing was equivalent to a great victory, is shown by the success of the flank movements of the army, which would have been overwhelmed, and the troops making them captured or destroyed, had the main body suffered a repulse. But the defeat of the rebels, still menaced by a superior force, allowed General MITCHEL to move forward unopposed, and to occupy the line of their communication for an hundred miles in extent, capturing the rolling stock of their most important railroad, with a large number of prisoners, and unquestionably a large amount of munitions and stores. In a strategic point of view nothing can exceed the value of the advantage gained. The two wings of the rebel army are now fighting unsupported. The defeat of one necessarily involves that of the other.

abstract: The anniversary of the attack on Fort Sumter could not have been more fitly celebrated than it was by the capture of Fort Pulaski, by its rightful owners, from the rebels, who for sixteen months have usurped its possession. Twelve months to a day from the time the now discomfited BEAUREGARD summoned Major ANDERSON to surrender Sumter, the beleaguered garrison in Pulaski capitulated to the National force. Whether Gen. HUNTER had an eye for a bit of poetic justice in thus timing the attack, we know not, but the gratifying achievement is made doubly gratifying by presenting a conspicuous instance of historical retribution.

abstract: There seems to be no  doubt about Greytown HOLLINS figuring among the prisoners in the hands of Gen. POPE. HOLLINS is an invaluable acquisition. In the calendar of Rebellion there are heroes of first rate, and heroes of second rate classification.
lead_paragraph: -- There seems to be no doubt about Greytown HOLLINS figuring among the prisoners in the hands of Gen. POPE. HOLLINS is an invaluable acquisition. In the calendar of Rebellion there are heroes of first rate, and heroes of second rate classification. HOLLINS belonged to the former. He, with SEMMES and PEGRAM, were the naval demigods of the South; TATNALL had been beaten, and his laurels are drooping. To have secured this gallant Captain, who is only known to history for bombarding a defenceless village in time of peace, and for an unsuccessful night attack upon an unsuspecting enemy, is indeed a triumph worthy of the National arms. If it be asked, what shall we do with him? suppose he be made a powder-boy on board the Monitor, where his talents will be exercised upon a foe neither unarmed or unforewarned, and for once in the interest of his country.

abstract: A let  ter, published yesterday, from the rebel General JOHNSTON, who uses slain at the battle at Pittsburgh Landing, fully sustains the ground that we have always taken, that the number of the rebel forces have everywhere been greatly exaggerated.
lead_paragraph: -- A let ter, published yesterday, from the rebel General JOHNSTON, who uses slain at the battle at Pittsburgh Landing, fully sustains the ground that we have always taken, that the number of the rebel forces have everywhere been greatly exaggerated. The army collected at Bowling Green, he tells us, was purposely magnified as to numbers, the object being to avert attack and gain time for foreign interference, for the release of cotton. It is well known that the almost solo dependence of the rebels was upon such aid. Every day gained, consequently, was, in their programme, of the utmost value. The same trick was unquestionably everywhere played, with a similar object. The vast forces at Manassas, which they [???] believe numbered fully 200,000 men, have, upon a careful examination of the ground, dwindled down to some 85,000 or 40,000; or say 60,000, as the maximum at any one time. The stupendous works which the balloon disclosed never had an existence. We always felt assured that the rebels could never bring into the field the vast numbers of which their armies were said to be composed. The South cannot accomplish impossibilities, with all their ardor and devotion, and with all the advantage which they claimed for Slavery. Our people have, from the outset, greatly magnified the effective force of the enemy. We may not have lost much by doing so, as it has only served to increase the extent of our preparation, while it must have correspondingly decreased his. We have learned a lesson, too, which will not be forgotten in the future. We shall no longer take for granted what a wily and cunning foe, interested in deceiving, tells us; nor allow play to our imagination till it has multiplied three or four times every object it sees.

abstract: editorial on NY Tribune reporting on bill
snippet: editorial on NY Tribune reporting on bill
lead_paragraph: It is quite possible that the Tribune may succeed in misleading a few of its readers concerning the Health bill by personal abuse of the editor of the TIMES. The fact that it falls back upon such a method of vindicating its position, proves conclusively its intrinsic weakness. Whether the TIMES, or Mayor OPDYKE and the Tribune, have been the most "consistent and straightforward" in regard to the Health bill, is a question which future inquiry may determine; but it is one which may safely be postponed. The main question now is whether New-York City is to have any Health bill, or whether the control of its health is to be left in the hands of the political profligates and vagabonds who have controlled it hitherto; and the decision of this question rests mainly with Mayor OPDYKE and the Tribune.

abstract: editorials on lr
snippet: editorials on lr
lead_paragraph: The remarkable expose of rebel military affairs in the Southwest, made by Gen. SIDNEY JORNSTON, who was killed at the battle of Pittsburgh, throws a good deal of light upon late rebel movements and prospects in Kentucky and Tennessee. The failure of that distinguished rebel officer to hold Bowling Green -- his signal failure to defend successfully Forts Henry and Donelson, which were the keys to his Department -- his failure to defend Clarksville -- his flight from Nashville --his retreat from Murfreesboro -- his abandonment of the entire State of Kentucky and nearly the whole of Tennessee -- his decampment into Alabama -- his miserable failure everywhere, had called forth execrations upon his head from every part of rebeldom. He was hooted at by the Tennessee rebels for delivering them up into the hands of HALLECK; he was cursed by the Cotton States for bringing the war within their borders; he was maligned by his own subordinates, and his army was deserting him; he was fiercely assailed in the rebel Congress; he was bitterly criticised in the rebel newspapers -- until finally he is reported to have said despondingly that he had not a friend left in the Confederacy. And yet he was the man who, of all others, had been until lately looked upon in the South as a commander without a peer for active field work -- combining in himself science, skill, daring, coolness, resoluteness, experience, popularity, and whatever other characteristics or elements of success are supposed to belong to a great leader. This was the fourth war in which he had seen and done service; and in each of the previous wars, he had gained only renown and achieved always success. His letter to Gen. JEFF. DAVIS attempts to explain the causes of his present failure. It is apologetic and defensive in statement and tone; and as the rebel disasters in the Southwest all date from the fall of Fort Donelson, he makes that the event upon which to hang his defence.

abstract: -- We have at last an official report of the great battle in Southern Tennessee. It is given to the public ten days after the close of the fight -- not a very long time, but long enough to have engendered the most painful popular rumors, and induced a state of suspense in regard to the reality of our triumph which has had very depressing results. It is dated on the 9th, two days after the battle, and might certainly have been transmitted to the Press a week ago. This report of Gen. GRANT is, of course, merely preliminary, and will doubtless be supplemented by a full report from Gen. HALLECK, as soon as he can digest the material upon which it must be based.

abstract: The People vs.JohnCole. The prisoner was indicted for the murder of Thomas Morton. Cole, who is apparently about 47 or 48 years of age, was foreman in the kindling-wood factory of John T. Williams, corner of Horatio and Washington streets, thisCity. On the evening of Christmas last, about 5
lead_paragraph: The People vs.JohnCole. -- The prisoner was indicted for the murder of Thomas Morton. Cole, who is apparently about 47 or 48 years of age, was foreman in the kindling-wood factory of John T. Williams, corner of Horatio and Washington streets, thisCity. On the evening of Christmas last, about 5 3/4 o'clock, he, in company with Wade Fielder, a carman, was walking down Greenwich-street, near the lower corner of King-street, when deceased and one Fay met them, and struck and pushed them, as is contended. Offensive language was used, and a melee followed, during which Morton was stabbed, and died from the wound shortly after the parties were taken to the station-house. A knife having blood on it was found on the person of the prisoner. Fay was searched, and a pair of brass or copper knuckles found on him. Fielder was considerably injured on the face.

abstract: The President signed the District of Columbia Emacipation Bill yesterday morning, and accompanied his notice of the fact to Congress with a Message, in which he says he never doubted the constitutional authority of Congress to abolish Slavery in the District, and had ever desired to see the National Capital freed from the institution in some satisfactory way. Hence there had
lead_paragraph: The President signed the District of Columbia Emacipation Bill yesterday morning, and accompanied his notice of the fact to Congress with a Message, in which he says he never doubted the constitutional authority of Congress to abolish Slavery in the District, and had ever desired to see the National Capital freed from the institution in some satisfactory way. Hence there had never been, in his mind, any question, upon the subject, except the one of expediency, arising in view of all the circumstances. He is satisfied that the two principles of compensation and colonization are both recognized and practically applied in the act. In the matter of compensation, however, it is provided that claims may be presented within ninety days from the passage of the act, but not thereafter, and he points out the fact that there is no saving for minors, femmes coverts, insane or absent persons. He presumes this is an omission by mere oversight, and recommends that it be supplied by an amendatory or supplemental act.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Canada at Halifax, we receive advices from Europe two days later than were brought by the Norwegian at Portland. It is announced that the ship Yorktown, a regular packet running between London and New-York, had been captured by a rebel privateer-where or when we are left to guess.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Canada at Halifax, we receive advices from Europe two days later than were brought by the Norwegian at Portland. It is announced that the ship Yorktown, a regular packet running between London and New-York, had been captured by a rebel privateer-where or when we are left to guess. The British House of Commons had debated the question of the relative value of fortifications and floating batteries, and had adopted resolutions providing for a suspension of the fortifications at Spithead. The expediency of empowering the Government to use the money already voted for the forts in the construction of iron-sheathed vessels, was also soon to be considered. Some explanations had been made in Parliament relative to the withdrawal of a large portion of the British contingent from Mexico. The Continental news is generally unimportant. The Liverpool Cotton market was unchanged. Breadstuffs and Provisions were dull. Consols were quoted at 93 7/8@94 for money.

abstract: -- Capt. ERICSSON told the Navy Department that the name Monitor had been chosen for his turreted boat, because it was to serve as an admonition to the British Admiralty that the age of wooden walls is passed. The admonition has been heard, heeded, and the name is justified. England has not only surrendered her wooden navy on the spot, but loses all faith in her walls of stone. The works at Spithead, and works everywhere, destined to repel invasion, are to be instantly discontinued. This prompt learning of the American lesson does credit to the docility of John Bull. By unflagging application, he may presently learn to be a soldier, as well as a sailor, in this American school of arms.

abstract: THE COALITION. -- The defection of England from the Anti-Mexican coalition is likely to be an example to Spain. The Canada reports an official declaration of the Spanish Government, that in no circumstances will it take part in any effort to deprive Mexico of sovereignty and independence, and as the projects of France clearly involve such a privation, France, we are left to infer, will have to pursue its projects alone. The attitude of Spain would no doubt have been much less resolute, if a Bourbon, rather than a Hapsburg, had been the nominee of the French Emperor for a throne. But the Bonapartes have no affection for the Bourbons. It will not require weary waiting to see how far this utterance of the Spanish Cabinet is the opening of a new policy, or the mask of an old one.

abstract: report on Col. Blair April 11 speech in House on Lincoln policy and how to solve slavery question
snippet: report on Col. Blair April 11 speech in House on Lincoln policy and how to solve slavery question
lead_paragraph: Mr. BLAIR, of Missouri, said: The charge has frequently been heard, here and elsewhere that the President is without a policy in his Administration. I shall endeavor to show that this imputation is unfounded, to explain my conceptions of his policy, and to demonstrate that it is wise in every aspect, and commends itself to the lovers of the Union and of freedom. There can be no dispute with respect to the object of the war so far as he is concerned. He says, in his Annual Message, that he has been anxious that it "shall not degenerate into a violent and remorseless revolutionary struggle. I have, therefore," he adds, "in every case, thought it proper to keep the integrity of the Union prominent as the primary object of the contest." No one can refuse belief to this utterance, if the President stood on his mere declaration, his life has been so marked by integrity that all men yield implicit faith to his words, as the true index of his heart. But the language truely characterizes his conduct. It has not been attempted to show that he has not endeavored, in every way, to prevent the struggle from degenerating into a violent and remorseless revolutionary struggle, and, as its first great object, to maintain the integrity of the Union.

abstract: meeting of the Chamber of Commerce, yesterday, there was read a letter from Secretary WELLES, congratulating the Chamber on the success of the ovation at the Academy of Music, in behalf of the crew of the Cumberland. It will throw some light into the depths of the Secretary's sympathy, to recall that every officer of the Cumberland, though stripped by the sinking of the frigate of all his worldly goods, was, as soon as the news reached Washington, reduced by the Navy Department to half pay. So eager was the Secretary to condole with the survivors of a calamity for which the incapacity of his administration is alone responsible.

lead_paragraph: After a full discussions of the Stevens Battory, on its merits, and at the conclusion of the most desperate opposition on the part of its few enemies, Congress has passed, by a majority of more than two to one, in both branches, the appropriation necessary to finish the vessel: But since some of the other features of the general bill to which this appropriation was attached, as passed by the Senate, were not concurred in by the House, there is another delay; and this formidable engine of defence which ought to be covered with workmen at this very hour, has got to wait till a Committee of Conference finish their dispute about some other matters entirely foreign to it.

abstract: -- It is evident that a new element has been suddendy thrown into the campaign in New-Mexico. Heretofore we have heard only about the giving up of one National fort after another, the repealed surrender of bodies of regular troops, the routs of regiments of New-Mexicans -- disaster following disgrace, until a handful of Texan rebels had obtained possession of nearly the whole Territory, including its capital. The only redeeming incident in the campaign there was the personal heroism of Capt. MCRAE, who, at the battle of Valverde, fought his piece until all who manned it had fallen or fled, and then, planting himself against it, fought hand to hand with the enemy, until he fell dead. But now the scene is changed. There is real fighting, positive progress, advancing movements, there as well as on other fields. A regiment of frontiersmen and miners from the gold territory of Colorado, after a march without a parallel, reached Fort Union from Denver City; and, instead of laying down their arms at the orders of the foe, "advanced immediately upon his works." The news which we had the other day by way of Denver City, of a battle at Apache Pass, in the mountains to the northeast of Santa Fe is fully confirmed this morning by intelligence direct from Fort Union, New-Mexico. The rebels had intrenched themselves in that noted Pass, which has been the scene of so many Indian fights; but Col. SLOUGH advanced upon thorn, gave them battle, and defeated them, with a loss estimated at three or four hundred. They fled to Santa Fe, but our troops, it seems, are following them up, and, it would appear from the present position of Col. SLOUGH, that he is about to take them in the way so greatly in vogue of late, "in the rear." There will be no more surrenders of National troops heard of in New-Mexico; the forts there will now all speedily be repossessed, and held; and the bloodthirsty Texan marauders will be dispersed or destroyed. Such, at least, is the work which SLOUGH's men have undertaken for themselves; and it is not in the power of all the rebels in New-Mexico to balk their purpose.

abstract: The confidence of many people in the victorious result of the battle at Pittsburgh Landing, has been much shaken by the announcement of Gen. BEAUREGARD that he had taken eight thousand prisoners and thirty-six pieces of artillery. The doubt is, perhaps, natural; but
lead_paragraph: The confidence of many people in the victorious result of the battle at Pittsburgh Landing, has been much shaken by the announcement of Gen. BEAUREGARD that he had taken eight thousand prisoners and thirty-six pieces of artillery. The doubt is, perhaps, natural; but it is not well founded. The effect produced is just what the wily Louisianian aimed at. He knew that people generally would ask, how could BEAUREGARD carry off so many prisoners if he were finally beaten? But there is no inconsistency whatever between the capturing and the keeping of even 8,000 prisoners, and a final victory over their capturers. For when prisoners are taken they are immediately marched off to the rear, far out of the way both of harm and of rescue. These prisoners being taken on Sunday -- when, Gen. GRANT's force having been surprised by an overwhelming force of the enemy, we suffered severely, and would have been almost hopelessly defeated but for our gunboats, -- were of course sent to the rear of the rebel army; and on the morning of Sunday, were doubtless with their guard nearer Corinth than Pittsburgh Landing. But owing to the arrival of Gen. BUELL and the proceedings consequent thereupon, Monday saw Gen. BEAUREGARD's front rapidly converted into his rear. His rear of course became his front, and the prisoners whom he took on the previous day were soon going off in the van of his retreating army, with his whole force between them and their pursuing friends. There was thus probably no way of releasing these men but by the capture of the whole rebel force. It does not at all diminish the certainty or the importance of our victory to admit that, under the circumstances, our army was not able to follow the flying foe fast enough to get between him and the base of his operations. The true character of BEAUREGARD's position appears clearly in his announcement that he has "fallen back upon Corinth," and that he is "able" to maintain himself there. This is the language of a man defeated, though not annihilated.

abstract: Samuel D. Haring vs. Joseph Shannon. This was an action for alleged fraud in obtaining nineteen head of cattle. The plaintiff, who resides at Bergen,
lead_paragraph: Samuel D. Haring vs. Joseph Shannon. This was an action for alleged fraud in obtaining nineteen head of cattle. The plaintiff, who resides at Bergen, New-Jersey, alleged that in November, 1859, the defendant wrongfully took the cattle from him, and converted them to his own use, and that they were worth $645. The defense set up a denial, and alleged that the cattle were paid for by an order on one PUNDY, which was verbally accepted. The defendant also alleged that the transactions were in good faith, and without any intention on his part to defraud the plaintiff.

abstract: MR. BLAIR ON EMANCIPATION AND COLONIZATION. -- In other columns of the TIMES is given a report of a speech on the President's view of Slavery, delivered in the House of Representatives by Mr. BLAIR, of Missouri. Mr. BLAIR is the author of an admirable, if practicable, plan of removing the African race from this to some other American territory. As long ago as 1858, he commenced the public discussion of his project, securing, among other converts, the actual President, who, having always held that emancipation and colonization should go hand in hand, cheerfully accepted the idea of a Central American home for the deported race. The accord of Mr. LINCOLN's opinions with those of Mr. BLAIR is understood to be perfect upon the entire subject. Both believe that Slavery is only indirectly chargeable with the war; that the real groundwork of Southern aversion from the North is a belief that negro freedom is to carry with it negro equality; and that nothing will so surely extirpate the opposition to emancipation as a knowledge that the two races are to be forever separated. Mr. BLAIR discusses these propositions with his usual ability and earnestness; and will be listened to by the public with the greater attention because he reflects the policy which the Government proposes to follow.

abstract: The act of the President, in signing a bill to put an end to Slavery in the District of Columbia, places the Government of this country in its proper position, in reference to the subject of human bondage. It is a declaration
lead_paragraph: The act of the President, in signing a bill to put an end to Slavery in the District of Columbia, places the Government of this country in its proper position, in reference to the subject of human bondage. It is a declaration that its sympathies and its action, as far as they can be constitutionally exerted, are henceforth to be in favor of freedom, as better in a moral point of view, and more economic in a material one, than Slavery. Such is the genious of the age, as well as Christianity. This act of Government is but the record of a progress in this country in liberal ideas, common to the whole civilized world. In the United States, the comparative economic value of freedom and Slavery have had a double test, At the adoption of the Constitution, the two sections exactly divided the population between them, but Slavery claimed by far the fairer portion of the country. Seventy years have elapsed, and the Free States, with equal area, number nearly twice the population of the Slave, and ten times their wealth and material strength, to say nothing of the infinitely superior type of civilization of the former. The Slave States denied this superiority, and demanded the arbitrament of the sword. The last decision has been conclusive in favor of freedom. We cannot avoid the effect of the moral if we would, while the action of the slaveholding section has fully warranted Government in affirming a judgment irresistibly sustained by results, and at the same time by the general sense of mankind. Henceforth it will stand as the representative of freedom and progress, although the members of what it is composed may, for an indefinite period, maintain Slavery, which must, for the future, as it should, look to local law for its support. The Constitution of the United States cannot be directed to its overthrow in the States composing the Confederacy, but it must not be used as the instrument of its extension.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a large number of petitions and memorials were presented. Mr. HALE, of New Hampshire, at the request of the other members of the Naval Committee, withdrew his  resignation as Chairman. The resolution calling
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a large number of petitions and memorials were presented. Mr. HALE, of New Hampshire, at the request of the other members of the Naval Committee, withdrew his resignation as Chairman. The resolution calling for information relative to the arrest of Gen. STONE was taken up, and Mr. MCDOUGALL, of California, made another speech on the subject. The Confiscation bill was subsequently considered, and Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, addressed the Senate in opposition to its passage. The bill was then postponed until Friday afternoon. A special Message was received from the President, announcing that he had signed the bill for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia. The death of Representative COOPER, of Pennsylvania, was then announced, and the Senate soon afterward adjourned.

abstract: Hon, Edwin M.Stanton, Secretary of War:  During Tuesday and Wednesday, the gunboats amused themselves by shelling the woods below Gloucester. One of them approached within two miles of Yorktown yesterday morning, when the rebels opened from a new battery concealed in the woods. The boat having obtained the position of their guns, returned to her position without receiving any damage.

abstract: The jury in this case retired at 2 3/4 P.M. At 5 3/4 they came into Court again, and announced a verdict of manslaughter in the first degree. Judge SMALLEY stated to them that, although by the laws of this State the verdict would be a correct one -- by the United States laws, there was no such crime known as the first degree of manslaughter. He would, therefore, say that, unless the jury saw fit to change their verdict, he should direct the clerk to enter it as one of manslaughter simply. No objection being made by the jurors, the verdict was so entered.

abstract: Mr. GRAU's opera season (of one week only) will commence at the Academy of Music on Monday next, with the debut of the new tenor, Signor TOMBESI, in VERDI's opera of "Rigoletto." The cast in other respects is admirable, including the names of Mme. D'ANGRI, (as Magdalena,) Signor FERRI, (as Rigoletto, an excellent impersonation,) and Miss CLARA LOUISA KELLOGO as the heroine. We doubt if the opera has ever been given in this City with so effective a distribution.

abstract: The rebels have been for several days building large fortifications on the Gloucester side of York River, about two miles from Yorktown, and within sight of our gunboats; but their guns were of too long a range to allow of the approach of the gunboats to shell the works. About 1,000 men were at work on the fortifications, and the mortars were not of sufficient range to check the operations.

abstract: Cornelius Baker et al. vs. Seth W. Benedict and William A. Colt. -- This was an action to recover the value of a check and a promissory note. The complaint alleged that the firm of James H. Benedict & Co., of this City, on the 23d of September, 1857, made their check on the Bank of Commerce for $2,535, which was indorsed by the defendants, in their firm name of Benedict & Colt. The check was presented for payment, and payment refused, and notice of non-payment waived by the defendants. The note mentioned in the complaint as alleged was made by one E.R. Mason for $3,000, and indorsed by the defendants in the firm's name of Benedict & Colt. The defendant, Benedict, admitted in his answer the making of the check and note, but claimed that they had both been paid. The defendant, Colt, in a separate answer, set up that he knew nothing of the notes or the indorsement, until the commencement of this action, and that if the notes were indorsed by Benedict it was without his consent, and thus the note and check were accommodation paper, and Benedict had no authority to indorse the firm name. The principal question which arose on the trial was whether the check and note were accommodation paper or not. The Court charged the jury that if they found that the paper was accommodation paper, and that Mr. Colt had not convinced to pay the amount since they were signed, that they would not find him liable, as one partner had no authority, to blind the others on accommodation indorsements.
lead_paragraph: Cornelius Baker et al. vs. Seth W. Benedict and William A. Colt. -- This was an action to recover the value of a check and a promissory note. The complaint alleged that the firm of James H. Benedict & Co., of this City, on the 23d of September, 1857, made their check on the Bank of Commerce for $2,535, which was indorsed by the defendants, in their firm name of Benedict & Colt. The check was presented for payment, and payment refused, and notice of non-payment waived by the defendants. The note mentioned in the complaint as alleged was made by one E.R. Mason for $3,000, and indorsed by the defendants in the firm's name of Benedict & Colt. The defendant, Benedict, admitted in his answer the making of the check and note, but claimed that they had both been paid. The defendant, Colt, in a separate answer, set up that he knew nothing of the notes or the indorsement, until the commencement of this action, and that if the notes were indorsed by Benedict it was without his consent, and thus the note and check were accommodation paper, and Benedict had no authority to indorse the firm name. The principal question which arose on the trial was whether the check and note were accommodation paper or not. The Court charged the jury that if they found that the paper was accommodation paper, and that Mr. Colt had not convinced to pay the amount since they were signed, that they would not find him liable, as one partner had no authority, to blind the others on accommodation indorsements.

abstract: The Newbern prisoners who arrived here on Wednesday, in the transport Albany, were transferred to Governor's Island at noon yesterday. The com missioned Officers, viz., Col, AVERY, Captains RAN and MAYAN, and seven Lieutenants, are quartered in the Garrison, and the non-commissioned officers and privates, numbering one hundred and thirty, are confined in Castle William, which is surrounded by a cordon of sentinels.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to prevent frauds in laying out streets and avenues in this City was reported favorably; also the City Tax Levy. Among the bills ordered to a third reading was the one relative to the rates of wharfage in this City and Brooklyn. A large number of bills were passed, mostly of only local interest. The one relative to the inspection of unsafe buildings in this City was among them. The bill to adopt the Canals of the State to the defence of the Northern and Northwestern Lakes was recommitted, with instructions to so amend it as to leave it optional with the Canal Board to enlarge the locks of the Oswego Canal, or build a new Canal from the Clyde to Great Sodus Bay. The Metropolitan Health bill came up as the special order, when a majority and minority report from the Special Committee were presented -- the former being the Assembly bill with amendments, and the latter being the same bill without amendments. They were made the special order for today, after the presentation of reports. The Assembly amendments to the Swill-Milk bill was not rejected, and the bill was laid on the table.

abstract: The news from Gen. BANKS' column indicates that it is steadily advancing up the Shenandoah Valley. A dispatch to the War Department announces that our troops occupied Mount Jackson, in Shenandoah County, yesterday morning. The enemy were reported to be near by at Rude's Hill, where they intend to give battle. The dispatch announces that our troops would last night occupy Newmarket, in the extreme southeastern corner of Shenandoah County, and in the rear of the rebel position at Rude's Hill. Another dispatch says that our troops, in their advance upon MountJackson, surprised and captured a company of rebel cavalry, who were profaning a church by their presence. A third dispatch says that our troops had also seized two locomotives and several cars at Mount Jackson. The rebels meant to destroy all the bridges and property, but they were outwitted by Gen. BANKS' swift movement.

abstract: Gen. SCOTT reached his old residence in Elizabeth, N. J., on Wednesday, where, it is stated, he intends to remain for the future. He was met at Elizabeth Port by a large delegation of his old friends and neighbors who received him with the most touching demonstrations of delight, and escorted him to his residence with all the respect due to his exalted character and services.

abstract: editorial on US-Mexico relations
snippet: editorial on US-Mexico relations
lead_paragraph: A few days ago, the TIMES laid before its readers a remarkably thorough and instructive history of the origin of the European coalition against Mexico. It was illustrated with the text of all the more important dispatches which had passed between the British, Spanish and French Governments, and with abstracts of papers of secondary moment. This remarkable chapter of diplomatic history we have now completed. On Tuesday, the President submitted to the House of Representatives a statement of the relations of the American Government with Mexico, accompanied by copies of the correspondence which has taken place between the State Department and Mr. CORWIN, our Minister at the Mexican Capital. These papers, reproduced in our columns yesterday, show with what steadfast loyalty Secretary SEWARD has adhered to the great American principle, adverse to entangling alliances; how tenaciously he has grasped the Monroe doctrine, and with what zeal he has employed all the resources of diplomacy to save Mexico from impending ruin. And in the more detailed intelligence, in another column, of recent events in the adjoining Republic, our readers have made perfect in their favor a summary of the Mexican question, as it stands to-day.

abstract: -- It is remarkable that while the rebels reappear at the Aquia Creek batteries, the National gunboats have ascended the Rappahannock to a point only a few miles distant from those works, and find the country entirely free from enemies. The fact is significant. The line of the Rappahannock has doubtless been abandoned by the large bodies of troops concentrated at Yorktown, some scattered forces being left on the forsaken ground in order to delude our commanders. In all probability the direct road from Washington to Richmond has no obstacle to - the advance of our troops. That advance accomplished, the rebel army at Yorktown would be captured, and the war practically ended. Where is MCDOWELL? Where is BANKS?

We thank thee, Jew, for teaching us that word.

abstract: The correspondent of the Cincinnati Gazette says that the line of battle agreed upon for our forces on Monday was: Right wing, Major-Gen. LEW. WALLACE; left wing, Brig.-Gen. NELSON. Between these, beginning at the left, Brig.-Gens. TON. CRITTENDEN, A. MCD. MCCOOK, HURLBURT, MCCLERNAND and SHERMAN. In the divisions of the three latter were to be included also the remains of PRENTISS' and W.H.L. WALLACE's commands -- shattered, disorganized, and left without commanders, through the capture of one, and the probably mortal wound of the other.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to amend the act creating the Court of Claims, recently passed by the House, was referred to the Judiciary Committee. The House bill amending the act to authorize the issue of certificates of indebtedness, was referred to the Finance Committee. A joint resolution appropriating seven thousand dollars for the relief of the officers and privates of the Marine Battalion, who lost their personal effects on the Port Royal expedition, was passed. The bill prescribing the qualifications of electors in the District of Columbia, was passed. The House bill for the establishment of a Department of Agriculture was debated at considerable length, but finally postponed. The Indian Appropriation bill was also debated, amended, and laid over to be printed. The House bill for the establishment of a branch mint at Denver, Colorado, was passed. The resolution relative to Gen. STONE was postponed until Monday. The bill providing for a steamship line between San Francisco and Shanghai, was under consideration, when the Senate went into Executive session, and subsequently adjourned.

abstract: Report on Tammany activities
snippet: Report on Tammany activities
lead_paragraph: The time-honored Society of St. Tammany, whose lightest movement excited universal curiosity and interest throughout our political circles only a few years since, has, of late, rested in comparative seclusion. The annual election of Sachems has, for some time past, been a mere formality -- the same old stereotyped set of officers being returned, year after year. But the death within the past twelvemonth of Messrs. JAMES CONNER and WM. D. KENNEDY, two of the most influential members of the Order, seems to have reawakened the elements of strife around "the sacred spring."

abstract: The battle of the ironsides in Hampton Roads has produced almost as stunning an effect on the British public as the Merrimac itself did on the wooden walls before the Monitor appeared on the scene of action. We predicted at the time of the battle that it would make a profound impression in England; but we hardly anticipated that it would throw John Bull into a panic such as it has hitherto been reserved for a "French invasion" to arouse. In the extended debate, which took place in the House of Commons on the 30th ult. on the subject of the respective merits of fortifications and iron-clad vessels as means of harbor defence, it was urged by the various speakers, with wonderful unanimity, that not only has the day of wooden ships gone by, but that, as Mr. BERNAL OSBORNE said, "it would be folly to spend another shilling upon fortifications until we are in a position to know that they will be able to hold their own against the monsters of the deep which are now being constructed." Accordingly, Parliament has directed the suspension of operations on the works at Spithead, and promises soon to consider also the subject of a general transfer of the fortification appropriations to build armor-clad ships.
lead_paragraph: The battle of the ironsides in Hampton Roads has produced almost as stunning an effect on the British public as the Merrimac itself did on the wooden walls before the Monitor appeared on the scene of action. abstract: Editorial on difficulty of press in pinning down exact location of Fort Pillow on Mississippi River
snippet: Editorial on difficulty of press in pinning down exact location of Fort Pillow on Mississippi River
lead_paragraph: -- Next to the question of the identity of JUNIUS, seems to be the difficulty of locating Fort Pillow. It is supposed to be situated somewhere on the banks of the Mississippi River; but no two of our cotemporaries, no couple of intelligent contrabands, no pair of reliable deserters, no brace of rebel captives, no two maps, though in other respects they may be duplicates, can be found to agree as to its definite position. They differ, as to its location, tens and even hundreds of miles from each other; and if Commodore FOOTE, like the rebels, shapes his movements entirely after newspaper statements, he will have some difficulty in discovering Fort Pillow, now that he has set out in search of it. The Herald, with its accustomed versatility and determination to suit every taste, has, in its various descriptions, located the fort along the entire line of the river from Columbus to Memphis, and the last Herald "map" we attempted to decipher, planted it almost in the heart of Memphis. The Tribune yesterday gave a remarkable diagram of the fort, which, if the cut be correct, must be a work worthy of the ditch-digging hero after whom it is named, and in the accompanying description said it was located "just above the city;" but gave scope to the imagination in the remark that "there are (sic) in the rear of the fort a line of breastworks five or six miles long," and twelve hundred negroes working at it night and day -- who, by this time, must have carried the works up nearly to Columbus. The World yesterday said that the fort was "situated about thirty-five miles from Memphis, near two villages called Randolph and Fulton "-- which two villages, by the way, are about seventy miles above Memphis. The TIMES, of yesterday, located the fort at a point different from either of its cotemporaries, -- at which precise spot Commodore FOOTE is now throwing shot and shell. The country editors are, of course, fearfully obfuscated in regard to the situation of the fort; and those who are daring enough to mention the thing at all, conceal their ignorance in the Herald way, by scattering it along the river generally. If the loyal Press (not including the Herald) is thus "mixed up" in regard to the situation of Fort Pillow, the rebels who built the work ought to know something about it; and they say (we quote the Memphis appeal) that it is located on the cast bank of the Mississippi, seventy miles above Memphis, near the mouth of the Hatchie River. In order to give the City Press, our country cotemporaries, and our readers generally a correct idea of its situation, we give the map on the first page; and when the news comes -- as it soon will come -- that Fort Pillow is ours, the Herald, Tribune and World can also give their unhappy readers some authentic conception of its geographical bearings.
headline: {'main': 'WHERE IS FORT PILLOW?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'WHERE IS FORT PILLOW?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A lecture upon this theme was delivered before a large audience of ladies and gentlemen, last evening, at the headquarters of the Young Men's Central Republican Committee, by STEUART L. WOODFORD, Esq., the former Chairman of the Committee. After alluding to the attack upon Fort Sumter, a year ago, and the extraordinary uprising of the North which immediately followed, and briefly sketching the history of the struggle thus far between loyalty and treason, Mr. WOODFORD proceeded to discuss the principles involved in the contest, and the questions growing out of the war that now present themselves for solution. The purpose of the rebellion was and is to destroy the Federal Union -- the purpose of the loyal men of the nation to perpetuate it. Is the purpose of preserving the Union and restoring the Federal authority over the entire National domain worth the effort necessary to its achievement? Will the desired end repay the labor and suffering, the treasure and blood at which alone it can be bought? These were questions which we need not fear to ask; rather were they questions to which we should make full and ready answer, for, unless they could be honestly, logically, and convincingly answered in the affirmative, this struggle would even yet be abandoned without achievement. The speaker proceeded to consider these questions at length in all their bearings, and argued with great force that the perpetuation of our liberties as citizens, our dignity, stability and power, as a people, our freedom from internal strife, our interests of every kind, economical, social, moral and intellectual, not only favored, but absolutely demanded that we should continue a united people, in no other way can the great problem of our National existence, which, in the language of WEBSTER, is to "determine whether Governments can be stable as well as free," be successfully solved. The recognition of Southern independence to-day would be but a temporary truce, before a final and more deadly struggle -- a struggle which would mean, not a restoration of a Union, but iron-heeled subjugation. Nor would the new Confederacy remain long at peace among themselves. The doctrine of State secession, on which it is based, would give rise to new rebellions. Once break the charmed circle of the Union, and accustom the people to regard secession as a political right, and you steadily proffer inducements to treason. Intestine struggles would be speedily followed by foreign intervention, and even if they were not, war itself, when long continued and often repeated, as it would be among a number of different Republics, is fatal to liberty. The value of the Union then is the worth of the personal liberty and equality of rights which it secures; the worth of free speech, a free Press, and free worship; the worth of our ballot-boxes, our school-houses and our churches. Its value is the worth of our material and National growth, the worth of our farms, factories and forges, our railroads and telegraphs, our industry and commerce, our history and progress, our army and navy, our flag streaming in every wind and our power behind the flag -- in fine, it is worth all the possible cost, whatever it may be, of its complete restoration. The paramount duty of every man, therefore, was to use all his influence and all his means to the attainment of this object.

abstract: At an early hour yesterday morning, Capt. THORNE, of the Fourth Police Precinct, with several men, male a descent upon a disorderly house on James-street, known as the "Flag of Our Union." About fifty persons, male and female, were taken into custody. The house, which is kept by FREDERICK LEWER, is one of the most notorious in the Fourth Ward. A short time since a man was killed there by being shot with a pistol. The proprietor was arrested upon the charge of having committed the homicide. He was afterwards tried and acquitted in the Court of General Sessions. The parties arrested were taken to the Tombs yesterday morning. Justice BRENNAN held the proprietor in $500 bail, to answer the charge of keeping a disorderly house. The females, fifteen in number, were committed for examination, and the men were discharged. The group was composed of persons of all nations and languages.

abstract: -- The ingenuity of the croakers has been, these several weeks, tried painfully. The steady success of the National arms; the broad areas recovered to the Union; the audible tolling of rebellion's last hour, are provocations to cheerfulness, insufferable to these political Mark Tapleys. To the strong and sonorous chorus of triumph, therefore, the croakers have maintained as a constant under-song, the coming of the Merrimac. The skeleton they bring to the popular banquet has been iron-plated, fire-belching. No assurance from the most belief-worthy that the monster cannot live in salt water, and that the means provided by Government are ample for its destruction, quieted these inconsolables until the Merrimac came forth, and again hobbled back to Gosport seeking repairs. The part of this particular confidencequeller was thus played. Another invention was demanded. This, which has just come to hand, is neither very new or very shocking. We are threatened with a dissolution of the Cabinet. Cabinet quarrels and dissolutions are the pieces de resistance of these prophets of evil. They serve to fall back upon in the absence of anything better. But as changes are quite likely to occur in the counsels of the President, for reasons which it is not proper to mention, we may go so far as to say, that no change will lake place in consequence of antagonistic opinions, or because the President is dissatisfied with the conduct of any of his Secretaries. The Cabinet having been never more thoroughly harmonious than at present, the foreboders will have to find some other theatre of disaster than the Council Chamber.

abstract: -- The visit to the rebel Capital of the French Minister, M. MERCIER, is, of course, too good a quarry of canards not to be extensively worked, and some of the funniest of mares' nests have been found in that perfectly simple occurrence. The motive of the visit was, without doubt, correctly indicated in our yesterday's Washington telegram, though the form of statement was not altogether accurate. It was stated that the object of M. MERCIER's visit was to secure new and ample protection for the tobacco stored at Richmond, and owned by French merchants. Now, though such an object might appear hardly to call for an exercise of ambassadorial functions, their exercise becomes perfectly justified when it is understood that the tobacco referred to, instead of belonging to French mechanics, in reality belongs to the French Government. [???] will known that tobacco is a staple which, in France, is monopolized by the Government, and this monopoly, known as the Regie, contributes largely to the revenues of the Empire. About the time of the outbreak of the rebellion immense quantities of the staple were purchased by Government agents, and stored at Richmond. This tobacco was at one time in danger of confiscation, and it has since been in perpetual danger of conflagration. To secure its safety is the object of the French Minister's visit, though it would certainly be worth while knowing what form of argument he will use toward the insurgent chiefs, maddened and desperate at their failure to secure the recognition of their "Government" by France, in common with the other European Powers.

abstract: -- The battle of Inkermann is known in the British army as "The Soldiers' battle," and that of Pittsburgh Landing, or Shiloh, claims the same honor for the brave fellows who won it. Both battles were brought on by a surprise; both were fought by the victorious party at first against great odds; in both each party was strongly reinforced, and both were won, and hardly won, not by generalship, but by the hard fighting of rank, file and officers. In fact, the officers became soldiers in each, and distinguished themselves, not by tactics, but by personal valor. At Pittsburgh Landing the commanding General of the insurgent force fell while cheering on his men, and the final rout of the rebels was the result of a charge of six regiments of National troops, with the Major-General in command at their head. But this is not generalship. A commander-in-chief at a great battle has (according to all military rule) no business in the van of the army, charging sword in hand. Since war became an art, his place is a stationary one in the rear. Men like RICHARD the Lion-hearted were not great Generals, but great leaders. Their success depended upon their daring, their muscle and their skill in the use of arms. Generals win their way by will and brain. But the more cause for exultation on our part, when we see that shortcomings in generalship can be supplied by the personal bravery and daring of our men. Amid our reasonable dissatisfaction at the surprise and early discomfiture of our army at Pittsburgh Landing, we derive some consolation from the fact that one of the most important victories of the war may be justly called our Soldiers' battle.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to establish a land office in Colorado Territory was passed. A report was made from the Special Committee appointed in July last to inquire into the matter of  Government property at the Pensacola and Norfolk Navy-yards, and the Harper's Ferry Armory. A bill was introduced by Mr. HARRIS, of ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to establish a land office in Colorado Territory was passed. A report was made from the Special Committee appointed in July last to inquire into the matter of Government property at the Pensacola and Norfolk Navy-yards, and the Harper's Ferry Armory. A bill was introduced by Mr. HARRIS, of New-York, to increase the salaries of the Surveyors at Albany and Troy, and reduce the number of Customs officers at each place from seven to three. It was referred. A resolution calling upon the Superintendent of the Census Bureau for information relative to the slaves of the District of Columbia, was passed. The bill to establish an armed mail steamship line between San Francisco and Shanghai was debated at considerable length, but no vote was taken upon it. The Confiscation bill was also considered as the special order, and Mr. HOWARD, of Michigan, made a speech urging Its immediate passage. The Senate adjourned until Monday.

abstract: Nearly $3,000 more for the wounded were collected here yesterday. Ward Committees to make and report daily collections, were appointed. Over two hundred applications as physicians and nurses were necessarily declined. Another steamer, chartered by our Mayor and Sanitary Committee, freighted with stores and bedding and carrying the Louisville and Frankfort delegations of surgeons and nurses, has left. Frankfort Sends four surgeons and seven nurses.

abstract: The Selection of Col. BERRET, the ex- ...  The selection of Col. BERRET, the ex  Mayor of Washington, as one of the Commissioners under the District Emancipation act, has been sharply questioned. The fact of the nominee having been a prisoner in Fort Lafayette is assumed to be evidence of his disloyalty, and the President is accused of choosing a noted sympathizer with the Pro-Slavery ...
lead_paragraph: The Selection of Col. BERRET, the ex-Mayor of Washington, as one of the Commissioners under the District Emancipation act, has been sharply questioned. The fact of the nominee having been a prisoner in Fort Lafayette is assumed to be evidence of his disloyalty, and the President is accused of choosing a noted sympathizer with the Pro-Slavery rebellion, to fill a position so important in relation to the future fate of the negro. The subjoined extract from a private letter from a gentleman of this City, a life-long friend of Mr. BERRET, and unquestionably loyal, goes to acquit the President of an impropriety, and Mr. BERRET of treason, overt or covert;

abstract: The London Observer, of March 15, says: "A rather tall, white-headed, gentlemanly-looking man, who refused his address, but gave the name of FITZ-SIMMONS CALHOUN, Captain in the American service, was charged at Bow-street with fraudulently obtaining £10 under the following circumstances: Mr. G.O. HALL, a gentleman possessed of large estates in Louisiana, said: I am at present staying at Norfolk-villas, Paddington. Last April I was residing in Gloucester-square. About that time the prisoner called, and said he was brother to a gentleman known to me in Paris by the name of MEREDITH CALHOUN. I invited him into my parlor, and in the course of our conversation he said that on his way from Sweden to London he had lost his pocket-book. He also said he wanted to go to Philadelphia, and asked me to lend him £10, and that when he got to Liverpool he should have some funds from Mr. BROWN, the shipper, and he would remit it the following day, or he would give me a bill on his brother in Paris. I lent him the £10, and he gave me an order. I never received the £10 again, and I afterwards heard he was an impostor, and for form sake, as I had a friend going to Paris, I got him to present it. Mr. CALHOUN was out, but his wife, who was at home, confirmed the report as to his being an impostor, by saying that they knew nothing at all of the prisoner. Yesterday, I saw him in Burlington-arcade, and for the sake of public security I gave him in charge for forgery, as he had signed himself 'Francis Fitzsimon Calhoun,' and when I addressed him yesterday he said his name was 'Fitzsimmons Calhoun,' Prisoner after saying that he knew some of the most eminent men in America, was remanded."

Yesterday, I saw him in Burlington-arcade, and for the sake of public security I gave him in charge for forgery, as he had signed himself 'Francis Fitzsimon Calhoun,' and when I addressed him yesterday he said his name was 'Fitzsimmons Calhoun,' Prisoner after saying that he knew some of the most eminent men in America, was remanded."

abstract: In the House of Commons, on the 3d inst., Mr. OSBORNE moved that it be expedient to suspend the construction of the proposed forts at Spithead until the value of iron-roofed gunboats for the defence of our ports and roadsteads shall have been fully considered. Having observed that the statement made by Government upon the subject, a few days ago, was most unsatisfactory, the honorable member detailed at some length the steps which had been taken since the time of Mr. PITT to provide for the national defences. He quoted the opinion of the Royal Commissioners on National Defences, in 1859, that no fortification would be sufficient to arrest the progress of an iron-clad steamship, proceeding at a high speed, and read a letter from Admiral Sir R. DUNDAS, in which that gallant officer declared in the most emphatic terms that, for local purposes and the defences of harbors, iron-cased vessels would be necessary instead of permanent fortifications, and suggesting that a fleet of iron-clad gunboats should be at once provided. Mr. OSBORNE urged that our naval armament, as regarded guns, was in a most unsatisfactory condition, and asked Government if it was the fact that although £3,000,000 of money had been spent upon Armstrong guns, the only gun we could use for penetrating armor-plates, was the old 68-pounder. He denied that the fortifications of Spithead would afford the slightest protection to merchant vessels running into the harbor there, in the event of a war. He referred to the recent exploits of the Merrimac and Monitor, observing that Capt. COOPER COLES, an Englishman, and not Mr. ERRICSSON, was the inventor of the principle upon which the Monitor had been constructed. The invention of Capt. COLES had been for some time before the heads of the Admiralty; had been inquired into and reported favorably upon, and then quietly shelved. Now that its value had been tested in the American waters he thought there was some probability that we should hear more of the floating battery invented by the gallant officer. The whole principle of modern warfare consisted of mobility, as against permanence. Our system of artillery was in such a state that it must be entirely reconstituted, and in reconstituting it he thought much greater attention must be paid to our naval armaments than they had hitherto received. In the opinion of Lord DUNDONALD it was little short of National incredulity to expect that, because we erected imposing fortifications, an enemy would come to them when they could operate elsewhere without the slightest risk. He regarded immense fortifications as nothing more than so many National weaknesses, and concluded by expressing a hope that, whatever might be the fate of his motion, Government would not plunge into a reckless expense for the erection of useless fortifications. [Cheers.]

abstract: In the Senate, the Metropolitan Health Bill was considered in Committee of the Whole. It appeared during the debate that the Committee to whom it had been referred had agreed to strike out the "Police Commissioners," and insert the "Mayors of the Cities" in their place, but the bill had been printed without this amendment. After some argument, it was agreed to strike out all relating to the Police Commissioners, 14 to 13.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, the Metropolitan Health Bill was considered in Committee of the Whole. It appeared during the debate that the Committee to whom it had been referred had agreed to strike out the "Police Commissioners," and insert the "Mayors of the Cities" in their place, but the bill had been printed without this amendment. After some argument, it was agreed to strike out all relating to the Police Commissioners, 14 to 13. The word "physicians" was stricken out, and the words "physicians having diplomas as doctors of medicine" were inserted in its place. A motion to strike out of the seventh section all relating to the City Inspector's Department was lost. An amendment was made providing that no vessels shall be quarantined excepting for small-pox, ship fever, and cholera.
