abstract: The bombardment and capture of Fort Pulaski whereof we to-day give a detailed description by our special correspondent is one of those actions which, like the combat of the ironsides in Hampton Roads, have a double significance being at once a valuable success in our scheme of seaboard operations, and adding most important contributions to the science of attack and defence.
lead_paragraph: The bombardment and capture of Fort Pulaski whereof we to-day give a detailed description by our special correspondent is one of those actions which, like the combat of the ironsides in Hampton Roads, have a double significance being at once a valuable success in our scheme of seaboard operations, and adding most important contributions to the science of attack and defence. It has been the fortune of the present war to inaugurate a revolution in naval warfare; and the likelihood seems to be that it is destined to introduce a similar revolution into one branch of land warfare. Certainly, if it would be rash to say that our experiments on the Southern fortifications show that such works are powerless against modern heavy artillery and improved projectiles, in the same way as the wooden walls were powerless against the resistless shock of the Merrimac, we are at least justified in claiming that these experiments must henceforth introduce fundamental modifications into the theory and practice of land defences. The account of the bombardment of Fort Pulaski, which we publish, will, no doubt, be read throughout Europe with an interest almost equal to that with which the battle of the Monitor and Merrimac was received. That affair has already prompted the British Parliament to order the suspension of operations on the works at Spithead, and they will soon consider the propriety of a general transfer of fortification appropriations to build armor-clad ships. The bombardment of Fort Pulaski will probably clinch their determination to do so, while the illustrations it will afford of the effects of our American ordnance and improved projectiles, will probably visit them with unpleasant suspicions whether even their stoutest ironsides will be able to resist the terrible impact of these new Yankee notions.

abstract: In the House of Lords, on the 4th inst., the Earl of Hardwicke rose to ask the First Lord of the Admiralty what number of iron-plated ships were afloat and building, and what was intended to be done with the ships of the fleet that were built of timber. The noble Earl said that the intelligence which had lately been received of the maritime contest in American gave to that subject an extraordinary amount of interest and importance. For his part, however, he had for many years been convinced that iron should be substituted for timber in the construction of every efficient naval force; and he felt persuaded that the time had now come when the Government should no longer nibble with the question, but should undertake a complete reconstruction of our navy. We required two descriptions of vessels; one, which should act as floating batteries, which should be impervious like the Monitor, to shot and shell, but which would be capable of no rapid motion, and would only be used for purposes of coast defence; and another which could undertake long voyages and encounter every variety of weather. He cautioned the Government against building ships with such a large draft of water as twenty-six feet. Its mentioned this because he saw the Government pressed by all sorts of persons with inventions and hobbies. These men were not seamen, and to follow them would lead the Government probably into a grievous error. The old general principles he believed were applicable to all kinds of vessels, whether built of iron or wood, moved by steam or by sails. He had seen a proposition to build ships without keels. Why, how was a ship without a keel to be steered? He advised the Government never to build a ship without first taking the advice of men-of-war's men. With regard to the Merrimac, he believed she was not iron-clad. She had been cut down, and a pent-house kind of roof was built on her deck, made of railway rails cut into the required lengths. Now, he thought, instead of building what was called a cupola-decked ship, it would be better to cut down one of the existing ships and sheet her with iron. That he believed could be done for from £25,000 to £30,000 a ship. As an old officer he could see ahead a total change in the character of our navy and our seamen. Fleets of iron ships could not be kept at sea in a time war. It would be too expensive. Such vessels would be kept at home, and the officers would become mere scientific engineers, and the men stokers, and the character of the seaman would become the same as the modern soldier. He feared the change would have the effect of preventing the youth of the country from entering the navy. With regard to arming the ships of the new kind, he saw great difficulties. He could not see how such ships could have magazines sufficient for such armaments as they must carry. These were questions of great and paramount importance, and therefore he had taken this opportunity of calling attention to them.

abstract: further reports from Yorktown
snippet: further reports from Yorktown
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port of the steam transport McClellan, from Port Royal on the afternoon of the 14th inst., we are put in possession of full particulars of the bombardment and surrender of Fort Pulaski. It appears from our own accounts that the rebel dispatches announcing the fall of the fort were remarkably correct -- only a little exaggerated in regard to the effects of our fire, to afford a better excuse for the surrender after so short a bombardment. A brief dispatch to the War Department states that we opened fire on the morning of the 10th inst. After thirty hours' almost continuous firing, a practicable breach was made, and preparations for storming were about to commence, when the rebel flag was struck. Our captures, beside the fort itself, are forty-seven guns, seven thousand shot 'and shell, forty thousand pounds of powder, three hundred and sixty prisoners, with their small arms and accoutrements, and a good supply of provisions. Only one of our men was killed, and one wounded. The loss of the rebels was three wounded. Pull particulars of the affair will be found in the letter of our special correspondent.

abstract: Since I wrote you, Col. SLOUGH'S column, thirteen hundred strong, have advanced to HOGAN's  Ranche, twenty-five miles north of Santa Fe, where they encountered the enemy, whose strength was not known, and immediately engaged them. Major CRITTENDEN, with the First Colorado Volunteers, and two companies United States Infantry, Under Capt. LEW  IS, were sent across the river to fall upon their rear.

abstract: -- WORTHLESSNESS OF THE BLOCKADE. -- While we are quite ready to admit the impossibility of a perfect blockade, the existence of anything resembling perfection in the blockade of the Carolina coast must be emphatically denied. As the Nashville ran in and out of Beaufort Harbor without obstruction, so it seems she has been running in and out of Charleston. She appears at Nassau under another name, and simply as a trader, to boast of the impunity with which she has just entered and left Charleston Harbor. And, without any pretence of concealment, she has taken on board a load of arms destined for the rebels, announcing her intention to deliver them in some convenient port of the South.
lead_paragraph: -- WORTHLESSNESS OF THE BLOCKADE. -- While we are quite ready to admit the impossibility of a perfect blockade, the existence of anything resembling perfection in the blockade of the Carolina coast must be emphatically denied. As the Nashville ran in and out of Beaufort Harbor without obstruction, so it seems she has been running in and out of Charleston. She appears at Nassau under another name, and simply as a trader, to boast of the impunity with which she has just entered and left Charleston Harbor. And, without any pretence of concealment, she has taken on board a load of arms destined for the rebels, announcing her intention to deliver them in some convenient port of the South.

abstract: Yesterday morning, the enemy, who had marched from Hickman, composed of infantry, cavalry and artillery, in what force is not known, (we have heard estimates as low as twelve hundred and as high as nine thousand,) surrounded our pickets beyond Union City. It is stated on the [???] authority, that a portionof those picketed on the road by which the one my approached, had fell their posts during the night and collected together socially in an old church. They were all taken prisoners without resistance. A neighboring citizen ran to Union City and gave the alarm, which was immediately followed by the entrance of the enemy. This was at 7 o'clock in the morning.

abstract: Editorial on ex-Sen. C Breckinridge and other traitors
snippet: Editorial on ex-Sen. C Breckinridge and other traitors
lead_paragraph: It is devoutly to be deplored that the report of the capture of the arch-traitor JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE, at the battle of Pittsburgh Landing, has not proved true. The time has now come when their own personal safety will be the chief look-out of the leaders of the rebellion. They will presently seek to escape by flight the righteous vengeance which they feel in their guilty consciousness is prepared for them; but during the short time they still continue to play their sham part, whether in the field or at the rebel capital, their supreme aim will be to secure themselves from capture. This must not be permitted. Our Generals must bear in mind that the nation commits to them, as a special duty, to secure at whatever cost the live bodies of the leaders, civic and military, of the rebellion. If it is necessary, let them detail a posse comitatus for this special and exclusive purpose. It is better that ten thousand ordinary prisoners from the rank and file of the rebel army should be allowed to escape -- they will all be released as it is -- than that one DAVIS, BRECKINRIDGE, STEPHENS, YANCEY, TOOMBS, COBB or FLOYD, should be permitted to cheat the gallows. For them and their mates there is one sure fate -- be hanged by the neck till they are dead. This is the punishment provided for treason, and there is a growing conviction in the public mind that it must be fully meted out to the leaders of the rebellion that has lifted up its hand against the life of the Republic.
headline: {'main': 'The Traitor Breckinridge.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Traitor Breckinridge.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Under the now or amended charter, the power of giving out contracts for cleaning the streets, and repairing wells and pumps, is taken out of the hands of the Aldermen of the various Wards, and placed in charge of the "Board of Contracts," which is composed of the heads of the different City Departments, Including the Mayor. The giving out of these contracts was about the only way the Aldermen have had heretofore of bestowing favors upon their friends, and as may well be supposed, neither they or the contractors do not much relish the change. The Board 4.of Contracts, having given due notice to receive proposals for the work abovementioned, yesterday at one o'clock, and in the Common Council chamber, was the time and place appointed for opening the same. The audience portion of the chamber was filled with contractors and their friends, and the expressions of countenance manifested among the auditors as the different bids were opened and read aloud, presented an interesting scene. Them were 190 proposals for cleaning the streets, and 232 proposals for repairing the wells and pumps, and the following were announced as the lowest:

abstract: Gen. O.B. CONRAD, of Gilmer County, Virginia, is now in confinement in Wheeling, having been taken thither by National officers at Sutton, Braxton County, to whom he voluntarily surrendered himself a few days ago.
lead_paragraph: Gen. O.B. CONRAD, of Gilmer County, Virginia, is now in confinement in Wheeling, having been taken thither by National officers at Sutton, Braxton County, to whom he voluntarily surrendered himself a few days ago. He was a member of the Richmond Convention, which passed the ordinance of secession, and stood side by side with the best of the Union men of Northwestern Virginia, refusing at all times to vote for the ordinance. He returned home, however, and Gov. LETCHER made him a Brigadier-General. Since that time he has been recognized as a secessionist, but now he seems to have turned from the error of his ways.

abstract: Editorials on Union withdrawal of troops from Florida; on effects of war in cotton states
snippet: Editorials on Union withdrawal of troops from Florida; on effects of war in cotton states
lead_paragraph: The rebel leaders in the Cotton States, when urging secession upon the people of that section, assured them that in no event was there any danger of war being carried into their midst. The Border States, which they were sure would be induced to join fortunes with theirs, would form a broad and insuperable barrier against the advance of the North -- if the North should be so audacious as to declare war for the Union. The powerful State of Missouri would be a defence for Arkansas, Louisiana and Texas; the populous and warlike States of Kentucky and Tennessee, would form an invulnerable shield for Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia and South Carolina; while Maryland and Western Virginia would prevent the Northerners from crossing the Potomac or piercing the line of the Alleghany Mountains. Then, with the military possession of the forts that defend the cities of the Southern Atlantic and Gulf coasts, the Cotton States could bid defiance to the North in arms. The theory was a nice one, as well as a selfish one, and it seemed to them perfectly feasible.

abstract: editorial on McDowell march
snippet: editorial on McDowell march
lead_paragraph: The most important intelligence this morning is the announcement that a portion of Gen. McDOWELL'S army has occupied Fredericksburgh. Our troops, Col. KILPATRICK, of the Second New-York, in the advance, supported by the Ira Harris Cavalry, left Cattell's Station, in the vicinity of Warrenton Junction, on Thursday, and making a forced march across the country, encountered the enemy's outposts, which were driven in by the cavalry, who captured one of the rebel camps. On Friday, early, the march was resumed, Col. BAYARD, with the First Pennsylvania Cavalry, being in the advance. Be was attacked by a regiment of rebel infantry, a regiment of cavalry, and a battery of artillery, but our troops succeeded in driving the enemy before them, across the Rappahannock at Fredericksburgh. The bridge had been prepared for burning, and was set on fire by the retreating enemy, and consumed. Our loss in the skirmishes was five men and fifteen horses Allied, and sixteen men wounded. Several of the rebels were killed and wounded, but the number is not known. The suburbs of Fredericksburgh were occupied by our troops at 7 o'clock on Friday evening, and they are now, doubtless, in the city itself.

abstract: -- While Gen. BANKS is moving up the Shenandoah, Gen. MCDOWELL has moved Southward on the Rappahannock. We learn this morning that his command marched on Thursday from Warrenton Junction, near which it has been stationed for a few weeks past, and on Friday reached the Rappahannock opposite Fredericksburgh, drove away a Rebel detachment, and occupied the place. A glance at the map and at the railroad connections of Fredericksburgh, will show the importance of this movement. We cannot possibly foreshadow where MCDOWELL is now bound for; but if it be true that the rebel troops have all been concentrated down in the peninsula, the loyal people and the Virginia rebels can form their own opinions. Every corps and column of the Virginia army is now active. The small body under FREMONT is doing excellent service in the mountains; BANKS is advancing; MCDOWELL is moving; MCCLELLAN is at work. Decisive results of these movements will now appear.

abstract: The telegraph has informed you of the surrender of Fork Pulaski, and the consequent state of excitement you can well imagine. abstract: The Norfolk Day Book, of April 15, states that a party of gentlemen left Norfolk on Saturday last, in the steamer S.S. Anderson, and proceeded down the river, in the course of the day going well over the enemy's lines in the direction of Newport's News, and alongside of Her Britannic Majesty's steamer Rinaldo. They were not permitted to go on board the Rinaldo, being informed that no communition could be held with them at all, at which the Day Book becomes very wroth, and thinks the South can afford to abstain from communication with England, especially as it receives no benefit from the Government. The "Yankees," the Day Book states, made no attempt to interfere with the pleasure excursion.

abstract: Editorial says success of North is due to its technical superiority
snippet: Editorial says success of North is due to its technical superiority
lead_paragraph: When it was found, upon the outbreak of the rebellion, that the traitor FLOYD, as Secretary of War, had, in view, of the event, almost completely stripped us of arms and present means of defence or aggression, we predicted that in one short year the inventive genius of the North would devise new ones so superior to the old that the latter would be comparatively worthless in the hands of the rebels, and utterly unable to contend with our new instruments of war. Never was a predictionmore truly fulfilled. Not only are our new creations overwhelming the South, but they constitute for the whole world an era in modern warfare as important as that which followed the invention of gunpowder. The little Monitor, which hardly shows her deck above the water's edge, and which carries but two guns, is, according to English authority, the most powerful and destructive vessel afloat. Assuming that she could not be made fast to, and perhaps captured in this way, she might bid defiance to all the wooden ships composing the British navy. A well-directed shot from one of her guns would send the largest of them to the bottom, while her iron plates would be impenetrable to any metal they could, as now armed, throw. The fight in Hampton Roads has been echoed around the world, and dates the commencement of an entirely new system of naval warfare and fortifications. All nations, as far as their previous armaments, preparations for defence, and naval forces, are concerned, are instantly reduced to a common level. All are equally impotent or equally powerful. Past supremacy and prestige go for nothing; while these in future are again to be contended for, unless by general consent nations, as they must sooner or later at a similar crisis, consent to treat each other as friends, instead of enemies bent on mutual destruction through modes so terrible and expensive that even the successful party may sink under the incredible burden imposed.
headline: {'main': 'The Success of the North Due to its Mechanical Superiority.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Success of the North Due to its Mechanical Superiority.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Capt. ELISHA G. MARSHALL of the regular army brother of the Rev. EDWARD C. MARSHALL, of this City, has been elected Colonel of the Thirteenth Regiment New-York Volunteers. He is a native of the State of New-Your, and a descendant from one of the pioneer settlers of Windsor, Conn., who killed in King PHILLIP's war in 1675. Col. MARSHALL is a graduate of the West Point Academy in the class of 1850, and was gazetted in army order in 1859, for gallant conduct in a battle with the Mohave Indians in California.

abstract: The Norfolk correspondent of the Petersburgh Express, under date of April 1, refers to the proclamation of the Governor calling everybody to the field, and not excepting farmers, as extremely unwise, and says that all the indications are that a famine will be the consequence. The whole section from [???] Anne to Norfolk is one vast wilderness -- not a plow in a field, and no steps taken to provide for the public necessities of another year. He also says the militiamen are being drilled each day, but they can render no service unless properly armed. If muskets are not allowed them, let them be armed with shot guns --a formidable weapon in proper hands.

abstract: -- The manifestations of loyalty yesterday in Baltimore, indicate the wonderful changes which have taken place in that city within the past year. The 19th day of April, 1861, was one of the gloomiest days for the nation during that whole gloomy year. The first blood spilt in this rebel war was shed on that day; and Baltimore saw the soldiers from Massachusetts, marching for the defence of the National capital, assaulted by a bloodthirsty secession mob, bent on preventing their passage over the only railroad that led to Washington. The city seemed to be possessed of the devil, so mad was it with unreasoning excitement, so furiously was it bent on blood. No man dared say he was for the Union; no one dared display the flag of the Republic; none could lift a voice against the howling fiends who were in the ascendancy. The civil authorities were paralyzed, and, indeed, some of them were instigators and abettors of the rebels; and it seemed at that time as though, before we could get to the Capital, Baltimore would have to be laid in ruins, and our volunteers would have to hew their way through Maryland with the sword. The wrath of the North was raised high against the rebel city, and the people were willing to pay any price for its humiliation. It was hardly possible to keep the citizens of Boston and New-York from rushing there en masse, ready to sell their lives at any price, so that the national honor be redeemed and the national flag avenged.

abstract: -- The evacuation of Jacksonville, Fla., is an unpleasant pendent to the capture of Pulaski, but was, no doubt, inevitable. The great error of Gen. SHERMAN's administration of the Department now controlled by Gen. HUNTER was the diffusion of his small force over too largo an area. His soldiers were spread all along the coast, from North Edisto Island to Jacksonville. Gen. HUNTER left Washington with an understanding that powerful reinforcements should follow him forthwith. It is, no doubt, because the engagement of the War Department has not been kept, that this calling in of the scattered regiments, and exposure of a Union population to the vengeance of implacable enemies, has been rendered necessary.

abstract: To Maj.-Gen. David Hunter, commanding Department of the South:  SIR: I have the honor to report the conclusion of the operations of the siege of Fort Pulaski, in Savannah River, Ga., which have resulted in the capture of that fortress and its armament, and the unconditional surrender of the effective force of the garrison, amounting to 361, of whom 24 were officers; beside about 18 who were sick or wounded.

abstract: RICHMOND, March 31. -- Dispatches received this evening report that the enemy is advancinc in force against the positions occupied by our army on the Rappahanuock. On Friday a party of the enemy's scouts crossed the river and encountered our pickets. A skirmish ensued, in which twenty-nine of the Yankees were captured. The prisoners were brought to Richmond to-night.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, March 31. -- Dispatches received this evening report that the enemy is advancinc in force against the positions occupied by our army on the Rappahanuock. On Friday a party of the enemy's scouts crossed the river and encountered our pickets. A skirmish ensued, in which twenty-nine of the Yankees were captured. The prisoners were brought to Richmond to-night.

abstract: The Managers of the Northeastern Dispensary, corner of Lexington-avenue and Fifty-first-street, are arranging to throw open their capacious and well-arranged building for a brief home to a few, say five hundred if necessary, of our brave officers and soldiers now on the field of battle from this State, who may become wounded or disabled.
lead_paragraph: The Managers of the Northeastern Dispensary, corner of Lexington-avenue and Fifty-first-street, are arranging to throw open their capacious and well-arranged building for a brief home to a few, say five hundred if necessary, of our brave officers and soldiers now on the field of battle from this State, who may become wounded or disabled. The regularmedical and surgical staff of this Dispensary, numbering in its list nearly all of our ablest physicians and surgeons, tender their constant services freely in this, cause, and intend on this occasion, should it require, to outdo all their former efforts. This is a creditable charity.

abstract: The Picayune of April 1 says: Our Mississippi fleet, yclept, a few months ago, the mosquito fleet, promises to be, before long, a tolerably respectable one. it will be seen, by referring to our advertisements, that four more gunboats, with marine engines and boilers, are to be built in this city. abstract: Editorial on reported Confederate retreats in Shenandoah Valley
snippet: Editorial on reported Confederate retreats in Shenandoah Valley
lead_paragraph: BANKS, is marching up the Valley of the Shenandoah with American rapidity. The rebel JACKSON, with his "Stone-wall Brigade," arc pushing along the same pleasant valley with rebel rapidity. Since the battle of Strasburgh, which the rebels claim as a great victory for their side, the "Stone-wall Brigade" has shown anything but the immobility which ought to characterize walls of stone. It ran from Strasburgh to Woodstock, flew from there to Edenburg, then a wended Mount Jackson, from whence it stepped to Rudd's Hill, and now we hear that it has descended from these altitudinous regions, gone to Sparta, in Rockingham County, left Sparta, and gone we know not where. Gen. BANKS follows very closely in its rear, and it is undoubtedly this which lends fleetness to its steps, That, indeed, is a fact which might make even a stone wall anxious to move on. It seems as if JACKSON, at his present rate of motion, would soon reach Staunton, toward which important point ho appears to be tending. Whether Gen. BANKS will follow him there we do not know. It is remarkable topographical fact that there is a railroad from Staunton Richmond.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to prevent frauds in laying out and opening streets in this City was ordered to a third reading; also the bill to provide for the construction of railroads in cities, and the bill to amend the law relative to the Superintendent of Poor and the Coroners of Kings County.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to prevent frauds in laying out and opening streets in this City was ordered to a third reading; also the bill to provide for the construction of railroads in cities, and the bill to amend the law relative to the Superintendent of Poor and the Coroners of Kings County. Among the bills passed was the one to amend the General Railroad Law; the one to amend the laws relating to Public Instruction; the one to provide for rebuilding certain locks on the Champlain Canal; the one to authorize the payment of certain claims for expenses in raising volunteers; and the one to amend the act relating to Jurors and Commissioner of Jurors in Kings County. The Metropolitan Health bill was then taken up and debated until the recess. The Police Commissioners were restored to the Commission, and a subsequent motion to strike them out again was defeated.

abstract: HOMICIDE ON SHIPBOARD. Yesterday morning Officer HOLLAND, of the Harbor Police, received instructions from Marshal MURRAY to board the ship John Jay, just arrived from India, and to arrest THOS. BREEK, CHARLES BROWN and FERDINAND DEMAROHI, alias Hernando de Markel, upon the charge of having caused the death of a sailor named FRANK VHNSEN, by violent means.
lead_paragraph: HOMICIDE ON SHIPBOARD. -- Yesterday morning Officer HOLLAND, of the Harbor Police, received instructions from Marshal MURRAY to board the ship John Jay, just arrived from India, and to arrest THOS. BREEK, CHARLES BROWN and FERDINAND DEMAROHI, alias Hernando de Markel, upon the charge of having caused the death of a sailor named FRANK VHNSEN, by violent means. An investigation of the affair, before Commissioner OSBORNE (before whom the parties were taken soon after being arrested) was asked by the accused, when it was shown that DEMARCHI was the only man engaged in causing the death of VENSEN. The accused was shipped about six months since, at Newburyport, Mass., as an ordinary seaman in the bark blondell, for a voyage to Singapore, Before their arrival at the destined port, the prisoner had a desperate quarrel with VENSEN, during which the latter was beaten in such a manner that he died soon after. The Captain and Mates of the vessel regard it as a murder, and immediately put DEMARCHI in [???]. Upon the arrival of the ship at Singapore, the American Consul ordered the prisoner to be sent to New-York by the first opportunity, and also that BROWN and BREEK should be sent as witnesses. The accused was committed to the Tombs to await the action of the grand Jury, und the two witnesses were sent to the House of Detention in Mulberry-street. DEMARCHI is the 21 years of age. He is quite prepossessing in his appearance and,for a common sailor, is extremely well-informed. he denies having committed the offence with which he is charged.

abstract: A curious debate occurred in the City Council of Nashville on Thursday last, with reference to Gov. JOHNSON'S requirement that the members, of the Board should take the oath of allegiance. Mr. RAINS said that he objected to take the oath on principle, and not because he was an enemy of the United States. The additions and explanations were what he objected to. He spoke in feeling and eloquent terms of the benefit obtained from the United States Government, and his advocacy of it throughout his life, and concluded by declining to take the oath.

abstract: To hasten the construction of iron-clad war steamers for the defence of the coast and harbors of the State, there is urgent need of white-oak timber. The authorities call on the planters to assist them in supplying this want at once. The timber should be from 8 to 14 inches square, and if brought to any water-course, or line of railroad, will be gladly received by the Government. Let each planter see to it that he contributes at least one piece of timber to the iron-clad steamer, and there will be abundance in our ship-yard.

abstract: Some months ago we used now and then to hear of captures of our vessels at sea by those few sea-robbers of the South which es- caped through the blockade.
lead_paragraph: Some months ago we used now and then to hear of captures of our vessels at sea by those few sea-robbers of the South which es- caped through the blockade. They were generally announced with the stereotyped formula, "The privateers at work again." It was an unwelcome sound then and it was unwelcome to hear it again brought to us by the late arrival from Europe. But there is a class of people who do more harm than privateers -- and though it is a bad thing to hear that the privateers are again astir, it is worse to know that the croakers are at work again. We would almost rather hear that the Merrimac had come out, than that the croakers had made their appearance. But the dealings of this class have been one of the most troublesome things of all that have harrassed and hindered us in our National work through the past year, and has had its origin in the impatience of the people. That American characteristic which assumes that everything can be done in twenty minutes, was never displayed in more provoking prominence. Nor do we seem to improve in this direction much either. One would say that looking over the past year and calculating the immense amount of work that has been done, and the great results which have been accomplished, every one would feel how causeless has been the impatience which at times during the year could hardly be repressed, and that every one would learn and feel that our leaders, whether in the Cabinet or in the field, have but the interests of the country at heart, and are not men who will sacrifice those great interests selfishly to their own little ones, or who will adopt any course of action but the one which seems to them best adapted to bring about the best results.

abstract: As CURTIS has displayed no further stomach for the fray since the battle of Elkhorn,(Pea Ridge,) the indefatigable VAN DORN has pushed forward to the Mississippi with all rapidity.
lead_paragraph: As CURTIS has displayed no further stomach for the fray since the battle of Elkhorn,(Pea Ridge,) the indefatigable VAN DORN has pushed forward to the Mississippi with all rapidity. His army is in good condition, much reinforced, and is concentrating at Jacksonport and Pocahontas, Gen. [???] THOMPSON is operating closely in connection with VAN DORN's army, and it is thought that some Federals in the neighborhood of New-Madrid may be hurt before long. Thus both sides are [???] all their power for the great and desperate struggle for the mastership of the Mississippi River and Valley.

abstract: Advices from Commodore FOOTE are to Friday last, at which time the bombardment of Fort Wright was still proceeding. The firing on the day previous had been very heavy on both sides. On Friday the firing was not so brisk. The enemy had done no damage to our flotilla whether they had suffered any from our fire was not known.
lead_paragraph: Advices from Commodore FOOTE are to Friday last, at which time the bombardment of Fort Wright was still proceeding. The firing on the day previous had been very heavy on both sides. On Friday the firing was not so brisk. The enemy had done no damage to our flotilla whether they had suffered any from our fire was not known. There appears to be no expectation of an immediate reduction of the Fort, as the present high stage of the water in the Mississippi prevents cooperation on the part of Gen. POPE's forces. Deserters say that the rebel batteries now mount forty guns, and that they have sixty more which they are rapidly putting in position. BRAGG, it appears, is in command, having succeeded VILLIPIQUE. He is said to have about six hundred troops, and has the cooperation of four gunboats, mounting twenty-four guns.

abstract: The City Tax Levy is in the hands of the New-York delegation in the Senate. As reported and passed in the Assembly, it was accompanied by a bill so amending the charter as to permit members of the Common Council to receive compensation for their services. The feeling was general in favor of such an amendment; but as the bill also provided that no Alderman should hold a County office at the same time, Alderman GENET's friends rallied against it, and prevented it from coming up for action. The clause allowing the payment of salaries may be inserted in the Senate, though this will depend mainly on the action of the Democrats from this City. The Republicans are in favor of paying the members a fair compensation for their services. The usual efforts are made to smuggle into the Tax Levy all kinds of swindles, but they ere closely watched and will not succeed.

abstract: HIGHER GRADES WANTED  IN THE NAVY. Gen. MITCHEL, the astronomersoldiler has resolved his single Brigadier star into the double star of the Major-General. Congress has done well in conferring the honor, for his gallant exploits richly merit it.
lead_paragraph: HIGHER GRADES WANTED IN THE NAVY. -- Gen. MITCHEL, the astronomersoldiler has resolved his single Brigadier star into the double star of the Major-General. Congress has done well in conferring the honor, for his gallant exploits richly merit it. His expedition is really one of the most brilliant and interesting episodes of the war; It has penetrated almost to the geographical centre of rebeldom. It "cuts the great artery" by which the rebels in the Southeast have communicated with the rebels in the Southwest. It enables us to threaten the rebel position at Corinth on the right, while HALLECK threatens it in front, and POPE, after taking Fort Pillow and Memphis, may threaten it on the left. But while Gen. MITCHEL has fairly won his honor, there is another man whose gallant exploits merit similar promotion, but who, from the imperfect organization of the arm of the service he has adorned, is cut off from receiving the reward which the whole country longs to see bestowed on him. We mean the gallant sailor, FOOTE, the hero of Fort Henry, Fort Donelson, Island Ten and Fort Pillow, who first organized victory on the Western waters, who cleared the rebellion out of three Western States, and who is now carrying the flag of the Union on its conquering course toward the Gulf. NOW FOOTE only ranks as Commander in the navy, a rank subordinate to that of Captain, which is the highest grade attainable by the American naval officer. Why for his magnificent services he has not been promoted this one possible, step, we are unable to conjecture. The slowness and stupor which seem to reign around Secretary WELLES are perhaps answerable. But having already earned this grade, what is there left for FOOTE and other equally active officers to gain by their future services? Nothing. A higher grade than Captain is the want of our navy; and there can be no better name for it than that known in the naval service of all European countries -- namely, Admiral, Even this grade is subdivided, in the English service, into various classes -- as Admiral of the White, Admiral of the Red, Admiral of the Blue. The gallant FOOTE should have a chance to become Admiral of the Red, White and Blue.

abstract: This day was celebrated inall of the Catholic and Episcopal churches in this City and Brooklyn yesterday, and allusions to the event of which it is me anniversary were made in the churches of all denominations. At Trinity Church the services opened with an Easter hymn, "Christ the Lord has risen to-day." Au anthem by CUTLER, with the chorus "O Jerusalem that bringest glad tidings to Zion, lift up thy voice, be not afraid," was delivered with great effect. At St. Francis Xavier Church, in Sixteenth-street, a new Mass by Mr. BERGE; composed for the occasion, was produced, and proved a rare musical treat. The Church of the Holy Trinity, in Brooklyn, was beautifully decorated, and a very large audience was in attendance. After the usual musical exercises, an eloquent sermon was preached by the Rector, Rev. Dr. LITTLEJOHN, from the following text: "As in Adam all die, even so in Christ shall all be made alive," &c. 1st Cor., xv. 22.

abstract: We see that the House of Representatives has taken another step in a path of needed reform, by the passage of the bill reported by the Judiciary Committee, amending the act establishing the Court of Claims. That Court was established some years since for the investigation of claims against the United
lead_paragraph: We see that the House of Representatives has taken another step in a path of needed reform, by the passage of the bill reported by the Judiciary Committee, amending the act establishing the Court of Claims. That Court was established some years since for the investigation of claims against the United States, but as its decisions were in no way binding upon the Government, and every case had to be again passed upon by Congress, it did not reach the difficulty which had led to its creation. The passage of the present amendatory act comes nearer to it, as far as we can learn its provisions. It declares that this Court is to have jurisdiction of all claims for which the Government would be liable in law or equity, if it could be sued in a Court of justice, except such claims as Congress may by joint resolution specially declare shall be disposed of by act of Congress or otherwise, and that the judgment of the Court shall be final, subject to the right of appeal.

abstract: The step taken by the Republicans and other Union members of the Legislature to secure unity of action and harmony of counsels at the coming State election, is one of very marked importance. The details of their proceedings have not yet been published, so that we can comment only on the general results attained. It seems to he understood
lead_paragraph: The step taken by the Republicans and other Union members of the Legislature to secure unity of action and harmony of counsels at the coming State election, is one of very marked importance. The details of their proceedings have not yet been published, so that we can comment only on the general results attained. It seems to he understood that they have adopted a common platform of principles, and have proclaimed their adherence to the same National policy -- not ignoring nor seeking in any degree to evade the responsibility of dealing with the subject of Slavery. If the vague reports which have reached the public are reliable, this platform is quite as decided and explicit as any one could desire.

abstract: Editorial holds Great Britain surprised by favorable condition of Union finances; Editorial urges promotion of Comdr. Foote for his victories; Editorial holds Great Britain surprised by favorable condition of Union finances
snippet: Editorial holds Great Britain surprised by favorable condition of Union finances; Editorial urges promotion of Comdr. Foote for his victories; Editorial holds Great Britain surprised by favorable condition of Union finances
lead_paragraph: Private mercantile and banking letters from Europe continue to express the utmost surprise at the steady and comfortable condition of financial affairs in this country, pending a great and costly civil war. The writers could see how the machine of Government, for the conduct of the war, might be kept in motion for a brief season longer by resort to a scheme of paper-money finance, as authorized by the recent act of Congress; but the end of this, they moat assuredly believed, would be early and irremedial ruin, in the great depreciation of United States Notes, and the rise to panic premiums in the market value of gold, in exchange for such paper. Such, to be sure, was not the universal opinion among the English merchants connected with the trade of this country, as many of them are too intimately acquainted with the wonderful elasticity and material resources of our people, to be misled either by the false theories of their own journals, or the over-confident predictions of certain bullionists on this side, who opposed the legal-tender clause of the Loan and Treasury bill. But the burden of apprehension, for weeks pending the discussion of the bill in Congress, and for some time after its final passage and approval by the President, was to the effect that the country was to be ruined by a paper inflation, and the war brought to an inglorious end by a paper-money panic. The contrary was soon apparent here, and already begins to be appreciated on the other side. The wonder indulged in London at the ease in our foreign exchanges, and the nominal premium of only one or two per cent. on gold, continues to grow with each revolving week, and is reflected back by almost every steamer.

abstract: With very little of preliminary promise or parade, Mr. GRAU burst upon us with a new opera season, which, so far as programme and performers are concerned, will undoubtedly bear favorable comparison with the Easter seasons of the few past years. Mr. GRAU does not enter largely into the bill-poster and imaginative advertising line of business, but he gives us the names of a sufficient number of reallyfirst-class artist, and falls back upon a repertory of such standard musical works as he knows will afford his patrons a more than reasonable average of entertainment and delight. He has been partially disappointed by the sudden illness of the new soprano who was to have been the sensation of his opening night; yet, undismayed, he brings forward a new tenor to the relief, and starts off with a vigor that augurs well for the future enterprise and energy wherewith he means to conduct this, his second managerial adventure of the Academy.

abstract: This is an Association of ladies, formed for the purpose of aiding, in such ways as may be necessary, young women, and others of their own sex, who are compelled to earn a livlihood, and yet have not the protection of parents or the safeguards of Christian homes. In carrying out their plans, they have kept
lead_paragraph: This is an Association of ladies, formed for the purpose of aiding, in such ways as may be necessary, young women, and others of their own sex, who are compelled to earn a livlihood, and yet have not the protection of parents or the safeguards of Christian homes. In carrying out their plans, they have kept up for two years a boarding-house, where special care has been taken to provide for the refining and elevating influences of a Christian family, in this particular, they have been most successful. From their last report, we learn that fifty young women a have been accommodated during the year. A clergyman and his wife have charge of the house, and every attention is paid to the comforts and religious interests of those who reside there. To young women coming to the City to engage in any of the branches of pursuit open to females, such a provision is of inestimable value. No one knows how many such have been lost to society and to themselves for the want of just such a house. There is not a more interesting and valuable class among us than the young women who are engaged as teachers in our public schools, clerks in stores, seamstresses, engravers, and apprentices in our millinery and mantua establishments; and yet there is no class more unprotected or less cared for. Many of these have to struggle with poverty -- with hardships of every kind -- and it is not surprising that under their manifold discouragements they yield to temptation, and throw themselves away. We are glad to find that the ladies of this Association are devoting themselves particularly to this class. Their boarding-house has been quite successful, and many young women have enjoyed its benefits during the year, and will bless God forever that such a home was provided for them. Instead of one, there should be twenty such boarding-houses in the City.

abstract: Final action will probably be had upon the Health bill in the State Senate to-day. Its passage is doubtful. It is compelled to encounter not only the open hostility of those Democrats, who are unwilling that their party should lose the benefit of the seventy or eighty sinecures of the City Inspector's office, but also the more unnatural and unaccountable opposition of a few Republicans, among whom is the Lieutenant-Governor and Mayor OPDYKE. We presume they have reasons, either personal or political, which satisfy them of the propriety of their action in thus sacrificing the most important measure to the health and cleanliness of this City, which has been presented to the Legislature within the last five years. Whether they will be equally satisfactory to the public at large, will appear when the appeal is taken.

abstract: Yesterday, CHARLES WOLFSBERGER, keeper of a disreputable house in Mott-street, was arrested by Officer GOLDEN, and taken before JUSTICE BRENNAN. He was charged with assaulting LAWRENCE LANGSTON, and then robbing him of a wallet containing $9, while in his house, on Saturday night. The accused was locked up.....HONORA GARNER, a girl of the town, was arrested yesterday, for stealing two $50 bills from CHARLES J. FEWLER.

abstract: The military situation at the mouth of the Mississippi becomes daily more and more intensely inter-  esting. The City of New-Orleans is virtually besieged by land, lake, and river; and as we hear of the fall of one fort, and the assault upon another, our anxiety increases for the news that the metropolis of the South is once again under the flag of the Union.
lead_paragraph: The military situation at the mouth of the Mississippi becomes daily more and more intensely inter- esting. The City of New-Orleans is virtually besieged by land, lake, and river; and as we hear of the fall of one fort, and the assault upon another, our anxiety increases for the news that the metropolis of the South is once again under the flag of the Union. The defences of the City, natural and artificial, now being assailed by our naval forces, have been described as of vast extent, and very formidable. But we have heretofore had no information of them, at once recent and authentic. The description we gave recently in the TIMES, was mostly taken from rebel newspapers, and it was evident that many of the statements were in the usual style of rebel exaggeration. We are enabled this morning to publish a correct sketch of the city and its defences, from a New-Orleans gentleman, derived from data obtained on the spot after the defences were essentially in the condition in which they will be found by Gen. BUTLER and Commodore PORTER. This evidence was submitted to the War and Navy Departments some time ago, and is now in the hands of our gallant commanders engaged in forcing the passes of the river.

abstract: In the Senate, on Saturday, the bill to prevent frauds in laying out and opening streets in this City was ordered to a third reading; also the bill to provide for the construction of railroads in cities, and the bill to amend the law relative to the Superintendent of Poor and the Coroners of Kings County. Among the bills passed was the
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, on Saturday, the bill to prevent frauds in laying out and opening streets in this City was ordered to a third reading; also the bill to provide for the construction of railroads in cities, and the bill to amend the law relative to the Superintendent of Poor and the Coroners of Kings County. Among the bills passed was the one to amend the General Railroad Law; the one to amend the laws relating to Public Instruction; the one to provide for rebuilding certain locks on the Champlain Canal; the one to authorize the payment of certain claims for expenses in raising volunteers; and the one to amend the act relating to Jurors and Commissioner of Jurors in Kings County. The Metropolitan Health bill was then taken up and debated until the recess. The Police Commissioners were restored to the Commission, and a subsequent motion to strike them out again was defeated. During the afternoon session the Supply bill was debated.

abstract: Gen. C.B. CONRAD, of Gilmer County, Virginia, is now in confinement in Wheeling, having been taken thither by National officers at Sutton, Brazton County, to whom he voluntarily surrendered himself a few days ago. He was a member of the Richmond Convention, which passed the ordinance of secession, and stood side by side with the best of the Union men of Northwestern Virginia, refusing at all times to vote for the ordinance. He returned home, however, and Gov. LETCHER made him a Brigadier-General. Since that time he has been recognized as a secessionist, but now he seems to have turned from the error of his ways.

abstract: We publish in another column a letter from Hon. GREENE C. BRONSON, Counsel to the Corporation, sent in to the Assembly some days since, in reply to the imputations cast upon him in the report of a Committee appointed last year to investigate the subject of street openings. That report was apparently intended quite as much to inculpate this officer as to expose the abuses which unquestionably abound in this department of our City affairs. Judge BRONSON does not enter into the general subject at all, but denies explicitly some of the most serious of the imputations cast upon his official conduct. As we published the original report, we publish also his reply, which has been ordered by the Assembly to be printed with the farmer document.

abstract: We give place in another column to a remarkable letter from Judge MCCUNN. The writer is evidently convinced that his judicial eccentricities need the assistance of note and comment, and it will be seen he dogmatizes about his rum-selling dicta as if they were as sound law as COKE upon LYTTLETON. We can forgive this enlightened magistrate. His opinion is his own, and is likely to be so; and he may surely be indulged in partiality for a possession which none can possibly share.

abstract: Three years ago, a consolidation of the Sixth and Seventh avenue Dutch Reformed churches took place, since which time they have been presided over by Rev. J.C. DUTCHEE, with the popular prefix of Union. The school numbers two hundred and ten pupils, and is of thirty years standing. Regular monthly meetings are held in order to advance the
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, a consolidation of the Sixth and Seventh avenue Dutch Reformed churches took place, since which time they have been presided over by Rev. J.C. DUTCHEE, with the popular prefix of Union. The school numbers two hundred and ten pupils, and is of thirty years standing. Regular monthly meetings are held in order to advance the mission cause in the West, and they have also contributed to the more immediate borne missions -- as, for instance, the "Howard Home for Little Wanderers" in the Fourth Ward, as well as sending prayer books to the camps. The anniversary of last evening was their third since the Union took place, and was highly esteemed as a medium of good fellowship, if one could judge by the crowded aisles and gallery. Original hymns were sung, and fifty prizes awarded, in the shape of books prettily bound and filled with wisely told tales, to the deserving student and exemplary attendant. The library contains 527 volumes. A very interesting infant class is formed numbering 56 pupils.

abstract: A severe rain-storm last night interfered seriously with telegraphing in every direction, and very little news from any of our armies in the field had reached us up to 2 o'clock this morning. Our latest advices form Yorktown indicate that the siege operations were progressing as rapidly as possible, and that the great struggle will soon commence.
lead_paragraph: A severe rain-storm last night interfered seriously with telegraphing in every direction, and very little news from any of our armies in the field had reached us up to 2 o'clock this morning. Our latest advices form Yorktown indicate that the siege operations were progressing as rapidly as possible, and that the great struggle will soon commence. A dispatch from Gen. BANKS' command, dated Sparta, Sunday, states that everything was quiet in front. A cavalry reconnoisance had penetrated the valley several miles toward Harrisburgh, and found plenty of forage and fresh provisions, but no enemy. JACKSON's advance was then at McGaugheystown, east of Harrisburgh, in full retreat, ASHBY's command still forming the rear guard. No further news from Fredericksburgh has been allowed to come through by the War Department.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. A Well-known opera at the commencement of a new season, when seasons in opera have been as plentiful and as brief as they have lately been, ordinarily presents but little to notice or to criticise. We may perhaps say that the house was crowded it will generally be so on the...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- A Well-known opera at the commencement of a new season, when seasons in opera have been as plentiful and as brief as they have lately been, ordinarily presents but little to notice or to criticise. We may perhaps say that the house was crowded it will generally be so on the first night of a new season, unless the elements render this a matter of impossibility; we may possibly discover that the orchestra and chorus were a trifle stronger or a trifle weaker, better or worse, than they have usually been; and then with a brief compliment to the management and the artists we have previously known, or possibly the reverse, the business is ended. However, in the present instance, it is not in this manner than we can dispose of it. Last night Mr. GRAU, in commencing his thirteenth or fourteenth season, 1861-'62 -- we believe we are right, and apologize to our readers should we have made a computative error -- presented to his patrons a well-known opera; but with it, be gave us our old friend D'ANGRI as Magdalena, for the first time in three years -- the some two years since favorite of New-York, FERRI, in his fine part of Rigoletto -- a new tenore who has never previously appeared in this country, and offered us as conductor an old acquaintance who, however singularly he may conduct German opera, is never at fault with the composers of his own country, and may certainly lay claim to be considered the best Italian conductor we have ever had here; we allude to Signor MUZIO. Such a dish of novelty, actual and comparative, is rarely placed before the musical epicure, and most certainly has never been in so brief a season as the present one -- it is a season only of three nights. We should consequently be induced in any case to award Mr. GRAU the most liberal praise, even if his first night had been a comparative fiasco. It was very far from being so, and we may fairly say that if this was to be the invariable style of commencement for a brief season, we should be disposed to say the briefer the better, and might wish for a new one in every week of the musical year -- that part of it which lies between the commencement of October and the end or May.

abstract: Editorial on war in eastern Virginia
snippet: Editorial on war in eastern Virginia
lead_paragraph: While the forces of Gen. McCLELLAN and those of JOHNSTON are face to face on the old battle-ground of Yorktown, the principal actors in a stupendous drama, it is worth while to note carefully the secondary characters and the by-play, which throw forward upon the forthcoming denouement much helpful light. There is little doubt that Gen. JOHNSTON opposes to the disciplined force of the Union General a force numerically its equal; and secured behind intrenchments and guns of the hugest magnitude. But there is every reason to believe that a very considerable proportion of Gen. JOHNSTON's army consists of raw recruits, the products of the recent conscription, men more apt at handling the tool of the mechanic or plowman than the weapon of the soldier, and whose reluctant coming to the field, and novice fears will insure their speedy flight when battle is fairly afoot. And to get this unseasoned army, the whole of Eastern Virginia has been drained. Beyond the handful of troops in the valley, the relics of the Western Virginian army on the one hand and of Gen. JACKSON's depleted and retreating army on the other, there is probably no mentionable aggregation of rebel troops anywhere away from the Yorktown peninsula. The enemy has massed his entire strength there, there to decide the fate immediately of Virginia, and, in the event, of the insurgent Government and cause throughout the entire South.
headline: {'main': 'The Last Scene in Eastern Virginia.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Last Scene in Eastern Virginia.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- Should theLegislature fail of its duty in regard to the physical health of the City, what it has done for its moral hygiene may be received as some atonement. The Concert Saloon Bill is a law, and Concert Saloons, with their mirth and meretriciousness, lubricity, drunkenness and multiform indecency, are things of the unsavory past. And the age of Pretty-Waiter-Galism being over, we hope the Police may be trusted with seeing that the law is thoroughly executed, and the nuisance finally quelled. Ingenuity will be taxed to suggest evasions and safe defiances of the law. Magistrates of a very common sort will demonstrate their love of order and decency by explaining the act so as to permit the continuance of the practice, with trifling modifications; or, by declaring the law unconstitutional. But if the Police Department prosecute the subject with the ardor it throws into its warfare upon the gamblers, and something more than the zeal it devotes to the prevention of Sunday dram-selling, it will presently rally public opinion to its support, and drive a debauched Magistracy from the bench. Thus a double benefit will come from the good deed of the Legislature.

abstract: Editorial on negotiations in progress with Great Britain for anti-slavery treaty
snippet: Editorial on negotiations in progress with Great Britain for anti-slavery treaty
lead_paragraph: The execution of GORDON, last February, was a warning to all engaged in that abominable pursuit, that the man who now occupies the Presidential chair will not allow them, if caught, to escape with impunity. It was a demonstration to Europe that the party now in office have no sympathy for such offenders, and do not fear to enforce the law against any who violate it. But our first Magistrate has not been content with merely giving to the world the foregoing proof of his firmness and sincerity. More recently, in order to evince to Great Britain how earnestly he desires to cooperate with her for the annihilation of the Slave-trade, he authorized Mr. SEWARD to negotiate a new Treaty, to that effect, with Lord LYONS. The response of the British representative to the proposition of the Sacretary of State was prompt and cordial in the extreme. He stated that it was the ardent wish of Her Majesty's Government to act in concert will the President of the United States for the attainment of the object contemplated; assured Mr. S. that the English Government was fully convinced that the cooperation of the American Republic was indispensable to success; and expressed his readiness to enter at once on the negotiation in question. What was a labor of love to both diplomats did not require much time for completion; the new treaty was signed by Lord LYONS and Mr. SEWARD on the 7th inst.; and, immediately after, was submitted to the consideration of the Senate's Committee of Foreign Relations, who have reported favorably upon it. As the text has not yet been published, we cannot judge of the merits of the instrument; but it is said that, if its provisions be faithfully carried out, the odious commerce against which it is directed, will cease to exist within ten years. Should such, however, not be the case, another and more stringent treaty is to be substituted for the present one, and the efforts of the two Governments are not to be relaxed, till the iniquity has been eradicated.

abstract: THE CONCERT SALOONS AND THE POLICE. It was generally expected last night, that the Metropolitan Police, under the direction of Superintendent KENNEDY, would make a general onslaught upon all the Concert Saloons in the City. Owing, however, to ...
lead_paragraph: THE CONCERT SALOONS AND THE POLICE. It was generally expected last night, that the Metropolitan Police, under the direction of Superintendent KENNEDY, would make a general onslaught upon all the Concert Saloons in the City. Owing, however, to the fact, that the Superintendent had not received a copy of the bill, as passed by the Legislature which provides for the summary abolition of these places of amusement, he decided to defer the movement for a day or two, and in the meantime, the proprietors of the Saloons will receive a proper notice to close up their business without delay. Unless they do this, it is the intention of the authorities to enforce the law, as they understand it, without fear or favor.

abstract: diagram of McDowell movements against Fredericksburg
snippet: diagram of McDowell movements against Fredericksburg
lead_paragraph: The City of Fredericksburgh, Spottsylvania County, a position to which a large body of the rebels from the Potomac and from Manassas lately fell back and of which we herewith give a map from actual survey, together with a part of the rebel position, as it existed ten days ago, is situated in a fertile valley,on the south side of the Rappahannock River, fifty-six miles from Washington, and sixty-two from Richmond, on the line of the Great Southern Railroad. It is at the head of tide water, about a hundred and fifty miles from its mouth. The Rappahannock is navigableonly for vessels of 140 tons to the Falls, a short distance above the town.

abstract: Capt. JAMES L. WAUGH, in command of Company H, of this Regiment, now stationed at Newport's News, is in the City for a few days, having with great difficulty obtained a brief furlough, for the purpose of visiting a son, dangerously sick. He will, he requests us to say, be happy to bear letters or small packages, addressed to any member of his company, or of the Regiment, if left at his residence, No. 112 Franklin-street. Capt. WAUGH is well known in military circles as the commander of the famous "Tompkins Blues," when that company was unapproached in drill or discipline by any in the City; and, having carried into the field of active operations all his military instincts and experience, he will doubtless prove that he is quite able to win, in war, the laurels he has so long worn in peace.

abstract: --The success of the expedition to Apalachicola, announced in the TIMES a fortnight ago, was a foregone conclusion. The place had never been held by rebel regulars. The militia had thrown up some embankments, without designing them for anything more than shams; and had been prepared for flight at the first appearance of a National gunboat off the town. Lieut. STELLWAGGON had nothing to do but land and possess himself of an unarmed town.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a petition was presented from free colored citizens of the United States, praying for colonization in Central America if possible. Memorials were presented for a ship ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a petition was presented from free colored citizens of the United States, praying for colonization in Central America if possible. Memorials were presented for a ship canal from Lake Michigan to the Mississippi River. Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, offered a resolution asking information of the Secretary of State relative to the arrest of citizens of his State, and their confinement in forts, camps and prisons. It was objected to, and laid over under the rule. The resolution relative to the arrest of Gen. STONE was then taken up, and Mr. MCDOUGALL, of California, made another speech, in which he assailed the course of the Committee on the Conduct of the War. Mr. WADE, of Ohio, replied in vindication of the Committee, and justifying Gen. STONE's arrest. The debate was long and animated, being participated in by several other Senators. Finally, Mr. MCDOUGALL consented to accept Mr. WILSON's substitute, calling upon the President, if not incompatible with the public interests, to furnish all the information relative to the arrest and imprisonment of Gen. STONE, and it was passed. The Senate then went into Executive Session, and afterward adjourned.

abstract: -- It is to be lamentedthat Gen. BURNSIDE is to be withheld from active participation in the Summer campaign. His exploits in North Carolina have illustrated his invaluable skill and steadiness as a General; and have proved the irresistible intrepidity of his troops. Why such a leader and such an army should spend their time in fortifying Newbern and shelling out Fort Macon, when there are railroads to be seized and secured, and Norfolk to be attacked, is one of those military mysteries commended to the solvent of such puzzles, the Committee on the Conduct of the War. It passes the understanding of the inexpert.

abstract: Bushnell Stevens vs. Gideon Palmer. This was an action to recover possession of certain premises in Forty-sixth-street, in this City, being part of the farm formerly owned by John W. Morton, and known as ....
lead_paragraph: Bushnell Stevens vs. Gideon Palmer. -- This was an action to recover possession of certain premises in Forty-sixth-street, in this City, being part of the farm formerly owned by John W. Morton, and known as the "Hermitage," the plaintiff claiming to be the original owner, and that the defendant has no title. The defendant set up a general denial, and alleged that he obtained a good and sufficient title to the premises under a sale thereof by the Comptroller, for taxes, made in 1846.

abstract: -- Mr. ASHLEY, from the House Territorial Committee, some time since reported a bill for the organization of Arizona. It is sincerely to be hoped Congress will not adjourn without making the bill an act. Arizona is peculiarly the property of the North. Its mines have been explored and partially developed by northern men, employed by northern capital. Since the war commenced it has been in the possession of the rebels, and the great line of communication between the Atlantic and Pacific has been sundered. Recently it has become the seat of an active immigration. All the rebellious and disaffected, from California and Western Texas, have congregated there upon the Mexican frontier, ready for the execution of extensive fillibuster attempts upon Mexico. The opening of hostilities between the allied European Powers and the Mexicans, will no doubt be the signal of an irresistible invasion of these wretches from the North, who will take possession of the fairest territory along the Gulf of California and the Pacific. Government has duties to perform toward its own subjects, as well as to its allies. It has no right to withhold the exercise of its power in restoring property to its wronged owners; it has no right to leave Mexico exposed to the mischievous effects of our own inactivity or carelessness. Arizona should therefore be cleared of these desperadoes; Union men should be placed in possession of their own; and the cloud which hangs on the northern horizon of Mexico should be dissipated. And the first indispensable step in the fulfillment of these duties is the erection of Arizona into a National Territory. Congress, with a causeless haste, unknown before Congressmen were paid a yearly salary irrespective of the length of the session, is preparing to shove the business of the Spring over to the Winter. This Arizona bill should not must not, be thus disposed of.

abstract: Editorial on Union progress towards reconstruction of captured areas
snippet: Editorial on Union progress towards reconstruction of captured areas
lead_paragraph: It is easy to foment, and often easy to subdue a rebellion, but the rarest thing in the world for a Government, in achieving its triumph, is to maintain its paternal character, and reclaim the erring members, not by severity, but by humane and forhearing treatment; and by patient and methodical labor, but in perfect harmony with law, to seek gradually to remove the causes of the past differences, and reconstruct Government upon the solid foundation of unity in interest and ideas. This is a sublime spectacle, and, for that reason, all the more unintelligible to those who have reviled because they hated us, and who desired to chronicle the complete failure of the great experiment of humanity in America, which was in its best days, and is again destined to be a rebuke to the corruptions of the Old World, and be the source of unrest and change until everywhere a perfect harmony shall exist between Government and institutions and the welfare of the people. That a people of our own blood in the Old World should hail with such delight our assumed fall, has been the most striking scene in the grand drama. The impotence of our Government -- the rottenness of our institutions -- the demoralization of our people, and the utter impossibility of restoring the previous political status which promised so much in its inception, but which all enemies of social equality had assumed to be a contemptible failure, was proclaimed far and wide. The London Times was the chief trumpeter of our disastrous fall; but its intense earnestness was only the reflected satisfaction of the great body of the people.
headline: {'main': 'Our Progress toward Reconstruction.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Progress toward Reconstruction.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: JEFF. DAVIS announced to the rebel Congress the winning of a "great and glorious victory" in the battle at Pittsburgh Landing, in advance, as he told them, of the receipt of official reports. He would have done better to have waited until the official reports came in. He would then have been saved the shame which even he could hardly help feeling at learning that he had exulted over a victory where he had met with defeat, and that the very soldiers whom he had announced as endeavoring to make their escape in their transports, had driven his, as he supposed, victorious troops from the field so speedily as to leave behind them, in addition to cannon, ammunition and supplies, the body of their General, whose death he announced in the same lying message. A lying message, indeed, but it contained one truth. He tells them, "There is enough to chasten our exultation in the continued presence of invaders on our soil." And we quite agree with him; although he said what was far truer than he probably knew at the time. If the repulse of that army under their three best Generals, with the loss of their Commander-in-Chief, the shutting up of the remains of it within its intrenchments, compelling its leader to ask for leave to bury his dead, and the progress of the "invaders" upon their soil, so as to cut off its railroad communication with the rebel Capital, while at the Northwest Island No. 10, with all its stores and its thousands of prisoners, had fallen into the hands of those invaders, who were also at that moment rapidly placing in position the terrible rifled guns which breached the walls of Pulaski, deemed till then impregnable; if all these circumstances were not enough to "chasten" any exultation the rebels might feel, they must have far more of the Mark Tapley element in them than we have given them credit for.
lead_paragraph: JEFF. DAVIS announced to the rebel Congress the winning of a "great and glorious victory" in the battle at Pittsburgh Landing, in advance, as he told them, of the receipt of official reports. He would have done better to have waited until the official reports came in. A lying message, indeed, but it contained one truth. He tells them, "There is enough to chasten our exultation in the continued presence of invaders on our soil." And we quite agree with him; although he said what was far truer than he probably knew at the time. If the repulse of that army under their three best Generals, with the loss of their Commander-in-Chief, the shutting up of the remains of it within its intrenchments, compelling its leader to ask for leave to bury his dead, and the progress of the "invaders" upon their soil, so as to cut off its railroad communication with the rebel Capital, while at the Northwest Island No. 10, with all its stores and its thousands of prisoners, had fallen into the hands of those invaders, who were also at that moment rapidly placing in position the terrible rifled guns which breached the walls of Pulaski, deemed till then impregnable; if all these circumstances were not enough to "chasten" any exultation the rebels might feel, they must have far more of the Mark Tapley element in them than we have given them credit for.

abstract: THE WATER RATES THE TEMPORARY CLOSING OF A STREET TO FACILITATE THE OPERATIONS OF GOVERNMENT. A regular weekly meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, and in the absence of the President of the Board, Alderman WOOD, Alderman O'KEETE of the Twelfth Ward was called to preside. Immediately after approving
lead_paragraph: THE WATER RATES -- THE TEMPORARY CLOSING OF A STREET TO FACILITATE THE OPERATIONS OF GOVERNMENT. A regular weekly meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, and in the absence of the President of the Board, Alderman WOOD, Alderman O'KEETE of the Twelfth Ward was called to preside. Immediately after approving the minutes, under a special order, the communication of the Board of Water Commissioners, recommending water rates, was taken up for consideration. This matter was under discussion for nearly two hours and was finally adopted as presented, with the single exception of Section 11, under "special rates," the charge for "cart and other work horses," was amended so as to read "$1 each," instead of "$1 50 each," as recommended by the Commissioners. This was reduced because it was deemed unnecessarily high and oppressive to the poorer classes. The general rates for dwellings are arranged upon a basis of three cents for each one hundred gallons of water used. Under "special rates," which includes business places where a large quantity of water is used, the basis of estimate is at two and a half cents per hundred gallons.
