abstract: Davis vs. Hackley, et al. -- This case came before the Court according to adjournment. Messrs. Clark and Bunnell moved to dissolve the injunction on affidavits of Anthony S. and Thomas Hope, and also of Mr. Bliss and Mr. Yelverton, to show that the day after the contract for cleaning the streets was awarded to Mr. Hackley, an agreement was made by which each of the Hopes was to have one-fourth of the profits for cleaning the streets, Mr. Hackley one-fourth, and Hon. Benjamin Wood one-fourth; that at that time Mr. Wood was in Washington, and Mr. Davis' name was inserted in place of Wood's, although he had no interest in the agreement, and that he never had any interest in it. That the Hopes, on the 15th day or June, transferred their interest In the contract to Bliss & Yelverton, who agreed to compensate them for the $40,000 advanced and all other moneys since advanced by them. Mr. Garvin read an affidavit of Mr. Hackley to show that Ben. Wood had told him that he had relinquished all claims whatever under the agreement, and had "torn the agreement in pieces" Mr. James, offered to read affidavits of Mr. Benjamin Wood, and Mr. Davis, and also of a clerk in Fernando Wood's office, explaining the affidavits read by the defendants, as well as to explain what was done with the $10,000. Counsol for defendant objected to the reading of the affidavits, on the ground that on the return of an order to show cause in a case like this, new affidavits could not be read by the party who obtained the order. Judge BARNARD said that he would consult with the other judges of this Court in relation to the question, and decide it this morning at 11 o'clock, to which hour the Court adjourned.
lead_paragraph: Davis vs. Hackley, et al. -- This case came before the Court according to adjournment. Messrs. Clark and Bunnell moved to dissolve the injunction on affidavits of Anthony S. and Thomas Hope, and also of Mr. Bliss and Mr. Yelverton, to show that the day after the contract for cleaning the streets was awarded to Mr. Hackley, an agreement was made by which each of the Hopes was to have one-fourth of the profits for cleaning the streets, Mr. Hackley one-fourth, and Hon. Benjamin Wood one-fourth; that at that time Mr. Wood was in Washington, and Mr. Davis' name was inserted in place of Wood's, although he had no interest in the agreement, and that he never had any interest in it. That the Hopes, on the 15th day or June, transferred their interest In the contract to Bliss & Yelverton, who agreed to compensate them for the $40,000 advanced and all other moneys since advanced by them. Mr. Garvin read an affidavit of Mr. Hackley to show that Ben. Wood had told him that he had relinquished all claims whatever under the agreement, and had "torn the agreement in pieces" Mr. James, offered to read affidavits of Mr. Benjamin Wood, and Mr. Davis, and also of a clerk in Fernando Wood's office, explaining the affidavits read by the defendants, as well as to explain what was done with the $10,000. Counsol for defendant objected to the reading of the affidavits, on the ground that on the return of an order to show cause in a case like this, new affidavits could not be read by the party who obtained the order. Judge BARNARD said that he would consult with the other judges of this Court in relation to the question, and decide it this morning at 11 o'clock, to which hour the Court adjourned.

abstract: Much curiosity has been expressed at the inactivity of the Monitor and other agencies arranged by Government for the destruction of the Merrimac, when the latter vessel defied them the other day in Hampton Roads. We have reason to know that the fault is not with the officers of the National vessels. They Were confident of their ability to sink the monster; and all hands chafed at the disgraceful position in which they wore placed, while the enemy insultingly dared them to conflict, and captured the shipping of loyal owners undisturbed. But the barrier to action could not be surmounted. The Secretary of the Navy had given strict orders for them not to move or discharge a gun, unless the Merrimac attacked them. We presume there is no doubt of the Secretary's loyalty. Is he mad?

abstract: Although the tendency of the securities of Government have been steadily, though gradually upward, we do not look forward to an advance to the rates which they maintained for so many years, till the result of the rebellion is distinctly seen, for two reasons -- the uncertainty which exists us to the amount of bonds which may have have to be issued, and the unwillingness which naturally prevails to invest, till the result of the contest is proved to a demonstration. No matter now probable this may be, there is always a large class who will await the event. Still there is every reason to expect a gradual appreciation, to keep pace with the successes of our arms, and with the increasing supply of money.

abstract: THE OPERA IN BROOKLYN. -- Last night, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Mr. GRAU's troupe gave "La Favorita" with the same cast as that at the Academy in this City. For a variety of reasons the house was exceedingly slim, but in quality made up what it lacked in quantity, owing to the desire on the part of many to hear D'ANGRI in "Leonora." D'ANGRI never looked, acted or sang better; BRIGNOLI was hoarse, but in capital humor; Final and SUSINI did more than well, and the performance was a success.

abstract: But there are inland triumphs which we are not able to parallel. In countries which is our days were but mere wilderness there are fights and defeats.
lead_paragraph: But there are inland triumphs which we are not able to parallel. In countries which is our days were but mere wilderness there are fights and defeats. There are desultory contests even so far off as New-Mexico, and the savages and backwoodsmen are gratifying their natural hatreds under the name of a new cause. But the Federals are fighting their way down the Mississippi just as they are making incuisions from the coast, and the doubtful attack we hear of near Memphis is one in which again their naval supremacy and their superior resources give them a right to victory. The last new land victory, however, startles us rather by its locality than by its magnitude.While we hear of Federal successes in distant States it seems that it has been necessary to resist an attack and to defeat a Confederate army even in the northeast of Virginia and on the banks of the Potomac. There is a great deal of Confederate American soil which does not lie upon the sea-coast, or upon the banks of great navigable rivers, and, if the Southerners are in earnest not to be conquered, the Northerners must do more than keep within reach of their gunboats. This is what the army of the Potomac is now about to attempt. In addition to the vasious expeditions which are creating diversions from the sea upon the east, and from the rivers on the west, Gen. MCCLELLAN is now advancing with an army of 80,000 infantry, 4,000 cavalry, and 180 guns. This is the result of all the energies of the North, and of all the mountain of debt which has been piled up. To clothe and pay and discipline these troops, and to provide them with the best arms which the world can yield, is the great achievement of the last ten mouths. We are now to see what this army will effect. Nothing in the South ought to be be to withstand it. It ought to march on till it finds an enemy, and to crush him wherever it finds him. All the armories of Europe have been open to the invaders -- every means of supply has been closed to the invaded. If they do not now succeed, they never can. They are a fully armed and disciplined host against an insurgent population. The state of that army, as it is described by our correspondent, represents the advantages of money and credit, and the command of the sea. Yet the contest is not over, not the victory [???] A Washington of a Wellington might [???] give victory to [???] side. Up to time, the [???] has produce no strategic[???] There has been no [???] no aggressive enterprise, no brilliant handling of troops, no prompt improvement of successes on either side. The Generals seem to have no faith either in themselves or in their men and if they get the better in a skirmish, they seem satisfied with what they have done, and glad they are well out of it. This is war as war is carried on by commonplace cautious officers; but such a war is the opportunity of a man It is time for him to appear if he anywhere exists, We shall see whether he can be produced between Manassas and Richmond.

abstract: Current scene
snippet: Current scene
lead_paragraph: It is stated that on the 10th inst., by order of his Majesty, a Commission composed of the highest Generals in the service would meet to consider the possibility of effecting a further reduction of the Military Budget. Gen. WRANGEL would preside. In the approaching meeting of the Chambers several bills upon changes in the tariff may be expected. It is also the intention of Government to repeal the taxes upon corn, and a considerable reduction of import duties upon rice, cattle and meat, and also on mining productions, the latter to consist of a reduction of 1 per cent, annually for the next three years, in order to support the iron trade against foreign competition. A proposal is also under discussion to increase the price of salt to its former rate, for the purpose of raising a fund to be devoted to the augmentation of the Prussian fleet.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Harbormasters bill was reported complete, and ordered to a third reading. The Judiciary Committee reported that they would not have time during the present session to act upon the Assembly Assessment bill.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the Harbormasters bill was reported complete, and ordered to a third reading. The Judiciary Committee reported that they would not have time during the present session to act upon the Assembly Assessment bill. Bills were passed -- to incorporate the Union Home School for the children of volunteers; to provide for the consolidation of telegraph companies; to encourage the investment of small sums in State stocks, and for the preservation of moose, deer, fish, etc. The report of the Conference Committee on the Congressional Apportionment bill was considered, and after some debate it was agreed to, 19 to 8. The bill to provide pay, subsistence, etc., for the volunteers, was passed. A bill was also passed to establish bulkheads and pier lines for the port of New-York.

abstract: THE "FRENCH LADY" ATTEMPTS TO ESCAPE.  On Monday night, THOMAS, who is better known as the "French Lady," for having passed out of Baltimore in woman's attire, last Summer, attempted to escape from the hospitable mansion of Col. BURKE, near Fort Hamilton. It is said that he obtained a
lead_paragraph: THE "FRENCH LADY" ATTEMPTS TO ESCAPE. -- On Monday night, THOMAS, who is better known as the "French Lady," for having passed out of Baltimore in woman's attire, last Summer, attempted to escape from the hospitable mansion of Col. BURKE, near Fort Hamilton. It is said that he obtained a number of tin canteens, and corking them tightly, used them as buoys in an attempt to swim beyond the immediate jurisdiction of those who look after his welfare at Fort Lafayette. A sentinel discovered an object floating in the water, an alarm was given, a boat launched and Mr. THOMAS was again restored to terra firma and Government rations.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a report was made from the Select Committee on the case of Senator STARKE, or Oregon, to the effect that Mr. STARKE is disloyal to the Government. Mr. AN
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a report was made from the Select Committee on the case of Senator STARKE, or Oregon, to the effect that Mr. STARKE is disloyal to the Government. Mr. ANTHONY, of Rhode Island, presented a resolution calling upon the President for documents relating to Gen. SHERMAN, and his connection with the Department of the South. Mr. ANTHONY explained that he wished to prove that the credit of taking Fort Pulaski belonged to Gen. SHERMAN, and that if he had not taken Savannah it was because he had acted in accordance with orders. The bill for the establishment of a Department of Agriculture was briefly considered, but gave way for the Confiscation bill; and Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, occupied the remainder of the session in a speech against its passage. He had not concluded when the Senate went into Executive Session.

abstract: George E. Mendurn vs. Maltby G. Lane. On the 27th of September, 1860, as claimed, the plaintiff offered for sale five lots on 131st and 132d sts., Hariem. At that time there were two buildings upon the lots, and they were sold at auction to the defend- ant at $710 each, without any reservation of the build- ings at the time of the sale, as alleged lby the defendant. It subsequently appeared, however,that the plain-
lead_paragraph: George E. Mendurn vs. Maltby G. Lane. -- On the 27th of September, 1860, as claimed, the plaintiff offered for sale five lots on 131st and 132d sts., Hariem. At that time there were two buildings upon the lots, and they were sold at auction to the defend- ant at $710 each, without any reservation of the build- ings at the time of the sale, as alleged lby the defendant. It subsequently appeared, however,that the plaintiff had, before the auction sale, sold the buildings to one Fitzpatrick, who, before the time mentioned at the sale for the delivery of the deed, removed the buildings. The defendant thereupon refused to complete the purchase, unless the premises were put in the condition they were at the time of the auction sale. This action was therefore brought to compel a specific performance on his part.

abstract: Dr. WILLIAM A. HAMMOND, who had just been appointed Surgeon-General of the Army, was burn in Maryland, but his family have long resided in Pennsylvania. He formerly held an Assistant-Surgeon's commission in the army. He distinguished himself in various ways, and his contributions to medical and surgical science, the results of close study, active practice and remarkable experiments, have made his name well known to the Profession in Europe as will as in this country. In the year 1860, he resigned from the army: but since the war broke out, he has been serving as a Surgeon in a volunteer regiment.

lead_paragraph: The Moniteur publishes a circular addressed by Count PERSIONY to the Prefects, which states that 766 Conferences of the Society of St. Vincent de Paul have each declared in favor of acting independently of one another, and that 88 Conferences have accepted the General Council, under the Presidency of a high dignitary of the Church. Count PERSIONY states that, as the question of organization has been definitely settled by the Conference, and the legal existence of the Society admitted by an Imperial decree, each of the Conferences of the Society will henceforth exist independently of each other, and have no connecting central tie. Count PERSIGNY, then alluding to a letter of M. BANDON, in which that gentleman asserted that he would preserve the centralizing power of the Society, says that this would he an infraction of the laws which would not be permitted by the Government.

abstract: The mission of M. MERCIER, the Ambassador of the Emperor NAPOLEON, to the rebel Capital, has given wide room for speculation on the part of journalists, both National and traitor. While every movement of the rep
lead_paragraph: The mission of M. MERCIER, the Ambassador of the Emperor NAPOLEON, to the rebel Capital, has given wide room for speculation on the part of journalists, both National and traitor. While every movement of the representative of so powerful a friend or enemy as the French nation, is sufficient to awaken a laudable interest, it is vain to speculate beyond what the special facts involved in the commercial relations of the United States and France may rationally warrant. These afford quite an instructive field for consideration, and lead to the conclusion that there is at least one other product of the United States beside cotton which deeply and, it would appear, vitally interests some of our transatlantic cousins and allies. The telegraph informs us that rebel speculatists mainly associate M. MERCIER'S sudden presence among them with the French demand for that "sublime tobacco" which BYRON has so glowingly apostrophized.

abstract: By the arrivel at this port of the screw-steamship City of New-York, we have advices from Europe four days later. A new steamer, called the Ovicto, sailed from Liverpool on the 22d of March, and according to rumor she is intended for the service of the rebels in destroying Northern commerce on the Atlantic. The Ovieto was
lead_paragraph: By the arrivel at this port of the screw-steamship City of New-York, we have advices from Europe four days later. A new steamer, called the Ovicto, sailed from Liverpool on the 22d of March, and according to rumor she is intended for the service of the rebels in destroying Northern commerce on the Atlantic. The Ovieto was built at Liverpool, ostensibly for the Italian Government, and is consequently adapted for warlike purposes. She measures 750 tons, is capable of carrying several guns of the largest calibre on a draft of about 12 feet, and is represented as one of the finest and fastest vessels of her class afloat. Gibraltar advices of the 3d inst. states that the Sumter was still at that port, and the National sloop Tuscarora remained at Algesiras. The schooner Sophia arrived at Liverpool, from Charleston, which port she left in company with sundry other vessels, on the 2d of March. Her cargo consisted of cotton, tobacco and resin.

The residents, are greatly exasperated at this outrage.

abstract: Our Washington correspondent gives a fresh and highly characteristic illustration of the mode in which the Secretary of War exercises his functions as Military Censor. On Sunday last, the President, accompanied by Secretaries CHASE and STANTON, visited Aquia Creek, with a view to acquainting themselves with the state of things at that importent point, possibly, so as to decide upon the propriety of Gen. MCDOWELL prosecuting his advance. Our correspondent thinking no
lead_paragraph: Our Washington correspondent gives a fresh and highly characteristic illustration of the mode in which the Secretary of War exercises his functions as Military Censor. On Sunday last, the President, accompanied by Secretaries CHASE and STANTON, visited Aquia Creek, with a view to acquainting themselves with the state of things at that importent point, possibly, so as to decide upon the propriety of Gen. MCDOWELL prosecuting his advance. Our correspondent thinking no evil of this necessary journey, carried his statement of the fact, as in duty bound, to the telegraph office, and left it for transmission to the TIMES. The dispatch was never sent; but through another agency there was sent a brief report, in which, regardless of truth, the visit was transferred to Saturday, and the supposed odium of Sunday travel escaped at the cost of an official lie.

abstract: Current scene
snippet: Current scene
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons, on the 7th inst., Mr. DISRAELI made a general attack upon the financial policy of the Chancellor of the Exchequer. He denounced the idea of commencing the year without a surplus, while the trade of the country was diminishing and its revenue declining. He thought England might find herself in a most unpleasant predicament, if unforeseen difficulties arise in America or on the Continent. He then dissected and argued in opposition to the various fiscal arrangements of Mr. GLADSTONE since he assumed the office of Chancellor of the Exchequer.

abstract: rest of ex-Secretary CAMERON at the suit of PIKRCE BUTLER, rises a variety of questions, which affect the determination of a thousand similar cases hereafter. Mr. BUTLER, upon a
lead_paragraph: rest of ex-Secretary CAMERON at the suit of PIKRCE BUTLER, rises a variety of questions, which affect the determination of a thousand similar cases hereafter. Mr. BUTLER, upon a charge of treason, in lending aid and comfort to the enemy, was confined in Fort Lafayette by order of the recent Secretary of War. Subsequently released upon swearing the oath of allegiance, he resolved upon obtaining legal redress for the alleged wrongful detention, and taking advantage of Mr. CAMERON's presence in Philadelphia, procured his arrest and afterward instituted an action for damages. The fact, that the ex-Secretary was invested with ambassadorial privileges, is of secondary moment, though that of itself would seem to be sufficient to screen him from arrest. But what is the authority of State tribunals to hold and try officers of the Government for fulfilling the orders of the President, is a question of higher import, and one likely to arise, in an endless variety of forms, before all the outstanding accounts of the rebellion have been audited. The President has distinctly assumed the act of Secretary CAMERON. He declares that the latter proceeded solely upon instructions, and ministerially. With what equity can the subordinate be held pecuniarily answerable for the deed of the superior?

abstract: Three steamers have arrived from Europe since our last issue -- the Bohemian at Portland, and the Teutonia and the Persia at this port. The latter brings advices three days later than were received by the City of New-York, having left Liverpool on the 12th, and Queenstown on the 13th inst. The news is not specially important excepting as it relates to the Mexican question, and to the matter of iron-clad vessels and the projectiles in process of manufacture to be used against them with success. It is intimated that me Allies are by no means agreed as to the policy to be pursued in Mexico, and there appears to be some danger of an open rupture among them. The matter of partially-submerged vessels, on the plan of Mr. STEVENS, had been brought to the attention of Parliament, and it appears that somebody in England has been experimenting upon the principle with partial success. The Sumter and the Tuscarora were still at their old stations at Gibraltar and Algesiras. An advance had taken place in the Liverpool Cotton market. Breadstuffs had improved somewhat, but Provisions were dull. The latest quotation of Consols is 93 3/4@93 3/8 for money.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution, offered by Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, directing the Military Committee to inquire whether any General in the army before Yorktown had exhibited himself drunk in the face of the enemy, and if any measures had been taken for the trial and punishment of such officer, was adopted after some debate, during which it transpired that the officer alluded to by Mr. MORRILL, of Vermont, in the House on Tuesday, is a Gen. SMITH. The bill recognizing the independence of Hayti and Liberia, and providing for a diplomatic representation was taken up, and Mr. SUMMER, of Massachusetts, made a speech in advocacy of its passage, after which it was postponed until to-day. Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, resumed his remarks on the subject of confiscation, commenced on Tuesday. The debate was continued by other Senators, until the adjournment.

abstract: Editorial on difficulties encountered by Foote and Pope in forcing way down Mississippi River to Gulf
snippet: Editorial on difficulties encountered by Foote and Pope in forcing way down Mississippi River to Gulf
lead_paragraph: TO THE GULF -- FOOTE and POPE are finding considerable difficulty in forcing their way down the Mississippi River. But it is not Much over a month since FOOTE left Cairo with his gunboats, and already he is fighting a hundred and seventy-five miles down stream from that point. Between Cairo and Memphis therebels had constructed some half a dozen fortifications at the strongest natural points. The most formidable of these works were at Columbus -- and they were the first which the rebels were forced to abandon. With this position they also abandoned the fortifications at Hickman. Next came the forts and batteries at New-Madrid, which were captured by the gallant and indomitable troops of Gen. POPE. Next came Island No. 10, an invulnerable position selected by BEAUREGARD himself, which was captured by the combined navy and army of FOOTE and POPE. Now they are fighting away at Fort Wright, or, as it was formerly called, Fort Pillow. It took them twenty-three days to reduce Island No. 10, and they have now been at work ten days upon Fort Wright. But we learn that matters are progressing there as finely as could be desired. FOOTE is throwing big shells night and day among the rebels, and POPE is getting things ready to cross the river, and take their works in the rear and by assault. Nobody need doubt of soon hearing that the fort has fallen, and that FOOTE and POPE have bagged some six, eight or ten thousand additional rebels. Ten miles below Fort Wright, and on the same side of the river, there are other formidable works, known as Fort, Randolph. Then comes the real original Fort Pillow, and then Memphis. There are beside those named some minor works before reaching Memphis, both on the eastern and on the Arkansas sides; but none of them would retard our progress more than a day, if at all. When FOOTE and POPE reach Memphis, they will act in conjunction with Gen. HALLECK in a grand assault upon the rebel lines extending from Corinth to Memphis. It will not be long now before both parties are ready for this work, which will decide the fate of that part of the Mississippi and its valley which is yet in rebel hands.

abstract: The funds on the 11th opened with an improving tendency but afterwards became dull. Consols closed at 93 7/8@94 for money, and 94@94 7/8 for account. Notwithstanding the distribution of the dividends a considerable demand for money existed, and the terms for good bills were 2 @2  per cent. In the Stock Exchange it was difficult to employ money at 1  per cent.

Notwithstanding the distribution of the dividends a considerable demand for money existed, and the terms for good bills were 2 @2 per cent. In the Stock Exchange it was difficult to employ money at 1 per cent.

abstract: ports from the field of Shiloh or Pittsburgh Landing, one has been generally circulated and credited, that the body of the rebel General, ALBERT SIDNEY JOHNSTON, fell into the hands of our forces under Gen. NELSON. We have the best possible authority for saying that this story is not true. Mr. WILLIAM PRESTON, late our Minister to Spain, now a Colonel in the insurgent army, was near Gen. JOHNSTON when he fell: he died in the arms of Col. PRESTON, who retained possession of his remains, has them still in keeping, and will probably send them to Scott County, Texas, for interment. From the same source we learn that the body of "Provisional Governor" GEORGE W. JOHNSON has been sent to Louisville.

abstract: editorial says visit was to obtain tobacco; Editorial on Union gains
snippet: editorial says visit was to obtain tobacco; Editorial on Union gains
lead_paragraph: If the more ardent and sanguine among us are not fully satisfied with the progress of the National cause, it is for the reason that we do not consider how much we have gained, and how rapidly the rebels are being weakened in the loss of men and territory, but above all, in resources. They have been driven from all the food-producing districts, and have in this way lost the means of feeding properly not only their armies, but themselves. The best portion of their population for military purposes are held in check by the presence of our arms. Those of the sections we have not yet [???] are mainly occupied in discussing how to destroy what available means they have lot in cotton and tobacco. Every article of domestic economy among them has risen to fabulous prices. Labor is directed with the sole object of providing a scanty subsistence. Commerce and trade are annihilated. Every day brings the whole population South one step nearer to actual want, and absorbs no inconsiderable portion of the means of existence left.

abstract: The news from the Department of the Rappahannock is important. An officer who arrived in Washington last night, from the vicinity of Warrenton Junction, reports that the rebels are in strong force on the south side of the river, in the direction of Gordonsville.
lead_paragraph: The news from the Department of the Rappahannock is important. An officer who arrived in Washington last night, from the vicinity of Warrenton Junction, reports that the rebels are in strong force on the south side of the river, in the direction of Gordonsville. At the crossing of the river the rebel Gen. EWELL is said to be stationed,with some eight thousand men, while Gen. GUSTAVUS W. SMITH is at Gordonsville, strongly intrenched, with thirty thousand men, and JACKSON on the way from the Shenandoah Valley, to join him, with eight thousand more. The National force in front of Manassas is considered sufficient to take care of all these rebels, even should the figures prove to be reliable. From Fredericksburgh we learn that the steamer Yankee succeeded on Tuesday in getting through the obstructions in the river, and made her appearance at the City. Seven rebel schooners were captured, one of which had a valuable cargo of dry goods, medicines and saltpetre, and two small steamers also fell into our hands.

BARNES, Esq., of the Eastern District, alone having on the different tables more than one hundred pots, embracing some
lead_paragraph: SPRING EXHIBITION OF THE BROOKLYN HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY. The annual Spring exhibition of the Horticultural Society was opened, yesterday, at the Academy of Music, and will be continued during the remainder of the week. The display of choice and rare plants and flowers is better than at any previous Spring exhibition of the Society H.M. BARNES, Esq., of the Eastern District, alone having on the different tables more than one hundred pots, embracing some of the rarest plants; among the number is the cyanophyllum magneficum, from Madagascar, the largest of the class ever seen in this country. The azalias, ferns, cacti, orchids, ericas, pelangoniums, roses, fuchsias, gloxinias, carnations, are all creditable to the producers, and some of the varieties are exceedingly fine. There is also on exhibition strawberries, string beans, lettuce, rhubarb, radishes, Wardian and [???], moss baskets of grape-vines, peaches &c., grown without earth, by the use of chemicals along, and many other things pleasing to the eye. Mr. JOHN CADNESS, of Flushing, has a new seedling double [???], very fine, which he has named "Gen. McClellan."The rooms were crowded to excess, last evening, and all present were delighted with the exhibition.

abstract: Valentine Sillcosks vs. Henry Bruner. This was an action for damages alleged to have been sustained by reason of the defendant's excavating the earth on the premises adjoining the plaintiff's houses on Wooster and Prince streets, in this City.
lead_paragraph: Valentine Sillcosks vs. Henry Bruner. -- This was an action for damages alleged to have been sustained by reason of the defendant's excavating the earth on the premises adjoining the plaintiff's houses on Wooster and Prince streets, in this City. It was claimed on the plaintiff that the defendant excavated the earth to a greater depth than ten feet below the curbstone, and that he has not protected the walls of the plaintiff, in accordance with the act of Jan. 24, 1855, for the protection of party walls; and that he cut the water-pipes running over to the plaintiff's premises, causing damages to the amount of $3,000.

abstract: Editorial on Congress reluctance to act on bills on confiscation of Southern property
snippet: Editorial on Congress reluctance to act on bills on confiscation of Southern property
lead_paragraph: The Confiscation bill of Mr. BINGHAM met its fate, yesterday, in the House of Representatives. By a vote of 54 to 48 the House laid it on the table. Another bill, authorizing the President to emancipate the slaves of rebel owners, was then discussed, and tabled by a vote equally decided. It is evident the House hesitates to enter on this vindictive business. The Judiciary Committee has had before it a dozen measures of the same general scope, and has reported against the passage of any one of the number. A legislative warfare upon the beaten South is not the present humor of Congress.

abstract: Editorial on national defenses
snippet: Editorial on national defenses
lead_paragraph: While it has beenour fortune of late to set the whole world reconsideringthe resources of attack and defence, it would be unhappy should apathy in high places prevent our promptly acting on the revolution which our own experiments have inaugurated. That this is not likely to be the case we have pretty good proof in the Report on National Defences which the House Committee on Military Affairs yesterday presented to Congress, through its Chairman, Mr. FRANK BLAIR. This document discussesthe question in all its bearings, analyzing the systems of defence which have hitherto prevailed, and showing that the invention of armored war-ships necessarily produces a change in the methods of defensive warfare.It then specifies eight points for the consideration of Congress, to show what should be done in order to bring our defences up to the needs of the times:

abstract: -- The Legislature adjourned yesterday morning. A number of measures of public moment were left on the calendar of unfinished business, the Health bill, so urgently needed by our people, being perhaps the most important. The Broadway Railroad was not acted upon in either House; there is no new Charter to replace the old one; the Tax Levy passed without any of the barnacles usually fastened upon it by the City Hall lobby. What has been accomplished may indeed compensate for what is left undone; and this must always be said -- almost peculiarly -- of the Legislature of 1862, that its action has been free from suspicion of improper influences. The taint of corruption has not in the slightest degree attached to it. The proceedings have been characterized by decorum, fairness, and unusual intelligence; the discussions have been practical and marked by striking ability; and every disposition has been exhibited to consider first the public good, and secondly partisan and personal considerations. In the history of State legislation the present, may indeed, be marked as the era of reformation.
lead_paragraph: -- The Legislature adjourned yesterday morning. A number of measures of public moment were left on the calendar of unfinished business, the Health bill, so urgently needed by our people, being perhaps the most important. The Broadway Railroad was not acted upon in either House; there is no new Charter to replace the old one; the Tax Levy passed without any of the barnacles usually fastened upon it by the City Hall lobby. What has been accomplished may indeed compensate for what is left undone; and this must always be said -- almost peculiarly -- of the Legislature of 1862, that its action has been free from suspicion of improper influences. The taint of corruption has not in the slightest degree attached to it. The proceedings have been characterized by decorum, fairness, and unusual intelligence; the discussions have been practical and marked by striking ability; and every disposition has been exhibited to consider first the public good, and secondly partisan and personal considerations. In the history of State legislation the present, may indeed, be marked as the era of reformation.

lead_paragraph: Rumors were current that the Italian Minister for Foreign Affairs had addressed most energetic remonstrances to the Prussian Minister, Baron BRASSIER DE ST. SIMON, in charge of Austrian interests at the Court of Turin. The objections of the Italian Government relate to the concentration of Bourbon adherents at Trieste, and their embarkation to augment the numbers of the brigands in Southern Italy. The continental journals contain accounts of several clerical conspiracies in Italy.

abstract: MY EVER DEAR FRIEND: Your letter of the 8th inst. reached me, and I avail myself of the earliest opportunity to reply. I feel deep regret for the sad intelligence it conveyed to my highly esteemed friend and fellow-prisoner, Lieut. DEMPSEY. I have been using my best endeavors to console him, and I am happy to say that he looks upon the matter in a truly Christian manner.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND. Va., April 19, 1862.

abstract: Editorial on prevalence of Confederate guerrillas in western Virginia
snippet: Editorial on prevalence of Confederate guerrillas in western Virginia
lead_paragraph: Rebel marauders and guerrillas are making their appearance, with the green leaves, in quite a number of the counties of Western Virginia. We hear of them suddenly springing up in some unexpected quarter, attacking a hamlet, or a Union camp, or a supply train, or executing vengeance upon some loyal citizen, or in some other way disturbing the peace of the country. Gen. FREMONT is doing his best to put these gangs down; but the work is one which, in the thinly-peopled mountain regions of Western Virginia, can neither be done easily nor quickly, and the consequence is civil turmoil and social insecurity. It is doubtful whether it is possible to destroy effectually these rebel guerrillas before the great rebel army in Eastern Virginia has been defeated. While the fate of the State appears yet doubtful -- while the rebel army is able to hold Richmond, and check our advance at half-a-dozen different points -- while the laws of the rebel Confederacy are in force over three-fourths of Virginia, and nominally over the whole of it -- there will be perpetual attacks on our outposts, and efforts to annoy and harass the "invaders" wherever it is possible. But when, by the defeat and expulsion of the rebel army, it is clearly seen that the State is irrevocably in the Union, the resident rebels will learn that nothing can be gained to their cause by the ravages of these robbers, and they end the local magistracy will unite with the National authorities in [???] to put them down. This is the way things have worked in Missouri. Last Fall it appeared as though the whole of that vast State was about to be overrun by rebel guerrillas. They seemed to spring up from the ground in North Missouri as well as in Southern Missouri. They tore up railroad tracks, fired bridges, ravaged towns and slaughtered Unionists, until it looked for a time as though the State were to suffer from a reign of anarchy. But since the rebels were chased southward, since PRICE was driven from Springfield, and he and all his comrades were defeated at Pea Ridge, the State has enjoyed almost entire quiet. Here and there a small gang of marauders is occasionally heard of, but the exercise of a little wholesome severity is disposing of these rapidly enough. So, in all probability, it will be in Virginia. When the rebel army is expelled from the State, a short period of martial law will dispose of the guerrillas. Until that time, it is hardly worth while for Gen. FREMONT to be at any very great trouble or expense in vain attempts to suppress them.

abstract: The Legislature adjourned yesterday forenoon sine die. Both Houses met at 9 o'clock. In the  Senate the bill to provide for the public defence was killed.
lead_paragraph: The Legislature adjourned yesterday forenoon sine die. Both Houses met at 9 o'clock. In the Senate the bill to provide for the public defence was killed. The House concurred in the Senate'samendments to the New-York Tax Levy, thus passing the bill without any extra items outside of those contained in the Comptroller's original bill. No other business was done. A joint resolution was adopted to adjourn at 11 A.M. When that hour was reached a farewell letter was read from Lieut.-Gov. CAMPBELL, after which Mr. BELL, President pro tem., with appropriate remarks, declared the Senate adjourned. At the same hour, Speaker RAYMOND addressed the Assembly in a feeling and eloquent farewell speech, and declared the House finally adjourned. The parting of members was marked with much cordiality and good feeling.

abstract: Twelve out of the fourteen little States or provinces, with their sovereign rights and Congresses, Governments and all, had submitted to the new Government of Gen. MITRE, of Buenos Ayres. Gen. URQUIZA keeps yet his province of Entre Rios in an armed position. His convention with MITRE is still kept secret. Gen. MITRE has called a Congress to assist him in the Government. There are so many jealousies to appease, so much passion to control, and so many [???] to look after in all these States, that Gen. MITRE will have to be wise above most rulers to make a smooth [???] of it. He had commenced dis[???] his troops -- some say as a step toward a final peace, and others [???] because he fears a mutiny among them. The standing army of Buenos Ayres is 14,300 men equipped in the best European style, with Minie and Vincennes rifles. Her navy carries (80 vessels) and 3,000 men.

abstract: The Connecticut River, at the toll-bridge in Springfield, Monday night, had receded about 15 Inches from its highest point on Sunday. The singularity of this flood, in exceeding that of 1854 at West Springfield and Chicopee, while it was not so high in...
lead_paragraph: The Connecticut River, at the toll-bridge in Springfield, Monday night, had receded about 15 Inches from its highest point on Sunday. The singularity of this flood, in exceeding that of 1854 at West Springfield and Chicopee, while it was not so high in [???] accounted for by the Agawam and Chicopee Rivers now being only at their averagefreshnet height, so that the water runs away freely,while in 1854 these rivers, and particularly the Agawam, were extremely high from chocked ice andflood-wood, and the water was "set back" againstthis city. At Chicopee the flood has been 7 incheshigher than, in 1854, stopping all the mills with backwater, and causing considerable damage to cellarsand outbuildings. At Holyoke the water is upwardsof 11 feet above the dam, but is receding slowly, andto-day the repairs on the railroad will probably becommenced.

abstract: Davis vs. Hackley et al. -- This case, which has been before the public so often, was concluded yesterday. Mr. James, in concluding his argument, said that he pitied Mr. Hackley, for by the deed between the Hopes and Bliss & Yelverton, he was prevented from acting in the matter, while he had to bear all the odium. He said that the deeds showed that Anthony Hope had appointed himself a receiver with a salary of $1,500 a year.

abstract: quest was held yesterday afternoon upon the body of the sailor who died at the New-York Hospital, on Wednesday, from violence at the hands of Ex-Policeman CHARLES H. BUNT. The testimony given went to show that the name of the deceased was BENDIX THORSEN; that he was very much intoxicated when he went into the house, No. 19 Howard-street, and that while there a difficulty occurred between him and the woman who kept the house, in regard to some drinks which had not been paid for. Deceased was soon after put out the house, after much resistance. BUNT and a friend of the deceased followed him to the door. An alteration then took place, during which BUNT kicked and struck deceased on the head and face in such a manner that he died a few days after. The jury rendered a verdict, that "THORSEN came to his death from a fracture of the skull, the result of violence, at the hands of CHARLES H. BUNT." Upon the rendition of the verdict, the accused was committed to the Tombs, to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: The wrongs and injuries arising out of this rebellion can never be numbered. Setting aside those which are the direct results of willful wrongdoing, there will be injuries springing out of inadvertence, error, honest misjudgment, or mistake, far more than any history will ever tell in the future -- far more than will even be known to the public now. We have had our minds turned in this direction by the narration to us of some facts" relating to Col. SERRELL's Engineer Regiment. We learn that, owing to an error of some sort, whether in the formation of the regiment or in the mustering it into the service, it has been found impossible to pay the men in accordance with the regulations of the service, and they, accordingly, have been paid but once during the whole term of their service, while they have been doing such laborious and useful duty among the swamps and inlets of South Carolina, and under the walls of Fort Pulaski -- and this one payment was held by the Department to have been entirely irregular. The result of this has been, of course, great suffering and dissatisfaction among the men, in spite of all the exertions of their officers. One very touching case was narrated to us of one of the men, a mechanic from Connecticut, who learned from home that, in consequence of this failure of his pay, his wife had gone into the poorhouse, and his children were starving. The grief and anxiety were too much for his brain, and he was found wandering through the swamps with a piece or two of cracker in his hand, which he said he was going to carry to his poor starving boys.

abstract: GUNBOATS THROUGH THE CANALS, AND THE LEGISLATURE. -- An error, which obtained general currency in the newspapers of yesterday, is corrected by a note from Mr. SAMUEL B. RUGGLES, in another column. The bill inviting the National Government to enlarge the locks of the State canals so as to admit the passage of "Monitors" into the lakes was not defeated, but was passed through both Houses of the Legislature by very large majorities, and received the signature of the Governor. The subject is now transferred to Washington, where the public will be rejoiced to see action as prompt, emphatic and favorable.
lead_paragraph: GUNBOATS THROUGH THE CANALS, AND THE LEGISLATURE. -- An error, which obtained general currency in the newspapers of yesterday, is corrected by a note from Mr. SAMUEL B. The bill inviting the National Government to enlarge the locks of the State canals so as to admit the passage of "Monitors" into the lakes was not defeated, but was passed through both Houses of the Legislature by very large majorities, and received the signature of the Governor. The subject is now transferred to Washington, where the public will be rejoiced to see action as prompt, emphatic and favorable.

abstract: Gov. CLARK, of North Carolina, was to consult and truly represent the opinion and feeling of the people of that State, we have no doubt that he would do precisely what the telegraph this morning attributes to him -- make proposals to Gen. BURNSIDE for the surrender of the State. The mass of the North Carolinians never were rebellious any more than the mass of the Kentuckians; and was North Carolina geographically located as is Kentucky, she would probably have as many regiments fighting for the Union to-day as has Kentucky. She was engineered out of the Union by a small but powerful and adroit body of secession politicians; she was forced out by the tremendous pressure brought to bear upon her from South Carolina on one side and Virginia on the other; she was compelled to join the new Confederacy on account of her geographical situation, because otherwise she would be politically isolated from all the surrounding States; she was swindled into secession by a fraud as palpable, direct and atrocious as fraud could be. The State Legislature of 1860 provided that no ordinance dissolving the connection of North Carolina with the Union "should have any force or validity until it should have been submitted to and ratified by a majority of the qualified voters of the State;" and yet to the present day the secession ordinance has not been submitted to popular vote at all -- so that the State is not legally out of the Union even by its own provisions. It is not much over a year since the North Carolina delegation in the National Congress telegraphed to the then Governor to quell at once all incipient insurrectionary movements, that thus the State might be "saved from being drawn into the vortex of certain ruin." The advice was unheeded by the secession Governor; and he himself ordered the seizure of Fort Macon and the other fortifications which are now, one by one, again falling into our hands. The ruin which her Union representatives foresaw, as the consequence of disunion, has now overtaken her. Nearly the whole of her seaboard and the cities thereon are now in our hands; many of her citizens are fugitives from their homes; a great part of her population has been forced to fight the bloody battles of JEFF. DAVIS; her commerce is ruined; and she is threatened with the devastations of a retreating rebel army. If Gov. CLARK was wise, and would save to his native State what yet remains of honor and prosperity, he would at once give up the rebellion, as it is reported he has done, and as is truly the case, proclaim the State to be yet in the Union. But we do not believe that under present circumstances he has done anything of the kind, nor that he will be likely to do so until the rebel army in Virginia is defeated. After that event, such a story as now reaches us would be extremely plausible. North Carolina had a number of rebellions and insurrections last century, and in at least two of them the rebels laid down their arms and took the oath of allegiance when their cause became hopeless. The present generation would show its wisdom and discretion by following the wholesome example of the fathers.

abstract: -- Gen. MITCHEL and Gen. BANKS are the two traveling Generals just now -- one in Alabama, and the other in Virginia. Gen. MITCHEL has the advantage of railroad conveyance, and consequently travels fastest. He is now reported to be at Tuscumbia, some sixty miles west of Huntsville, which he captured ten days ago, and on the south side of the Tennessee River. When he took Huntsville he rushed eastward, and secured the important railroad junction of Stevenson; but, finding no enemy there worth fighting, he turned his footsteps in the direction of BEAUREGARD. He recently said that ho had chased the rebel through three States, trying to get a fight [???] of thorn; he is now on the verge of the fourth State, and with a bright prospect before him at last. He is but forty or fifty miles from the headquarters of that liar and rebel BEAUREGARD; and it would not be surprising now to see him perform a brilliant flanking operation. This movement of Gen. MITCHEL, added to the recall of POPE's men from the west side of the Mississippi to Corinth, and the movements of other bodies of Western troops, now rapidly going on, show that Gen. HALLECK is adopting the Napoleonic tactics. He must now have an immense army in front of Corinth, and it is in fine trim and spirits, and nearly ready to engage the enemy. The columns of MITCHEL and POPE are composed of the best drilled regiments in the Western army. It cannot be long now before another battle, with more decisive results than that of Shiloh, will be fought somewhere between the Tennessee and the Mississippi.

abstract: We learn from the Southwest, that the division of Gen. MITCHEL has arrived at Tuscumbia, Franklin County, Alabama, and that MITCHEL has possession of two hundred miles of the Charleston and Memphis Railroad. This move-...
lead_paragraph: We learn from the Southwest, that the division of Gen. MITCHEL has arrived at Tuscumbia, Franklin County, Alabama, and that MITCHEL has possession of two hundred miles of the Charleston and Memphis Railroad. This movement looks as though Gen. MITCHEL, instead of pushing into East Tennessee, as it was supposed he would do, is preparing to cooperate with Gen. HALLECK in the grand assault on the Corinthian rebels. Large reinforcements have arrived at Pittsburgh.

Our approaches command the rebel intrenchments. Everything is working as well as the most sanguine could wish.

abstract: We have intelligence this morning of the loss of the steamship Karnak, which has for some time been running between this port and Havana, touching at Nassau, N.P., each way. She was...
lead_paragraph: We have intelligence this morning of the loss of the steamship Karnak, which has for some time been running between this port and Havana, touching at Nassau, N.P., each way. She was lost on the 14th inst., while attempting to enter the harbor of Nassau, on Tony Rock Reef, inside the bar. She thumped heavily for about an hour, when she bilged, and it was expected that she would go to pieces during the next high wind. The passengers were all taken off safely, but her cargo was badly damaged. It is thought the pilot was entirely to blame for her loss.

abstract: By a curious synchronism, the same day that brings from Europe proof of the formal disruption of the Anti-Mexican coalition, brings also from Mexico proof that the disruption is an accomplished fact. The intelligence from Europe is to the...
lead_paragraph: By a curious synchronism, the same day that brings from Europe proof of the formal disruption of the Anti-Mexican coalition, brings also from Mexico proof that the disruption is an accomplished fact. The intelligence from Europe is to the effect that Spain, agreeing with England, had declined to participate in the French Emperor's plans for reversing the Mexican political system, and placing a monarch on the apex.

abstract: The French, Spanish and Belgian Press teems with letters, articles and communications on the Mexican question mutually contradictory and inconolusive. From a careful perusal of the leading jour-...
lead_paragraph: The French, Spanish and Belgian Press teems with letters, articles and communications on the Mexican question mutually contradictory and inconolusive. From a careful perusal of the leading journais we elicit two important facts, viz.: That the English and Spanish Governments are acting together, and are becoming alarmed at the pretensions of France in Mexico, and that the latter has decided to push her expedition forward to the capital of that country, and will there and there only treat with the Mexican Government concerning the future. Among the most explicit of the foreign statements in reference to this important matter, we quote below the language of the Paris Presse, of the 7th inst.:

abstract: -- Coroner Murphy yesterday impanneled a jury to investigate the circumstances attending the result death of DANIEL MCCUTCHEON, at No. 138 Grand-street, Eastern District, and the hearing of testimony was postponed until 3 o'clock this afternoon. The deceased, with his father-in-law, CHARLES H. SUMMERSGILL, carried on the jewelry business at No. 138 Grand-street. Some weeks ago they had a difficulty about business matters, when the deceased attacked his father-in-law, who, it is said, in self-defence, stabbed MCCUTCHEON so severely that he died on Wednesday evening last. Before death he took all the blame of the affair upon himself, entirely admitting his father-in-law of any blame in the matter.

abstract: The nomination of HORATIO KING, in place of Col. BERRET, as one of the Commissioners upon Manumission in the District of Columbia, is especially apt and proper. The President evidently intended to have a majority of the Commission residents, and fairly representative of the District. Mr. GOODLOE, a native of North Carolina, who has lived longer in Washington than most men, and who has been a strenuous opponent of Slavery extension, was one of the two selected. Propriety exacted that the second should not only be a citizen of the District, but a member of the party opposed to that of Mr. GOODLOE, and hence the choice of Mr. BERRET, and subsequently, upon his declension, of Mr. KING. The latter has lived in Washington twenty-five years. He was a member of the Democratic party, and during the latter days of Mr. BUCHANAN's Administration, acted as Postmaster-General, of course filling a seat in the Cabinet at the time when such men as DIX and HOLT rallied to the support of the sinking Government. A practical business man, a true patriot, and possessing the confidence and respect of the slaveholding population of the District, he will at once illustrate the impartially and sound judgment which have governed the action of the President.

abstract: The trial of Capt. ROBERT AVERY, Of the One Hundred and Second New-York Volunteers or, what is more familiarly known as "The Van Buren Light Guard" upon an indictment for murder in the first degree, was concluded in the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday, when the jury rendered a verdict of "Not guilty." The history of this case was given briefly, in the TIMES yesterday.

abstract: In the senate, yesterday, a communication was received from the War Department, transmitting copies of contracts made by the Department in 1861. A great number of petitions from beer and malt liquor manufacturers were presented, asking for a reduction on the proposed tax. Mr. POWELL,...
lead_paragraph: In the senate, yesterday, a communication was received from the War Department, transmitting copies of contracts made by the Department in 1861. A great number of petitions from beer and malt liquor manufacturers were presented, asking for a reduction on the proposed tax. Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, moved to take up the resolution offered by him, relative to the arrest of citizens of Kentucky, but objection was made. The bill for the recognition of Hayti and Liberia was taken up as the special order, but was laid aside after debate. It was subsequently, however, passed. The Confiscation bill was then taken up, and Mr. COLLAMER, of Vermont, made a speech in opposition to its passage. At the conclusion of his speech, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: length of time that has elapsed since we got reliable news from the army and navy supposed to be besieging New-Orleans or its outposts has made a good many people suspect that BUTLER, PORTER and FARRAGUT had some other work on hand than the ostensible work of capturing the Crescent City. It is nearly five weeks since it was semi-officially announced from Washington that the City had actually been captured, and was in possession of our troops; but the announcement was undoubtedly ahead of the fact. Since that time, however, we have had rumors from rebel and other sources, of the capture of Fort Pike, guarding the entrance to Lake Ponchartrain; of the capture of Fort Jackson, same distance above the debouchure of the Mississippi, and of naval movements against other of the City's defences. At the present time those rumors are multiplying; but there are none of them coherent or satisfactory. Yesterday we gave an extract from the private letter of an officer, saying that seven of our bomb-ketches and three gunboats had gone up the river, and passed beyond Fort Jackson, on their way to New-Orleans. We have this morning a statement, by way of Havana, to the effect that the rebels had abandoned both Forts Jackson and St. Philip without removing their cannon, and that there was nothing to prevent our fleet from sailing directly up to New-Orleans. A third statement, from a correspondent at Havana, mentions that Gen. BUTLER's nephew, who had just arrived there, reported that our forces would open fire on the 14th upon the forts guarding the city. It would seem as though these rumors, coming from so many different sources, must have some basis of truth to them, and that an attempt either has been or is to be made to capture the great city of the South. We said, some days ago, that we doubted whether the small military force under Gen. BUTLER would actually occupy a place of the size of New-Orleans; but if our army and navy succeed in seizing all the lake and river defences of the city, and in capturing the railroad running north, and the short line running west, (and by these roads the city's supplies are now mainly brought,) it will not be long before we shall have a capitulation. It is probably because he is slowly and cautiously doing this work, that we do not hear much from him of the operations going on. The city must be now nearly devoid of fighting rebels, as BEAUREGARD has ordered all the troops to Corinth, except, we believe, JOURDAIN's negro regiment. The people who remain are mostly non-combatants, Creoles, Yankees, foreigners, women and slaves. These will not hold out long when Gen. BUTLER has them at his mercy. It is to be hoped he will have this work done, and the Northern Railroad in his possession, and the river completely in his control, before the hordes soon to be defeated by Gen. HALLECK can be hurled upon the city.

abstract: "The Atlas and Argus distinctly intimates this morning, the probability of a proposition from the Democratic organizations of this State, to participate in a Union nomination for the ensuing election. It is also of the opinion that such an affiliation would be distasteful to the standing Republican party. In this we think it is mistaken, for the official Republican State Committee proposed precisely the same arrangement for last year. Republicans certainly have not grown less liberal than they were at that period."

abstract: It is a bright, beautiful day. These April mornings in Virginia brim with more joyousness than crowns even the full cup of June in your more northern latitudes. It is impossible to sit and sip sunshine and cloud alternately and leisurely as we do among your mountains and valleys, one wishes to press the goblet, of which yon horizon seems the blushing rim, to his lips and drain it at a draught.

abstract: Amelia Yeaton vs. Aaron Clafflin et al. -- The defendants in this action are the well-known firm of Clafflin, Mellen & Co. The plaintiff sues to recover the possession of goods taken to the amount of $2,500. The defence set up is that the defendants obtained judgment against one Thomas S. Brooks, who is the son-in-law of the plaintiff, and that the property for which this action was brought was his property and did not belong to the plaintiff. It was claimed on the part of the plaintiff that the goods were formerly the property of Brooks, but that he owed Mrs. Yeaton, and sold the property to her to secure the payment of her claim. The bill of sale of the property was offered in evidence and objected to by the defendants on the ground that it was interlined and that it did not show that the interlineations were in the bill of sale when it was signed by Brooks. The Court, however, overruled the objection, and admitted the bill of sale as evidence.

abstract: observations on reforms
snippet: observations on reforms
lead_paragraph: The partial eclipse of the conceit halls, which threatens soon to become total, or to disappear altogether, continued last night. The entire business is at a temporary stand-still, awaiting the result of the made case already before the Courts, to test the constitutionality of the new law. As on the previous evening, there was an entire compliance with the law at all the smaller establishments, and the larger ones dropped this or that feature so as to keep within the letter of the statute. But the concert men are only defeated, not conquered. They despond but do not despair. They place a firm reliance upon the skill and ability of the legal talent which they have employed, and, with knowing wink and meaning smile, (both kinds of smile,) predict that, ere another sun sets, one of the highest Courts of the State will have decided that, since liquor-selling, theatrical performances and pretty waiter-girls are separately legal and proper, that when conjoined they cannot be prohibited by any constitutional statute. "Why," they say, "we can get a license, and the City takes our money, for either the performances or liquor-selling; and some of the most respectable establishments have employed waiter-girls. How is it that, when we combine all three in one business, we can be punished for misdemeanor?"
headline: {'main': 'THE CONCERT SALOON REFORM.; Prolongation of the Eclipse The Status Quo Maintained Waiting for the Constitutionality of the Law to be Tested Judge Barnard to Decide To-day, & c.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE CONCERT SALOON REFORM.; Prolongation of the Eclipse The Status Quo Maintained Waiting for the Constitutionality of the Law to be Tested Judge Barnard to Decide To-day, & c.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We have, already, had occasion to notice at some length WM. M. DAVIS' painting entitled the "Neglected Picture," on exhibition at the establishment of BALL, BLACK & Co. Mr. DAVIS has produced another characteristic piece of similar character, styled "Done Gone," and portraying the miseries of expiring secessionism. E. ANTHONY, No. 501 Broadway, has got out some very finely executed photographic copies, carte de visile size, of these two noted pictures, and of one by DARLEY entitled "Discretion is the Better Part of Valor," which are sold at 25 cents apiece. They are beautiful specimens of the minor fine arts and should command a wide popularity.

abstract: The schooner Anne C. Leverett, Capt. SQUIBER from Jacksonville on the 20th inst., with merchandise for MCCREADY, MOTT & Co., arrived yesterday. She left the United State gunboat Seneca, Pemdins and Ottawa at Jacksonville. The United State troops had evacuated Jacksonville, and the city was in charge of the Confederates, but the gunboats remains of anchor off the town to protect the loyal inhabitants. The Leverett brought the following passengers Mrs. Col. Samis, daughter, grandson and two servants'; C.L. Mather, Mrs. M. Mather, Mr. Fox, Mr. Fairbanks C. Raul.

abstract: -- The keepers of the Concert Saloon brothels make two equally shameful appeals: one to public sympathy, and the other to the "Constitution." So many thousands are to become "breadless," that they expect the community and the Police will relent; or, failing here, they trust to legal wit to devise some issue which will suspend the practical application of the law, and leave them to prosecute their infamous business indefinitely. The Sunday-Theatre men tried this scheme, with partial success, two years ago; and the Liquor Dealers' Association have practiced it successfully for years. Unless we mistake the temper of the Police, the public, and the counsel of the House of Refuge, this dodge will fall, Whatever legal questions may be raised, there is power enough intrusted to the several authorities concerned to compel obedience to the statute until it is repealed or invalidated -- which will be never. The outrages are so monstrous that the strong hand can alone arrest them, and the strong hand must be used -- patiently, firmly, but surely. And the result will be that shameless wickedness will shrink back to its hiding-places, after flaunting its hideous visage on our thoroughfares long enough to have concentrated upon itself the loathing and disgust of all decent men.

abstract: A serious accident occurred to-day to the through train from New-York, at Charlestown, ten miles from the Susquehannah. The rear car was thrown off the truck by a misplaced switch, and after running 200 feet, struck sidewise against a loaded dirt car standing on a side track. The shock was very severe. Half the side of the car was stove in. The seats were demolished, and the passengers pitched headlong into the ruins.

abstract: Our readers must have digested City Judge McCONN'S law, logic and other "beverages" by this time. A second reading of his letter satisfies us that we did injustice to this production when we only styled it "remarkable." It is more.
lead_paragraph: Our readers must have digested City Judge McCONN'S law, logic and other "beverages" by this time. A second reading of his letter satisfies us that we did injustice to this production when we only styled it "remarkable." It is more. A whole page of WEBSTER's quarto,unabridged, hardly contains words enough to characterize this unique performance; and the two hundred English grammars in the State Library do not embody rules enough to cover the eccentricities of style in which an indignant jurist indulges; while, as a piece of strategy, this clever ruse de guerre will rank with BISSELL's cut through the swamps around "No. 10." Our sole issue with His Honor was one of law and beverages; he attempts to make it one of military prowess and soldierly conduct. A harmless illustration of the worthlessness of an obiter dictum sols him off on a column of military history and autobiography -- all very interesting and important, doubtless, but not specially vital to the question of Sunday beverages. We return to the question.

abstract: A curious interest attaches to this remarkable French novel, which Mr. CARLETON, of New-York, has in press from advance foreign sheets. The author's only other novel, Notre Dame de Paris, was accepted by its publisher on condition that he should bring out every succeeding work by that author. Notre Dame proved a brilliant success, and made the fortune of -- the publisher. VICTOR HUGO then wrote Les Miserables, determining to respect the condition, but to make his own terms with the unscrupulous brain-trafficker. These terms were at once rejected, and the author, unreleased from the old obligation, was obliged to put by his manuscript for a more favorable season. Year after year he renewed proposals, increasing each year his demand, until at last the publisher died, and, after waiting nearly a quarter of a century, the well-seasoned, if not seasonable, Les Miserables is in press.

abstract: The steamers Belle of Memphis and Choctaw, from Pittsburgh Landing Wednesday morning, arrived last night. They were fired into 38 miles below Pittsburgh by a band of guerrillas, from behind some dwellings on the left bank of the Tennessee. The Choctaw received seven shots. Her mate was killed. The Belle of Memphis received twelve shots, mortally wounding one negro boy.

abstract: Sarah Emma Sturges vs. Charles Sturges. -- This was an action for divorce a vinculo on the ground of adultery with certain persons mentioned in the complaint. The defence set up a denial, and the case was referred to the Hon. Murray Hoffman, late Justice of this Court, to take the testimony and report his finding to the Court. The referee found in favor of the plaintiff, and the Court now granted a decree of divorce on the ground charged.

abstract: -- At a meeting of the Police Commissioners Thursday, ISAAC W. EDSALL, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, (City Hall Police) was dismissed from the Department. Three distinct charges of a violation of the rule against blackmailing were preferred against him. The Board decided that the evidence in each case was sufficient to warrant a dismissal.
lead_paragraph: -- At a meeting of the Police Commissioners Thursday, ISAAC W. EDSALL, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, (City Hall Police) was dismissed from the Department. Three distinct charges of a violation of the rule against blackmailing were preferred against him. The Board decided that the evidence in each case was sufficient to warrant a dismissal.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Mr. GRAU closed his season last night at the Academy, and, we regret to say, closed it when there was every prospect of his continuing it highly successfully. But so it is. Just when the ball comes into most of our hands, we neglect to cast it, and why should an operatic manager be expected to do differently from the remainder of the world. "La Favorita" was the opera given lastnight, and ELENA D'ANGRI made her debut in New-York in the part of Leonora. It would seem that this opera, originally written for a mezzo soprano, is always a favorite opera with contralti. Why this should be, it is at present scarcely necessary for us to inquire, although it is, perhaps, partially due to the fact that Madame STOLZ originally created so great a sensation in the rule of Leonora, and partly to the chances which it affords the operatic actress. We say the "actress," because it is a noticeable fact that, with but few exceptions, contralti are generally good actresses. It is, therefore, we suppose, upon this account, that Madame D'ANGRI has added the opera to her repertoire, and achieved so thorough a success in it. We, indeed, without any exception, must regard her as the best Leonora that has yet appeared in this City. Her share in the duet with the King, "In questo solo," in the second act, was the first thing which led us to expect this. It was charmingly vocalized, with a tenderness which was scarcely to be expected, and gave us a pleasant hint of the manner in which she would sing the remainder of the opera. "Omlo Fernando," though most ungraciously cut in two by the applause of the indiscriminating portion of the audience, was rendered with consummate taste and feeling, lacking, if anything, in nobility of style, for which she made more than amends by the deep feeling she threw into it. In the last act she was grand, and was magnificently supported by BRIGNOLI, whose "Spirto Gentil" was exquisitely rendered. Indeed, after hearing any other tenori, we are always compelled to admit that BRIGNOLI is the best of them we have had for many years in this country. TOMBESI may make a success, as STIGELLI and others have done before him. But they cannot displace our old favorite, who, in spite of his cool laissez-aller mode of strolling upon the stage, and laziness as a vocalist, is indisputably the pleasantest voiced of tenori. We have also to speak very warmly of FEREI, whose King in this Opera is very finely sung. He was in good voice, and somewhat eschewed that constant tremolo, which is one of his most remarkable virtues or vices. SUSINI was unfortunately suffering from a cold -- too ill to appear -- but was replaced, by BARILI, who, although by no means so good as the vocalist whose place he took, managed to get through Balthazzar acceptably. The house was crowded, as may be inferred from what we said at the commencement of our notice, and we were gratified that it should be so, as this is decidedly the best operatic season, musically, which Mr. GRAU has this year given us.

abstract: Editorial says Confederates have staked their cause at Yorktown, Va, and Corinth, Miss, battlefields by heavy concentration of troops; editorial says Confederates have staked their cause at Yorktown battlefield by heavy concentration of troops
snippet: Editorial says Confederates have staked their cause at Yorktown, Va, and Corinth, Miss, battlefields by heavy concentration of troops; editorial says Confederates have staked their cause at Yorktown battlefield by heavy concentration of troops
lead_paragraph: The rebels have decided to stake their cause upon two great battles at Yorktown in the East, and Corinth in the Southwest. At these points they have concentrated all their available forces in the two sections. We certainly ought to be well satisfied with their decision. Upon both battle-fields it is vastly easier for the North to concentrate and mass its forces, than for the rebels. Yorktown is upon the extreme northern verge of the territory held by them. The supplies necessary for the maintenance and equipment of their army there are drown from distant regions, and necessarily at great cost and labor. By having command of the sea, Yorktown is as accessible to the North, as Staten Island or Newport. The rebels consequently offer battle where we are the strongest and they, (not taking into consideration the particular position occupied,) the weakest. If their army is defeated, it is destroyed. We do not have to exhaust our forces by marching hundreds of miles by land, over wretched roads, through almost impenetrable forests and regions traversed by unnavigable but unfordable rivers to attack them, where their defeat might only serve to transfer the contest to a more distant field, but where a reverse to our own army might prove fatal to it, surrounded, as it would be, by a hostile population, and unsupported by reserves. It was by avoiding a general engagement, and constantly retreating, that the Russians drew NAPOLEON so far into the interior of the Empire that, in this end, hardly a man of his vast hosts escaped. Had they hazarded all upon the result of a single battle at the very outposts of their country, the result of the campaign would in all probability have been completely reversed.

abstract: -- We have at last definite news of the commencement of naval operations against the outposts of New-Orleans. The report has all the usual rebel exaggerations, but there is no doubt of the truth of the main fact which it announces it does not appear yet what day the work was really commenced. An article we gave yesterday from a Richmond paper stated that the bombardment of the forts below the City was going on on Saturday last; but the probability is that the operations at that time were only preliminary to, and initiatory of, the grand assault. By the news this morning it looks as though the guns and mortars opened if earnest upon Fort Jackson on Tuesday of this week. The fire was kept up all Tuesday night, and was still active on Wednesday, when the dispatch is dated. No casualties are reported to our fleet, and it may be taken as certain that if we had suffered any serious damage it would have been described and magnified in the most fearful manner. The rebel telegram says that twenty-five thousand 13-inch shell had been flung at the fort -- which is a large story to tell or to credit; and that a thousand of them had fallen inside the fort. The rebels in the fort, however, are said to be still cheerful, and assert that they can stand it as long as we can. That is certainly a remarkable case of cheerfulness under adverse circumstances, and if the fire-eaters can really swallow 13-inch shell as long and as fast as FARRAGUT and PORTER can furnish them, the reduction of the fort by that means is hopeless. But this is precisely the kind of bluster that in every case has preceded a rebel defeat or surrender. It is the language that was used at Fort Pulaski, at Island No. Ten, and in a score of other cases. We expect that the next news will announce the fall of Fort Jackson, and then we shall hear from the rebels that Fort St. Philip is impregnable.

abstract: There are no local military items of special importance to report. At Fort Hamilton a great change has been made since Gen. BROWN went there. The General has the reputation of being's pretty stirct officer in fact, a martinet but, withal, a good man to a soldier who does his duty.
lead_paragraph: There are no local military items of special importance to report. At Fort Hamilton a great change has been made since Gen. BROWN went there. The General has the reputation of being's pretty stirct officer in fact, a martinet but, withal, a good man to a soldier who does his duty. Every man must nowbe in full uniform, buttoned up to the throat, and must at all times appear neat and soldier-like. Hitherto there has been some laxity in this matter, and nothing was said so long as the men were all right on parade.

abstract: A serious accident occured yesterday to the through train from this City to Washington, which resulted in the injury of several persons from this vicinity. The rear passenger car was thrown from the track, ten miles beyond the Susquehanna River, and striking against a dirt-car on a side track, was smashed to pieces, the passengers being scattered among the rubbish. A list of the  passengers injured will be found in our dispatch.
