abstract: details of Mitchell expedition
snippet: details of Mitchell expedition
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Cincinnati Gazette gives a detailed account of Gen. MITCHEL's expedition to Huntsville and Decatur. On Tuesday, April 8, at 3 o'clock P.M., the Eighth Brigade, Col. TURCHIN commanding, took up the line of march for Fayetteville, the county seat of Lincoln County. On the morning of the 9th the remainder of the Division followed, the Seventeenth Brigade, Col. LYTLE, bringing up the rear. Col. JONES, of the Forty-second Indiana, succeeded Col. POPE as Provost-Marshal at Shelbyville.

abstract: Editorial questions superiority of British military discipline over that of Union armies
snippet: Editorial questions superiority of British military discipline over that of Union armies
lead_paragraph: The English Press and military authorities, have spoken, during the progress of this war, with undisguised contempt, or with severe rebuke, of the ability of our officers, both volunteer and regular. The rank and file havegenerally been represented as a mere mob, gradually brought into some resemblance to a disciplined army, while it has generally been assumed by Mr. RUSSELL and other Englishmen, that a small force of British regulars, could sweep our whole vast Potomac army from the field, with but little difficulty. Bull Run was represented as lost, as much through the incapacity and want of experience of the officers, as by the poor discipline of the men.

abstract: Better order never existed in an army than has prevailed among the troops occupying Falmouth. The stringent order directing all plunderers and marauders to be shot, if detected in the act, effectually prevented any destruction of property whatever during our advance upon Fredericksburgh, and since the occupation of our present quarters, but a single depredation was committed, which was immediately atoned for, and the perpetrators punished.
lead_paragraph: FREDERICKSBURGH, Wednesday, April 23.

abstract: rumor has reached us, based on statements made by passengers who have reached Cairo from up the Tennessee, that Gen. HALLECK has already attacked the rebel position at Corinth.
lead_paragraph: rumor has reached us, based on statements made by passengers who have reached Cairo from up the Tennessee, that Gen. HALLECK has already attacked the rebel position at Corinth. It is not sufficiently definite, however, to be relied upon. The passengers state that when at Savanna, they heard heavy cannonading in the direction of Pittsburgh, and that they continued to hear it for miles this side of Savanna. They state, also, that on Wednesday last, Gen. HALLECK was making preparations for an attack. This is telegraphed from Chicago. A dispatch from Cairo direct, however, makes no mention of any such nows, although the arrival of the steamer from Savanna is announced; and another dispatch from Chicago throws doubt upon the whole statement, as no such intelligence had reached headquarters, and dispatches were received from Gen. HALLECK on Thursday, which gave no intimation of an intended immediate attack.

abstract: Late on Thursday night the United States steam transport Cossack arrived at this port, brining 149 wounded men from Newbern and Roanoke. They were in charge of Dr. WHITE, of the Ninth NewYork, and Chaplain J.B. CLARK, and were attended by Lieut. BENNETT, Dr. WHITE, Hospital Stewards HEVITAGE and COOK, and Nurses SMITH and HILL, of the Twenty-fifth Massachusetts, JAMIBSON of Fiftyfirst New-York, HERRICK and TILTON.
lead_paragraph: Late on Thursday night the United States steam transport Cossack arrived at this port, brining 149 wounded men from Newbern and Roanoke. They were in charge of Dr. WHITE, of the Ninth NewYork, and Chaplain J.B. CLARK, and were attended by Lieut. BENNETT, Dr. WHITE, Hospital Stewards HEVITAGE and COOK, and Nurses SMITH and HILL, of the Twenty-fifth Massachusetts, JAMIBSON of Fiftyfirst New-York, HERRICK and TILTON. Early yesterday morning the Cossack was visited by Col. HOWE and Capt. ALMY, of the New-England Soldiers' Relief Association, and Col. BLISS, of Gov. MORGAN's Staff, who did all they could, by carrying with them the good things of this life, to alleviate the sufferings of the wounded. Subjoined is a list of the regiments the men belonged to, and the place where they were wounded:

abstract: Editorial says 2 great chains stretched across Mississippi River have not stopped Union gunboats
snippet: Editorial says 2 great chains stretched across Mississippi River have not stopped Union gunboats
lead_paragraph: -- actual iron chains, mind you, composed of ordinary links -- across the Mississippi River: one of them sixty miles below New-Orleans, to keep us from ascending the river; and the other at Columbus, a thousand miles above New-Orleans, to prevent our descending the river. The one at Columbus was stretched across by Gen. PILLOW, of immortal memory; but like the other military efforts of that old peacock, it proved a wretched failure -- all that remains of it now being a piece a few yards in length lying on the river bank at Columbus, while the gunboats which it was intended to stop are operating a hundred and fitly miles below. The other chain, that near the mouth of the river, would seem to have proved an equally great failure -- that is, if we may credit the report that comes from the South, and which we publish this morning, that one of our gunboats has passed up the river beyond Fort Jackson and Fort St. Philip. The chain stretched from shore to shore between these fortifications was composed of cables stolen from the ships in the harbor of New-Orleans, at the time of the breaking out of this rebellion. It was suspended within a few feet of the surface of the river by rafts, which, in turn, were held in their places by guys, running up stream, and fastened to the neighboring trees. This chain was supposed to be formidable, because our boats must approach it from below, and in striking if would have to push it up stream, having both the strength of the chain and the twice of the current to contend with. The rebels do not inform us whether our gunboats pushed the chain up stream, or "sank it to the depths below," as Com. PORTER said he would do, or ran over it, or crept under it. But it was passed, it would seem, in some way. New-Orleans had three great agencies of defence -- the rebel forts, the rebel chain, and the rebel gunboats. Two of them are now virtually disposed of. It only remains to seize or sink the gunboats, lick the regiment of negroes which guard the city, lick the "Home-guard" militia, and the city is ours. The New-Orleans papers have often descanted, in grandiose style, upon the impregnability of this chain. They can now keep up their spirits for a short time by descanting upon the impregnability of JOURDAINE's Africans, and of HOLLINS' ram, Manassas.

abstract: The work is progressing so rapidly on the ironclad frigate Philadelphia that she will be ready for launching by the first of next month. The 4  ...
lead_paragraph: The work is progressing so rapidly on the ironclad frigate Philadelphia that she will be ready for launching by the first of next month. The 4 1/2 inch iron plates, which are to be below the water-line, are nearly all in place, and those which are to be above the water-line will be put on after she is launched. Her spar-deck is nearly finished. It consists of three inches of wood and one inch of iron. She will be bark-rigged, and her spars so arranged that when in action they all come down to the deck. The ship begins to present a most formidable appearance, and when completed will, no doubt, be able to withstand the shots from any antagonist.

abstract: Editorial says Texas guerrillas are helping Confederates fight war in other Southern States because theirs is only state not occupied by Union soldiers
snippet: Editorial says Texas guerrillas are helping Confederates fight war in other Southern States because theirs is only state not occupied by Union soldiers
lead_paragraph: -- Texas is the only State of the rebel Confederacy which has not National soldiers on its soil, and the National flag unfurled somewhere within its limits. In every other State, from Virginia to Arkansas, from Tennessee to Florida, we have gained a military foothold, and are continually widening our borders. Texas, in the meantime, has sent out a large number of rebel soldiers to fight the battles of JEFF DAVIS. We have encountered Texas rebels in Arizona, in New-Mexico, in Missouri, in Arkansas, in Kentucky, in Tennessee, and in Virginia. Their own State having no need for their services, they have wandered off wherever there was the scent of blood, or a prospect of plunder. These Texas troops are mostly organized as cavalry regiments -- if they may be said to be organized at all. They are must accomplished, however -- quite equal to the Tartars -- great fighters, ferocious, wild and savage, and for certain kinds of work unequaled by any men in the country; they are also more experienced in war than any other of the rebels, from the long fightings with Indians, with the Mexicans, and with each other. The only class of men able to cope with them in their own style were the men of the Lane expedition, which is now completely broken up. It may, however, be an advantage to us that we have got the greater part of the Texas fighters outside oftheir own State, and this side of the Mississippi, and are likely to encounter them en masse at Corinth and in Virginia. It will be much easier for us to defeat them there than it would be in Texas. Twenty thousand guerrillas spread over the vast area of that State would be very hard to cope with or to subdue. Guerillaism in the other Gulf States is almost an impossibility, and in the Border States such a mode of war is opposed to the character and interests of the people. But we have now got the Texas guerillas in such a position that they will have to fight in a way most disadvantageous and disagreeable to themselves; and where, instead of hand-to-hand encounters with knife and shot gun, they will encounter rifled cannon and iron-plated gunboats. When this characteristic semi-savage Texas element is disposed of, it will be a comparatively easy matter to deal with the remnant of ordinary rebels now left in the Lone-Star State.

abstract: Hospital described
snippet: Hospital described
lead_paragraph: A stroll of inspection in and about Bellevue Hospital is not now what it was short years agone, when the ten governors held sway and rats ran riot through its wards seeking whom they might devour, occasionally concentrating over a pauper baby for a midnight lunch, thus emulating their regal co-conspirators who recognized faint difference in value between a rat and a brat; and regarding the unconscious mother upon the all too narrow couch whence their feast has just fallen, as only a pauper whom nobody owns, regaled themselves upon her offspring's tender flesh and yet quivering muscles. These things have given place, and with functionaries dethroned abuses have been abolished and vermin taught to feed on less congenial diet, viz.: poison, which has so disgusted them with the present administration that they have left for parts unknown. Other abuses have been overcome, and economical improvements have superseded them, the last year showing up a goodly array of such. Among these is the little printing office, which gets off, "with skill and dispatch," all the small printing, such as labels, cards, permits, &c., pertaining to the different departments of charity and correction under the Commissioners. The labor of the printing office is all done by Workhouse hands, which saves the salaries which would otherwise be required for outside assistants. There has also been established a telegraph office, connecting all the island institutions and departments in this City with headquarters at No. 1 Bock-street. The mechanical details of the office are conducted by Randuff's Island boys.

abstract: Gen. C.F. SMITH, the melancholy fact of whose death we learn from the West, was on officer of unsurpassed courage and skill; and his loss at the present time will be a great blow to the army of the Southwest, by the men of which he was beloved as was no other commanding officer.
lead_paragraph: Gen. C.F. SMITH, the melancholy fact of whose death we learn from the West, was on officer of unsurpassed courage and skill; and his loss at the present time will be a great blow to the army of the Southwest, by the men of which he was beloved as was no other commanding officer. Gen. SMITH was a regular army officer, and a Pennsylvanian by birth, being a son of the late Dr. SAMUEL B. SMITH, of Philadelphia. He graduated at West Point in 1825, as brevet Second Lieutenant of Artillery. He had successively several responsible positions in the Military Academy up to the year 1842. At the beginning of the Mexican war he held the rank of Captain. He was distinguished in the battles of Palo Alto, Resaca de la Palma, Monterey, Contreras, and Cherubusco, being breveled for each, the last brevet being that of Colonel. In 1854 he received regular promotion as Major of the First Artillery, and in 1855 was made Lieutenant-Colonel of the Tenth Infantry, which rank he held up to last year. At the beginning of the war, he received a commission as Brigadier-General, and was assigned to the command of the Forces at Paducah, Ky., where he acted efficiently and with much vigor. He led his splendid command from there to Fort Donelson, where he was fatally wounded; and his conduct on that great occasion saved for us the day. His heroism and his masterly still was then duly chronicled in these columns. When the army moved up the Tennessee, he accompanied it, and for a time was in chief command. His health, however, got low, and at last he sank so low that he was unable to take the field at the battle of Pittsburgh. He died at Savanna, Tenn., on Friday, the 25th inst. from the effects of a contused wound received at the storming of Fort Donelson. The country and the army, as well as his own family, will suffer a great and deplorable loss in the death of this truly gallant and distinguished soldier.

abstract: Our intelligence from Gen. HALLECK'S army is of the highest importance. Passengers from up the Tennessee, who arrived at Cairo yesterday, report that on Thursday an engagement took place between the advance guards of the National and the rebel armies, in which the rebels were driven back toward Corinth, and that Gen. HALLECK was pushing his whole army vigorously forward. A second dispatch mentions the fact
lead_paragraph: Our intelligence from Gen. HALLECK'S army is of the highest importance. Passengers from up the Tennessee, who arrived at Cairo yesterday, report that on Thursday an engagement took place between the advance guards of the National and the rebel armies, in which the rebels were driven back toward Corinth, and that Gen. HALLECK was pushing his whole army vigorously forward. A second dispatch mentions the fact that a reconnoissance had been made toward Corinth, which was pushed as far as Pea Ridge only six miles from Corinth, where our forces remained from 11 o'clock in the morning until 3 o'clock in the afternoon without molestation. It is probable that another great battle has by this time been fought, unless the rebels have concluded rather to evacuate their positional Corinth -- a contingency which is hinted at in our dispatches.

lead_paragraph: THE TORY FOR 1862 -- FASHION SPRING TROTTINO. The time for the annual Spring meeting of the Fashion Association Club is approaching, and affairs being to assume a trotting shape in the neighborhood of the course. Some of the most prominent competitors for the large stakes are on the ground, and by their fine appearance give high promise of a glorious meeting. There are also several celebrated drivers and trainers permanently at the track, whose well-known experience and established integrity will give confidence to the public. Among the most prominent of them is Mr. S. CROOKS, who has retraining the wonderful [???] station Shepherd Knopp. He is a remarkably pretty animal, 4 years old, and very fast; his backers are prepared to match him against any four-year old trotter alive in the shape of horse flesh. His owner, Mr. HENRY W. GENET; deserves to have one of the best trotters in the land. He has also gain. Lady [???], s.g. What is it? b.w. [???] Lady Crochern. Mr. D. TILLMAN has the following trotters in train at the above course: b.g. Pame, blk.g. Lancet, b.g. Redfford, b.s. Admiral, and a number of green horses. Mr. [???] was in his string b.g. Nature American, s.m. [???], s.g. Nimble Dick, and several [???]. Mr. H. has in train Gen. Butter and some young horses. The trotting will commence on Wednesday, April 30, for a purse of $100, mile heats, best 3 in 5, to wagons, for which there are four entries, size: 3. m. Gill, m. Lady Lincoln, s.g. Tom Murphy, s.g. Nimble Dick. From the premiums which are official for trials of speed, large attendance of the inhabitants of the surrounding countries may be expected, and the proceeds of the meeting are likely to be [???]. The Fashion Course and stables are just now among the most interesting places for in afternoon visit that can be found in the vicinity of New-York.

abstract: The trial of HOWARD C. CONRADY, a member of the Ninth Precinct Police, for shooting PAUL O'NEIL on the morning of the 18th of March last, was concluded yesterday, in the King's County Court of Oyer Terminot, the jury rendering a verdict of "Guilty of manslaughter in the fourth degree," with a recommendation to mercy. This verdict involves ...
lead_paragraph: The trial of HOWARD C. CONRADY, a member of the Ninth Precinct Police, for shooting PAUL O'NEIL on the morning of the 18th of March last, was concluded yesterday, in the King's County Court of Oyer Terminot, the jury rendering a verdict of "Guilty of manslaughter in the fourth degree," with a recommendation to mercy. This verdict involves a sentence of two years' imprisonment in the state Prison, or a less term of imprisonment, or nothing but a fine, in the discretion of the Court.

abstract: Editorial sees decisive battles of war about to take place
snippet: Editorial sees decisive battles of war about to take place
lead_paragraph: With this morning we enter upon a week in transcendently important events. Before another Sunday issue of the TIMES the great battles, which are to determine the military superiority of the combatants in the civil war, and test the comparative value of their material resources, will, in all human likelihood, have been fought, and we shall be hanging with breathless interest over the details of victory or defeat, and peering into the future to measure the consequences of whichever result. For at no previous period of the war has the attitude of the respective parties been so sharply defined; the lists so clearly laid out, or the antagonists drawn up in better preparation for the immediate onset.

abstract: In the Massachusetts Senate, on Thursday last, the Committee on Federal Relations, Mr. NORTHEND, Chairman, submitted a report on iron-clad steamers and the manufacture of ordnance. They refer to the ...
lead_paragraph: In the Massachusetts Senate, on Thursday last, the Committee on Federal Relations, Mr. NORTHEND, Chairman, submitted a report on iron-clad steamers and the manufacture of ordnance. They refer to the former action of the Legislature in the appropriation of $500,000 for coast defences, and to the subsequent authority to use that amount for the construction of one or more iron-clad vessels. The Commissioners appointed by the Governor in relation to iron-clad vessels, in an interview with Capt. ERICSSON, found that from his engagements with the General Government, he could not furnish plans and specifications for the State. It was also ascertained that two of the iron-clad steamers of the Government would be built in Massachusetts, and believing it inexpedient to come into competition with the General Government, it was thought best to plate such vessels partially built as are suited to that purpose, and they have great confidence in a plan of armor covering proposed by Lieut. E.E. STONE, of the navy. If this is approved by the General Government, it is proposed to adopt this plan, and they state that these steamers can be prepared for service in fifty days at an estimate cost of $256,256 each, which will consume the entire appropriation.

abstract: Matter of Josephine Binley. -- This case was stated in the TIMES of yesterday. The girl was brought before the Court on a writ of habeas corpus, having been arrested at Canterbury Hall, under the provisions of the Concert Saloon bill, while passing lager-beer to a person in the saloon. Mr. Brady said it appeared to him that the statute was defective, and that they intended to test the constitutionality of the law. On consent of counsel, the case goes to the General Term for adjudication, and will be brought on at the next Term on the first Monday in May.
lead_paragraph: Matter of Josephine Binley. -- This case was stated in the TIMES of yesterday. abstract: o'clock on Thursday night, Mr. F. GREEN passing his pawn-shop No. 231 West Forty-third-street, on his way home from Brooklyn, discovered a light in his establishment. He immediately concluded that thieves were at work inside, and therefore called officers KELLY and HILDRETH, to aid him in capturing them. Upon entering the store, they discovered that the rear door had been entered by removing the panels. Two men were busily engaged in packing up, preparatory to removal, a large number of watches, jewelry, and other articles. Mr. GREEN at once seized a stick, knocked one of them down, and then handed him over to Officer KELLY. The other burglar, in the meantime, jumped out of the window and tried to make his escape, but Officer HILDRETH soon after took him into custody. He was taken to the station-house and searched. Upon his person were found thirty-one watches, which were identified by Mr. GREEN as having been taken from his store. He gave his name as JOHN MELSON. The other man says his name is MICHAEL BRENNAN. He was taken to the Twentieth Precinct Station-house. Upon searching the premises, a coat containing thirty-nine watches was found by one of GREEN's assistants. The culprits were taken before a Police Magistrate and committed in default of $1,000 bail each.

abstract: THE HOSPITAL FOR SOLDIERS. -- The hospital which has just been fitted up at the corner of SouthFourth and Eric streets, Jersey City, under the direction of Mayor VANVORST, was inaugurated on Friday bythe arrival of several soldiers of the Ninth New-Jersey Regiment who fought so gallantly, and were wounded at the battle of Newbern. The building is two stories in height, 75 feet front and 25 feet deep, well ventilated, and will comfortably accommodate about forty persons The first floor is divided into three apartments; one large room for patients, another for surgical operations, bath and nurses room, and the third for the use of the Ladies' Relief Association. The upper floor is divided into two apartments, filled with spring cot bedsteads, furnished with shaw mattresses and new bedding. The rooms are well lighted and ventilated. The following named soldiers were brought to the hospital on Friday afternoon: JOHN W. DENNIS, from Mount Holly, Company C, on the sick list; will leave for home to-day. GEO. R. WORTH, of Toms River, Company B, gunshot wound in right breast and right arm; will leave for home to-day. WM. P. BURKE. Salem County, Company I, gunshot wound through the right breast; doing well. JONATHAN BURREAL, of Stanhope, Company K; left leg amputated below the knee. JOHN LORENCE, of Gloucester, Company K. both legs shot off below the knee. Mr. LORENCE, who is a very intelligent man, is the one who, while being borne off the field on a litter, cheered on the soldiers as he passed them. He will be provided with cork legs before he leaves.

abstract: The Southern newspapers are amusing the rebel soldiers' leisure by tales to the effect that Gen. HALLECK's army has fled from Pittsburgh and taken refuge in the gunboats, and that HUMPHREY MARSHALL, with the assistance of SMITH, has captured Nashville and taken a great haul of National prisoners. It is astonishing that, after this feat, the redoubtable HUMPHREY is so liberal and lenient as still to permit Gov. ANDREW JOHNSON to rule in the Capital of Tennessee. It is remarkable that he and SMITH do not at once lead a small expedition to the banks of the Tennessee River, and destroy -- say, by torpedoes -- the gunboats on which HALLECK's army has taken refuge, und thereby rid the State at once of the whole Union army. It is highly probable, however, that the prodigious HUMPHREY is making up for time lost in the gaps and hills of Eastern Kentucky, and is devoting himself entirely to gormandizing in his new quarters. He must have attained to a ghostly leanness during his long Winter's campaign among the barren and dreary Cumberland ridges, aggravated also by the two fearful drubbings given him in January and March by Gen. GARFIELD. But having got to Nashville, the question for HUMPHREY now is, how is he going to get away again, even supposing ANDREW JOHNSON requite his leniency by furnishing him with a pass outside of the city limits. For at the risk of furnishing information to the enemy, we would inform the fat knight that HALLECK's army has not taken refuge in the gunboats; but is in very large, in fact overwhelmingly large force, near Pittsburgh; and it would be quite a difficult thing even for the stout HUMPHREY to hew a passage through the National lines. He cannot move over the railroad to his late quarters at Abingdon, for Gen. MITCHEL has completely foiled him in that; he cannot move up the Cumberland by steamer, for Fort Donelson is still in our hands; he cannot move northward over the railway to Louisville, for there his terrible foe, GEO. D. PRENTICE, is perpetually on the watch for him. In fact, there is no way of escape whatever; and, if it should be that he and SMITH have surreptitiously crept into Nashville, the best thing for him, at least, to do, is to stay there, give up soldiering, in which he has made such a ridiculous failure, take the oath of allegiance, and spend the last half of his life as he spent the first, in gluttony and drunkenness -- that is to say, if Gov. JOHNSON do not first hang him. But, notwithstanding the assertions of the Mobile Tribune, we agree with the skeptics of the Richmond Examiner in seriously doubting whether, after all, SMITH and HUMPHREY MARSHALL really have captured Nashville. Serious inquirers are referred to ANDREW JOHNSON, at that place.
lead_paragraph: The Southern newspapers are amusing the rebel soldiers' leisure by tales to the effect that Gen. HALLECK's army has fled from Pittsburgh and taken refuge in the gunboats, and that HUMPHREY MARSHALL, with the assistance of SMITH, has captured Nashville and taken a great haul of National prisoners. It is astonishing that, after this feat, the redoubtable HUMPHREY is so liberal and lenient as still to permit Gov. ANDREW JOHNSON to rule in the Capital of Tennessee. It is remarkable that he and SMITH do not at once lead a small expedition to the banks of the Tennessee River, and destroy -- say, by torpedoes -- the gunboats on which HALLECK's army has taken refuge, und thereby rid the State at once of the whole Union army. It is highly probable, however, that the prodigious HUMPHREY is making up for time lost in the gaps and hills of Eastern Kentucky, and is devoting himself entirely to gormandizing in his new quarters. He must have attained to a ghostly leanness during his long Winter's campaign among the barren and dreary Cumberland ridges, aggravated also by the two fearful drubbings given him in January and March by Gen. GARFIELD. But having got to Nashville, the question for HUMPHREY now is, how is he going to get away again, even supposing ANDREW JOHNSON requite his leniency by furnishing him with a pass outside of the city limits. For at the risk of furnishing information to the enemy, we would inform the fat knight that HALLECK's army has not taken refuge in the gunboats; but is in very large, in fact overwhelmingly large force, near Pittsburgh; and it would be quite a difficult thing even for the stout HUMPHREY to hew a passage through the National lines. He cannot move over the railroad to his late quarters at Abingdon, for Gen. MITCHEL has completely foiled him in that; he cannot move up the Cumberland by steamer, for Fort Donelson is still in our hands; he cannot move northward over the railway to Louisville, for there his terrible foe, GEO. D. PRENTICE, is perpetually on the watch for him. In fact, there is no way of escape whatever; and, if it should be that he and SMITH have surreptitiously crept into Nashville, the best thing for him, at least, to do, is to stay there, give up soldiering, in which he has made such a ridiculous failure, take the oath of allegiance, and spend the last half of his life as he spent the first, in gluttony and drunkenness -- that is to say, if Gov. JOHNSON do not first hang him. But, notwithstanding the assertions of the Mobile Tribune, we agree with the skeptics of the Richmond Examiner in seriously doubting whether, after all, SMITH and HUMPHREY MARSHALL really have captured Nashville. Serious inquirers are referred to ANDREW JOHNSON, at that place.

abstract: A sermon was preached last Sunday by Rev. N. L. RIOE, D.D., of this City, in which he took occasion to define his position on the great question of the day.
lead_paragraph: A sermon was preached last Sunday by Rev. N. L. RIOE, D.D., of this City, in which he took occasion to define his position on the great question of the day. He took as his text, "Render therefore unto Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and unto God the things that are God's." Dr. RICE proposed to depart from his ordinary course and speak upon a subject which he seldom deemed it expedient to introduce into the pulpit, viz.: The state of the country and his own position with reference to it. He did this not for the purpose of stirring up the patriotic feeling of his people. It was wholly unnecessary at such a time as this, when that feeling was just as intense and earnest as it was desirable it should be. Why stir up patriotism when it it is already at the burning point? Patriotism is not a Christian virtue. It is just as natural to love one's country as to love one's home. Multitudes love both who are not Christians. Yet patriotism may be guided and directed by Christian principles. Indeed, it sometimes happen that that which is natural is too strong. Parents sometimes commit a sort of idolatry in the love which they lavish on their children; and men sometimes, in their ardent love of country, forget their country's interest. Christianity serves to moderate those natural feelings when too strong, and make men not only patriots, but, what is nobler philanthropists -- lovers of all mankind. It is remarkable, that there is no command in the Bible to love our country: so that, if one were about to preach upon that subject, he would be perplexed about a text. If patriotism seems not to exist in any instance, it is because depravity has destroyed natural affection. So, if you would restore natural affection, you must elevate the morals; if you would bring back a man's love of country, restore his moral sense. If we have morals and religion, patriotism will not be wanting.

abstract: -- The affair at Elizabeth City has furnished an illustration of what manner of news it is the public gets when left to the War office, unaided by reporters of the Press. The first story furnished by the censorship at Fortress Monroe was a rebel rumor, obtained at Norfolk, that a portion of Gen. BURNSIDE's command had sustained a repulse in attempting to land at Elizabeth City, the victors numbering only one thousand against five thousand of the vanquished. Then, through the same channel, though not from Norfolk, came a statement that the Union force was victorious, and the enemy badly beaten. A series of obscure and contradictory rumors followed, one of which, apparently authentic, represented a number of National soldiers, wounded in the conflict, as having reached Norfolk, and as awaiting exchange. This was not symptomatic of victory. The public knew not what to think. At last we know that the National troops did sustain a repulse. Under Gen. RENO, they landed at the point indicated, drove the enemy before them for some distance, and then learning that the rebels had been reinforced, left their wounded behind them, and took to their transports. This is not the way of victors. To trust the wounded to the foe is the best evidence of a hasty retreat -- a position somewhat cogently argued against the claim of BEAUREGARD to a victory at Pittsburgh Landing. Disagreeable as this conclusion is, we can only accept it as act. And as a sequel of the manifold variations, and the dense obscurity spread about the story by "official dispatches," we are disposed to institute a comparison advantageous to "our own correspondents." If, unaided by the Press, the public had waited for the first official tidings of the battle of Pittsburgh, it would have been a week before the long-suffering public would have known from official dispatches that any such battle had been fought. If a reporter of the Press had been at Elizabeth City, and had been permitted to report what be saw, the vexatious tissue of contradictions with which the official censors and official reporters have obfuscated the public for a week past, would have been entirely avoided.

abstract: Contrary to the expectations formed last Winter, the work of fitting the Merchants' Exchange to be used as the Custom-house of the port, has not, as yet, been commenced. Some months since the Sub-Treas
lead_paragraph: Contrary to the expectations formed last Winter, the work of fitting the Merchants' Exchange to be used as the Custom-house of the port, has not, as yet, been commenced. Some months since the Sub-Treasurer, Mr. CISCO, wrote to the Secretary of the Treasury, calling his attention to the fact that the building at present occupied as the Sub-Treasury, was inadequate to the wants of the Department, and urging that some provision should be speedily made for his better accommodation. The proposition then made was, that the Government should purchase or lease the building at present known as the Merchants' Exchange, to which the business of the Custom-house should be transferred. It was argued that the building was much better adapted for the purpose intended than any in the City, being large, commodious and well located. It was shown that it contained a much greater space than the building now occupied as the Custom-house; in fact, that it was sufficiently large for the accommodation, not only of the Collector and Naval Officer, but also of the Surveyor and Appraisers. It was also proposed that should the Merchants' Exchange be occupied by the Government for the purposes indicated, the present Custom-house should be transformed into the Sub-Treasury. These propositions met with favor with the authorities at Washington, and the result of the deliberations on the subject was that Mr. S.M. CLARK, acting engineer in charge of the Treasury Department, was sent to New-York to examine the building it was proposed to obtain. In course of time the authorities decided to lease the Merchants' Exchange, and the bargain was quickly made with the owners on terms considered advantageous to the Government. By removing the business of the Custom-house to this building, and that of the Sub-Treasury to the present Custom-house, the expenses of the Government are, we believe, by the estimates of Mr. CISCO, diminished instead of increased, as many supposed they would be. The following is a list of the Government buildings at present occupied by officers whose business is connected with the collection of revenue at this port.

abstract: -- Our last intelligence from Mexico has points of importance beyond those already noticed in our columns. So impatient were the French to set out on their expedition against the Republic, that they could not even wait till after the conferences which were to open on the 15th, but called a meeting of the allied Plenipotentiaries at Orizaba, and announced their determination to commence at once their march toward the capital. To this the English and Spanish objected, and began to make preparations for a return to Vera Cruz, thus terminating the European coalition for the subjugation of Mexico. It appears, however, that, although England and Spain have withdrawn from the enterprise, France is not without an ally. She has found in the very heart of the Commonwealth, confederates more unscrupulous, and merciless, than were the foreigners who have just abandoned her. For the sake of recovering power, the Reactionist Party, with ALMONTE at its head, has thrown itself into the arms of the invaders, and raised the standard of rebellion against the Government -- the Republic. A programme has been also issued by the rebel leader, doubtless, with the sanction of his patrons, which will give us some idea of his audacity, and of the designs of the aggressors. In this paper, after deploring the intolerable evils which the supremacy of the Liberals has inflicted on Mexico, our new candidate for empire, proceeds to set forth the objects of the plot. The authority of President JUAREZ having been repudiated, a Supreme Chief of the Mexican nation and forces is to be nominated, who is to be empowered to treat with the interventionists, and to guarantee security of life and property, as well to natives as to all foreigners sojourning in the territory of the Republic. Of course the man to be thus exalted and trusted is to be no other than ALMONTE himself; but whether he is to be rewarded for his treason by being simply raised to the First Magistracy of the Mexican Union, or by being constituted its Dictator, like SANTA ANA, or by being placed in the throne which was intended for the Austrian, does not as yet clearly appear. It is probable, however, that, while NAPOLEON is about the thing, he may as well transform Mexico into a kingdom, and put its crown upon the head of its protege, as invest him with every attribute of tyranny save the title. Would not that of NEPOMUCENO the First sound as fairly and become the page of history as well as the name of MAXIMILIAN? But as the Emperor is now freed from English and Spanish trammels, perhaps he will consider the of the Prime Minister quite reward enough for the services of ALMONTE, and reserve the royal dignity for some scion of the House of Bonaparte. Let us wait and see.

abstract: Editorial attacks journalistic loyalty of Journal of Commerce and Evening Express
snippet: Editorial attacks journalistic loyalty of Journal of Commerce and Evening Express
lead_paragraph: The Journal of Commerce has been readmitted to the privileges of the mails. The Evening Express has never been excluded from them. Both are generously tolerated by the public authorities, but for no truth or genuine loyalty to the Government. The recent course of the one, in all that relates to the end of the war, le jesuitical; that of the other, sneaking and characteristic. The morning attacks of the senior laborer in this vocation are rehashed with comments and commendation for the afternoon editions of the junior. We cannot say that they are improved by the process, but altogether they constitute as notable specimens of latent treason as one need look upon in the midst of the largest, as it is one of the most loyal and tolerant communities in the country. Their authors grow bold in the work in proportion to the decisive nature of the victories of our army, upon the calculation, no doubt that their readers may now safely dispense with even their pretended support of the Government. In this sense, perhaps, the matter is one of public indifference, but the motive is not the less wicked, nor the meanness with which it is habitually indulged of late the less offensive to public decency.

abstract: The city is wild with rejoicing to-night over the news of the advance of our gunboats upon New-Orleans, in spite of the resistance of Forts Jackson and Philip, and the probable surrender of that city from the vile clutches of rebeldom, and its return to loyalty and trade with all the world. New-Orleans is probably in possession of Gen. BUTLER at present writing. The President is in high glee over the news.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sunday, April 27.

abstract: A VISIT TO FREDERICKSBURGH.  Mr. COVODE, from the Committee on the Conduct of the War, recently paid a visit to Falmouth, opposite Fredericksburgh, to note the movements in McDOWELL'S column. He returned yesterday, and after reporting progress, left in the afternoon train for Philadelphia, Harrisburgh and Pittsburgh.

abstract: The military excitement here seems almost to have died out with the echoes of the guns that de- cided the possession of Pulaski. The little affair on Wilmington Island, of which I wrote you, was like a sharp thundergust succeeding a wild tempest; but the lightning marked its path with blood. The real warfare of elements also ceased about the same time; and the peaceful landscape now sparkles and glows in the brightest of sunlight.

abstract: The work is progressing so rapidly on the iron-clad frigate Philadelphia that site will be ready for launching by the first of next month. The 4 1/2-inch iron plates, which are to be below the waterline, are nearly all in place, and those which are to be above the waterline will be put on after she is launched. Her spar-deck is nearly finished. It consists of three inches of wood and one inch of iron. She will be bark-rigged, and her spars so arranged that when in action they all come down to the deck. The ship begins to present a most formidable appearance, and when completed will, no doubt, be able to withstand the shots from any antagonist.
lead_paragraph: The work is progressing so rapidly on the iron-clad frigate Philadelphia that site will be ready for launching by the first of next month. The ship begins to present a most formidable appearance, and when completed will, no doubt, be able to withstand the shots from any antagonist.

abstract: The population of New-Orleans, by the last census, was 168,472. This has, undoubtedly, been largely decreased since the rebellion. The commerce of the city, which was its main support, has been totally ruined, and thousands of the people have fled to the country, or anywhere that they could find a scanty subsistence, while other thousands have been drafted into the rebel army. The city is the emporium of the Mississippi Valley, and is situated on the left bank of the river, about a hundred miles from its mouth. The older portion of the city is built on the convex side of a bend of the river, which here sweeps around in a northeast, east, and southeast course. From this location it derives its familiar soubriquet of the "Crescent City." In the progress of its growth up stream, the city has now so extended itself as to fill the hollow of a curve in the opposite direction, so that the river front presents an outline somewhat resembling the letter S. It stretches or straggles along the bank of the liver some six or seven miles, with an average depth of one mile, it only being possible to build on the narrow strip of land lying immediately on the edge of the river, the highest point being in front, and then rapidly sinking in the rear until lost in interminable swamps. In the rear of New-Orleans, a half a male, perhaps, beyond the suburbs, is the Metarie ridge, a narrow strip of high land two or three feet above high water mark, of an average of a half mile in width; then you come again to the swamp, which continues to the shores of the take beyond, almost as dense as any in the surrounding valley, gloomy and peculiar and uninhabited, except by alligators and bitterns. The front of New-Orleans is of course on the river, and from the peculiarity of the country, and the levee which serves to protect the city from being overflowed by the Spring rise, our fleet, when it reached the city, must have been above the ground on which the city is built, and commanded it as from an eminence. This circumstance, with the fact that the breaking of the levee by a cannon-shot, or a few minutes' work with the spade, would submerge the whole place, makes New-Orleans, with its defenceless rear, the weakest and least protected place of any commercial importance in the world. The defences of the city were so fully and, as the event has proved, accurately described in the TIMES of Monday last, that it is not necessary now to rehearse the facts. What has become of the rebel gunboats and rains, of which we have heard so much, it is hard to conjecture.

abstract: The closing of most of the volunteer rendezvous has had a stimulating effect upon recruiting for the regular army. The various offices in the City booked upward of thirty men last week, which is more than double the weekly average of the last three months, and, in addition to this, the applicants generally were of a better class than those who usually present themselves for enlistment.
lead_paragraph: The closing of most of the volunteer rendezvous has had a stimulating effect upon recruiting for the regular army. The various offices in the City booked upward of thirty men last week, which is more than double the weekly average of the last three months, and, in addition to this, the applicants generally were of a better class than those who usually present themselves for enlistment. The country stations are beginning to send more men in, both to Governor's Island and to the two regiments -- the Eighth and Twelfth Infantry -- at Fort Hamilton, Company A of the Eighth has been full some time, and its Captain, Col. M. COOGSWELL, of the Tammany Regiment. is very anxious to lead it to the held, if he cannot go back to the Tammany. The Colonel is still on parole, and there does not appear to be any immediate likelihood of his being exchanged. Lieut. S.P. FERRIS, of this regimen, has taken charge of the rendezvous in Eighth-avenue.

abstract: From a report received to-day, there is little doubt that the information communicated to the rebels in an editorial in Friday's issue of the Herald is being acted upon. The report alluded to is to the effect that a strong rebel force is concentrating, prob- ably from Richmond and Yorktown, at a point about six miles south of Fredericksburgh, for the purpose of disputing McDOWELL'S advance across the Rappahannock.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sunday, April 27.

abstract: NEW-ORLEANS is repossessed! The mortar and gunboat fleet of Capt. PORTER is in front of the City. The rebels have fled in conster- nation, after destroying, by military order, all the cotton in the presses and warehouses of the place, and burning all the steam craft at the wharves, except such as were required to carry off the munitions and supplies of the army, for which they would seem to have no use at home.
lead_paragraph: NEW-ORLEANS is repossessed! The mortar and gunboat fleet of Capt. PORTER is in front of the City. The rebels have fled in conster- nation, after destroying, by military order, all the cotton in the presses and warehouses of the place, and burning all the steam craft at the wharves, except such as were required to carry off the munitions and supplies of the army, for which they would seem to have no use at home. The news comes through rebel sources, and on the point of resistance, after PORTER had successfully passed Forts Jackson and St. Philip, the dispatches are somewhat blind. But the plain inference is that more thought was taken as to how the rebel forces should make their own exit than of the way to resist PORTER's entrance. The telegraphic operator, after announcing the appearance of the fleet, the consternation of the city, the wanton destruction of property under martial rule, took his own hasty leave, and in this probably followed, rather than anticipated, the example of the rebel army of defence.

abstract: PHILHARMONIC SOCIETY. -- The fifth and last Concert given by this Society came off on Saturday evening at Irving Hall, under the conductorship of THEODORE EISFELD. It was, as usual, crowded by those who love, or pretend that they love classical music, while the dilettanti of the City, whether possessed of a profound critical taste or not, clustered around the entrances to the hall in true dilettante fashion. The programme was sufficiently good, although its arrangement was ill-judged. As an example of this, we may mention that LIPINSKY's "Concerto Militaire," for the violin, (executed cleverly by BRUNO WOLLENHAUPT,) was placed immediately after SCHUBERT's Symphony in C, and lost in effect considerably by the ridiculous contrast enforced between the merit of the two compositions. The Symphony, which is fine in conception, and very delicately treated by the master, is full of coloring and vitality, and was very satisfactorily rendered by Mr. EISFELD, who is one of the best conductors -- if not the best -- that Society has had since it was first instituted. It, however, suffered from the want of sufficient rehearsals, as we should presume. We may point out that the third movement needed a more sedulous attention to its nuances, and was deficient in the requisite amount of light and shade, which SCHUBERT so peremptorily demands from his translators; while portions of the fourth --which is a very difficult study for the stringed instruments -- went rather unsteadily. These two compositions constituted the First Part of the Concert. The Second commenced with "Orphee," a Poeme Symphonique, by LISTZ, which was played for the first time. This pleased us much better than we had expected, and we believe we are right in stating that this was the general impression of the audience. It is a brief study, somewhat slight in general character, and not so pronouncedly personal as most of the master's works ordinarily are. Then came MOZART's "Concerte No. 8, in D," for the piano. This was played by Mr. RICHARD HOFTMANN, who wants largeness of style to render the greater composers as massively as they demand. Probably on this account, it went off somewhat tamely. As a compensation for this, we had a concertino for the trombone, written by FELICIEN DAVID, which took us by surprise, as, from his instrumental writing for the violin, we are free to own that we had by no means anticipated so striking and talented a work. But, if the composer agreeably disappointed us in this, which was given for the first time, we are bound to say that more than one-half of our unexpected pleasure was due to the style in which it was rendered by the artist, F. HERSCH. The adagio in the second movement, which was very charming, was translated by him in a most masterly manner, and deserves the warmest critical recognition. Both in delicacy and refined power, he is indisputably the best performer on the trombone at present in this City. As a conclusion, we had the overture to BEETHOVEN's "Fidelio," of which more than enough criticism has been written, and, at present, the notices of it resolve themselves into simple eulogy. The orchestra of course rendered it with precision and feeling.

abstract: May
snippet: May
lead_paragraph: The Atlantic Monthly, for May, is as bright and fresh as the season. It opens with an excellent paper, entitled "Man Under Sealed Orders," from the pen of Rev. J. TREADWELL WALDEN, of Norwich, Conn., who takes an ariel flight with the electric telegraph and the steam-engine, and when they droop their weary wings, soars further on the pinions of Christian trust into that lofty region of moral progress and perfection which balance and complete our physical successes. "My Garden," a pleasant morning walk and chit-chat, by Miss M.A. DODGE; "Lyrics of the Street," by Mrs. JULIA WARD HOWE; the "South Breaker," by Miss HARRIET B. PRESCOTT; "Methods of Study in natural History," by Prof. AGASSIZ; "Spirits," by Mrs. L.M. CHILD; "The "Titmouse," by RALPH WALDO EMERSON, outvieing in peculiarity all that is Emersonian or in any other way peculiar; "Saltpetre as a Source of Power," by Prof. A.A. HAYES, and "Weather in War," by C.C. HAZEWELL, two useful and readable Articles in their way; "Lines Written Under a Portrait of Theodore Winthrop," a little gem of taste and fooling; "Hindrance," by DAVID A. WASSON; "The Statesmanship of Richelieu-Scholarly, Keen, Profound" -- by Prof. A.D. WHITE, of the Michigan University; Under the Snow," by the late Gen. F.W. LANDER -- a piece of sculpture in rhyme, worthy of the cunning chisel with which the noble sister of this dead knight of olden time in modern days molds the obedient marble: "Slavery in its Principles, Development and Expedients; "The Volunteer," by ELBRIDGE J. CATLER; "Speech of Hon. Preserved Doc in Secret Caucus," by JAMES RUSELL LOWELL., and a series of brief and literary notices, make up this varied and acceptable number.

abstract: A correspondent, in another column, takes us to task for pronouncing the spirit of the various confiscation bills heretofore introduced into Congress to be vindictive. He argues generally against a disposition to deal leniently with rebels and traitors; and advocates the employment of all means tributary to the termination of the war. So far as the leaders of the rebellion are concerned, we presume we are not exposed to the charge of undue clemency, since we have pointed them out as for objects for the extreme visitation of law. It must be in regard to the mass of Southern people that we are in fault, because we advocate an act of general amnesty to these. And here a wide discussion opens. Are we nowhere in the South to find or make friends to the Union! Are we to treat brethren whose ignorance we have pitied, and whom we admit to have been misled into insurrection by a class of men in whose counsels they have been accustomed to confide implicitly, as a subjugated and impoverished people? And against them are we to use any means tributary to the extinction of the rebellion? If so, and we must rob them of property which procures them food, may we not logically bombard and burn down the property that gives them shelter, and strip them of the garments which protect them from the weather? May we not massacre them pitilessly? For all these are instrumentalities which protract the war; and if we make war upon these so much will we shorten the rebellion. The truth is, in trying to make just enough of a case to free all the slaves on the South, our correspondent inevitably proves too much. He opens the door for practices utterly repudiated by civilized warfare. By the law of South Carolina the slave is as much property as the house and land and cattle of his legal owner. The Federal Government professes to admit the property in the one case to be under State law quite as inviolable as the other. But no property can be confiscated for a longer period than the life-time of the owner; and this only after due trial and conviction for treason. What will our correspondent have? Will he hang 8,000,000 of people, one by one, for treason. Will he confiscate all the property, real and personal, of the South, for practically it is the possession of traitors? If not, if he will all stop short anywhere of this extreme measure, had ho not better pause at the limit marked by humanity, conciliation and the TIMES?

Are we to treat brethren whose ignorance we have pitied, and whom we admit to have been misled into insurrection by a class of men in whose counsels they have been accustomed to confide implicitly, as a subjugated and impoverished people? And against them are we to use any means tributary to the extinction of the rebellion? If so, and we must rob them of property which procures them food, may we not logically bombard and burn down the property that gives them shelter, and strip them of the garments which protect them from the weather? May we not massacre them pitilessly? For all these are instrumentalities which protract the war; and if we make war upon these so much will we shorten the rebellion. The truth is, in trying to make just enough of a case to free all the slaves on the South, our correspondent inevitably proves too much. He opens the door for practices utterly repudiated by civilized warfare. By the law of South Carolina the slave is as much property as the house and land and cattle of his legal owner. The Federal Government professes to admit the property in the one case to be under State law quite as inviolable as the other. But no property can be confiscated for a longer period than the life-time of the owner; and this only after due trial and conviction for treason. What will our correspondent have? Will he hang 8,000,000 of people, one by one, for treason. Will he confiscate all the property, real and personal, of the South, for practically it is the possession of traitors? If not, if he will all stop short anywhere of this extreme measure, had ho not better pause at the limit marked by humanity, conciliation and the TIMES?

abstract: Editorial favors uniform postage rate like that used in Great Britain
snippet: Editorial favors uniform postage rate like that used in Great Britain
lead_paragraph: When the British Government established the penny postage, the English law-makers saw that there would be a vast increase of correspondence, and that to give the people the greatest possible, advantage of the new facilities and low charges, and make the labor in tho Post Office as economical as possible, a11 redundant operations, useless ceremonies and everything like extra charges and double payments must be laid aside, or the new system would be a failure. Our law-makers andPostal authorities are nearly as shrewd; they are decidedly so in one thing -- they take precious good care to attach so many troublesome and expensive processes and petty labors to the mailing and reception of letters on the part of the public, that there will be very few letters sent through the mails. While the American people have the highest social qualities, probably no civilized country on the face of the globe has so small a social correspondence. The population of France -- not two millions more than in the United States -- write 300,000,000 letters annually; while Great Britain, with a less population than our own, has a yearly correspondence of 564,000,000 letters; and ours has never exceeded 160,000,000.

Ex- press, and by the latter from a copy of the Rich- mond Examiner of Saturday.
lead_paragraph: New-Orleans has fallen! This glorious intelli- gence comes to us from the rebels, and we therefore have no right to doubt its correctness. The War Department has received the news from both Gen. WOOL and Gen. McDOWELL taken by the former from a copy of the Petersburgh (Va.) Ex- press, and by the latter from a copy of the Rich- mond Examiner of Saturday. It is announced that our forces passed Fort Jackson on Thursday morning at 4 o'clock, and that when the news reached New-Orleans the excitement was boundless. Martial law was put in full force, and business was completely suspended. All the cotton in the city was burnt, and all the steamboats, excepting such as were necessary to transport coin, ammunition, etc. At 1 o'clock on Friday telegraphic communication was stopped by the operator at New-Orleans, with the announcement that the National forces had appeared before the City. Further details will probably reach us to-day, by the way of Fortress Monroe.

abstract: The combined movements ordered by Gen. FREMONT against the guerrilias in Webster County have proved eminently successful. Lieut. The town of Addison, a small place, the only one in the new county, being deserted, was burned.

abstract: Editorial on frauds in Government contracts
snippet: Editorial on frauds in Government contracts
lead_paragraph: The full length and official report of what occurred in the House of Representatives on Friday, on the matter of Army and Navy con- tracts, is rather a discreditable exhibition of personalities. At the same time some public good may come of it, and certain private reputations will not profit by it. Beyond the circumstance that Mr. DAWES, of Massachusetts, led the discussion, on behalf of his Committee, who had been violently assailed in their absence the previous Monday, the whole affair appears to be a Pennsylvania story. CAMERON, CUMMINGS and STEVENS, all of that old Commonwealth, are arraigned for jobbery; while STEVENS, KELLY and MOREHEAD, of the Pennsylvania delegation, are made counsel for the defence. To be sure, Mr. COLFAX, of Indiana, is brought to their assistance, not so much, perhaps, as the apologist of the Ex-Secretary of War, as the assailant of the Committee for their mode of investigation of the Fremont contracts. It will scarcely be denied that Mr. DAWES makes a strong case against the Pennsylvanians, and in it he is backed by his entire Committee. A couple of errors in the report weakened his position somewhat before the House, and one of these he found it rather embarrassing, in reply to Mr. KELLY, to explain away, the mistake involving a serious injustice to CUMMINGS, which ought, perhaps, to have been acknowledged on the application of CUMMINGS himself, several months ago.

abstract: The news of the capture of New-Orleans which we received from the South at a late hour last night, clears up gloriously the mystery which for some time has Lung around the movements of our navy and army upon the Lower Mississippi. We had already had intelligence that our bombketches had opened fire upon Fort Jackson, 60 miles below the city, and yesterday morning we published news derived from the rebels that one of our gunboats had run past that work. But the defenders of the fort, it was said, had sent word to their friends that they were confident of their strength, and were able to endure the shelling as long as our fleet was able to keep it up. That news was up to Tuesday last. It appears certain that, notwithstanding the rebel bombast, Fort Jackson, and probably, also, Fort St. Philip, on the opposite side of the river, were reduced that very day; for by the gray dawn of Wednesday morning, our armada had steamed past the fortifications, and by noon it appeared, with power and terror, before the Crescent City. At this point the telegram stops short, and leaves us completely in the dark as to what has been done during the past four days. Whether Gen. BUTLER, as is probable, sent in a demand for the capitulation of the city, and what may have followed -- a compliance with, or refusal of the terms of the demand -- we do not yet know. But it is altogether unlikely that any serious attempt was made to defend the city itself. Indeed, New-Orleans was utterly incapable of defence, when once our fleet got in front of it. With a hundred gun and mortarboats riding high above the city, ready to pour down upon it a torrent of fire and iron, it would be madness for the rebels to dream of any other terms than unconditional surrender. It has been thought that the land force accompanying the expedition was too small to repossess a city, which must still count somewhat like a hundred and fifty thousand inhabitants. And so it would be if the military contingent had to act alone. But the fact is, that the naval arm when once raised over the city, was of itself sufficient to hold it in complete subjection. And the only work for the troops would be to seize and garrison some few important positions in the city, raise the Stars and Stripes over the United States property and other public places, and act as a repressive police force. The rebels will be disarmed; the Union element, which is known to be strong in New-Orleans, will be organized; and Gen. BUTLER, from his headquarters in the St. Charles Hotel, will put in force whatever other measures are necessary for the securing of public order.

abstract: editorial questions whether Beauregard has evacuated Corinth
snippet: editorial questions whether Beauregard has evacuated Corinth
lead_paragraph: -- No one will be surprised at hearing of the evacuation of Corinth. Two or three rumors to the effect that BEAUREGARD has already departed are current, the probable forerunners of the truth. With the seizure of New-Orleans the possession of the Mississippi is transferred to the National forces. The Arkansas and the Red River are at the mercy of our gunboats, and Federal transports can land Federal troops wherever they are wanted. BEAUREGARD is thus hemmed in on the North, the East and the West; his supplies and communications cut off; and he has the alternative of retreating upon Memphis or Mobile, or of fighting under desperate conditions an enemy greatly his superior in strength and discipline. The news that our flotilla had passed Fort Jackson was doubtless carried to him on Thursday last. On Friday he must have known of the immediate proximity to the city of the Union forces, and of the abandonment of all thought of defence on the part of the inhabitants. The significance of this news was distinct. The source upon which he chiefly relied for supplies and reinforcements was lost to him. The enemy, in what force he knew not, might from that direction assail his rear; the river was in hostile hands, and even at Memphis he might find FOOTE and FARRAGUT effecting a junction, in order to bombard that much-fearing city. In these circumstances, we may well imagine the rebel General to be grievously beset, and solicitous to find less crowded quarters. Jackson, Miss., is named as the position selected for another stand. The probabilities, however, are, that when Corinth is left, some point, on the railroad to Mobile will be the next halting-place, the rebel chief naturally desiring to reach the system of railroads by which he may rejoin the rebel army in the Atlantic States. Separated from that, and from his base at New-Orleans, he is certainly lost.

abstract: Five contrabands left Portsmouth, opposite Norfolk, at 1 o'clock last night, and arrived here this morning. They bring several late papers and much valuable information. They are intelligent men, and give interesting accounts of affairs in the vicinity of Norfolk. They confirm the reported capture of New-Orleans by our forces, and state that much excitement prevails in the South regarding it.

lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship North Amercan off Cape Race, we receive advices from Europe five days later. She left Liverpool on the 17th, and Londonderry on the 18th inst. The political news is not of much importance. A deputationof the British and Foreign Anti-Slavery Society had waited upon Minister ADAMS, and presented an address, in which the hope is expressed that the restoration of the Union will be founded upon the abolition of the true cause of strife. Mr. ADAMS' reply is said to have been satisfactory to the deputation. Cotton was buoyant and 1/2d.@1/4d. higher for American. The sales of the week were 80,000 bales, and on Friday 12,000 bales. The advance on other descriptions was 1/4d.@3/4d. Breadstuffs closed firm, and with a still advancing tendency. Provisions quiet and steady. Consols closed at 93 7/8@94 for money.

abstract: We have been at some trouble on this side of the Atlantic, to startle the indifference with which the progress of our arms is regarded on the other. Our efforts have thus far proved successful. Fort Henry, Fort Donelson, Pea Ridge, Island Ten, Roanoke and Newbern, the occupation of Nashville and Huntsville, have been so many events which, with our better knowledge here, we have been able to appreciate at their full significance, but which in England, and to some extent in France, have failed to attract that notice and receive the appreciation which they have certainly deserved, if we have demanded a recognition of the fighting qualities exhibited by our volunteers, it is because the army has been treated in Europe as an undisciplined rabble, incapable of the achievements of regulars, and frightfully subject to panic fears. If we have sought fair appreciation of the material advances made in restoring the Southern States to the Union, it is only because public opinion in Europe has decided a restoration of the Union to be impossible, and knowing the contrary, and possessing, to prove it, the hard facts of battles won and territory recovered, we have not unnaturally sought to make this testimony exert a proper effect upon transatlantic prejudice.
lead_paragraph: We have been at some trouble on this side of the Atlantic, to startle the indifference with which the progress of our arms is regarded on the other. abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a communication was received from the Secretary of the Interior, concerning the number and ages of the slaves in the District of Columbia. Petitions were presented from tobacco manufacturers, asking for a reduction of the proposed tax on tobacco. A bill relative to the organization of the Signal Department of the army was indefinitely postponed. The Secretary of War was requested to inquire into the condition of the Harper's Ferry Archery, and  whether it is expedient to restore it. A bill was introduced to prevent the importation of adulterated liquors by providing a punishment therefor. The resolutions of the Ohio Legislature, relative to the rebel prisoners at Camp Chase and the slaves were referred to the Military Committee. Mr. TRUMBULL's bill for the more convenient enforcement of the laws, etc., was passed. The Senate soon afterward went into executive session, and when the doors were opened, adjourned.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a communication was received from the Secretary of the Interior, concerning the number and ages of the slaves in the District of Columbia. abstract: -- The last act of the rebel Congress was to order a sweeping conscription. Simultaneously, the National Government ordered a cessation of voluntary enlistments. The one drives the people to arms at the point of the bayonet; the other has to shut the door upon the throng who insist on serving the country. No illustration of the relative strength of the parties to the struggle could be more instructive.

abstract: William Grosnenor vs. The New-Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company. -- This was an action to recover damages for an injury to the plaintiff while being carried on the defendants' road. The plaintiff gave evidence to show the following facts: He took the cars at Jersey City on Sept. 1, 1860, to go to Newark. Some friends were with him, but there was not room for all of them in one car, and plaintiff and mother went into the smoking car. When the car reached Centro-street, the conductor called out Newark, but the train did not come to a full stop. Plaintiff got off on the platform when his friend knocked on the window and told him that was the wrong station, and he then caught hold of the ratling of the car to jump on again, the car being in motion, but could not get on, and was dragged some twenty feet when he fell and injured his foot. He was taken into the sitting-room and a doctor sent for, who, however, refused to do anything for his foot until the railroad doctor came. He was then sent over to New-York, went to the hospital, and was there nearly six months before he could walk even with crutches.
lead_paragraph: William Grosnenor vs. The New-Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company. -- This was an action to recover damages for an injury to the plaintiff while being carried on the defendants' road. The plaintiff gave evidence to show the following facts: He took the cars at Jersey City on Sept. 1, 1860, to go to Newark. Some friends were with him, but there was not room for all of them in one car, and plaintiff and mother went into the smoking car. When the car reached Centro-street, the conductor called out Newark, but the train did not come to a full stop. Plaintiff got off on the platform when his friend knocked on the window and told him that was the wrong station, and he then caught hold of the ratling of the car to jump on again, the car being in motion, but could not get on, and was dragged some twenty feet when he fell and injured his foot. He was taken into the sitting-room and a doctor sent for, who, however, refused to do anything for his foot until the railroad doctor came. He was then sent over to New-York, went to the hospital, and was there nearly six months before he could walk even with crutches.

abstract: -- The Tribune, of yesterday morning, denies to Gen. MCCLELLAN the credit of planning the great series of victories which have steadily driven the rebel forces from all their chosen strongholds, because, forsooth, "he does not direct the movements of the rebel Generals." Of course he does not, except in the way of compelling them to fight the National forces with almost a certainty of being beaten, or retreat before them; which has been done pretty effectually. Did any General ever direct the movements of his enemy in any other way? But in another article the Tribune, coming again to judgment upon matters military, says, "We consider the wide dispersion of our forces a mistake." This touches the very point at issue between the Tribune and Gen. MCCLELLAN. If the General -- we mean the army General -- has dispersed our forces for the purpose of drawing them together upon the insurgents, and the consequence is victory all along the line, then to him will be the honor; but if defeat, then the Tribune may throw up it's cap.

abstract: The news of the capture of New-Orleans is fully confirmed this morning, in official dispatches from Fortress Monroe. Our dispatches also give some few additional particulars from the rebels relative to the capture, which appears to be accepted as a fixed fact, and has spread the utmost consternation throughout the South. In connection with these dispatches, we publish a number of letters from our special correspondent accompanying the great Mortar Fleet, giving highly interesting details of all the preliminary movements of our forces, up to the time of the attack upon Forts Jackson and Philip. It will be seen from these letters that the labor preparation has been a gigantic one, and that the difficulties overcome would have been to a less determined people insurmountable.
lead_paragraph: The news of the capture of New-Orleans is fully confirmed this morning, in official dispatches from Fortress Monroe. Our dispatches also give some few additional particulars from the rebels relative to the capture, which appears to be accepted as a fixed fact, and has spread the utmost consternation throughout the South. In connection with these dispatches, we publish a number of letters from our special correspondent accompanying the great Mortar Fleet, giving highly interesting details of all the preliminary movements of our forces, up to the time of the attack upon Forts Jackson and Philip. It will be seen from these letters that the labor preparation has been a gigantic one, and that the difficulties overcome would have been to a less determined people insurmountable.

abstract: -- There is no naval officer whose services the country can so ill afford to lose as those of the gallant Commander of the Western flotilla, Commodore FOOTE. His exploits on the Tennessee and Mississippi Rivers, whether we consider the science with which they were planned, the daring with which they were executed, or the vastness of the consequences flowing from them, rank among the foremost achievements of the campaign, and have justly won for him the gratitude of the nation. On these very grounds, it is to be hoped that the Navy Department will not defer acceding to the request for a temporary relief from the care and responsibility of active service, which the wound received by Commodore FOOTE has compelled him to put in. Of late his ankle, injured in the Donelson fight, has, we hear, become greatly swollen and exceedingly painful, and he ascends the deck of his flagship with extreme difficulty. He is also much worn, and is suffering from general debility, and the surgeon reports that until he has complete rest and freedom from care, he cannot hope for recovery. It is true that Commodore FOOTE does not ask to be relieved on personal grounds. His life, he says, is at the service of his country. But his country needs his service too much to afford to imperil its loss. Already we have lost one officer in another arm of the service from a similar cause. LANDER, the bravest of the brave, fell a victim to a neglected wound. He desired to be recalled, but, like FOOTE, the Government did not see how his services could be spared; and the drain on the vital powers caused by the arduous duties of an active campaign, aggravated his wound, and carried him to his grave. The Navy Department has so far considered the case of Commodore FOOTE as to send him out an efficient assistant in the person of Capt. DAVIS. But this is not enough. He needs entire exemption from duty for a season. And it will he good economy in the Government to allow him this, for there is much yet remaining for the gallant sailor to do; and the whole country will pray that he may soon be restored to perfect health, to push on the good work and lead up the numerous tributaries of the Mississippi the conquering flotilla bofore which rebellion disappears.
