abstract: One notable consequenceof the complete success thus far of the plan for the thorough reduction of the rebellion, is that cotton is beginning to pass, in no small quantities, directly from the hands of the Southern planter into those of the Northern merchant. We learn from a cotton buyer who has just returned from Tennessee, that the small planters there have not only not destroyed any part of their crops, but have no notion of doing anything of the kind. Our informant saw many of this class, and found most of them violent Secessionists; but a goodly minority were loyal men, putting their country first and then State after. Some of the Union men had brothers and sons in the rebel army; and vice versa. But he found that wherever there was most ignorance, most bluster and most whisky, there was least regard for the Union, and the greatest expression of hatred of the Yankees. On one point, however, rebels and loyal men were unanimous; as they were all ready to sell their cotton, and to take United States Treasury notes for it. Devotion to "the cause of the South" -- the euphemism for Slavery -- seemed in no case to be an impediment to the driving of a good bargain. From various individuals our informant bought several hundred bales of cotton; and he can be but one of many who have visited Tennessee within the last six weeks on a like errand.
lead_paragraph: One notable consequenceof the complete success thus far of the plan for the thorough reduction of the rebellion, is that cotton is beginning to pass, in no small quantities, directly from the hands of the Southern planter into those of the Northern merchant. We learn from a cotton buyer who has just returned from Tennessee, that the small planters there have not only not destroyed any part of their crops, but have no notion of doing anything of the kind. Our informant saw many of this class, and found most of them violent Secessionists; but a goodly minority were loyal men, putting their country first and then State after. Some of the Union men had brothers and sons in the rebel army; and vice versa. But he found that wherever there was most ignorance, most bluster and most whisky, there was least regard for the Union, and the greatest expression of hatred of the Yankees. On one point, however, rebels and loyal men were unanimous; as they were all ready to sell their cotton, and to take United States Treasury notes for it. Devotion to "the cause of the South" -- the euphemism for Slavery -- seemed in no case to be an impediment to the driving of a good bargain. From various individuals our informant bought several hundred bales of cotton; and he can be but one of many who have visited Tennessee within the last six weeks on a like errand.

abstract: -- It would seem that the rumors we bad from the South-west. on Sunday and Monday last, of a great battle having commenced between the armies of HALLECK and BEAUREGARD, was premature. Our advices from the vicinity of Pittsburgh now extend up to Monday night, and no mention is made of anything but a cavalry skirmish, which took place on that day at a place about midway between the position of the main body of the two armies. Rebel prisoners captured, say that BEAUREGARD's army now numbers upwards of eighty thousand men, and that it is still at Corinth fortifying, and will fight there. It may be that the prisoners had no special means of accurate information, but still it is highly probable that these statements were about correct. We have had news lately of BEAUREGARD's receiving reinforcements from as far away as Texas, and even South Carolina has given him a regiment; while the conscription act is now furnishing him with men from Mississippi, Alabama and Arkansas, with all of which States his communications are yet open. These additions have probably doubled the size of his army since he fought at Shiloh. BEAUREGARD cannot fight at a more advantageous point than Corinth, if he fights anywhere this side of the Mississippi; and his late defeat was not so severe as to destroy his hopes of success with his largely-increased army. On the other hand, our own army is reported to be in capital spirits; and the late skirmishes near BEAUREGARD's lines show that it is not afraid to go out in search of the enemy.
lead_paragraph: -- It would seem that the rumors we bad from the South-west. on Sunday and Monday last, of a great battle having commenced between the armies of HALLECK and BEAUREGARD, was premature. abstract: Since the battle of Pea Ridge the public have almost lost sight of the magnificent National column of Gen. CURTIS. We know that all the rebel forces in Western Arkansas (ALBERT PIKE's cannibals excepted) have been moved down the Arkansas River, and are now with BEAUREGARD's army at Corinth. This left Gen. CURTIS without an enemy in his front; and as it was impossible for him to follow the rebels in the route they took, he began to move his forces eastward for action on another field. We have had from time to time news of his progress from Bentonville, Arkansas, to Cassville, Missouri, and from thence to Forsyth, in Taney County, at which point our latest advices left him, with his whole army. The news we published from the Memphis Avalanche on Monday indicated his subsequent movements. The road from Forsyth leads across the Ozark Mountains in an almost direct line to Doniphan, Ripley County, on the Current River, at which point, says the rebel newspaper, are "ten thousand Federal troops engaged in building flatboats with which to descend Black and White Rivers." The troops of Gen. STEELE (National) have been in this vicinity for some time past; and, if CURTIS' column has formed a junction with STEELE's, and if the rebel surmise as to their destination be correct, it will be seen that a very important movement is on foot. The Current River flows southward and empties into the Black River, the Black flows into the White, and the White forms a junction with the Arkansas, which empties into the Mississippi a hundred and fifty miles below Memphis. It may be a matter of doubt, however, whether the rebel surmise as to the destination of the Army of the Southwest be correct; but the fact, which we are pleased to learn, that "ten thousand Federal troops are engaged building flatboats on the Current River," indicates that our army out there is not idle, and that it is not likely to encamp for a great while on the banks of that stream.

abstract: -- No portion ofour foreign immigrant population are more respected, so far as they are self-respecting, than the Germans. Their marked devotion to the country of their adoption, in this time of trial, is suited to conciliate the kindest feeling. It will be their own fault alone if they do not share to the full the blessings of institutions which cost us something to found and defend. It is little that is asked in return, nothing that we do not exact of our own citizens. Of that little, the editors of our German papers seem to withhold a part. They have taken the habit of sneering at law and public authorities with a rudeness that we do not care to resent, but which is quite unbecoming, either as a matter of manners or morals. We have, more than once, found it necessary to allude to this and like delinquencies of the Staats Zietung; the Demokrat, (Rep.,) is even more offensive. In its article of Saturday on concert saloons, it talks of "Superintendent KENNEDY directing his myrmidons to enforce the law;" of the "careless and illogical composition of the law," "after the favorite superficial American manner," so that "an incarnate Nativist, a pious Puritan, or a superzealous Police Superintendent can find a hook to connect it with a persecution against the harmless German concert-gardens," etc., and much more of this sort of slang.

abstract: -- The bogue Minister, Rev. R.J. HALL, who was arrested in this City a few weeks since, upon the charge of obtaining money by false pretences, from various churches, was taken before Justice BRENNAN a second time, yesterday, upon another complaint, made against him by Mr. EUGENE THOMPSON. The latter alleges that hegave HALL $25, to aid him on his way from Corinth, Miss., to the State of Vermont, whither he and his wife were fleeing to escape the wrath of the Secessionists. HALL was committed for trial.

abstract: We may reckon it not the least of the many important consequences of the capture of New-Orleans, that our fleet will bag the whole of the rebel flotilla of iron-clad vessels and steam-rams that for many months have held undisputed possession of the Lower Mississippi. Indeed, there is already an announcement that one of their iron-clad gunboats was destroyed on the passage up by the United States steamer Pensacola. This is probably the Louisiana, which was only completed ten days ago, and which the Richmond journals have lately described in formidable colors as a second Merrimac. If this craft has really been sunk by one of our wooden gunboats, the exploit will certainly be a most important contribution to our knowledge of the relative capacities of wooden walls and iron sides -- concerning which latter, perhaps, there may have been a tendency to leap to too absolute a judgment. Whether any other iron-clad vessels appeared to dispute the passage of the National fleet up to the city remains also to be seen. Indeed, it remains to be seen whether they really had any completed beyond the one which is reported to have been destroyed. To be sure we have had awful announcements of the iron navy of the lower Mississippi, and no less than eleven mailed vessels were reported months ago to be lying at New-Orleans. These were un doubtedly, however, only ships in buckram, though it is not at all unlikely that they may have had two or three on the stocks; and the fact that the Louisiana was finished in time to take part in the engagement, shows that they have not been idle. But the point of most interest is to learn what has been the fate of HOLLINS' famous ram, the Manassas? It is known to have returned from its jaunt up to Memphis -- but whether it remained to defend the Crescent City, and prudently escaped up river on the approach of the armada of FARRAGUT and PORTER, or whether HOLLINS took the creature down to the scene of operations at Fort Jackson and did some more "peppering," only to be himself terribly dished -- are questions whose solution we shall have to await yet a little while. But if he was not nabbed by the fleet going up, he will certainly be nabbed by the fleet coming down, and between FOOTS and FARRAGUT, Bombastes HOLLINS must be caught. Into this drag-net, too, the whole of the rebel navy on the Mississippi must inevitably fall -- gunboats, iron-clad vessels and rams, both afloat and on the stocks.

But the point of most interest is to learn what has been the fate of HOLLINS' famous ram, the Manassas? It is known to have returned from its jaunt up to Memphis -- but whether it remained to defend the Crescent City, and prudently escaped up river on the approach of the armada of FARRAGUT and PORTER, or whether HOLLINS took the creature down to the scene of operations at Fort Jackson and did some more "peppering," only to be himself terribly dished -- are questions whose solution we shall have to await yet a little while. But if he was not nabbed by the fleet going up, he will certainly be nabbed by the fleet coming down, and between FOOTS and FARRAGUT, Bombastes HOLLINS must be caught. Into this drag-net, too, the whole of the rebel navy on the Mississippi must inevitably fall -- gunboats, iron-clad vessels and rams, both afloat and on the stocks.

abstract: Although the constitutionality of the new Concert Saloon law is soon to be passed upon by the Supreme Court, the wonted appearance of the concert saloons has quite disappeared. The Police compel a rigorous compliance with the statute, and will not permit the waiter-girls, the liquor, and the theatrical entertainments to be enjoyed conjointly. The consequence is, that the attendance on the saloons has dwindled down to a small number, in comparison to the former patrons, and the receipts have proportionately diminished. The decision of the Supreme Court is anxiously awaited by all parties. The proprietors of the Concert Saloon No. 616 Broadway, who were arrested by Capt. WILLIAMSON, of the Fourteenth Precinct Police, on Monday night, upon the charge of violating the law in regard to concert saloons, were yesterday brought before Justice OSBORNE, at the Essex Market Police Court. The names of the accused parties are WM. DEVWINEY and FREDERICK REUTZE. The proprietors said that the entertainments given at their place consisted of a band of music, which was seated on a platform at the rear end of the hall. In answer to this, Capt. WILLIAMSON insisted that there were girls in attendance, and that they were engaged in carrying lager bier and liquors of a stronger nature, to the guests who were in attendance, and that for this reason he made the arrests. Justice OSBORNE held each of the parties to bail in the sum of $500, to appear before aim to-day for examination.

abstract: Joseph A. Veazie vs. Isaac Ames. This was an action to chargs the defendant, individually, as a stockholder of the American Blank Book Ruling and Paging company, with the payment of a note which that Company made in February, 1857, payable twelve months after date. An action had been brought against the Company, and judgment recovered for the amount of the note, with costs.
lead_paragraph: Joseph A. Veazie vs. Isaac Ames. -- This was an action to chargs the defendant, individually, as a stockholder of the American Blank Book Ruling and Paging company, with the payment of a note which that Company made in February, 1857, payable twelve months after date. An action had been brought against the Company, and judgment recovered for the amount of the note, with costs. The present suit was brought to charge the defendant individually as stockholder, under Section 10 of the Act of 1848, for the incorporation of Companies for medicinal and chemical purposes, on the ground that the whole capital stock of the company had not been paid in. The defence set up was that the defendant was not individually liable under section 24 of the same act, which declares that the stockholders shall not be personally liable for the payment of any debt contracted by the Company which is not to be paid within one year from the time when the debt is contracted, and that, as the note sued on was payable in law only at the end of twelve months and three days from the time when it was made, this suit could not be maintained. After argument by counsel, the Court sustained the objection, and dismissed the complaint.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, James Kennedy was placed on trial for murder in the first degree, in killing Patrick McGrath at No. 54 West Broadway on the 4th of March last. The only witness to the homicide was a little daughter of the deceased, who testified that Kennedy struck her father with some instrument resembling a hammer, and kicked him after he was down. McGrath died at the City Hospital, on the 20th of March, from the effects of his injuries. The case was not concluded at the adjournment of the Court.

abstract: Preparations at Yorktown are now in such a state of forwardness that the great bombardment of the rebel stronghold cannot be much longer delayed. The weather is reported to be more favorable, and Gen. McCLELLAN, it will be seen, speaks cheerfully and confidently. The rebels appear to be just waking up to the fact that the combinations being made against them are of the most formidable character, and yesterday, for the first time, attempted seriously to annoy our working parties, who are erecting formidable earthworks almost within speaking distance of them. They kept up a severe cannonading, but without effecting any damage. It was only a waste of powder. On Monday a portion of Gen. HANCOCK's Brigade made a gallant dash into a piece of woods in which a party of the enemy were concealed, and succeeded in driving them out, leaving a number of dead and wounded behind them. A new battery which the rebels had erected in the woods, was also effectually demolished and the guns rendered useless.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a remonstrance from the wool manufacturers, against the proposed tax on wool, was presented; also a petition for a general bankrupt law. Bills were reported from the Military Committee to create a bureau of transportation and a bureau of clothing; also a bill to authorize a Medical Inspector-General, and an Inspector to discharge soldiers for physical disability. A bill was reported providing that the School tax collected from colored people in the District of Columbia shall be applied to the education of colored children. A bill to amend the bill of last session, confiscating slaves, so as to include the wives and children of slaves, was introduced by Mr. WILSON, of Massachussets. Mr. POWELL's resolution, calling upon the Secretary of State for information relative to the arrest and imprisonment of citizens of Kentucky, was called up by him. Mr. SUMNER [???] to amend by calling upon the President for the information, if not incompatible with the public interests, but Mr. POWELL objected to it. Debate on this point was continued until the espiration of the morning hour, when the Confiscation bill was taken up as the special order. Mr. COWAN, of Pennsylvania, moved that the whole subject be referred to a Special Committee of seven. Mr. BROWNING, of Illinois, made a speech in opposition to any measure of confiscation, as unconstitutional. The Senate then adjourned.

abstract: Mary A. Peters vs. Harney W. Fowler. -- The plaintiff, who is a milliner, brought this action to recover the sum of about fifty dollars, the value of bonnets and other articles of millinery sold to the defendant in 1857. The defence set up was that the plaintiff was, at the time the goods were sold, a married woman, and that her husband carried on the milinery business in Troy, where the goods were bought, and the plaintiff was not the party in interest. Also, that the defendant had rendered professional services as a physician to Mr. Peters, who owed him more than the value of the millinery.
lead_paragraph: Mary A. Peters vs. Harney W. Fowler. -- The plaintiff, who is a milliner, brought this action to recover the sum of about fifty dollars, the value of bonnets and other articles of millinery sold to the defendant in 1857. The defence set up was that the plaintiff was, at the time the goods were sold, a married woman, and that her husband carried on the milinery business in Troy, where the goods were bought, and the plaintiff was not the party in interest. Also, that the defendant had rendered professional services as a physician to Mr. Peters, who owed him more than the value of the millinery.

abstract: Editorial on various means of taxation to help meet increased Government expenditures
snippet: Editorial on various means of taxation to help meet increased Government expenditures
lead_paragraph: Among the numerous propositions for a scheme of finance or taxation, which shall produce a revenue equal to the greatly increased expenditures of Government, we have seen none that appears to accomplish this end so fully, and to which so few objections can be urged, as an uniform tax upon transfers, or sales of merchandise. The limit or amount of tax proposed is one per cent. The revenue which this rate would yield is, to a certain extent, conjectural, but it would be very large. If inadequate, the rate has only to be increased to produce a sum equal to any emergency. By the scheme proposed the tax is levied upon consumption, or what is the same thing, upon capital in the form of money. No one payment would ever be felt to be a burden by the consumer. If it amounted to $100, he would pay $1; if $1,000, $10 -- a rate that would subtract in no appreciable degree from a person's comforts or style of living. It is a tax that would be daily paid, bringing with it an increased stimulus to exertion. A person who daily purchases A half-dozen of newspapers does not feel the amount paid to be a drain upon his purse, for the reason that the day's expenditure is met by the proceeds of the day's industry. The former is graduated upon the scale of the latter. But let the bill for the whole run for the year, and the amount would be considered so excessive that the whole of them would probably be discontinued, from a sense of absolute necessity. The money that should, and, if daily demanded, would have been paid for them, has gone for other objects, and the bill has to be charged against the earnings of the coming year.

abstract: -- The following prisoners of war arrived by United States steamer Connecticut, and were handed over to the United States Marshal, who sent them to Fort Lafayette; Alex. Smith, Master of schooner Glide, captured off Charleston; Louis Greene, Charles West, James J. Vanderbilt and Edward Flynn, comprising part of the crew of the Confederate schooner Jesse J. Cor, captured by the United States steamer Colorado, off Southwest Pass.
lead_paragraph: -- The following prisoners of war arrived by United States steamer Connecticut, and were handed over to the United States Marshal, who sent them to Fort Lafayette; Alex. Smith, Master of schooner Glide, captured off Charleston; Louis Greene, Charles West, James J. Vanderbilt and Edward Flynn, comprising part of the crew of the Confederate schooner Jesse J. Cor, captured by the United States steamer Colorado, off Southwest Pass.

abstract: A WEAK INVENTION. -- A statement to the effect that the rebels have called for a cessation of arms, with a view to a peaceful adjustment of the National difficulties, has obtained currency in certain quarters, where it is believed as well that the President has consented to a parley. The story is, in every particular, palpably untrue. While there is everything in the condition of the rebels to suggest; submission and peace, there is no evidence of any such a disposition among their leaders, who, having nothing to hope from the National Government, are wiling to draw down with them, into perdition, the mass of the people. On the side of the Union there is sufficient argument against either armistice or compromise. The latter word will never again be listened to at the North. There can be no further concession or terms with that mutinous spirit of the South, which has cost the country all the blood and the money of this frightful war. The motto of the Government, as it is of our Generals, is unconditional surrender. It is proposed to subjugate the South, not to the yoke of Northern dictation, but to the plain, explicit, sense and requirements of the Constitution; and it will only be when the rebel leaders announce their willingness thus to submit, that the project of a truce will be considered. The war is costing this generation, and perhaps two or three generations to follow it, at the rate of two millions a-day. Not a day therefore can we afford to waste upon negotiations, which must have no beneficial result. The Government will continue to strike until the last armed rebel shall have perished or disappeared.
lead_paragraph: A WEAK INVENTION. -- A statement to the effect that the rebels have called for a cessation of arms, with a view to a peaceful adjustment of the National difficulties, has obtained currency in certain quarters, where it is believed as well that the President has consented to a parley. The story is, in every particular, palpably untrue. The war is costing this generation, and perhaps two or three generations to follow it, at the rate of two millions a-day. The Government will continue to strike until the last armed rebel shall have perished or disappeared.

abstract: REBELS. -- We remarked, the other morning, that the kind of intelligence we were receiving now-a-days from New-Mexico indicated that a new element had been thrown into the war on the National side there, in the regiment of pioneers and miners from Colorado; and that the first exploit of these men had shown that they did not go into New-Mexico merely for the purpose of furnishing supplies of arms to the rebels, as some of our Regulars seem to have done, but that they went there to fight, and would be likely to make short work of the small band of rebel fillibusters from Texas, who had overrun the Territory, reduced its forts, seized its capital, and all but completed its subjugation. The work, It seems, has been done even quicker than seemed possible. Not only has the conquering march of the Texans been suddenly arrested, but, since their late defeat at Pigeon Ranche, northeast of Santa Fe, what remains of them has turned tail upon the territory, and is now heading for Arizona. By a telegram of this morning, we learn that on the 12th current, they had reached a point fifty miles south of Santa Fe, and about an equal distance from the Arizona line, and were still in full flight southward. Arizona, it will be remembered, has, since secession times, been almost entirely in the hands of the meanest and most bloodthirsty tribe of savages on the Continent -- the Apache Indians, who have of late kept up a fearful reign of terror and the tomahawk; and if the rebels are not so fortunate as to get captured by our soldiers who are pursuing them, the chances are that they will be all killed and scalped by the Indians.
lead_paragraph: REBELS. -- We remarked, the other morning, that the kind of intelligence we were receiving now-a-days from New-Mexico indicated that a new element had been thrown into the war on the National side there, in the regiment of pioneers and miners from Colorado; and that the first exploit of these men had shown that they did not go into New-Mexico merely for the purpose of furnishing supplies of arms to the rebels, as some of our Regulars seem to have done, but that they went there to fight, and would be likely to make short work of the small band of rebel fillibusters from Texas, who had overrun the Territory, reduced its forts, seized its capital, and all but completed its subjugation. The work, It seems, has been done even quicker than seemed possible. Not only has the conquering march of the Texans been suddenly arrested, but, since their late defeat at Pigeon Ranche, northeast of Santa Fe, what remains of them has turned tail upon the territory, and is now heading for Arizona. By a telegram of this morning, we learn that on the 12th current, they had reached a point fifty miles south of Santa Fe, and about an equal distance from the Arizona line, and were still in full flight southward. Arizona, it will be remembered, has, since secession times, been almost entirely in the hands of the meanest and most bloodthirsty tribe of savages on the Continent -- the Apache Indians, who have of late kept up a fearful reign of terror and the tomahawk; and if the rebels are not so fortunate as to get captured by our soldiers who are pursuing them, the chances are that they will be all killed and scalped by the Indians.
